HEADLINE: BACKTALK;
Wrigley Is Old-Fashioned, But Packed With Panache

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA; David Barboza, who is based in Chicago, is the Midwest business correspondent for The New York Times.

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
They call this area Wrigleyville, and fans swarmed here on opening day on April 10 to see the ballpark that remains a symbol of old-fashioned baseball.
This is where games are still played in the middle of the day. The view from home plate is of ivy-covered walls and Waveland Avenue, where scores of fans can take in the game from neighborhood rooftops. There is no giant Coca-Cola bottle perched in the center-field bleachers, no Gap advertisement in left-center or Ruggles restaurant just beyond the 400-foot mark in right field. 
 At a time when major league teams have christened multimillion-dollar corporate palaces like Comerica Park in Detroit, Enron Field in Houston and Pac Bell Stadium in San Francisco, Wrigley Field is bucking the trend toward corporate sponsorships and spanking new refurbishments.
The Cubs' old park, which was built in 1914, retains what is, in effect, a ban on corporate advertising on the field, the only such ban in the majors. And even though Wrigley is set in a busy, residential neighborhood where one of the largest parking lots is at a local convent, significant alterations are not even being contemplated.
"There is no interest in doing anything that's going to change the nature of Wrigley Field," said Andy MacPhail, the president and chief executive of the Chicago Cubs. "We never say never, but we recognize that this place is special."
How can the Cubs make this high-minded choice? Wrigley has 39,000 seats -- making it and Fenway Park in Boston the only two parks in the league with fewer than 40,000. Fenway has the smallest park in the majors, seating 33,871, but Red Sox tickets are among the most expensive -- ranging between $14 and $45 -- and Fenway has a lot of advertising. Moreover, the Red Sox are considering replacing Fenway with a park that has more luxury boxes, corporate sponsorships and other cash-generating ventures, which would make Wrigley the last park of a bygone era.
And why not? In good years and bad, fans seem to flock here, not just to see Sammy Sosa whack balls onto Waveland Avenue, but to revel in an old ballpark, with its charms and its absence of new-age spectacle. A year ago, Wrigley sold more than 92 percent of its tickets -- a record 2.9 million tickets, third best in the majors -- despite the fact that the team ended up in the basement of the National League Central. And that doesn't count the rooftops around the park, where three flats have been fitted with rows of stadium-like seating. The team also has among the lowest ticket prices in the majors, with the most expensive seats often selling for just $25.
The Cubs can get along with a creaky, old park and bargain ticket prices because of the hefty television revenue that comes from being in the third-largest media market in the nation. Although Cubs management has finally made the off-season personnel moves to bolster Sosa and his four-year, $42.5 million contract, history shows that fans come no matter how the Cubs are playing. Most games are sold out largely because Wrigley is an old-fashioned "field of dreams" for fans who root, root, root for the "Cubbies."
"Compared to other clubs, the Cubs don't care what players they put on their field because they sell out every game," said Todd Gruen, an editor at the Team Marketing Report, a sports marketing firm in Chicago. "Even without Sammy Sosa, it's a fun ballpark."
Wrigley, however, is not the oldest park. That distinction belongs to Fenway, which opened in 1912. Tiger Stadium (1914) was also a nostalgic site, but it got the wrecking ball. And while the new park in Boston may well retain the historic Fenway name, the trend these days is to sell the naming rights for a pretty penny. A decade ago, fans jammed into Candlestick, Three Rivers Stadium and Fenway. Now, they are welcomed to Qualcomm Stadium, Bank One Ball Park and Tropicana Field, names that don't exactly roll off the tongue or conjure images of hot dogs and pennant fever.
But corporations do generate cash, a lot of it. Pac Bell paid $50 million for the naming rights to the San Francisco Giants' new stadium for 24 years; Bank One paid $66 million for 30 years; and Enron paid about $100 million to associate itself with the Houston Astros' park through 2030.
What Wrigley gives up in sponsorships, parking and luxury boxes, Cubs officials say it makes up for in sellouts and television revenue, even though the games are broadcast on WGN, which, like the Cubs and Wrigley, is owned by The Tribune Company, publisher of The Chicago Tribune.
"In the best of circumstances, they could generate another $20 million in a new stadium, but the White Sox have a new stadium and they're doing terribly," said Andrew Zimbalist, a sports economist at Smith College in Massachusetts. "The Cubs do well with what they have. There's a certain cache that comes with playing in an old ballpark."
Indeed, in recent years, other teams have tried to incorporate some of the Wrigley charm into new parks. There is a movement toward smaller, retro stadiums -- not even stadiums, parks or fields, they now say. Baseball owners are trying to create a neighborhood feel, using brick fencing, and almost Disneyesque recreations of Main Street around the park. Gone is the 60,000-seat dome movement of the 1970's and 1980's. But the new stadiums are also crowded with corporate logos and billboards.
"Arizona looks like a minor league park -- it's plastered with billboards," said Benjamin De La Fuente, a Cubs spokesman.
Pac Bell Park has dozens of corporate logos, including a 90-foot replica of a Coca-Cola bottle in the center-field stands, next to a giant sculpture of a baseball glove. At Enron Field, which is named after a natural gas company, there is the Conoco Home Run Alley, and the Conoco Bell Tower, named after the oil company. Some 27 companies -- UPS, Miller, Budweiser, Chevy, Ford, Dodge, A.I.M. management funds, Kroger's supermarkets, to name a few -- have signs in the stadium.
There are also restaurants, batting cages, waterfalls, fireworks shows and fantasy baseball at the new stadiums, for when fans get restless with watching all baseball all the time.
At Wrigley, logos and promotions appear only in the concourses. There are also small, almost invisible promotions on the backs of some seat cup-holders. Even though Wrigley is named for the founder of the Wrigley chewing gum family that sold the team in 1981, The Tribune Company has largely ignored the corporate juggernaut, choosing instead to gradually upgrade an old park, which put in lights for night games only as recently as 1988.
The motto here: don't spoil it. The charm of Wrigley, the Tuesday afternoons with beer in the bleachers, the ivy-covered walls, the old organ that plays at the beginning of each game, and the white and blue flags that signal whether the Cubs have won or lost that day's game. Any major changes, the thinking goes, would generate huge resistance among the fans.
"If they ever decided to junk Wrigley Field, the fans would protest," said George Castle, who has covered the Cubs for The Times of northwest Indiana for 20 years. "They'd tear down the Tribune Tower."
Then again, critics here say the owners aren't exactly opening their pocketbooks to snatch up talent, either.
"The talk around baseball is why don't the Cubs spend more money?" said Castle, who has written a book about why the Cubs have not won a pennant since 1945. "If they spent more, they'd make more in television revenues."
Of course, at $55 million last year, the Cubs had a hefty payroll, far more than the Kansas City Royals ($18 million), but far less than the Yankees ($88 million.)
With free-agent contracts skyrocketing, the Cubs and other teams are trying to develop strong farm systems. But when Sosa's contract comes up next year, the Cubs may need to rethink an old stadium that has just one elevator, little room for food and beverage concessions and luxury boxes that even top executives say aren't quite luxurious.
But MacPhail insists the team will find a way to sign top players without altering the stadium.
"I don't think it would mean if Sammy Sosa's a free agent we need to put a second deck on the bleachers," he said. "We wouldn't make a change that can last 50 years to accommodate one player."

HEADLINE: The Andes in Tumult, Shaken by Political Tremors

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER with CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

 BODY:
Guerrillas and the cocaine trade batter Colombia. A strongman rides roughshod over a discredited Congress and courts in Venezuela. Ecuador reels from an economic crisis and a coup. Bolivia has just emerged from a state of siege. And Peru awaits an election between an autocrat accused of trying to steal the presidency and a political firebrand.
Suddenly it seems as if all the Andes are in tumult. Recent events have exposed fractures in each society, some old and some new, and one Wall Street firm has gone so far as to warn its clients that the region is becoming "the Balkans of Latin America." 
 But if it does appear that institutions in these countries are breaking down, many of the conflicts that divide the societies today are different from those in the past. Turmoil is no stranger to the region, which has had more than its share of dictators, guerrilla movements and economic crises. But the current discontent is being generated less by conflict over the type of government countries should have than the quality.
Democracy has been ascendant in the region for a decade, but the longing for more representative and responsive governance is greater now among the region's 100 million people than ever before, experts say. That aspiration increasingly bumps up against governments that have been unable to provide an equitable sharing of power and wealth.
"The one thing these countries have in common," said Michael Shifter of the Washington-based research group Inter-American Dialogue, "is deterioration and decay in the quality and performance of institutions, in their inability to produce the results that people demand and will respect."
While cautioning against "the trap of talking about an Andean virus," he said, "There is something going on that is not supposed to happen."
These problems are most visible in Peru and Venezuela. After years of ineffectual governance, both countries -- first Peru with Alberto K. Fujimori in 1990 and then Venezuela with Hugo Chavez in 1998 -- elected political outsiders who promised sweeping democratic changes.
But in each case the line between overhauling the institutions of democracy and usurping them altogether became quickly blurred by men who have shown authoritarian tendencies. The challenge now -- particularly with each country facing elections in coming weeks -- is to reassert where that border is. That may mean voting the men out of power and vigorously protesting any attempt at fraud.
But the situation in Ecuador, where the government has been headed toward a total collapse, may be even more acute. It has had five presidents from various parties over the last four years and not one has been able to deliver the political and economic stability that citizens crave. Now, as a desperation measure, the government has adopted the dollar as Ecuador's currency.
In January, President Jamil Mahuad was overthrown in an uprising jointly organized by disgruntled colonels and Indian leaders, who for generations have felt excluded from the political and economic life of their country but have had little opportunity to change their circumstances.
The military coup was the first to succeed in Latin America in more than a decade. Though it ended with the army installing a civilian leader -- the country's vice president, Gustavo Noboa -- the action sent a strong signal through the region that soldiers may yet be tempted to short-circuit democratic governments they consider corrupt or ineffective.
Beyond Ecuador, in all five Andean countries, long-simmering feelings of political and economic exclusion have begun to boil over in populations that are at the same time susceptible to charismatic political figures who offer a bold new path, one that sometimes tempts citizens with undemocratic measures.
"The institutional vacuum is the real problem," said Eduardo Gamarra, director of the Latin American and Caribbean Center at Florida International University in Miami. "The lack of leadership, the inability of parties to throw up new candidates, and the absence of formal linkages to the population is really striking and very, very worrying."
Each country has sought its own kind of savior. When Peruvians first looked to Mr. Fujimori a decade ago, he was elected in a break from the traditional political parties, which had failed to control debilitating terrorism and hyperinflation.
Now Peruvians are considering Alejandro Toledo, a business school professor who is offering a surprisingly strong challenge to Mr. Fujimori, forcing a runoff election that must take place by June. Mr. Toledo has promised to resuscitate democratic institutions, like the Congress and judiciary, smothered under Mr. Fujimori's heavy hand.
In Bolivia, Gen. Hugo Banzer, who was the country's dictator in the 1970's, was voted into power in 1997 pledging to fight corruption, eradicate coca production and modernize the state. His return clearly demonstrated how democratic aspirations still mingle with the lingering desire for a firm hand.
Much the same can be said of President Chavez in Venezuela, a cashiered army colonel who last year assumed the very office he tried to gain in a coup seven years earlier. While he now promises a "peaceful social revolution," a number of signs suggest that he intends to concentrate power in his own hands.
While Mr. Chavez's attacks on Venezuela's Constitution, Congress and courts have resonated overwhelmingly with Venezuelans, his attempts to forge an all-powerful presidency have not. Instead, they are generating growing suspicion of an equally grave threat to the country's democracy and have led to the unexpected emergence of a rival in the presidential vote set for May 28, from a fellow coup plotter, Francisco Arias Cardenas.
Now Colombia's president, Andres Pastrana, seems to be trying to take advantage of the same discontent. Faced with twin plagues of Marxist guerrillas and drug trafficking, he is proposing a referendum to dissolve the Congress, seen by most Colombians as corrupt and inefficient, and replace it with what he pitches as a more responsive body.
But Mr. Pastrana, whose own popularity has been slipping, may be too late to capitalize on such sentiment. The apparent front-runner in the presidential election, now two years off, is Noemi Sanin, leader of a non-party movement called Colombia Yes, who is sounding many of the themes that have proved so appealing elsewhere.
"In Colombia the state is not operating," Ms. Sanin, a former foreign minister, told the newsmagazine Semana. "We do not want to participate in the sterile fights and embraces between which the traditional parties alternate while they carve up bureaucratic spoils and the national budget."
The situation in each country points to a regional crisis that is first and foremost political, where the urgent need for more effective government converges with the desire that those governments be democratic.
The most striking recent example was in Peru. "What I saw was a rejection of the imposition of a regime that said, 'We'll do what we want,' " Enrique Zileri Gibson, editor of Caretas, Peru's leading magazine, said of the protesters who took to the streets after Mr. Fujimori was accused of trying to steal a presidential election two weeks ago and chanted, "Democracy yes, authoritarianism no!"
But the region's severe economic and social problems cannot be ignored. The smaller Andean countries are so hard-pressed that Bolivia's attempt to levy a 20 percent increase in water rates this month provoked a response so violent that Mr. Banzer dusted off his old autocratic tools and declared a state of siege. High unemployment rates have worsened and expanded the already huge informal sector of these economies.
"This is the largest growth sector of society, but no one is speaking for them," Dr. Gamarra said. "The problem is that because they are so tenuously tied to the system, with no unemployment insurance, health care or social security, they will vote for whoever promises a wonderful reform."
To a large extent, that excluded economic class coincides with the Indian and mestizo, or mixed race, population, and those people of indigenous descent are becoming more dissatisfied and assertive, especially as they move from village to city.
The coup in Ecuador was the clearest indication of this discontent. Another is the rise of Mr. Toledo and even, to some extent, Mr. Chavez. Both have strongly Indian features and a mestizo appeal.
The rise of this new type of leader is striking in a region where politicians have traditionally tended to be upper class, lighter skinned and of purer Spanish descent, and where many questions born in colonialism and surrounding ethnic identity, language and culture have remained unresolved for 500 years.

HEADLINE: Americans Of Two Minds On Sanctions, A Poll Finds

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
The more Americans know about the world, the more likely they are to favor diplomacy over punitive sanctions in dealing with troublesome foreign countries, a poll has found. Embargoes, they say, not only isolate the nations at which they are aimed but also hurt American business.
When Americans lack information about a country, or when their leaders do not adequately publicize and explain their policy thinking, many fall back on long-established stereotypes of "bad" and "good" nations, the poll found. Judgments about how to deal with those nations are then made on those images. 
 The survey -- by First International Resources, a business consulting group, and the polling organization Penn, Schoen & Berland -- was done in two parts for the sake of comparison. A national sample of 995 average voters was made first, and then 176 knowledgeable "elites" working in government, academic life and research institutes were surveyed.
The full poll results are expected to be made public next week. The survey, based on interviews from Feb. 28 to March 21, focused primarily on attitudes toward economic sanctions on Iran, but when respondents were asked to name "good" and "bad" countries, the findings suggest that the attitudes apply to sanctions policy toward other nations.
Respondents in the general public knew very little about Iran and the recent political changes there, including gains by moderates in parliamentary elections. Only 15 percent of them had heard about advances by Iranians who advocate reform; only 2 percent knew of the 1997 election of a more moderate Iranian president, Mohammad Khatami. Among more knowledgeable people, 58 percent had heard about the shifts toward moderation.
Both groups, however, were still instinctively unfavorable to Iran, based on its reputation for support of terrorism and Islamic militancy. Only Iraq outranked it on the enemies' list among the general population. But the elite respondents were far more likely to say that Iran had changed -- they ranked Serbia, Libya and Iraq as worse cases -- and that Iranian moderates should be helped. These more knowledgeable people also said that sanctions got in the way of dialogue with Iran.
"Both the general public and the elites believe it is extremely important to keep channels of communication open with countries like Iran," the poll concluded, "and that penalizing or isolating rogue countries is not the way to get them to change."
Sanctions have been a major policy tool of the Clinton administration, whether imposed by the United States alone or through the United Nations. Other nations, including American allies in Europe, have been critical of long-running embargoes and other sanctions, saying that they rarely hurt dictators but can harm ordinary people. They also get in the way of international business, or create tensions when the United States tries to force other nations to adhere to its own trade and investment restrictions.
Recently, an American embargo on Iran was eased to allow for importing certain goods like caviar, pistachios and Persian carpets -- a move of which 6 of 10 poll respondents in the general public were unaware. Sports exchanges that have taken place drew universal support in the poll, and 77 percent of average voters and 90 percent of the elite respondents said sanctions should be lifted if Iran responded favorably to an initial easing of the embargo.
In Congress, a small but widening movement is questioning the long-term value of inflexible embargoes. There are concerns that in Iraq, for example, a decade of sanctions may be strengthening the hand of Saddam Hussein while causing unacceptable hardships to the Iraqi people.
Representative Tony P. Hall, Democrat of Ohio, was in Iraq last week to assess the cumulative effects of the comprehensive sanctions imposed in 1990 after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. He is expected to announce the results of his trip today.
The new poll found that while Americans continued to think that sanctions should remain a tool of foreign policy and that big business would from time to time have to make sacrifices because of embargoes, respondents in both groups preferred sanctions to be imposed through international organizations.
They also expressed concern about the use of sanctions if American jobs were at risk, and when presented with facts about American losses, were more likely to want sanctions lifted, or at least eased.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: In Japan, Start-Up and Risk Are New Business Watchwords

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 22

 BODY:
Starting this week, music fans across Japan will be stepping up to a gadget that resembles a souped up, stand-alone automated teller, plugging in a blank minidisk, dropping in some coins and, 30 to 40 seconds later, walking away with their favorite recordings. And they will not be limited to just a few selections; thanks to a super-fast, high-capacity digital connection to a central computer, thousands upon thousands of popular songs will be potentially available at the touch of a few buttons.
No more long waits. No more illicit downloading of MP3 files. Just music fast, simple and cheap. 
 It's called a Music POD, and while it may seem like just another plaything for Japanese teenagers, it is in fact a powerful representation of the tectonic shifts taking place in the economy here.
What the Music POD embodies is the entrepreneurial vision of a 30-year-old college dropout and the business skills of a 40-something former salary man, founders of a young company called V-Sync. They are the sorts of men who five years ago would have toiled anonymously inside a major corporation, climbing the ladder of seniority and keeping their dreams tightly locked up in their heads.
But today changes in the relationship between employer and employee, the liberalization of the financial markets and the explosion of new business models in the freewheeling arenas of the Internet and information technology are spawning a whole new breed of entrepreneurs who care little for the conventions that have dominated Japan Inc. for decades.
"I don't want to be a gear turning the wheels of a big company," said Katsuma Fujii, V-Sync's chairman and the younger of its co-founders. "It's difficult for a lowly gear to get his bosses to listen to, let alone accept, his out-of-this-world ideas in a traditional Japanese corporation. I want to do what I want to do."
While the number of start-ups that can be counted is still low in comparison with the United States, venture capitalists say they began detecting a significant increase in activity last year that is continuing today despite the weak economy. The number of initial public offerings was up for the first time last year since the peak in 1995, and the percentage of those companies that were less than 10 years old was the highest it had ever been, according to Jafco, Japan's largest venture capital company.
Japan, of course, has always been a nation with many small businesses, despite its image as the land of corporate leviathans manned by regiments of salary men. And what gets forgotten is that some of those leviathans -- Honda, Kyocera and Sony, to name a few -- were spawned by visionary entrepreneurs.
But the economic structure that evolved after World War II, with its heavy emphasis on government-directed bank lending, its punitive tax structure, its ban on stock options and its lack of pension portability, stifled the entrepreneurial spirit here.
"What we would call the upside didn't exist under that system," said Karl K. Fooks, managing director in charge of deploying venture capital for J. P. Morgan in Tokyo, where it has recently announced investments in three start-ups. "The banks forced you to pledge your entire family as collateral, and the tax man took most of your profits."
Thus, until the last year or so, when many of those disincentives started eroding, entrepreneurs tended to be shackled to the big kaisha, or corporations, which provided them with a steady stream of orders, helped them establish a line of credit with a bank and squeezed their profits in hard times. They were, effectively, the minor outlying satellites of the business clusters called kei retsu, and their fortunes very much depended on the kaisha's patronage.
So Japan's best and brightest made the rational choice to join the big companies, where salaries were small but benefits like cars, housing allowances and school tuition were generous and untaxed. The further one climbed up the ladder, the better the benefits became, making lifetime loyalty far more attractive than striking out on one's own.
"People love to say the Japanese are risk averse," Mr. Fooks said. "That simply isn't true. There was just no reward for taking entrepreneurial risk in the past."
All that is now changing. For one thing, many big companies are slowly realizing the benefits of competitive procurement practices and the costs of providing life support to so many small partners. Corporations are also struggling to pare their work forces, largely by drastically cutting hiring of new employees. Unemployment hit another high in March, and a record share of college graduates this year will be unable to find established jobs, a trend that is encouraging more and more people to start businesses.
Further, the big companies that still dominate the economy are adopting compensation programs based on performance and abolishing remuneration determined by seniority, fast diluting the attractions of lifetime employment.
The evolution of the financial markets here is also helping entrepreneurs, as new stock markets emerge designed to foster young businesses and a flood of venture capital provides money that once was parceled out almost exclusively by big banks largely interested in corporate customers and real estate developers.
"I didn't even go to a bank when I started my company because I was pretty sure about the answer -- no," said Moto Kuroi, co-founder of Neuromagic, a Web design and strategic consulting firm. "I started the company with money from my friends and myself."
To be sure, V-Sync and Neuromagic have a few beneficial ties to big business. Sharp, Sumitomo Trust, Marubeni and other established Japanese companies have invested in V-Sync. Similarly, Neuromagic relies on Dentsu, the giant Japanese advertising agency, for some of its orders.
The difference is that were either of these two companies to lose those backers, they would scarcely miss a beat. When Internet Initiatives Japan, which specializes in connecting corporate customers to the Internet, wanted to raise money here two years ago, it was stymied. It finally went public last summer -- on the Nasdaq market in the United States.
But since then, two new stock exchanges have been set up specifically to foster fledgling enterprises -- Mothers, which made its debut late last year, and Nasdaq Japan, which will open this summer. Meanwhile, the pool of venture capital here is swelling. Even the government is eager to develop entrepreneurs, earmarking 10.3 billion yen, or about $97 million, for new ventures.
"I don't worry so much about finding money," said Mr. Kuroi, who almost sold Neuromagic recently but decided he would rather remain independent. "I worry about getting the right people to back us."
Part of the challenge for venture capitalists is that the large majority of money available to finance new businesses arrived only recently, so many of the entrepreneurs here have figured out ways to build their operations without it.
"Only one year ago, too little money was chasing too few deals," said Mitsumasa Murase, chairman and president of Jafco, the venture capital company. "Now, we have too much money chasing too few deals."
That is especially true now that barriers to taking young companies public have been eased, making private capital less crucial in nursing them. "Previously, if you invested in early stage companies, it would take 30 years to cash out and make money on them," Mr. Murase said. "Now, companies are going public at lightning speed, one and a half or two years after they are founded."
Just this week, V-Sync began making plans to offer shares to the public on the Mothers exchange. "We are rather like a telecom company, so we need money to build a fiber optic infrastructure," said Takaya Ibe, V-Sync's president and co-founder. "That requires a huge amount of money, and we feel the stock market is the best place to go for that."
In many ways, Mr. Ibe is even more remarkable than his whiz-kid partner, Mr. Fujii. To start with, after graduating from college, Mr. Ibe went to work for Hoechst, the big German chemical company, rather than a Japanese kaisha, a far rarer occurrence then than now.
He eventually left for a company specializing in semiconductor robotics, his second break from the traditional Japanese career pattern that chains employees to companies for life. From there, he went to Bandai, where he was part of a team that developed a variety of popular gadgets using computer chips.
But what most interested Mr. Ibe was developing circuitry to create three-dimensional computer games. At that time, about 15 years ago, Bandai was reaping the benefits of its simple, two-dimensional Super Mario games.
"I explained to the board that if we could introduce 3-D, the prospect for games would be great," he said. "But they told me, 'This two-dimensional Mario is beautiful and fun. Why should we create something new? What do we need 3-D for?' "
Disappointed, he stayed at Bandai a few more years but then struck out and founded his own company. On one project, he met Mr. Fujii.
The young Mr. Fujii was then working for a company that was a subcontractor to Bandai. "Even though I invented some smash hit products," he said, "the profit always went to Bandai. That's why I decided to start my own company and asked Mr. Ibe to be my partner."
Mr. Ibe had not forgotten his dreams, either. "I kept remembering the whole 3-D thing with Bandai and how Playstation and Nintendo had proven I was right," he said. "I did not want to repeat that mistake and miss out on an opportunity."
So he and Mr. Fujii pooled their money and went into business in hopes of exploiting the emerging network technologies already taking off in the United States. They were lucky when they received a research grant from Okayama Prefecture. They won a bid to supply information kiosks in train stations, beating out corporate titans like NEC and Fujitsu. And the giant Nippon Telegraph and Telephone turned to V-Sync when Mitsubishi Electric failed to deliver an information terminal.
The genius of people like Mr. Fujii has been in recognizing that subterranean Japan is a veritable spaghetti bowl of underutilized fiber optic cable and finding ways of putting it to use. Indeed, V-Sync's dreams go far beyond music; any kind of digital information -- books, movies, software, games -- can be downloaded through the POD.
That understanding of the power resident in telecommunications networks is what distinguishes many of the new entrepreneurs from their predecessors and the big kaisha. They have largely had to educate themselves, which has given them a self-confidence that is rare in Japan.
Mr. Kuroi, the Neuromagic founder, was a philosophy major studying at the International Christian University in Tokyo -- "I wanted to go to Hitotsubashi University," he said, "but I wasn't a good enough student" -- when he discovered the potential of networked technology.
"At that time, there was no commercial Internet, everything was operating at a speed of 2,400 baud, you couldn't send images or pictures of any kind, only text," he said. "I knew the technology would change, but my friends said what I was talking about was impossible."
After trying out a couple of different jobs, Mr. Kuroi met several employees of Apple Computer. "Those guys didn't think like Japanese, and being around them helped me to realize I don't need a protector."
So he started Neuromagic with a friend who left IBM Japan. They are still the sole owners of the company, which now has 20 employees.
Neuromagic, a pioneer in Japan's young Internet production industry, has worked on more than 100 Web sites, including sites for Sony Music Entertainment and Citibank Japan. It helped Gap plan its new store in Tokyo's trendy Harajuku neighborhood.
But Mr. Kuroi is not sanguine. Web site design companies are springing up all over, and he is well aware that his American counterparts are often operating outfits with 25 times the staff that Neuromagic has.
"We have to be more competitive, offer customers more services and ideas," Mr. Kuroi said. "That will take money."
His parents initially objected to Neuromagic, asking Mr. Kuroi to explain why they had wasted money sending him to college. "My father wanted me to work for Hitachi, Toshiba, Matsushita," Mr. Kuroi said. "That was his direction."
But Mr. Kuroi, who is 37, has now convinced his father that he made the right choice. "We are different from our parents' generation," he said. "We have different D.N.A."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 29; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk; Second Front

HEADLINE: Hard Choices for a Graying Island;
Battle Over Resources May Be Glimpse at America's Future

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

DATELINE: SHELTER ISLAND, N.Y., April 22

 BODY:
Snugly sheltered by geography and sensibility from the workaday bustle of Long Island's North Fork and the antsy glamour of the Hamptons to the south, this summer resort island has become a kind of year-round Elder Dorado. More than a third of its 2,300 winter residents are over 60, twice the average nationally and in the metropolitan area. The percentage may be even higher in summer when the population swells to about 10,000.
But even when gray is a primary color, it is not an ethnic, racial, religious or socioeconomic group. 
 Indeed, anthropologists from the booming geriatric-industrial complex might find a monograph of sorts here in the faltering campaign by some older residents to build a $750,000 center for the island's elderly. The plan has been attacked by some of the island's old people who think a senior center is unnecessary or should not be done without doing something as well for working parents and teenagers; they seem afraid of a tax increase, of change, of isolation, of seeming greedy, of being a burden.
"Which old people are we talking about?" asks the Rev. Fred Puelle, 65, a retired Lutheran minister who leads the island's Senior Citizens Affairs Council, an advisory board, and delivers Meals on Wheels. "The ones rocking in the corner or the folks who flirt, work out at the fitness center and enjoy the grape? The folks waiting for me to bring them food or the ones down in Palm Beach for the winter?"
Rockers or flirters, natives or weekenders, the old on Shelter Island did not arrive from somewhere else waving Medicare cards and a lease on a condo in an isolated village with the word leisure or heritage on the locked gate. Because the nation is aging rapidly, what is happening here now, while unusual, may be the harbinger of a returning way of life; the old here aged here and stayed here.
This 8,000-acre island, one-third of which is protected by the Nature Conservancy, was settled in the 17th century by the English, who displaced Indians and built a food and timber plantation worked by African slaves. Later, it was a base for fishermen.
Now, the mansions are best seen from the water, and the trailers and rusted cars in weedy backyards tend to be clustered in the island's middle. Most homes appear to be middle class, an eclectic mix of suburban ranches and split-levels, frame cottages and beachy boxes.
But as with any small island where the inhabitants know all and reveal little, the facades are misleading; living next door to occasional weekenders with city apartments and stacks of frequent flier miles are the house painters and real estate agents who depend on them.
And both groups include many on Medicare.
The island is not a place created for the needs of sunset-special diners; there are few stores or restaurants, it is accessible only by ferry and plagued by power blackouts, rampaging deer and Lyme ticks, all local badges of hardy courage. Local politicians can safely express their concern for the young families driven off-island because the older people who helped drive up real estate prices are so fragmented by their politics, economics and class.
"You want to think that this island is very special," says Art Barnett, the 70-year-old former publisher and editor of the weekly Shelter Island Reporter and now its town hall reporter. "But I've come to think that it's like everywhere else, except maybe you can see things more clearly here."
Most poignantly and universally, you can see those sore spots where individual vulnerability rubs against independence, and where the romanticized American past rubs against the present reality of communities trying to care for their own. The heroes of the island are the volunteers of the fire and rescue companies; yet the aging population has not only increased their workload, it has lowered their pool of young recruits.
Mr. Barnett, who opposes the all-senior center, and Seymour Weissman, 68, its most vocal champion, are aware of those sore spots.
Mr. Weissman, a retired Manhattan television producer, describes himself as the flamethrower of the nonprofit foundation formed to raise the money for the prospective all-senior center. Stocky, emphatic, he punches out his words.
"We've got an invisible elderly population here suffering from malnutrition and from the greatest disease of all, loneliness," he said. "A center would offer socialization, give caregivers respite, we could have nurses, technicians, social workers come in from off-island. There's a great deal of federal and foundation money available, but you have to have the building first. The money goes to programs, not to bricks."
Mr. Barnett discounts Mr. Weissman's bleak portrait as he campaigns for the renovation of the American Legion hall, underused as old soldiers fade away, into a community center for children, teenagers and the elderly. A former marketing executive from Long Island, Mr. Barnett speaks softly about using the past for guidance.
"I'm for what I call noninstitutional care," he said. "Neighbors looking out for each other, the way it's always been. It never gets into The Reporter, but the police are always helping an old man back into his bed, reassuring an old woman who has heard sounds in the night. Someone brings a casserole, drives you to the doctor, takes care of the dog. Someone looks out and sees that the lights are still on in Charlie's house, the newspaper hasn't been picked up, and calls Henrietta, who probably has done something about it already."
True, Henrietta Roberts, 67, the part-time coordinator of senior services, checks on three shut-ins on her way home and runs a "telephone reassurance" network for 14 others. But she thinks that "the islander mentality of taking care of their own" may be outmoded.
"It worked once, but there are too many old people now," she said, in her basement room off the Red Cross offices. A garage is filled with donated canes, walkers and wheelchairs. "I think we may now have almost 1,000 seniors on the island. They are living so long that their problems become very complex. Just like everywhere else. Sometimes this work is so depressing. It's a crystal ball of what's coming for me."
As did Mr. Weissman and Mr. Barnett, Ms. Roberts moved here permanently after years of vacationing on the island. She retired as a human resources manager for a Manhattan corporation. She likes the idea of an all-senior center because of the services and personnel it could draw, but she is torn; her 15-year-old grandson also needs a safe place to drop in with his friends.
"Ultimately it's all about money," she said. "People are afraid of taxes. When I wrote to the seniors about the Town Board giving us the land for a center, I got a letter back asking me to use cheaper stationery."
Money creeps into every conversation about the center. Critics of the proposal roll their eyes at an architect's rendering of four offices, a conference room, a classroom, a porch, a patio and a fireplace, and handsomely landscaped grounds.
"You have to look at the total community," Mr. Barnett said, "because you can't separate the needs of the aging from the needs of their grandchildren -- who may need a youth center to let off steam -- and of their sons and daughters who work and need day care for the kids. We don't even know exactly what the needs of the community are, and here we have a $750,000 Taj Mahal."
Mr. Weissman bristles at that. "Too good for old people? No one really wants to deal with this; the problems of old age are viewed with horror, coming attractions to be denied. No celebrities, it's not sexy. The Yacht Club raises money to send a young sailor around the world to race. That's fine so long as it's not at the expense of what's really necessary."
He takes a deep breath. "You know what it really is. Pure class warfare."
This is not a new idea. Some years ago, a letter published in The Reporter derided the faltering campaign for a new school building. Why even bother, asked the writer, whose address was one of the island's toniest, when graduates of the school would just go work on the island's ferry anyway? The backlash reinvigorated the campaign, and the town built a splendid new school, whose need is questioned to this day.
A more recent class warfare story is told at the weekly communitywide senior lunch at the Presbyterian church, the headquarters of senior nutrition services paid by Suffolk County. A year ago, 14 older bridge players from the Ram Island neighborhood, the island's geographical and social Upper East Side, appeared at noon one Monday. The regulars were thrilled and intimidated. The newcomers sat by themselves at the $2 lunch, stayed late to play cards and never returned.
But the moral of that story -- rich folks are snooty -- loses steam quickly; the regulars had made no effort to welcome the upper crust and, in fact, do not much mix among themselves either. Husbands and wives save seats for each other. When Dorothy Bloom, 76, once handed out numbers with instructions to find the matching chair, she had a rebellion.
"They were shouting, 'NO, I always sit THERE,' " Ms. Bloom said. "My mother had an expression about certain old people. 'He don't even know the Civil War is over.' "
Ms. Bloom was sitting at a Monday lunch with Alice Fiske, coquettish about her age and dressed for a cocktail party, who dismisses the cliquish Ram Islanders with a wave. She is the grande dame of Sylvester Manor, the island's original English settlement. Her late husband's ancestors once ran the slave plantation on the site. Why does she come to Monday lunch? "It is my duty," she said, "to support worthy causes."
She expressed her noblesse oblige amid 30 lively middle-class diners, mostly in their late 70's and early 80's. Typically, they had retired to Shelter Island 20 years ago after many years of summering here or visiting relatives. They had driven themselves to the church. They all happily complained about how busy their lives were; after lunch, which few lingered over, they had to rush off to shop, walk the dog, quilt, pick up a grandchild, see a doctor.
The elegant Ms. Fiske noted that no one had done a real study of what anybody of any age really needed. What kind of building do older people want? And which programs? Do Shelter Island retirees need or want square dance lessons, a dialysis unit, day care for Alzheimer's patients? She said she wanted more details about the kind of activities in any new center. "Why are old people old?" she asked. "Because younger people put them in places and stack them like logs."
A random telephone poll of 300 residents, presented to the Town Board recently, seemed to indicate that if no tax money was involved, people had no strong preferences among a community center, a youth center or a senior center. But the senior center dropped out of favor if taxes needed to be raised 3 to 5 percent. Where had those figures come from?
Town Supervisor Gerry Siller said he did not know, although he had endorsed the poll. He said it was financed by an anonymous older resident who had rejected Mr. Weissman's plea for a donation, citing a lack of data. Mr. Siller, a 46-year-old landscape contractor, thinks that the greatest priority is more affordable housing for local families, which was the lowest priority recorded in the poll. In fact, he confided, he is working back channels to finance such housing with that very same multimillionaire who financed the poll.
This, he said, was the Shelter Island way of taking care of its own, everyday people helping one another, and in crises -- like forestalling development -- going down those long private driveways to the big houses overlooking the deep-water docks.
But the senior issue, Mr. Puelle thinks, needs more than just money. "There has to be a readjustment in attitude," he said. "It's about acknowledging a population that no one -- including members of the population -- really wants to identify with."
He was talking fast as he steered the Meals on Wheels van up a driveway of overgrown weeds and broken concrete. In the back, his wife, Doris, also 65, prepared boxes of food.
This first house was dark, overheated and stinking of liniment, as were most of the dozen houses he visited that day. Mr. Puelle checked for danger signals: too many days of unwashed dishes, bathroom smells, moans of pain, dishevelment, silence. A querulous voice from a distant room finally ordered him to just put the food on a counter strewn with medicine vials. Mr. Puelle called out his standard farewell, "See you next week, God willing."
Back in the van, he asked, "So, what kind of senior center does he need? Do Doris and I need?"
