HEADLINE: 500 Years Later, Brazil Looks Its Past in the Face

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 24

 BODY:
It was envisioned as a feel-good patriotic festival like the American Bicentennial. But the Brazilian government should have known that its plans to mark the 500th anniversary of the landing of the Portuguese were doomed when an irate Indian chief marched into Congress earlier this month, drew his bow and arrow and threatened to kill the Senate president.
Sure enough, the yearlong commemoration got off to a bumpy start on Saturday, when military police officers used tear gas, nightsticks and rubber bullets to disperse 2,000 Indian-led demonstrators taking part in a "march of the excluded" in Porto Seguro, the focal point of the official celebrations. 
 More than 140 people were arrested and at least a dozen were injured in the clash. And today the director of the Indian affairs bureau resigned in protest over the government's stand in the whole affair.
"What happened today was the same thing that took place when Pedro Alvares Cabral arrived here," Nailton Pataxo, a leader of the Ha Ha Hae tribe, said Saturday. "He came, looted everything and used violence against indigenous peoples." Mr. Pataxo's tribe has been demanding that the government return traditional lands now occupied by ranchers.
Cabral was the leader of the flotilla that on April 22, 1500, sighted land in what is today the northern state of Bahia. The first landing party went ashore the next day, led by a Polish Jew who was the expedition's interpreter and whose languages included Arabic and Hindi. On April 26 the rest of the crew disembarked at the site known today as Santa Cruz Cabralia to erect a cross and offer thanks in the first Roman Catholic Mass on Brazilian soil.
Leaders of Brazil's 300,000 Indians have vowed to "resist" the commemorations of those and other events scheduled for coming days, and they are not the only ones complaining. Black groups have been marching to protest what they say is the marginal role to which Afro-Brazilians have been relegated.
And the Movement of the Landless, a leftist peasant group, is marking the anniversary with a campaign to occupy 500 ranches and farms that it contends are lying idle.
As the self-styled "country of the future," bursting with outsized dreams and ambitions, Brazil is not in the habit of scrutinizing its past. "Every 15 years Brazilians forget everything that happened in the past 15 years," is the way a political satirist, Ivan Lessa, once put it.
But the 500th anniversary has forced a process of self-examination, and many Brazilians do not particularly seem to like what they see.
"I am ashamed of Brazil," the country's most famous personage, the soccer star Pele, said in a newspaper interview this month, denouncing what he called "the diversion of government funds, thievery and dishonest politicians."
Though the country has largely bounced back from the crisis that threatened to sink the economy last year, glaring problems remain -- including urban violence and the concentration of income and land ownership in relatively few hands.
One result is an identity crisis. "Brazil is marking 500 years without knowing what it is," said a banner headline that ran in the daily Jornal do Brasil over the weekend.
Indeed, in the last year the best-seller lists here have been dominated by books that cast a critical look at Brazilian society and history. Ranging from biographies of Emperor Pedro II and other historical figures to trenchant analyses of social inequalities, such works been snatched up in record numbers by a public that in the past has not shown much of a commitment to buying books.
"I think Brazilians want to know why things have not turned out well, why Brazil hasn't worked," said Eduardo Bueno, the author of three recent books on early Brazilian history that have sold more than 500,000 copies. "Life is complicated, money is scarce, a feeling of citizenship is lacking and people sense that the answer lies in history, that perhaps things went wrong from the very beginning."
That is not the tone that the minister of tourism and sports, Rafael Greca de Macedo, sought to impart when he wrested control of the celebration from the more intellectual types at the Foreign Affairs Ministry. His goal, he says, was a series of events that would be "attractive, cheap and have popular appeal," helping the country's 170 million people build a positive self-image.
"You can't view history with a perspective of remorse," Mr. Greca said recently at a news conference here for foreign reporters about the anniversary celebration. He described Brazil as "a land of ethnic peace," praising its remarkable cultural and racial diversity and arguing that Indians had cause to be grateful for "their inclusion in Brazilian society."
Still, there have been complaints that the $20 million Mr. Greca has spent, some of it on concerts and the construction of a soccer museum, should have gone elsewhere. "Brazil would be much better off if the president had applied the money consumed in this insipid commemoration to building 500 schools and 500 hospitals," Artur Xexeo wrote in his column in Jornal do Brasil on Friday.
Back in the mother country on the other side of the Atlantic, a similar divide has emerged. Although President Jorge Sampaio of Portugal, who is here for this week's commemorations, has dismissed complaints about the colonial period by arguing that "we are responsible only for our own time," Portuguese intellectuals have taken a more negative view.
"The discovery was not a dialogue of cultures, nor an encounter of peoples," Jose Saramago, the novelist who won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1998, wrote recently. "It was violence, depredation and conquest."
Taking a cue from such declarations, the Roman Catholic Church here is about to issue an unusual mea culpa. At a weeklong conference scheduled to begin on Wednesday, the country's more than 300 bishops are to sign a statement asking forgiveness of Indians and blacks for sins the church committed against them during the colonial period.
"Many times the church's envoys were more allies of the conquistadors than the Gospel," Msgr. Marcelo Carvalheira, head of the committee that is drawing up the statement, said in explaining the need for the document. "The philosophy was conquer first and then catechize."
With the national mood so somber and contentious, President Fernando Henrique Cardoso has shown signs of increasing exasperation. "The 500th anniversary festivities shouldn't be an invitation to a wake," he said last week. But in the face of the protests, the president's itinerary in Bahia has been reduced, and he is no longer scheduled to attend the commemorative Mass on Wednesday.

SECTION: Section B; Page 9; Column 1; Style Desk; Fashion Page

LENGTH: 1209 words

HEADLINE: The Mini Rebellion Is Over. Long Skirts Reign.

BYLINE: By GINIA BELLAFANTE 

 BODY:
One recent morning, Becky Michaels, who handles advertising at a Midtown publishing house, left her Upper West Side apartment in the kind of look that hadn't called to her in many months: a skirt that sat somewhere in the mezzanine section of her thigh, not in the orchestra. Her husband, a musician, asked if she intended to go to the office "like that." Ms. Michaels, who had wavered about putting the skirt on in the first place, found herself feeling uncomfortably low-rent for the rest of the day.
For nearly as long as there has been a "Style With Elsa Klensch," designers have stood in front of television cameras trying to promote modern fashion as a laissez-faire enterprise. Hike your skirt up to your sciatic nerve; let it graze your Achilles' tendon. It doesn't matter; anything goes. But, of course, anything does not go. 
 For the better part of the last eight years, short skirts and dresses -- micro-minis, minis, garments with hemlines resting anywhere north of the knee -- have been rare sightings on the world's most influential runways, like Prada's. Even designers like Alessandro Dell'Acqua, once known for revealing skirts, have shown noticeably fewer of them lately. What runways and their ambassadors -- fashion editors -- have earnestly legislated instead is a length just at or below the knee.
Real women haven't necessarily abided. Until not too long ago, among the many women who don't read Vogue as carefully as if it were a warning on a can of paint stripper, shorter skirts turned up defiantly, just as flat shoes and other looks the fashion establishment considers passe managed to do. But now, it seems, working women are indicating that they would like to keep their legs more or less to themselves.
Jeffrey Kalinsky, the Atlanta retailer who last year opened a New York boutique, recently recalled that his customers used to fight him "tooth and nail" on the sophisticated knee length he encouraged. Shoppers, he said, would ask to get the skirts hiked up. He would try, often unsuccessfully, to caution them against it. He would offer them these words, he said: "If you go this short, it's going to look like Talbot's." But two years ago, Mr. Kalinsky noticed that women had stopped asking him to hem their skirts.
At shopping environments a little less rarefied than Mr. Kalinsky's, Henri Bendel, for example, sales of short skirts started to slip late last year. Ed Burstell, the store's fashion director, said that as a result, the store carries far fewer above-the-knee skirts than it once did. The style "could have the connotation of looking cheap," Mr. Burstell suggested, adding, "There are other ways you can convey sexuality."
New hemline opinions tend to raise the kind of questions that other shifts in taste lack the history and symbolism to force. One theory long promulgated by fashion watchers is that hemlines rise in boom times (the 1920's, the 80's) and fall during less economically vital years (the early 70's). The current abandonment of shorter lengths contradicts that idea.
But more important, what, if anything, does the shift represent? The triumph of fashion's dictatorial strain? The true death of the suit (with which short skirts were often associated) as a professional costume? Or perhaps something deeper, a weariness of bringing a "go ahead and objectify me" brand of feminism to the office? That is, a reluctance to display too much, after a protracted national conversation, in the wake of the Monica Lewinsky scandal, about what does and doesn't constitute sexual misbehavior at work.
Kathy McCarver Root, a photography editor at Us Weekly, said she stopped wearing short skirts to her Manhattan office in the last year because "I feel a little bit uncovered." Shannon Luckoski, 26, an administrative assistant in Atlanta, said her instinct to abandon short skirts was validated on a recent evening when she wore an animal-print version to a bar and found the hand of a former colleague on her thigh.
At a recent dinner shared by about 10 professional women, all in their 20's or early 30's, at an East Side restaurant, the talk turned to the fact that none wore short skirts anymore, not even at night. What was surprising was how many used words like "inappropriate" and "sluttish" to describe how they now felt in clothes they once wore without hesitation.
Later, Kerry Bernstein, who is 27 and works in marketing at a corporate investigations firm, said that while she was recently packing up clothes for the Salvation Army, she was shocked to discover skirts that fell to midthigh, ones she breezily wore to work two years ago, but would never wear today. "You don't want to think about men as you walk out of an office checking you out," she said.
Olivia Douglas, 30, a commercial real estate executive, said she had sent all of her short skirts to Goodwill, including one she was wearing when she met her husband at a wedding four years ago.
At Ann Taylor, arguably the nation's iconic purveyor of career clothing, the skirt suit -- or the interview suit, as it is known in retail parlance -- has had a noteworthy past couple of years. Calhoun Sumrall, a vice president and design director at the store, said that three or four years ago, the skirt length for the standard Ann Taylor interview suit was 19 inches, not too far above the knee on a woman of average height. It later dipped to 21 inches and now rests at 22 inches. Mr. Sumrall pointed out that while shorter lengths do well as part of the store's more casual collections, the best-selling length sits below the knee at 24 inches.
"The majority of women embrace a style long after avant-garde designers present it," he said.
Where showy skirts have received their greatest play of late is affixed to the waist of Julia Roberts in "Erin Brockovich," which is based on the story of a real-life single mother who didn't have much time for the fantasy of fashion magazines. Erin Brockovich set about uncovering deadly corporate malfeasance in three-inch heels and skirts that appear no wider than a Post-it note. Jeffrey Kurland, the film's costume designer, had most of the clothes made, in part because the streetwalker style Ms. Brockovich favored in the late 80's, when the movie is partly set, weren't so easy to come by.
Mr. Kurland has spent much of his career observing urban habits in the service of dressing characters that populate Woody Allen movies. He theorized that women have been moving subconsciously away from provocative lengths ever since Americans began speaking more openly about sexual harassment, which is to say, since the Clarence Thomas-Anita Hill hearings.
This is the sort of argument that Ally McBeal, champion of the uber-mini, might have had little tolerance for early on in her television life. Last season, Ms. McBeal, the angst-ridden lawyer, was held in contempt of court during one episode for wearing a skirt that barely reached past her hips. She was furious at being condemned for her choice, but as the episode progressed, Ms. McBeal came to see her brash attempts at postfeminist expression as a kind of trouble-making self-involvement, which made people around her uncomfortable.
This season Ally has often shown up at work in pants.

HEADLINE: Lycos to Buy 10% Stake in Autoweb.com

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: SANTA CLARA, Calif., April 24

 BODY:
The Web media network Lycos Inc. said today that it would buy a 10 percent stake in the consumer automotive Internet service Autoweb.com Inc. as part of a four-year strategic alliance they formed to build and jointly operate a new online automotive channel.
As part of the agreement, Lycos will also receive yearly multimillion-dollar payments. The exact amount was not disclosed. 
 In addition to starting the Lycos-Autoweb channel, the companies said in a statement that they would also deliver marketing and e-commerce opportunities to the auto industry in an attempt to capture a growing share of the multibillion-dollar online automotive market.
More than 55 percent of new car buyers use the Internet as part of their car-shopping process, according to J. D. Power & Associates, an automotive sector research firm.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1120 words

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
InvestorsFind Vulnerability In Microsoft

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
Since it first sold shares to the public 14 years ago, Microsoft has become more than a software company.
As it turned in steady increases in profit and revenue quarter after quarter, year after year, Microsoft convinced an entire generation of investors that no price was too rich to pay for a leading technology company. Sure, Microsoft's stock price always seemed expensive relative to its current earnings. But a year or two later, those earnings were much higher, and so was Microsoft's stock. 
 No more.
For the first time in more than a decade, investors have had to confront the reality that even Microsoft sometimes misses its mark. And they are not happy.
Microsoft shares fell more than 15 percent yesterday after investors digested the company's earnings report for the quarter ended in March and realized that operating profit was short of analysts' estimates, although net income was slightly ahead of expectations thanks to gains on its investments. In addition, Microsoft encouraged analysts to cut their earnings and revenue estimates for its fiscal fourth quarter, which ends in June, as well as all of fiscal 2001.
The disappointing news on earnings was compounded by reports yesterday that the Justice Department may try to resolve its antitrust case against the software maker by splitting Microsoft into two or more companies. With many technology stocks in a monthlong swoon, jittery investors shed Microsoft shares with extreme prejudice. By day's end, Microsoft had fallen $12.3125, to $66.625, in heavy trading, with more than 155 million shares changing hands. The decline shaved close to $70 billion off the company's market valuation, a drop larger than the total market capitalization of General Motors.
Microsoft's fall set off a rout in many technology stocks, with the technology-rich Nasdaq composite index closing yesterday at 3,482.48, down 161.40. That puts the index at its lowest level since a 9.7 percent plunge 10 days ago left it at 3,321.29. Page C18.
Despite the plunge, Microsoft's problems are not necessarily bad news for the rest of the technology sector. Worldwide technology spending remains strong and other big technology companies, including Intel, have reported first-quarter earnings well ahead of analysts' expectations.
"Almost across the board, technology spending appears to be extremely robust and healthy," said Michael Manns, senior portfolio manager at American Express Asset Management, which invests $7 billion.
But United States companies are spending less money on desktop computers and more money on high-end servers that they can use for crunching numbers in databases and running business-to-business Internet sites. Sun Microsystems, a maker of servers, benefits from this shift at Microsoft's expense, said Chris Mortenson, a managing director of Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown.
"For the last year we've been moving to a more server-centric environment," Mr. Mortenson said. "That is taking away from spending on the desktop."
Like other Wall Street analysts, Mr. Mortenson said most of Microsoft's slide yesterday came because of fears that its growth had slowed -- not because of the Justice Department's antitrust case. Mr. Mortenson said he did not think a Microsoft breakup would be good for the company's investors, but he noted that the lawsuit will take years to resolve and that no one knows the outcome.
Jeff Applegate, a longtime bull on technology stocks and chief investment strategist at Lehman Brothers, agreed that the antitrust case is less important to Microsoft's future than the shift in technology spending away from personal computers. "I've viewed the legal stuff, the antitrust issue, as more of a sideshow, and to me the real issue is can these guys migrate their business from a PC-centric to an Internet-centric world," Mr. Applegate said.
Microsoft's earnings report last week offered cause for concern on that score. The company said that its sales in the three months ended March 31 were $5.66 billion, up 23 percent from their 1999 level. But most analysts were predicting a much stronger increase, to $5.9 billion. Most of the shortfall came from lighter-than-expected sales of the company's Windows operating system software, with sales to business customers especially poor, analysts said. That crimped Microsoft's operating margins, which were down slightly compared with 1999.
While Microsoft's profits rose 23 percent compared with the 1999 quarter, to $2.4 billion, or 43 cents a share, much of that increase came from unexpectedly large gains in Microsoft's investments in other companies. Microsoft's operating profits were actually 2 cents short of analysts' expectations, the first time Microsoft has disappointed Wall Street since March 1989.
In addition, Microsoft told analysts that its revenue and profit growth would stay slow throughout this year and into 2001. While the company regularly talks down its future prospects, analysts said that this guidance was more conservative than usual, especially since it came after a soft quarter.
Still, investors would be wise to keep Microsoft's troubles in perspective. Most companies would be thrilled to have operating margins near 50 percent and a cash and investment hoard that tops $40 billion. And Mr. Applegate noted that since the rally in technology began in early 1993, there have been seven previous periods when technology stocks significantly underperformed the market, he said. Each time, they have eventually regained their lead.
"It's not like this has never happened," Mr. Applegate said. "It's typically a poster child which stumbles."
But Microsoft's success has made it more than just another technology company. Its gains have coincided with a decadelong economic renaissance in the United States, and an enormous bull market in technology stocks. Microsoft's growth taught many investors that technology could be enormously profitable. Then the even speedier ascent of Cisco Systems, the leading manufacturer of networking equipment, turned advocates of GARP, or growth at a reasonable price, into fans of GAAP -- growth at any price.
Now Microsoft's earnings shortfall has highlighted the downside of paying top prices for growth companies. It offers proof, as if any were needed, that no company can compound its earnings to infinity and that even the best-managed business sometimes falls victim to forces beyond its control.
"I don't have much sympathy for people who pay 100, 110 times earnings for companies like Cisco and Sun Microsystems," said Scott Black, president of Boston-based Delphi Management and a longtime value investor. "These are very fine companies. But trees don't grow to the sky."

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 637 words

HEADLINE: A Vietnam Premonition

 BODY:
As the nation reflects this week on the meaning of the Vietnam War 25 years after the fall of Saigon, a few fateful words of Lyndon Johnson's tumble across the decades to remind us that a senseless conflict might have been avoided. On a May morning in 1964, as Johnson was weighing whether to expand American military involvement in Vietnam, he confided in a conversation with Senator Richard Russell that he did not really know why Washington should go to war in Southeast Asia. Referring to Sgt. Kenneth Gaddis, who was one of his valets, Johnson said he was troubled by the idea of sending this father of six children to war. "And what the hell are we going to get out of his doing it?" Johnson asked himself. "And it just makes the chills run up my back."
Even so many years later it is hard not to be saddened and angered by Johnson's failure to follow that simple impulse. His comments, recorded by the White House and published a few years ago by Michael Beschloss in a compendium of Johnson tapes entitled "Taking Charge," captured a larger truth that still rests uneasily on the American soul. No compelling national interest was served by waging war in Vietnam, and the men who directed the war, including Johnson and his secretary of defense Robert McNamara, knew it at the time. More than 58,000 American servicemen lost their lives in a land of negligible political and economic importance to the welfare of the United States. The idea that Communism would advance inexorably across Asia if Ho Chi Minh was victorious in Vietnam was the hallucination of men numbed, and trapped, by the liturgies of the cold war. 
 The same men also violated a cardinal principle of politics and warfare by drafting citizens for combat without first building strong public support for their cause. The Gulf of Tonkin resolution, approved by Congress in 1964 after the Pentagon reported that United States naval vessels had been attacked by North Vietnam, was a flimsy license for committing the country to a land war in Asia.
As opposition grew, and demonstrations against the fighting spread across the country, Johnson and his aides failed to recognize that a divided democracy cannot sustain a foreign war without doing grievous damage to itself and its principles. By the time Johnson realized the harm he had done, his political career was wrecked and the domestic achievements of his presidency had been overshadowed by his reckless spilling of American and Vietnamese blood.
The physical wounds of those who fought bravely in Vietnam healed long ago, but the war will always loom large in their lives, as it does in the political memory of the nation. It changed America in innumerable ways, for better and for worse. It undermined a generation's faith in the judgment and truthfulness of its military and diplomatic leaders. But above all, it taught us that the United States must not commit its soldiers to protracted combat in the absence of clear security interests, and that future wars cannot be fought without the support of the American people.
For these and many other reasons, the Vietnam War Memorial in Washington is different from the other monuments where America honors its fallen soldiers. The starkness and simplicity of the memorial, with the names of each soldier etched in polished black granite, reminds visitors that no victory is celebrated on this spot, no noble cause honored in memory of those who sacrificed their lives.
The monument instead commemorates the needless sacrifice of troops who were betrayed by a president who prosecuted a war he did not believe in for a goal that he could not define in public speeches or private conversation. That, more than anything, is what the nation must remember this week, and that is why the words of Lyndon Johnson still sting.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Nasdaq Index Tumbles Again, Hurt by Microsoft Results

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stocks had another rocky session yesterday, as the aftershocks of Microsoft's most recent earnings report reverberated through the Nasdaq market. 
 Microsoft, which reported results from its third fiscal quarter after the market closed on Thursday, was battered, falling 12 5/16, or 15.6 percent, to 66 5/8. It was the biggest loss in the company's share price since Oct. 26, 1987, a week after the stock market crashed.
The slide was a huge contributor to the 161.40 point, or 4.4 percent, decline in the Nasdaq composite index, which closed at 3,482.48. A late rally in many Nasdaq shares pulled the index off its lows for the session. Still, Microsoft was responsible for more than 41 points of the Nasdaq's drop.
Investors moved into other sectors of the market as they exited Microsoft and other technology stocks.
The Dow Jones industrial average managed to rise, even though Microsoft is a component of the blue-chip indicator. The Dow closed at 10,906.10, up 62.05 points, or 0.6 percent. Gains in financial stocks like American Express, which reported strong earnings; General Electric; and J. P. Morgan outweighed weakness in Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard.
Rising prices for drug, chemical and consumer stocks helped to limit losses in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which closed at 1,429.86, down 4.68 points, or 0.3 percent.
But the Russell 2000 index of small company stocks was battered. The Russell, which has been dominated by the performance of a relatively small group of technology and biotechnology stocks, fell 13.30 points yesterday, or 2.8 percent, to 468.54.
"Even in the midst of the decline in technology over the last six weeks or so, I don't think investors have reconciled the fact they were overweight technology at the expense of everything else," said Jonathan Oleksy, head of block trading at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "We are seeing genuine interest in sectors like drugs, chemicals, banks and utilities. Technology will still ultimately command a large weighting of a person's portfolio. But by the time you wring out this excess ownership more of this rotational activity will have gone on."
With the Nasdaq market now down 31 percent from its peak on March 10 and 14.4 percent for the year, some analysts said they were beginning to look for signs that technology stocks are forming a bottom.
"The Nasdaq market is now just about as oversold relative to its two-month moving average as it was back in 1987," said Laszlo Birinyi, who heads his own stock market research firm in Greenwich, Conn.
William Meehan, chief market analyst at Cantor Fitzgerald, said: "We are getting close to a level where I may actually do a little buying myself, in Microsoft and in technology in general. If you are underweight technology, I would put some cash to work if the Nasdaq composite got to 3,250."
There is little question that Microsoft's stock has been harshly treated: so far this year, the stock is down 43 percent. Among Standard & Poor's 500 companies, the decline has dropped Microsoft into fourth place in terms of market capitalization. It now trails General Electric, Cisco Systems and Intel.
And it has put a major crimp in the carrying value of Bill Gates' holdings. Based on the most recent data on Microsoft shareholders, the decline in the stock since the start of the year has wiped out nearly $40 billion in paper assets from Mr. Gates's portfolio.
Microsoft was far and away the most actively traded issue yesterday. Nearly 157 million Microsoft shares changed hands, the third highest ever for an American stock. Trading in Microsoft was about three times that of the next most active issue yesterday, Cisco Systems. Cisco fell 1 11/16, to 63 7/16. The stock traded as low as 59 1/4.
On the whole, however, traders said business was fairly quiet. European markets were closed in observance of Easter Monday.
Among Dow stocks, American Express rose 7 1/16, to 150 1/16, after it reported first-quarter earnings that beat Wall Street's forecasts.
Merck, which also reported solid earnings, gained 2 3/16, to 71 15/16. And McDonald's rose 2 7/8, to 38 11/16.
Big chemical companies like DuPont and Dow Chemical gained. DuPont rose 1 3/4, to 56. And Dow Chemical was up 3 5/8, to 109.
Along with Microsoft, Exodus Communications was the biggest decliner on the Nasdaq market. Late Thursday the company, a manager of Internet sites, reported a loss that was wider than expected. Yesterday the stock was hammered, falling 25 3/16, to 82 1/2.
"If we didn't see this terrific rotation that is going on, I would be much more worried," said David Williams, manager of the $1.2 billion Excelsior Value and Restructuring fund at the United States Trust Company. "As long as the rotation continues, the market can probably move higher."

Treasury Prices Fall
(By Reuters) -- Treasury bonds and notes fell yesterday in thin trading, getting little help from safe-haven buying as technology stocks fell sharply while bond market players braced for strong economic data expected later in the week.
Price movements yesterday were exaggerated by the paucity of dealings. Trading was thin as American markets reopened after the holiday weekend, while Europe was still closed.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 23/32, to 105 9/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.87 percent from 5.83 percent on Thursday.
This Thursday, the market will get a double dose of economic data, which is expected to be robust. Those figures would keep pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates at its next meeting, on May 16.

HEADLINE: Boston Bank Says It Has Won Board Seats at Carver Bancorp

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
A Boston bank that has been waging a long-running battle over Carver Bancorp in Harlem said late yesterday that a court decision had given it two seats on the board of Carver, a financially troubled institution that is the largest black-run bank in the country.
Two executives of the Boston Bank of Commerce, a black-owned bank that is one of Carver's largest shareholders, ran for Carver's board at a tumultuous shareholder meeting in February; they were defeated by a narrow margin, 30,000 of the 1.7 million votes cast. The executives, Kevin Cohee and his wife, Teri Williams, have challenged the election on several grounds. 
 Yesterday, the Delaware Chancery Court issued a ruling invalidating about 86,000 votes that were cast in favor of the incumbent directors, David R. Jones, the bank's chairman, and David N. Dinkins, the former mayor.
"The judge ruled that Teri and Kevin are on the board," said Robert Patrick Cooper, general counsel of Boston Bank. "They look forward to sitting at the next board meeting."
But Carver executives believe the ruling is technical in nature and may appeal it, said Ruth Pachman, a spokeswoman for the bank. "It does not say they can go on the board," she said.
A trial on the other issues raised by Boston Bank is scheduled to begin next month in Delaware, where Carver is incorporated. The main issue in the case is whether Carver improperly sold shares to friendly Wall Street firms to stuff the ballot box rather than to strengthen the bank's financial position.
Yesterday's ruling is the latest twist in what has become a bitter fight over the future of the bank, which was founded in 1949.
The insurgents have criticized the bank's new president, Deborah C. Wright, for her lack of banking experience; though she once worked on Wall Street, she was more recently the president of the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, an economic development agency.
Ms. Wright and her supporters have, in turn, criticized Boston Bank as an interloper without the community ties that the bank needs. They note that Mr. Cohee has proposed merging Carver with his institution, a plan that he says he has abandoned.

HEADLINE: U.S. SAID TO WANT MICROSOFT BROKEN INTO2 COMPANIES

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY with STEVE LOHR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
The Justice Department intends to ask a federal judge this week to break Microsoft into two companies to bring about competition in the software industry, officials and others aware of the government's deliberations said today.
The proposal comes less than a month after settlement talks between the government and Microsoft broke down and a federal judge found Microsoft in wide violation of federal and state antitrust laws. 
 But even though the judge, Thomas Penfield Jackson, ruled that the company was a predatory monopolist, there is no assurance that he will accept the proposed remedy.
Microsoft called the idea "a radical and extreme example of government regulation that would be bad for consumers and for the high-tech economy." A spokesman, Mark Murray, added, "There is no basis in the evidence presented in this case for this sort of radical remedy."
Several people with knowledge of the Justice Department's plan said it called for one company to retain the Windows operating-system business and the other to take the rest of Microsoft's operations, including software programs like Word and Excel, Microsoft's Web browser and its Internet businesses.
The result would be about a 60-40 split of Microsoft's estimated $23 billion in revenue this year, with operating systems being the lesser share. While in some ways the plan would create two monopolies in place of one, the premise is that their incentives would differ and that they would therefore behave differently. News analysis, Page C1.
The Justice Department's inclination to seek a breakup of the company was reported today by The Wall Street Journal, The Washington Post and USA Today.
As recently as last week, officials said the 19 states that joined with the Justice Department in the case appeared to be seeking remedies short of a breakup. Now that the states have been briefed on the federal plan, they generally support it, several officials said.
But it is not clear whether the states will endorse the plan in full or formulate a plan of their own by Friday, the deadline set by the judge. It also remains possible that the states will fail to agree among themselves, in which case they are to submit a proposal based on the opinion of the majority.
The broad idea behind the Justice Department's plan is to create incentives for increased competition among operating systems and in related businesses. One reason Windows has no significant competitors is that Microsoft generally does not create software for non-Windows operating systems, with the exception of Apple Computer's.
Microsoft Office, the suite of programs that includes Word for word processing and Excel for spreadsheet calculations, commands more than 90 percent of that business, known as application software. So an operating system on which Office cannot run stands little chance.
But Microsoft argues that a new applications-software company would have no more incentive to write for smaller operating systems than is now the case. Mr. Murray, the Microsoft spokesman, said, "There is no evidence that would lead anyone to believe that Office stands as the linchpin for resolving all of the government's concerns."
Because any breakup proposal would probably be stayed pending appeal, the government plans to ask for several interim restrictions on Microsoft's behavior, to remain in force for three years if a breakup plan is ultimately approved and carried out, and 10 years if not.
As part of these so-called conduct remedies, Microsoft would have to publish a standardized price list for Windows so that it could not raise the price for companies that do not go along with Microsoft's requests.
Microsoft would be forbidden to strike exclusive contracts with other companies, as it did with Internet service providers that in past years were asked to feature Microsoft's Web browser and no others.
Microsoft would also have to make available the codes that allow other companies to write programs for Windows without discrimination.
And the company would not be allowed to build certain new applications into Windows, like Web browsers and media players, without also offering a version of Windows that does not provide access to that new application. Computer makers would get a discount if they asked for Windows without the new feature.
Microsoft calls most of these ideas excessive, beyond the scope of the evidence presented during the trial, and notes that these conduct remedies might be stayed pending appeal, along with the breakup proposal.
It was Microsoft's decision to build a Web browser, Internet Explorer, into Windows four years ago that prompted the government's suit. The decision assured that, over time, Internet Explorer would be installed automatically on nearly all of the world's personal computers, driving the market leader of the time, Netscape, to a marginal position today.
Under the new government plan, the applications software company would retain possession of Internet Explorer, meaning that Microsoft would have to create a stand-alone version -- something the company has adamantly refused to do.
The applications-software company could license Internet Explorer back to the Windows company -- but only once. When the time came to upgrade the browser, each of the new companies would have to do that on its own, thereby creating competition in the browser business.
The government would also ask for strong anticollusion rules for the new companies, and they would stay in place indefinitely. Those rules have not been described.
One individual close to the situation stressed that the Justice Department had settled on it for several reasons. First, it does not fragment the operating system, an approach that could have led to incompatible computers and programs.
Under this plan, the government would also not be required to maintain long-term, constant, intrusive monitoring of Microsoft, which both Microsoft and the courts would probably find objectionable.
It would be left to Microsoft's leaders to decide which of the new businesses would carry the name Microsoft and retain the key executives. And other details, including how to divide Microsoft's $17.8 billion cash reserve, would be decided later.
People close to the talks said the investment firm Greenhill & Company, which the Justice Department retained in December to study the financial impact of proposals to resolve the case, had not yet put a value on the separate businesses that would result from the breakup plan.
While the government position could change in modest ways over the next few days, officials said this fundamental plan was unlikely to be altered. Neither Microsoft nor the government shows any indication that it might try to settle the case before the remedy phase. Microsoft remains supremely confident that it will prevail on appeal.
After the plaintiffs submit their proposals, Microsoft will have until May 10 to respond. Judge Jackson has scheduled a hearing for May 24.
The Justice Department has been studying various remedy ideas for more than a year and had wanted to offer a structural remedy of this sort during the settlement talks that began in November and ended early this month. But Microsoft refused even to discuss the idea.
With the talks over, the Justice Department moved quickly back to discussions of structural remedies, and one official said Attorney General Janet Reno had approved the current approach.
Justice Department officials first shared their proposal with some of the state attorneys general who are partners in the suit on Thursday and Friday and asked them for help and concurrence. Both state and federal officials said the federal plan was modified in some ways as a result of discussions with the states.
A senior state official said the Justice Department "has been receptive and respectful of our point of view." But one knowledgeable official also said that while the government intends to enlist as many of the states as it can in its plan, it will file it with Judge Jackson by Friday regardless. Judge Jackson has said he would prefer a single remedy proposal from the plaintiffs but would be willing to accept two.
Until last week, the states had been promoting less severe remedies, even though many of them personally preferred the idea of breaking up Microsoft, several officials said. Concerned about their prospects on appeal, and about public opinion, among other issues, the states had been planning to ask only for conduct remedies.
Over the last several days, however, opinions began to change. Conduct remedies require strong enforcement mechanisms to remain effective, and the states were having trouble finding mechanisms they were certain could work. "The more we considered the conduct remedies," a state official said, "the more we saw that they would necessitate constant oversight and intrusion on Microsoft, and nobody was comfortable with that."
And then, last Wednesday, The Washington Post published an interview with Steven A. Ballmer, Microsoft's chief executive, in which he said the company had done nothing wrong and saw no reason to alter its business practices.
Some of the attorneys general, working that very day on enforcement mechanisms, "saw this as a real slap in the face," one official said. With that sort of attitude, he added, "'we knew enforcement would be ongoing and difficult."

HEADLINE: Insurgents Win Control of CUNY's Faculty and Staff Union

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
A group of insurgents calling themselves the New Caucus won control of the faculty and staff union at the City University of New York yesterday, and their leader pledged to push for more money for the university and for the union members.
The New Caucus won 14 of the 20 elective slots on the executive council, including the presidency, and may have won as many as 17, said Frank R. Annunziato, executive director of the union, the Professional Staff Congress. He said that the votes on three slots were very close and that some ballots had not yet been counted because of eligibility questions. 
 The union's newly elected president, Barbara Bowen, said she planned to press for more public investment in the university as well as for a better contract for union members. "For the first time, we will see what an active academic union can do in the huge battle over CUNY," she said in an interview.
"It's about rebuilding the City University," she added. "It's about stopping the erosion of professionals at the university. It's about bringing democracy and activism to the labor movement."
Of the nearly 10,000 active and retired professors and professional staff workers eligible to vote, about 6,000 returned their ballots, which were counted yesterday by the American Arbitration Association.
Dr. Bowen, who teaches at Queens College, is a former union organizer who went on to earn a doctorate in 17th-century English literature. She beat Richard J. Boris, a professor of political science at York University, who assumed the presidency in late January, when Irwin Polishook, president since 1976, retired.
"Our members voted for change," Dr. Boris said yesterday evening, adding that he wished the new leadership well.
Dr. Bowen, 44, said she helped found the New Caucus five years ago because she wanted a more aggressive union.
Her union experience began right after college, when she was a full-time organizer for apple pickers and tobacco growers in western Massachusetts. Even after she enrolled as a graduate student at Yale University, she remained active in union work, helping to organize the university's clerical and technical workers.
One quick test of the new leadership will be renegotiating the union contract, which expires on July 31. Dr. Bowen said CUNY professors have lower salaries and heavier workloads than professors at universities like the State University of New York and Rutgers. Without being specific, she said she planned "to engage the whole power of the membership to get a fair contract."

HEADLINE: In Search of Foreign Policy Respect, Bush Crosses Bridge Into Mexico

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY 

DATELINE: NUEVO LAREDO, Mexico, April 24

 BODY:
Eager to assure voters that he is not a foreign policy novice, Gov. George W. Bush went campaigning in Mexico today. Foreign soil may be an unusual place to win votes, but Mr. Bush seemed more in search of respect.
It was a short trip, about 400 yards across the Rio Grande into the Mexican scrub desert just west of this border city, and Mr. Bush did not stay long, about two hours. 
 In that time he dedicated the eight-lane, $128 million World Trade Bridge and shared a stage, and compliments, with President Ernesto Zedillo of Mexico.
"In the past there have been walls of divide between Mexico and the United States," Mr. Bush said to a crowd of a few thousand people, mostly Mexicans. "We must, we must be committed to raise the bridges of trade and friendship and freedom."
For Mr. Bush, the international stage, even one within eyesight of Texas, offered a chance to burnish his foreign policy credentials after some stumbles in the Republican primaries.
Mr. Bush, who has trumpeted his experience in working with Mexico, said the opening of the bridge was an example of the growing economic ties between the United States and Mexico.
Today, at a ceremony after a ribbon cutting on the bridge, Mr. Zedillo credited Mr. Bush with understanding Mexican culture and working as Texas governor to improve Mexican-American relations. "He's a great friend of Mexico," Mr. Zedillo said.
The growing closeness between officials in Mexico and Texas was largely attributable to the North American Free Trade Agreement, which has made Los Dos Laredos -- as the border cities of Laredo and Nuevo Laredo call themselves -- a choke point for 1.3 million truck crossings last year.
The World Trade Bridge is the fourth international bridge in the Laredo area.
In promising to push aggressively for free trade in this hemisphere, Mr. Bush, who has assiduously courted Hispanic voters, said he would tear down trade barriers from Alaska to "the tip of the Cape Horn."
In arranging this international photo opportunity, Mr. Bush nearly got mired in some tricky local politics. The bridge actually opened on April 15, in a ceremony whose host was Mayor Betty Flores of Laredo, a Democrat and friend of President Clinton.
Citing a scheduling conflict, Mr. Bush declined to attend that gathering, as did Mr. Zedillo after originally indicating that he would. Ms. Flores had said she was "disappointed."
How disappointed was she? The Bush campaign learned last week when the mayor initially declined to allow the governor's motorcade to cross the new bridge for the ceremony in Mexico. Ms. Flores said the international permit for the bridge specifically allowed commercial traffic only except for emergencies.
She suggested the governor's entourage use one of the other bridges or simply walk across. Or, she said, maybe he could just drive a truck.
"He could ride in a big rig," she said in a telephone interview on Friday. "Think about it. The Teamsters will love it."
But a weekend of telephone calls, including calls from Texas officials to the State Department, broke the impasse, and on Monday, the governor's car drove across the bridge.
Ms. Flores, who said she had not initially been invited to speak, did so, and made certain to thank the politician that Mr. Bush hopes to replace, President Clinton.

Malaria's Cost to Economies
A study by Harvard University and the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine found that malaria had hurt African economies more than was realized. Analyzing the effects of malaria on 27 African economies from 1965 to 1990, the study found that the disease cut 1 percentage point each year from the annual growth rates of those economies. If malaria were eliminated in 1965, the report said, Africa's annual gross domestic product would be $400 billion now, rather than $300 billion. A10

HEADLINE: Energy Secretary Asserts Blackout Threat Is Rising

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: NEWARK, April 24

 BODY:
Raising the specter of widespread blackouts, the United States secretary of energy said today that the nation's electric system might fare worse this summer than it did in 1999 because of a rocky transition to deregulation when demand for power is booming.
In meetings with government officials, corporate executives and customer advocates here and in Hartford, the secretary, Bill Richardson, called for new steps at the state and federal levels to line up customers who would be willing to be unplugged on the hottest summer days in exchange for appropriate payment, and for identifying the backup generators that some hospitals, factories and big companies maintain for emergencies and using them on days when the demand for electricity peaks. 
 "We're worried as a nation, despite a hugely booming economy, about problems in our electricity grid," Mr. Richardson said at a forum at the New Jersey Institute of Technology this afternoon. Mr. Richardson had a similar appearance in Hartford this morning and had scheduled one in New Orleans this evening. He plans to hold another, in Sacramento, on Friday.
Taking note of blackouts last summer, he said: "Fortunately, we were able to avoid a widespread systems failure, this time. But we may not be so fortunate in the future.
"Things may get worse before they get better. That's especially alarming in light of the National Weather Service prediction of a long hot summer in 2000."
But representatives of the region's electricity suppliers -- Consolidated Edison, Public Service Enterprise Group Inc. (the parent of Public Service Electric and Gas) and General Public Utilities -- all said that they had made extensive investments since last summer and would be ready for hot weather this year.
And in Hartford, Dean Pagani, a spokesman for Gov. John G. Rowland, said that state officials expected Connecticut's largest power generator, the Millstone 3 nuclear plant, to be in service this summer; last year, it was sidelined because of management problems.
But Mr. Rowland, who was the co-host of the session in Hartford with Mr. Richardson, said the public should be aware that conservation would be required on peak demand days. And in Newark, E. James Ferland, the chairman, president and chief executive of P.S.E.&G., said that New Jersey could face shortages "if there are problems in the Midwest and we are required to help."
Not everyone agreed with Mr. Richardson's short-term steps. "Turning on old dirty diesel generators that are the standby backup generators is going to be an environmental disaster," said Nathaniel Greene, an electricity expert at the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group, who was one of 19 panelists at the 90-minute session here.
The experts suggested a variety of reasons that the difference between electric supplies and peak demand had become uncomfortably small. One is that New England, New York and the Middle Atlantic states are all in various stages of deregulation.
Under the old system, the monopoly utilities generated power, transmitted it over their own lines and sold it to their own customers, but now some utilities have gotten out of the generating business while dozens of other companies have gotten into it. Under the deregulated system, electricity is bought and sold wholesale, hour by hour or minute by minute.
One difficulty, according to several participants, is that the new system has not provided proper incentives to companies to build new transmission lines.
Scott Weiner, a former head of the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection and Energy and now a senior vice president of Sithe Northeast, an independent power producer, said that the deregulated system was not "sending price signals that allow for the construction of new capacity and shoring up transmission systems."
Although New England runs low on spare capacity on peak days, he said, some companies are taking generators out of that region and shipping them elsewhere in the country to make larger profits.
The session was moderated by Kurt Yeager, the president and chief executive of the Electric Power Research Institute, a nonprofit organization in Palo Alto, Calif., that has complained recently that deregulation has cut investment in research and development. In a recent report, the institute said that the electric system was in the worst condition it had been since the great northeast blackout of 1965.
The Northeast, however, has advantages over other parts of the country. The six-state New England region is centrally controlled, allowing better coordination of supply and demand; New York State's grid is also highly integrated, as is a region called PJM, covering most of Pennsylvania, all New Jersey, Delaware and the District of Columbia, most of Maryland and part of Virginia.
The integration, according to experts, helps induce independent generators to build, providing new supplies and enhancing competition to lower prices. One task for the federal government is to encourage electric companies elsewhere in the country, notably in the South and Midwest, to tie themselves together.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Agency Revenue Was Up Last Year

BYLINE: By David Barboza 

 BODY:
Revenue and billings for agencies increased by double-digit percentages last year from 1998, according to the 56th annual Agency Report by the trade publication Advertising Age. The rise was fueled by spending for dot-com campaigns, the strong American economy and robust merger and acquisition activity.
Revenue increased 21.7 percent, to $31.2 billion, from $25.6 billion in 1998, Advertising Age reported, as billings rose 19 percent, to $235.5 billion, from $198 billion. The Omnicom Group in New York remained the world's largest agency in revenue in 1999, at $5.7 billion, up 13.5 percent from 1998, followed by the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York, at $5.1 billion, up 14.6 percent, and the WPP Group in London, at $4.8 billion, up 16.2 percent. 
 Ranked by billings, Interpublic remained first, at $47.2 billion, followed by Omnicom, at $45.6 billion, and WPP, at $37.1 billion.

HEADLINE: The Census and the Question About Race

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In "The Census' Race Problem" (Op-Ed, April 19), Dawn Stover writes that the idea of race lacks scientific legitimacy. She concludes that Americans should list themselves as "human race" in the 2000 census.
Historians refer to the social construction of race. But this does not mean that race lacks historical importance. Blacks seeking a mortgage, encountering the police or hailing a taxi cannot simply declare themselves members of the human race and expect to be treated accordingly. Racial categories, while unscientific, have been used to distribute economic resources and political power in an unequal manner. 
 If the census stopped asking about race, we could not compare black and white unemployment, life expectancy or family wealth. Racial statistics remain essential to reveal how far we have progressed from our racialized past, and how far we still need to travel.
 
ERIC FONER
New York, April 19, 2000
 
The writer is a professor of history at Columbia University.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE INSIDER;
A Gore Adviser Who Basks in the Shadows

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
There is only one member of Vice President Gore's staff close enough to call him Al.
It is Leon Sigmund Fuerth, Mr. Gore's longest-serving aide, who has acted as his elder adviser on national security matters for two decades. The two men know each other so well that, like an old married couple, they can communicate through a grimace or a glance. 
 The relationship goes back to 1980, when Mr. Fuerth, a staff member on Capitol Hill, tutored the young congressman from Tennessee nine years his junior several hours a week for more than a year on the arcana of arms control. Since then Mr. Fuerth has exercised an important influence on Mr. Gore, whose world view blends a belief in a strong defense, the elevation of issues like illness and the environment to the top of the national security agenda and a moralistic impulse to punish dictators. Mr. Fuerth has often stiffened his boss's spine, from pressing early on to use strikes to constrain Serbian forces from ethnic cleansing in Bosnia and Kosovo to taking an uncompromising line against Iraq, Iran and North Korea, which Mr. Fuerth has referred to privately as "giant zits on various parts of the body."
Yet for all his influence, including membership in the cabinet-level Principals' Committee that advises the president on foreign policy, the onetime foreign service officer labors largely in the shadows. He rarely gives speeches or interviews. He has written no great tomes. He likes to work alone. At one point he announced at a news briefing that his goal was to remain "nameless, faceless and odorless"; at another he told aides that his ideas "belong to the vice president."
Mr. Gore praises that approach as positively quaint and has hinted that he may name Mr. Fuerth as national security adviser in a Gore administration.
"He has a keen intellect, a strong character, absolute integrity and excellent instincts," Mr. Gore said in a telephone interview. "There is a certain quaintness to his insistence on taking as little credit for anything he can possibly push off to others, quaintness in the sense not that it is odd. In fact, I wish it were more common. In today's world that quality is all too rare."
Asked about Time magazine's prediction last year that Mr. Fuerth was "a cinch" to be national security adviser in a Gore administration, Mr. Gore at first stuck to his rule not to discuss potential advisers. But then he added, "If I were to break that rule for anybody, it would be for Leon."
Certainly quaintness is not a word that springs to mind in describing former national security advisers Henry A. Kissinger or Zbigniew Brzezinski. And when asked what Mr. Fuerth would be like in the job he once held, Mr. Kissinger replied, "I'm afraid I don't know the man."
Advisers to Gov. George W. Bush of Texas have already begun to criticize the vice president and his top national security aide by criticizing the performance of the Clinton administration. "A hallmark of the Clinton-Gore foreign policy has been ad hockery and case-by-case actions lacking in strategy," said Robert Zoellick, an under secretary of state in the Bush administration. So despite Mr. Fuerth's passion for anonymity, he inevitably will be drawn into the spotlight in a presidential campaign in which Mr. Gore is increasingly contrasting his foreign policy experience with that of Mr. Bush.
And that could be uncomfortable for the 61-year-old Mr. Fuerth, who has spent his entire career inside government and has never had to develop an ear for politics. By contrast, Samuel R. Berger, President Clinton's national security adviser, who is known as Sandy, knows how to shape foreign policy to fit politics. "Sandy came to the job as a political pro and had to master the foreign policy part of it," said Leslie Gelb, the president of the Council on Foreign Relations who has known both Mr. Berger and Mr. Fuerth for years. "Leon came to the White House as a foreign policy expert and he now has to master the politics."
Early in their relationship, Mr. Gore created a division of labor that both insist suits them fine. He told Mr. Fuerth to provide advice on what was good for the country and "leave the politics to me."
(On Super Tuesday, when it became clear that Mr. Gore would secure the Democratic nomination, Mr. Fuerth was not in Nashville celebrating and didn't want to intrude by calling; he sent a note of congratulations instead.)
But that division means that Mr. Fuerth can sometimes be out of the political loop. In an interview on March 30, for example, Mr. Fuerth was asked how his boss would resolve the case of the 6-year-old Cuban boy, Elian Gonzalez. "The administration's position and the vice president's position consistently are to navigate where the boy's best interests are," Mr. Fuerth said. "And in our system, the courts are the best place to get this task done."
At almost the same time, Mr. Gore was proposing a legislative solution that could have allowed the boy to remain in the United States. By Mr. Fuerth's own admission, he was unaware that Mr. Gore had decided to change course that day.
And there can be a downside to avoiding politics. It was Mr. Fuerth who told Mr. Gore that the much criticized fund-raising luncheon at a Buddhist temple in 1996 posed no problem from a foreign policy standpoint, instead of looking at it from a larger legal and ethical perspective. (The National Security Council, by contrast, warned that Mr. Gore should proceed with "great, great caution.")
While Mr. Gore at times has devised idealistic solutions for global problems, Mr. Fuerth tends to takes a darker view that stems from a deeply rooted belief that the world is a dangerous place. As a young man, Mr. Fuerth said he was so terrified by the 1960 classic "On Thermonuclear War" by Herman Kahn that he was reluctant to start a family.
Mr. Fuerth's vacuum-cleaner mind and his tenacity when he is convinced he is right can make him a formidable opponent in the decision-making process. "Contrarian" is a word often used to describe him.
One "contrarian" episode came in the fall of 1995, when he opposed a proposal by Richard C. Holbrooke, the chief negotiator on Bosnia and now the American ambassador to the United Nations, to suspend most economic sanctions against Serbia on the eve of peace talks in Dayton. Mr. Fuerth arrived at a crucial White House meeting armed with fold-out charts illustrating various sanctions and why none of them should be lifted without a reciprocal action by President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia. The sanctions stayed in place. "A very creative and idiosyncratic intellect," is how Mr. Holbrooke describes Mr. Fuerth.
Still, his hard line has not always prevailed. He fiercely opposed -- unsuccessfully -- Mr. Clinton's decision in 1998 to waive sanctions against three foreign companies that were big investors in Iran's energy sector, arguing that preventing investment in Iran was more important than offending the European Union.
Over the years, Mr. Fuerth has often given his boss the ammunition to take tougher, and counterintuitive, stands on national security. During Mr. Gore's unsuccessful bid for the Democratic nomination for president in 1988, Mr. Fuerth helped him formulate an uncritical pro-Israeli line. Mr. Gore even criticized the Reagan administration for trying to push Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel to go along with a peace initiative that called on Israel to withdraw from land it occupied in 1967 in exchange for peace with its Arab neighbors. After Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990, Mr. Fuerth provided Mr. Gore, then a senator, with a three-inch-thick binder explaining why he should break with other Senate Democrats and vote in favor of going to war. (He did.) In 1991, Mr. Fuerth helped draft a speech in Senator Gore's name in which he advocated the removal of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and the ruling Baath party leadership and the compilation of a war crimes file against them.
Early in the administration, Mr. Fuerth used his perch as head of an interagency process to institute sanctions against Haiti, Serbia and Iraq. He has persuaded the administration to embrace a complicated, controversial and expensive plan to transport Caspian Sea oil and gas through a route that will avoid Russia and Iran.
As manager of the binational commissions that Mr. Gore created with Russia, South Africa, Egypt, Kazakhstan and Ukraine, Mr. Fuerth has tackled unconventional issues that sometimes slip through the cracks. But both he and the vice president have been criticized for being slow to accept mounting evidence from the intelligence community of the level of Russian corruption.
Mr. Fuerth can sound downright eloquent when discussing issues about which both he and the vice president feel passionately, like the AIDS epidemic in sub-Sahara Africa. "If you get something which can burn out the heart of a generation, what is the difference if they're dying of disease or war?" he said. "They're dying! And people will not flourish, people will not live out their lives or make their full contributions. Societies will be destabilized. A generation of orphans will be created. So if you need an analogy to warfare, it's the consequences of war without the explosion."
Yet at other times, Mr. Fuerth's innate caution can make him difficult to decipher. When asked at a recent press breakfast what Mr. Gore would like to change about defense strategy, Mr. Fuerth replied: "I think his view is that the two major contingency strategies have served us very well, and it is possible to see exactly where the vice president has been in the Cabinet Room with the president and the others at moments when we have had to ask ourselves whether if we move a carrier from one place to the next, we are opening ourselves up to adventure by one opponent or the next."
Mr. Gore, nevertheless, relies on Mr. Fuerth for both data and analysis, which he often delivers in a constant stream of hand-written, humor-laced, policy-filled billets-doux during meetings, meals and even receiving lines. The note-passing became so disruptive during the president's cabinet meetings that protocol was abandoned and Mr. Fuerth was given a permanent seat at the vice president's immediate right.
Before every bilateral meeting with foreign officials, Mr. Gore gets the benefit of Mr. Fuerth's deeply detailed knowledge of policy, detailed in thick briefing books and then distilled on a stack of four- by six-inch cards.
Some years ago, when an aide urged Mr. Gore to dispense with the cards, suggesting he did not really need them, the vice president was said to reply that he did not want to hurt Mr. Fuerth's feelings. Mr. Gore now says that if he ever said such a thing, it was in jest and that in fact, he does need the cards.
Unlike Mr. Gore, Mr. Fuerth did not grow up privileged. His father, who drove an ice cream truck, died when Leon, an only child, was 8; his widowed mother went to work in a dry cleaning shop.
After majoring in English at New York University, Mr. Fuerth entered the ir Force as a second lieutenant. Back at the university, he began a doctorate in Russian history, but joined the foreign service when his wife, Lynn, had their first of two sets of twin girls and he needed a job.
Eleven years later, he went to work for the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence. When Mr. Gore moved to the Senate, he took Mr. Fuerth with him.
Mr. Gore describes Mr. Fuerth as a cross between "a rabbi and a stand-up comic." But many outsiders don't see his lighter side. His gruffness earned him the nickname Metternich on the Hill years ago and Darth Vader more recently in the corridors of the State Department.
Some people insist that too much work and too little staff account for his irritability; others say it stems from deep shyness. Said Toby T. Gati, who came to respect Mr. Fuerth when she was the National Security Council's Russia expert: "He's not a mother figure. He's not a father figure. He's a patriarch."
Part of Mr. Fuerth's image problem is his body language. He has a habit of casting his glance downward, staring at his tightly folded hands. The posture is so much a part of his persona that Mr. Gore parodied it at a party to celebrate Mr. Fuerth's 60th birthday a year ago.
After Mr. Fuerth suffered a mild heart attack in March 1999, he changed his lifestyle sharply, shedding 45 pounds and embracing a tough exercise regime. At his 60th birthday party a few weeks later, Mr. Gore had this advice for him: "We all want to say, 'Relax!' "
Indeed, he is trying to do that, even reaching out more to a class of people with whom he never felt comfortable: the Washington press corps.
Certainly Mr. Fuerth has come a long way from the briefing during Mr. Gore's 1997 China trip in which he inadvertently referred to the press corps as "clutter." "I have been adjusting my approach," Mr. Fuerth said, in an effort to "break down the wall I had put up."
Some of Mr. Fuerth's colleagues speculate that he may be better suited in the job of, say, director of central intelligence or secretary of defense than of national security adviser, which has typically required extensive public diplomacy and the ability to compromise.
But Mr. Fuerth has something that no other national security expert does: an intimate relationship with Mr. Gore. And Mr. Gore may just want to keep the man he calls "a great friend" close to his side, doing what he has always done -- keeping him informed, passing him notes, feeding him ideas, making him laugh and always, always giving him the credit.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
White House Foursome Swaps Familiar Roles

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

 BODY:
Bill Clinton may be president, and Al Gore may be vice president, but, as Tony Bennett put it, "the best is yet to come."
The song seemed tailor-made for a Democratic fund-raising gala last night in Midtown Manhattan where political ambition was unbound, both for Mr. Gore, who wants to be president, and for Hillary Rodham Clinton, who aspires to move on from the first ladyship to the Senate. 
 The Clintons and the Gores revived their 1992 bus-touring foursome for the evening, bringing in $2.2 million for the Democratic National Committee.
Tipper Gore introduced Hillary, Hillary introduced Bill and Bill introduced Al, just like old times, except this time Al was on top. He was presented as the ranking guest of honor, he spoke last and he gave the longest speech. And Mr. Clinton praised him most extravagantly.
"I feel absolutely comfortable putting the future of my daughter and the grandchildren I hope she'll give us in his hands," the president told more than 1,000 people who paid more than $1,000 each for a dinner of filet mignon and a chance to see the Fab Four at the Sheraton Towers on Seventh Avenue at 53rd Street.
The committee set up two reception rooms at the hotel, one with Mr. Clinton and one with Mr. Gore, and guests who had given or raised $25,000 each shuttled between them before sitting down to dinner.
With the help of Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore, the party raised $26 million in the first quarter of this year toward its 2000 goal of $100 million. About two weeks ago, they raised $2.8 million from roughly 100 contributors in Hollywood.
Guests last night included Lauren Bacall, the actress; Jean Kennedy Smith, sister of President John F. Kennedy; Arthur Schlesinger Jr., the Kennedy historian; Sam Waterston, the actor; Harvey Weinstein, co-chairman of the Miramax unit of the Walt Disney Company; Larry Rockefeller, a Republican and New York environmental lawyer; and Martha Stewart, the doyenne of home and hearth.
They were joined by several New York politicians, including Carl McCall, the state controller; Representative Anthony Weiner of Brooklyn; and Eliot L. Spitzer, the state attorney general.
The Clintons and Gores dispersed themselves at different tables throughout the vast ballroom but spent much of the night circulating and schmoozing. Seated with Mrs. Clinton was Bernard Schwartz, the chairman of the Loral Space and Communications Corporation, a major Democratic donor and friend of the Clintons. Loral is the subject of a Justice Department investigation into the export of satellite technology to China.
If there was any question that the Gores were separating from the Clintons, they all did their best to erase that impression as they passed around the compliments, waxed nostalgic about their eight-year public relationship, and Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore embraced in a big bear hug.
Mrs. Gore called Mr. Clinton one of the party's "greatest presidents ever." She said Mrs. Clinton "embodies all the best values of the Democratic Party" and "knows how to achieve results."
Mrs. Clinton, who delivered a campaign-like stump speech, said the nation's current economic success would not be possible "if this administration had not kept faith with you."
She said she and her husband were feeling nostalgic because they had just held their last Easter-egg roll at the White House. She raised a few eyebrows when she added that they had been "thinking about everything that has happened since 1992," but Mr. Clinton raised more when he made a glancing reference to his impeachment.
Mr. Clinton said that some previous presidents had complained about how hard the job was but that they had nothing on him. "Most of those guys haven't had as tough a time as I have," he said. "I don't know what the heck they're talking about." He and Mrs. Clinton laughed.
Mr. Clinton praised his wife, saying she would be "a worthy successor to Robert Kennedy and Pat Moynihan." And of her speech delivery, he said approvingly, "I think she's getting the hang of it, don't you?"
But the president saved his most extravagant praise for Mr. Gore. He said he wished he had "half the experience coming into office" as Mr. Gore has and "he has performed in an absolutely stunning manner."
And in a voice and words suffused with unusual intimacy, Mr. Clinton said he could vouch for the vice president. "I probably know more about him than anybody but Tipper," the president said. "I know what he likes and what he can't stand. I know what he loves, I know when he's having a bad day and how he deals with it. And by the way, he knows the same about me."
Mr. Gore said that Mr. Clinton's comments were "by far the most generous introduction I've ever had." He praised Mr. Clinton for demonstrating "the capacity to bring us all together" and said "his legacy will endure."
And as he repeated much of his campaign stump speech, he warned: "Everything flowing from the vision of Bill Clinton is instantly at risk if the other party is put in charge of economic policy."
The event caused considerable traffic gridlock across New York. The president and Mrs. Clinton arrived together from Washington on Air Force One but then left in separate motorcades. Mr. Gore arrived later on Air Force Two, and Mrs. Gore arrived separately. The foursome presented a such a heightened need for security that the director of the Secret Service traveled with the Clintons on Air Force One.
