HEADLINE: Rent Proposals Raise Specter Of Big Increases

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
The agency that decides rent increases for the one million rent-stabilized apartments in New York City is considering major changes in its formulas that could theoretically raise rents 8.5 percent for a one-year lease and 12 percent for a two-year lease. Rent increases that size have not been seen since the era of double-digit inflation two decades ago.
But the head of the agency, the Rent Guidelines Board, said that the final figures this year were unlikely to be that high. 
 Another option being explored, for example, could raise rents 6 percent for a one-year lease and 10 percent for a two-year lease. Even that would far exceed the levels authorized in the last three years, which were 2 percent for a one-year lease and 4 percent for a two-year lease.
"Don't get hung up on the numbers," the board's chairman, Edward S. Hochman, said in an interview. "The odds of it being either of those two sets of numbers, 8.5 and 12 or 6 and 10, are quite limited. There will be variations."
The board now imposes rent increases based partly on an index of landlords' operating costs compiled by the board. One of the proposed changes in the formula would expand the index to include the effect inflation has on the landlords' operating income. Another would take into account how their operating income is affected by tenants who renew with two-year leases. A third change would exclude from the calculations the additional income that landlords collect in accordance with a 1997 state law entitling them to charge up to 20 percent more to the next tenant after a vacancy.
In an annual rite of spring for New Yorkers, representatives of landlords and tenants clash over the rent increases in debates at the board's public hearings, with cheering and jeering audiences. One side or the other -- if not both -- can be counted on to complain about being shortchanged.
But the debate is likely to intensify this time, with both the rent increases and the complex method of calculating them being discussed.
The proposals, which Mr. Hochman outlined in a memorandum to the board, will be made public at a board meeting today. No immediate decision is expected, however. The board's preliminary vote on the maximum rent increases is scheduled for May 8, with a final vote on June 22. The new rates will go into effect on Oct. 1.
Spokesmen for the landlords said that the board's methods were long overdue for revision. "There were some old rules of thumb that were really inappropriate," said Jack Freund, the executive vice president and chief economist for the city's largest residential landlord group, the Rent Stabilization Association. "They just didn't take into account things like two-year leases and inflation. The board's price index doesn't measure everything, like the fact that buildings are getting older and need more maintenance."
The proposals, however, drew a howl of protest from tenant leaders. "Outrageous," said Michael McKee, a co-director of New York State Tenants and Neighbors, an advocacy group. Landlords are already benefiting from excessive rent increases that are yielding record income, he said. At a time of low inflation, "there is certainly no need for any rent increase," he said, much less a need for a big one. Mr. McKee speculated that the giant increases being threatened would be scaled back to make Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani "look like a hero in an election year."
Mr. Giuliani, who appoints the rent board members and its chairman, is running for the United States Senate.
Mr. Hochman denied any political motives, saying, "The numbers are the numbers."
Mr. Hochman said he wanted the board to end its practice of debating which of three different formulas to follow, "two of which were pretty lousy, pretty inaccurate." Instead, he said, "I want to have the best formula and then fine-tune that."
Mr. McKee called the proposals "a grotesque change in methodology." He said that "all the methods are flawed and are set up to justify a rent increase, whether it's really needed or not."
Tenant leaders are also worried that as rents rise, more apartments will reach a $2,000-a-month rental threshold that can lead to deregulation of those apartments.
Besides reviewing the formula itself, the rent board is dealing with actual increases in income and costs. The board's annual price index of operating costs to be released today shows a hefty 7.8 percent increase.
Mr. Hochman blamed taxes, which he said rose 5 percent, and fuel oil for heat and hot water, which jumped 54 percent. "This created havoc," he said. Another element, yet to be factored in, is the recent contract settlement for the building workers' union.
"We have to produce rough justice," Mr. Hochman said. "We have to protect tenants against aberrational increases and still make the owners whole. It's a balancing of the equities."
From the owners' point of view, Mr. Freund said: "Rent increases are going to have to be significantly higher than they have been in the last three years. We had a low inflationary environment, and that has changed. Costs have gone up, and they have to be passed along. Someone has to pay for it. A lot of people are doing quite well out there. Remember, the median rental stabilized apartment is $650, so when we're talking about a percentage increase, even if it's high, you're not looking at big dollars. Not a lot of people will get excited by that."
But Mr. McKee said that basing permanent rent increases on temporary spikes in fuel oil prices was illogical and unfair and had proven costly to tenants. "The last time this happened was in 1996," he said. "Fuel prices started dropping almost as soon as the decision was made for 5 and 7 percent rent increases, and prices dropped to lower than they were before, but the rents were locked in forever."
A rent board study released two weeks ago showed that in 1998, the latest year for which figures are available, landlords recorded the highest net operating income and lowest cost increases of any year since the city began tracking those numbers nine years ago.
But Mr. Freund said: "Don't forget that owners took a real hit in the late 70's and early 80's. Only now are they getting back to where things were before."

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
Aiding an Indian Village With an Electric Chair

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
When a poor Indian village in the state of Kerala learns of a wonderful American product that will make life better and put the village on the international map, what could that item possibly be? A modern sanitation system? A medical clinic? A supercomputer? Think again.
What the people naively believe will bring them glory and elevate one of them into a national hero is an electric chair, or "electronic chair" as it's called in Murali Nair's dryly devastating movie, "Throne of Death." One of its benefits, an ambitious local politician promises, will be to enable all those seeking painless final exits from life to leave peacefully whenever they choose. Thanks to the generosity of the United States and the World Bank, he announces, it won't be long before every Indian village has its own electronic "throne of death." 
 The movie, which opens today at the Film Forum on a double bill with a touching Senegalese film, "The Little Girl Who Sold the Sun," is all the more scathing for keeping its tongue firmly in its cheek. Instead of being directed as a comedy, this satire of political corruption and public credulousness poses a work of lyric realism. As the camera moves in for dreamy close-ups of the faces of Krishnan (Vishwas Njarakkal), the "lucky" villager who will be the first to mount the throne, his wife (Lakshmi Raman) and their young son (Jeevan Mitva), they radiate the spiritual glow of downtrodden innocents in a Satyajit Ray film.
Gaunt and white-haired, Krishnan struggles to eke out the meagerest of livings as a laborer. His family is so poor that when he buys his son a rubber ball, it is a dangerous extravagance. Eventually facing starvation, Krishnan is reduced to stealing coconuts from his employer's property and is arrested. While in jail, he is indicted for an unsolved political murder (although no evidence exists connecting him with the crime) and sentenced to die. Krishnan meekly accepts his fate. What becomes a major issue in a local election isn't the injustice of his sentence or the corrupt legal system but the manner of Krishan's imminent execution. The villagers organize vigorous demonstrations supporting the more humane electrocution instead of hanging.
The movie suggests that the ceremonial pomp surrounding capital punishment in India is as grotesque as it is in the United States. As Krishnan is served an elaborate final dinner, you wonder if it's the only decent meal he's ever eaten. "Throne of Death" may be the first film to present a wrongful execution as a "happy" ending.
Djibril Diop Mambety's fable "The Little Girl Who Sold the Sun" also finds sunshine amid abject misery. The final film by Mr. Mambety, who died in 1998, this portrait of an indomitably spirited beggar girl wobbling on her crutches through the streets of Dakar is described in the end credits as a prayer for the world's street children.
What could have been a soggy mess is redeemed by Lissa Balera's tough but luminous portrayal of the little girl, Sili. Hitching a ride to Dakar from the city's rural outskirts, where she lives with her blind grandmother, she takes a job hawking newspapers on the streets. The only girl in a swarm of ragged, predatory boys who threaten her at every turn, Sili exhibits an extraordinary self-possession. After a miraculous windfall, she is accosted by a suspicious policeman who wonders how she came by such a large sum. Instead of running away, she leads the officer to the police station and pleads her case with his superior, demanding an apology. It is only one of several personal triumphs.
 
Both "Throne of Death" and "The Little Girl Who Sold the Sun" wonder how it is possible for the human spirit to transcend abject poverty and injustice, and both come up with the same answer. It has to do with a mysterious thing called faith.
 
THRONE OF DEATH
Directed by Murali Nair; written (in Malayam, with English subtitles) by Bharathan Njarakkal, based on a story by Mr. Nair; director of photography, M. J. Radhakrishnan; edited by Lalitha Krishna; music by Madhu Apsara; art director, Saji Varkala; produced by Preeya Nair; released by Flying Elephant Films. Running time: 57 minutes. This film is not rated. Shown with "The Little Girl Who Sold the Sun" at the Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, South Village.
 
WITH: Vishwas Njarakkal (Krishnan), Lakshmi Raman (His Wife), Jeevan Mitva (His Son) and Suhas Thayat (Politician).
 
THE LITTLE GIRL WHO SOLD THE SUN
Written and directed by Djibril Diop Mambety; in Wolof, with English subtitles. Director of photography, Jacques Besse; edited by Sarah Taouss Matton; music by Wasis Diop; released by California Newsreel. Running time: 45 minutes. This film is not rated. Shown with "Throne of Death" at the Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, South Village.
 
WITH: Lissa Balera (Sili), Tayerou M'Baye (Babou), Oumou Samb (Crazy Woman), Moussa Balde (Boy in Wheelchair), Dieynaba Laam (Grandmother) and Martin N'Gom (Gang Leader).

HEADLINE: Jean Head Sisco, 74, Management Consultant

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Jean Head Sisco, a Washington-based executive and consultant and an energetic advocate of putting women on corporate boards, died on Thursday at her home in Chevy Chase, Md. She was 74.
The cause was a brain tumor, her management consulting firm, Sisco Associates, said. 
 Mrs. Sisco was named to the boards of 23 corporations during her three-decade career.
She was named Director of the Year last year by the National Association of Corporate Directors and in 1995 received the Breaking the Glass Ceiling award of the National Women's Economic Alliance Foundation.
She was a partner in Sisco Associates, which she founded in 1979. It specializes in international risk and trade analysis.
Her husband, Joseph J. Sisco, a former under secretary of state for political affairs and a former president of American University, joined the firm in 1981.
She was born in Muleshoe, Tex., and received a bachelor's degree from the University of Louisville and a master's degree in business administration from the University of Chicago. She worked for the Woodward & Lothrop retail chain for 24 years, until 1974, and rose to be its vice president for personnel and labor relations.
Besides her husband, she is survived by two daughters, Dr. Carol Bolton Sisco of Riva, Md., and Jane Murdock Sisco of Bethesda, Md.

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 4; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 163 words

HEADLINE: The Price of Health Care

 BODY:

To the Editor:
It is not evident, as one expert states in your April 21 front-page article, that home health care is cheaper than inpatient care.
The national average hospital occupancy ratio is about 65 percent. Having armies of home care workers traveling to geographically disparate locations to visit patients requires more resources than would be needed to care for the same patients, if they were concentrated at half-empty hospitals. 
 And quality of care can be more effectively assured in a hospital than in a home care setting, where health workers cannot easily be supervised.
Careful economic analysis is apt to show that the cost of home care typically exceeds that of inpatient care at half-empty hospitals. The added cost can be justified only if home care yields patient and family a commensurately higher quality of life.
 
UWE E. REINHARDT
Princeton, N.J., April 22, 2000
 
The writer is a professor of economics at Princeton University. 
http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section A; Page 21; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Who Were We in Vietnam?

BYLINE: By Walter A. McDougall; Walter A. McDougall, a Pulitzer Prize-winning historian and University of Pennsylvania professor, was an army artilleryman in Vietnam.

 BODY:
Twas in another lifetime, full of toil and blood," began Bob Dylan's "Shelter from the Storm" in 1974, when "blackness was a virtue, and the road was full of mud." The fall of South Vietnam 25 years ago seems to me a scene from another lifetime.
I had returned from Vietnam in 1970, earned a Ph.D. in history at the University of Chicago, and just received a job offer from Berkeley (the letter was dated April Fool's Day). I was as sick of the war as anyone and eager to "open up that Golden Gate." But news that the North Vietnamese had launched an invasion more akin to the blitzkrieg of Poland than to a Maoist "people's war," and had overrun my old base camp 30 miles up Thunder Road from Saigon, turned my heart to lead. 
 I could not deal with it any more than I had the death of my mother a few years earlier, so I repressed it until, in 1994, a former student invited me to lecture on Vietnam to his prep school students. Thanks to him, I dredged up and purged all my anger, disillusionment, fear and pity -- for myself and the Vietnamese -- and promptly worked up a seminar on the war that I have taught ever since.
No one disputes Vietnam's manifold effects on America. Richard Nixon presided over replacement of the draft with an all-volunteer (and increasingly mixed-gender) force and reduction of the voting age to 18. The Vietnam syndrome and the public's aversion to casualties inspired the strict Weinberger-Powell guidelines for the commitment of forces abroad. Congress attacked the so-called imperial presidency through the War Powers Act, C.I.A. hearings and the movement to impeach Richard Nixon for abuses committed in the name of national security. A loss of trust in the presidency ensued, and the media became adversarial. Yet the turmoil at home also allowed Nixon to pursue the Silent Majority and Southern strategies that paved the way for Ronald Reagan and Newt Gingrich, and our policies are still perturbed by what candidates did, or did not do, back in the 60's.
Vietnam also completed the integration of the armed forces and launched the careers of thousands of African-American officers and noncommissioned officers, as well as others who returned home to work in law enforcement, government and the professions. The Pentagon itself addressed racial tensions so well after 1975 that the military became a model for civilian institutions.
The war's primary economic effect was "guns and butter" budgets that helped to spark the inflation of the 1970's and hooked the federal government on deficit spending until the 1990's.
But the deepest long-term effect on America may stem from the rich and undeserved contributions made to American life by the Vietnamese refugees who quietly went to work restoring blighted neighborhoods, building businesses and sending their children to college.
The lessons of the war, by contrast, are still up for grabs, as demonstrated by the flow of new books. Was the military derelict in its duty when it promised, then pretended, to win the war, or did arrogant civilians order the military into battle with one hand tied and no clear goals? Was the American effort in Vietnam a sin, a blunder or a "necessary war"? Should it stand as a warning against state-building projects in strange and violent settings, like the Balkans? Or did Vietnam's school of hard knocks teach Americans to do peacemaking and state building right?
Drawing lessons from Vietnam remains a political enterprise. It is also a deeply psychological one for those who designed the war and for the baby boomers who were obliged to wage, resist or just run from it. No one wants to admit being wrong back then, and all want to believe that what happened back then proves they are right today.
Still, post-cold war historians have revealed certain facts that Americans need to digest. One is that there was nothing inevitable about Ho Chi Minh's rise to the status of icon. He spent his mysterious years in Moscow and China doing virtually nothing useful, and was little regarded in the Indochinese Communist Party. What made possible his "triumphant return" in 1941 was Vietnam's premature uprising against the French in 1940 and the decimation of its Communist leadership.
We know, too, that Ho promoted the broad-based Viet Minh movement not only to rally the masses against the Japanese and the French, but also to co-opt or eliminate rivals. To be sure, he was a puppet of no one, least of all Vietnam's old nemesis, China. But when Hanoi decided in 1959 to approve armed struggle against Ngo Dinh Diem's regime in Saigon, Ho personified the third world "national liberation movements" that Khrushchev and Mao vowed to support and Kennedy was determined to thwart.
It is easy to chastise Americans for backing the French and then replacing them as patrons of South Vietnam. But we did, and great nations are responsible for their acts. That is why the most shameful aspect of all is how the United States, having adopted the non-Communist Vietnamese, betrayed them repeatedly. The first time was in 1963 when President Kennedy's men sanctioned the overthrow of Diem because he was an authoritarian patriot who refused to play puppet. If they were intent on judging the Saigon regime by different standards than they did South Korea and Taiwan, then they should have pulled out.
Instead, the Johnson administration not only took over the war, but chose means -- search and destroy missions in the South and calibrated bombing in the North, without any effort to cut the Ho Chi Minh Trail -- that were as ineffective as they were destructive. Then Lyndon Johnson just washed his hands of the mess after Tet 1968, when he halted the bombing, begged for peace talks, gave Hanoi time to recoup from the devastating losses suffered by Viet Cong cadres and bequeathed to his successor 540,000 demoralized American troops who knew we "weren't in it to win." That was America's second betrayal of the South Vietnamese.
When Paul O'Dwyer, a New York Democratic Senate candidate, told the 1968 Democratic convention that Democratic voters had registered "an indictment" against the war, it was over so far as doves were concerned. But the people who voted for Nixon and George Wallace were not tired of fighting; they were tired of losing. What is more, Nixon and Henry Kissinger hoped to salvage America's global posture through the China Opening, and soon suspected that the Chinese wanted Americans in Southeast Asia. Beset on their northern frontier by Soviet armies and rocket divisions, the Chinese were loath to see Vietnam unite under the tough pro-Soviet regime in Hanoi. So instead of blaming the Democrats and "bugging out" in his personal interest, Nixon determined to withdraw gradually. That did him in. He was a war president held to peacetime standards of governance, and when Congress cut off aid to Saigon after the 1973 Paris Accords, it was voting for defeat, not for peace. That was America's third betrayal.
A bright student from New York taught me that. Throughout the semester he had criticized United States involvement in Vietnam until, in the penultimate class, he suddenly changed his mind. Later I asked him wryly, "Who are you?"
He asked what I meant, and I referred to his flip-flop. He blushed, then said, "Nixon was right!" About geopolitics? No, he said, about honor: maybe we shouldn't have been there, but having created South Vietnam, urged its people to fight for 10 years at the risk of exile, prison and death if they lost, and done so much damage to their country, how could Americans just desert them? He even likened it to turning our backs on the Holocaust.
Who are you? It seems Americans will be answering that question for some time to come, with that other lifetime on their minds.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Erle Cocke Jr., 78, War Hero Who Led American Legion

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Erle Cocke Jr., a decorated World War II soldier who was the national commander of the American Legion in 1950 and 1951, died on Sunday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 78.
The cause was cancer. 
 Mr. Cocke, at age 29, became the youngest person to command the American Legion, the country's largest veterans' organization.
A native of Dawson, Ga., Mr. Cocke graduated from the University of Georgia in 1942 and was commissioned a second lieutenant in the Army infantry. He worked his way through the ranks, becoming a rifle company commander, a battalion executive officer and then a battalion commander.
He was wounded three times, was captured by the Germans and escaped three times. He narrowly escaped being executed by the Waffen SS after he was captured the third time, with his unit, in 1945.
Mr. Cocke and several others had escaped but were recaptured by SS troops. They were ordered executed, and he was left for dead among a group of American soldiers shot in a German village by a firing squad.
Hours later, a villager, Lukas Walters, found him and hid him in a barn. A farmer, Karl Bart, tended his wounds until he was rescued. Mr. Cocke would spent 14 months in 27 hospitals, 11 in the United States. He underwent 17 major operations.
His former division commander, Maj. Gen. Anthony C. McAuliffe, said later that Mr. Cocke had "displayed courage of the highest degree, enthusiasm and excellent judgment."
He left the service as a major after receiving the Silver Star, the Purple Heart with three clusters, the Bronze Star and the French Croix de Guerre.
In 1999 he said: "I would have apologized the rest of my life if I had not been in World War II. I owed my government that much. That was my opportunity to contribute."
After the war, he earned a master's degree in business administration from Harvard University.
He was a farmer and railroad executive when he was elected commander of the Legion. He was outspoken in the post, urging more than once that the Soviet Union be expelled from the United Nations.
Mr. Cocke headed a Legion drive to oust Secretary of State Dean Acheson and a campaign to have all members of the Communist Party in the United States arrested and tried for treason.
He also called for an end to the nation's foreign economic aid program.
In 1951, when President Harry S. Truman relieved Gen. Douglas MacArthur of command in Korea and the Far East, Mr. Cocke came out in support of the general's proposal to use Chiang Kai-shek's troops in Taiwan to open a second front against the Chinese Communists on the mainland. Mr. Cocke also backed MacArthur's demand for the authority to bomb Chinese bases in Manchuria.
Later that day Truman canceled a meeting with Mr. Cocke. Some days later, Mr. Cocke, in a speech at a Legion convention in Florida, contended that soldiers, not "swivel-chair politicians or striped-pants diplomats" should make the United States' war decisions.
Nonetheless, Truman would later appoint Mr. Cocke to be a consultant for the Defense Department. President Dwight D. Eisenhower named Mr. Cocke an alternate representative to a session of the United Nations General Assembly. He also held a World Bank post in the Kennedy and Johnson administrations and was a friend of President Jimmy Carter.
Mr. Cocke was active in Democratic politics, was a brigadier general in the Georgia National Guard and was president of the lobbying firm Cocke & Phillips.
He is survived by his wife, Madelyn; three daughters, Elise C. Cocke, Jennifer C. Carpenter and Carolyn C. Whitsett; six grandsons; and a sister, Alice C. Cofield.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Shares of 3M Are Hammered Despite 19% Gain in Profit

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, April 25

 BODY:
Shares of Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing fell 3.7 percent today after the company said that its profit in 2000 might fall short of analysts' highest estimates.
Although 3M's first-quarter profit rose 19 percent, beating expectations, marketing expenses are expected to offset a one-time gain. 
 "Now you've got management putting a damper on expectations," said Alex Henderson, an analyst at Prudential Securities. The extra profit "everyone was counting on isn't any good."
The stock fell $3.5625, to $93.8125. It had risen 20 percent the last year.
The company said in a conference call that full-year per-share profit would rise 12 percent to 14 percent compared with earnings in 1999, when it earned $4.21 a share from continuing operations. The company is expected to earn $4.68, the average estimate of analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial. Estimates ranged from $4.60 to $4.80 a share.
In the first quarter, profit from operations increased to $455.4 million, or $1.13 a share, compared with $384 million, or 95 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue rose 7.3 percent, to $4.05 billion from $3.78 billion. Wall Street estimates were $1.08 a share.
3M had a first-quarter gain of $31.6 million, or 8 cents a share, from ending a marketing agreement with Hoechst of Germany, which made net income $487 million, or $1.21 a share.
That gain will be offset by marketing spending expected in the rest of the year, the company said.
It receives more than half its revenue outside the United States and has benefited from rebounding economies in Asia and Europe. It is also selling more industrial products in the United States.
Robert J. Burgstahler, the company's chief financial officer, said the company expected to earn $3.60 a share -- "at the very top end" -- for the rest of the year. Added to the $1.21 a share it earned in the first quarter, per-share profit in 2000 would be $4.81 at most.
"That range today reflects some of these concerns," Mr. Burgstahler said. "We have been overcoming all of those and are delivering."

HEADLINE: City Presents Labor Proposals But Union Says It Is Insulted

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Seeking to push citywide labor negotiations forward, the Giuliani administration presented its first formal contract proposals yesterday, but the union local that received the proposals, one that represents school safety officers and Housing Authority workers, called the proposals an insult.
The city's labor commissioner, James F. Hanley, who has been overseeing the city's labor negotiations, presented a package that called for no across-the-board pay increases, with all raises coming instead in the form of individualized merit pay. The city also called for the workers to pay part of their health insurance premiums; the city now covers 100 percent of those premiums. 
 The city made those proposals in talks yesterday with representatives of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which represents 18,000 city workers. On March 2, that union local became the first union of municipal workers to present its demands in this year's round of negotiations.
Nicholas Mancuso, the union's chief negotiator, denounced the city's demands. "This proposal is an insult," he said. "We are taxpayers and we are not going to be treated like beggars."
Mr. Mancuso attacked in particular the city's merit pay proposal. "We will not entertain the idea of merit pay as a condition for a new contract," he said. "Merit pay is retrogression to a political patronage system."
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has repeatedly defended his merit pay proposal, saying the best way to encourage city workers to be more productive is to give raises to those doing the best work.
In the proposals that the local presented in March, it called for across-the-board wage increases substantially higher than the inflation rate and a cash bonus to compensate workers for the three-year wage freeze that they took as part of their old contract.
The union local represents school safety officers, police officers at city-owned hospitals and more than a dozen categories of Housing Authority workers, including maintenance workers, superintendents and heating technicians. For some of those workers, their contract expired on Dec. 31, while for others, it expired on March 31. The union's workers earn from $20,000 to more than $40,000 a year.
Local 237 officials said yesterday that they would hesitate to bargain again with Mr. Hanley, the labor commissioner, unless some of Mr. Giuliani's City Hall aides were on hand.
While many union officials have praised Mr. Hanley's professionalism, they say they believe that it will be hard to make significant progress in contract negotiations unless Mr. Giuliani sends top aides to join the commissioner at the table.
In yesterday's talks, the city requested a five-year contract. Local 237 and other municipal unions are seeking a three-year contract.

HEADLINE: They Can Get It for You Resale;
Secondhand Stores Moving Into the Retail Mainstream

BYLINE: By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
Shopping secondhand stores, once the passion of an eccentric minority, is becoming a mainstream activity.
In addition to the determined scavengers who have long hunted for vintage dresses and side tables at flea markets, some consumers are now looking to the resale industry as a cheaper way to buy everything from computers to designer jeans to Sub-Zero refrigerators. 
 Heightening demand is the fact that the industry has worked hard to transform itself, with many store owners adopting sophisticated marketing techniques, building chain operations and adding stores in affluent suburbs. Determined to shed their image as dank backwaters for the down and out, stores that sell used goods have installed better lights, dressing rooms and even coffee bars.
Internet auction sites like eBay have also given new exposure and high-technology chic to the age-old practice.
As a result, sales at pawnshops, antique stores and secondhand shops have been growing nearly twice as fast as other retail. In 1997, the last year for which the Census Bureau kept comprehensive numbers, Americans spent some $12 billion on merchandise bought at these secondhand stores, about a 30 percent jump from 1992, after adjusting for inflation. Census estimates, which will not be confirmed until 2002, suggest that the industry grew 23 percent, to $17 billion, last year.
The census does not list sales by category of used merchandise, but antiques sold by auction -- that is much of high-end antique furniture or art purchases -- are excluded.
While sales of secondhand goods amounted to only a little more than 2 percent of all dollars spent on general apparel, merchandise and furnishings in this country last year, the growing demand for used goods still represents a sea change in the way Americans perceive castoffs. And the heady growth is all the more surprising because it comes at a time when consumers can afford to buy new.
"The used-product business has really evolved to a mainline retail business," said Ted Manley, president and chief operating officer of Grow Biz International Inc., which runs six chains of used-goods stores, including Once Upon a Child and Play It Again Sports.
Over the last decade, traditional retailers have trained consumers to expect to find lower prices just about everywhere for just about everything. Discounters like Target and Kmart have grown at the expense of department stores and have lured upper- and middle-income customers with low prices on Martha Stewart pool furniture or embroidered tops.
As buying cheap has become synonymous with smart shopping, almost-new merchandise has also gained new cachet. "Just over the past five years, the increase in the acceptability of buying used has been amazing," said Christa Weil, author of "Secondhand Chic" (Pocket Books, 1999). "I used to slink around doing it and now friends brag about buying secondhand."
She points to her best friend, who after years of mocking her for shopping secondhand, bought her wedding dress from a thrift shop specializing in vintage gowns.
And while discount stores are still known for what are frequently second-rate goods, secondhand stores are gaining reputations for high-quality merchandise at low prices.
"I like nice things; I'm not a blue-light special person," said Pat Bolar, a homemaker who shops for secondhand designer wear at One More Time in an upscale neighborhood in Columbus, Ohio.
The boom economy has supplied secondhand stores, whether charitable or for-profit ventures, with enormous amounts of high-quality merchandise. As Americans grow wealthier, they are more likely to replace barely used sofa sets or cull from their closets the Gucci pants worn once to a wedding last year. Sporting goods, like high-quality tennis rackets bought with the best intentions, find their way to the used-product stores as well.
"Some people get tired of things very quickly," said Jane Strauch, owner of Patrick's Consignment Store in Pacific Grove, Calif. In January, for example, a local resident consigned a cherrywood jewelry chest that still had the protective plastic from the factory on it.
Also, areas of this market are increasingly being fueled by the rapid obsolescence of high-technology gear. The resale personal computer business barely existed a decade ago. Now industry experts estimate that it exceeds $5 billion a year, as businesses, in particular, race to keep up with newer gadgets and the increases in computing power each year. (Purchases by businesses directly from other businesses, which account for the bulk of the $5 billion computer resale market, are not included in the census's used-merchandise category.)
Consumers and businesses are mixing and matching their computer hardware. "We sell to a very broad base of customers," said Taylor Bond, until recently president of the 210-store used-computer chain Computer Renaissance. That chain is also under the Grow Biz umbrella and had $150 million in sales last year.
"Because our stores offer both new and used systems," Mr. Bond said, "we often build a nice, new customized system for mom and dad and then the kids will get refurbished machines, because they are the last people the parents want playing on the new system."
The used-music business is also exploding. "Vinyls would wear out, but the compact disc won't wear out absent physical abuse," said Jerry Grizzle, chairman and chief executive of CD Warehouse, a 360-store chain that sells used discs. "The technology gave validity to the used-music market."
But perhaps the biggest change in the secondhand business has been the revamping of the stores themselves. In recent years, businesses ranging from tiny thrift stores to giant nonprofit charities to pawn shops have upgraded store design, layout and organization of goods. Goodwill Industries International, for example, has added coffee bars to a half-dozen stores and has begun putting couches in its used-book areas so customers can loll about.
"The retail market is much more competitive, so we have to do everything we can to attract and retain customers," said Christine Bragale, the charity's spokeswoman, exhibiting the kind of consumer-first attitude that would make a Barnes & Noble manager envious.
Throughout the nonprofit sector, secondhand stores are sweeping away dust bunnies and adding overhead lighting. And, if anything, the changes have been more drastic in the for-profit sector. Grow Biz is just the largest of several corporations that have tried to organize and invigorate the resale business by bringing the levels of customer service and inventory display that shoppers associate with chains like the Gap.
Although most of Grow Biz's stores are independent franchises, they follow standard policies on returns and guarantees of service. Revenue for the corporation and its associated stores were $650 million in 1999.
That is a decrease from previous years, because Grow Biz has not been successful in all of the resale areas it has entered. For instance, it was forced to sell off its music and games franchises and the company turned from a profit to a loss in 1999.
Traditionally, resale businesses have been hard to organize nationally because stores buy goods piecemeal from local sellers who bring in castoffs. Advances in data-organizing software are making it easier, however. The CD Warehouse system tracks customer purchases at each store, ranks recordings' popularity with customers and assigns prices to them accordingly. Secondhand goods have also flourished in the new retail medium of the Internet. The explosion of used-goods auctions taking place at popular online sites from eBay to Yahoo to Amazon.com have made purchasing used memorabilia the cutting edge of chic, something that owners of secondhand-goods stores think only redounds to their own good.
"EBay and everything on the Internet has helped our industry," said Alexandra Carroll, the departing president of the National Association of Resale and Thrift shops. "It keeps us on the mind of our customers. The Internet has been a boon."

HEADLINE: Level of Consumer Confidence Is a Bit Weaker This Month

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Consumer confidence weakened in April for the third consecutive month, suggesting there could be some slowing of the spending that has fueled the nation's growth.
But Americans' expectations about future business and job opportunities remained strong, and economists said they expected this would cause the Federal Reserve's policy-setting committee to raise interest rates the sixth time since June 1999 when it meets on May 16. 
 The Conference Board, a private research group, reported yesterday that its consumer confidence index dipped to 136.9 in April from a revised 137.1 the month before. That was down sharply from the record 144.7 registered in January and was the lowest since October.
Still, the reading was stronger than Wall Street analysts had expected becuase of the recent instability in the stock market.
In a separate sign of economic strength, the National Association of Realtors reported that sales of existing homes rose 1.5 percent in March, the second consecutive monthly gain despite rising mortgage rates.
Lynn Franco, director of the Conference Board's research center, said market volatility "clearly had little, if any, impact on consumer confidence."
While consumers rate current economic conditions less positively than they did last month, their outlook for the next six months had improved, she said. "The boost in optimism, coupled with tax refunds, should continue to fuel spending," she said.
The consumer confidence figures, based on a survey of 5,000 United States households, provide clues on consumer spending, which makes up about two-thirds of the economy. The index compares results with its base year, 1985, when it stood at 100.
The economy's strength has prompted the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates for fear that too-rapid growth could cause inflation.
Economists said that both reports supported expectations that Fed policy makers would raise rates again when they meet next month. But the slight cooling of confidence has reduced fears the Fed will be more aggressive by raising rates a half- point instead of a quarter-point.
The latest report indicated that the Conference Board index measuring consumers' expectations for the next six months rose to 108.2 in April from 106.8 the month before. An increased number of those surveyed predicted better business conditions and stronger job opportunities.

HEADLINE: Nobel Economists Back China's Joining Global Trade Group

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
A group of 13 Nobel Prize-winning economists signed a letter today that backs China's bid to join the World Trade Organization. But the letter, released in a ceremony with top Clinton administration officials, was at least as notable for what it left out.
The four-paragraph letter, endorsed by 149 economists including the Nobel laureates, makes no mention of what the White House has called its top remaining legislative and foreign policy priority: persuading Congress to grant China permanent normal trade relations. The omission was conspicuous. As the administration has stressed many times, Congress has no say in whether China joins the trade body. Congress votes only on whether to elevate the trade ties, a step that is necessary if American companies are to benefit fully from China's membership in the W.T.O. 
 Clinton administration officials said the letter did not mention the vote because the administration sought to attract support from a broad array of economists. Some economists might not have agreed to sign the letter if it explicitly mentioned a political issue before Congress, the officials acknowledged. The officials said that they thought most of the economists who signed the letter personally support permanent normal trade relations, but that some do not and that others felt uncomfortable taking a political stand.
Qualms about delving into politics did not stop 200 corporate chief executives from endorsing permanent normal trade relations in a letter released earlier this month. And a group of former Treasury and State Department secretaries spanning five administrations explicitly backed the Clinton administration's position on the vote this month. So did 47 governors in a letter released in late March.
The White House released the economists' letter in high-profile fashion, kicking off the final month of an intense effort to persuade wavering lawmakers in the House to back permanent trade ties. The vote is expected in late May and the tally in the House is considered too close to call.
Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers; Gene Sperling, the director of the National Economic Council; and Martin N. Baily, chairman of the council of economic advisers, were on hand to present the letter to reporters. Robert M. Solow, a Nobel laureate from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, also came to Washington to speak in support.
"It's a once-in-a-generation event that Bob Solow and Milton Friedman, Paul Samuelson and Merton Miller are signing a letter on the same side of a major public policy issue," Mr. Summers said. He was referring to four of the Nobel-winning economists who signed the letter but have often taken opposing positions on other economic issues.
The lack of a clear stand on the issue before Congress also comes at a time when the administration is under scrutiny for its lobbying efforts on behalf of increased trade with China. A complaint from Representative Frank R. Wolf, a Virginia Republican who opposes making China's trade status permanent, prompted the General Accounting Office to open an investigation this month into whether the administration violated legal restrictions on lobbying Congress when it set up a White House "war room" to coordinate the campaign. That investigation is continuing.
When first asked why the economists' letter made no mention of permanent normal trade relations, Mr. Sperling said the administration had to abide by legal restrictions on what it could urge outsiders to say on a matter before Congress. But Mr. Sperling and other officials later said that explanation was incorrect.
They said that there were no legal restrictions at issue in choosing whether to mention the Congressional vote in the letter, and that it was drafted well before the G.A.O. began its investigation. The letter did not mention permanent normal trade relations because the administration was seeking support from a wide spectrum of economists on the left and right, some of whom might not want to weigh in publicly on a Clinton administration legislative priority, they said.
"The economists all believe that it's important to have open trade," said Commerce Secretary William M. Daley, who is leading the administration's lobbying campaign on the China vote. "But they want to stay out of the political fight."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
BroadRally Lifts Nasdaq To 6.6% Gain

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices staged a broad rally yesterday, with the Nasdaq composite index recording its third-biggest percentage gain.
The increase continues the wild gyrations in prices that have occurred during April, and it came just a day after the technology-heavy Nasdaq index was battered on worries about Microsoft, the industry's bellwether company. 
 Three of the 10 biggest daily percentage gains in Nasdaq history have occurred this month, but so have four of its largest declines.
"This is kind of manic behavior," said Philip S. Dow, a managing director in equity research at Dain Rauscher Wessels in Minneapolis. "I think it will be a feature of the market for some time to come. Institutions are struggling to determine what sort of valuation metrics they are going to use on technology stocks."
The Nasdaq opened the session strong and moved higher as the day progressed. At the close, the index was up 228.75 points, or 6.6 percent, to 3,711.23. The strength was extremely broad-based; 96 stocks in the Nasdaq 100 index rose.
Other market indexes posted big gains, although not as large as Nasdaq's. Led by technology stalwarts like Intel, Hewlett-Packard and I.B.M., the Dow Jones industrial average gained 218.72 points, or 2 percent, to 11,124.82. It was the first time the Dow had closed above 11,000 since April 12.
The stocks comprising the Standard & Poor's 500 index had an extremely good day: the index rose 47.58 points, or 3.3 percent, to 1,477.44. Of the stocks in the index, 415 rose in price, while 74 declined.
And the small stocks that make up the Russell 2000 index rallied. The index gained 20.49 points, or 4.4 percent, to 489.03.
Traders and analysts were at a loss to identify the catalyst for yesterday's rally. It is especially curious since financial markets will be asked tomorrow to digest important information on inflation and the economy. Traders and investors normally become cautious in advance of such reports.
Moreover, the strong performance in stocks came on a day when market interest rates rose sharply.
"Could this be another bear trap or sucker rally?" asked Kenneth M. Sheinberg, head of listed trading at SG Cowen. "There is a possibility for that. But I think we can carry through a little bit more because no one expects it."
Tomorrow, the government is expected to release first-quarter employment cost and gross domestic product data, numbers that will carry weight at the Federal Reserve Board. Fed policy makers are widely expected to approve another increase in short-term interest rates next month.
Concerns about interest rates seemed far from the minds of most investors and traders yesterday, because buyers far outnumbered sellers.
On the New York Stock Exchange, roughly twice as many stocks rose in price as fell.
Stocks in the Dow average that shone were led by Intel, which climbed 8 7/8, to 125. Hewlett-Packard gained 7, to 139 5/16. I.B.M. was up 5 7/8, to 112 3/8. Microsoft rebounded from a sharp 15.6 percent sell-off on Monday to rise 2 3/4, to 69 3/8. And General Electric closed at 165 3/4, a new high, after rising 3 3/4.
Other big winners on the Nasdaq included Qualcomm, which rose 5 5/16, to 104 15/16; JDS Uniphase, which jumped 13, to 93 5/16; and Sun Microsystems, which closed at 93 3/4, up 6 1/8.
Procter & Gamble and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing were two high-profile stocks that lost ground. P.& G., which was battered last month after it issued a profit warning for the rest of its fiscal year, fell 6 3/16, to 64 5/16, after it released results for its third quarter.
3M fell 3 11/16, to 93 13/16, after it said profits for all of this year might fall short of Wall Street's rosiest estimates. The diversified manufacturer issued that warning as it topped earnings estimates for the first quarter.
"Every 48 hours more stocks are oversold than overbought," said Bill Schneider, head of equity block trading at Warburg Dillon Read. "We are in a range-bound, 48-hour trading cycle. It must drive people to take a lot of Mylanta. But people are not as threatened by volatility as they used to be."

Bond Prices Are Down
By Bloomberg News
Treasury bond prices fell on concern that reports later this week will show that the economy did not slow much and that inflation accelerated in the first quarter.
Bond investors are concerned that economic growth "is going to come in at a higher number than is sustainable," said Dave Weigert, who helps invest $25 billion in fixed income at Aeltus Investment Management in Hartford. He has put new capital in cash to reinvest as the Federal Reserve raises interest rates. "Those numbers will clarify in people's minds that the Fed does need to move at least two more times and maybe three" this year, after five rate increases since June, he said.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 28/32, to 104 13/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.93 percent from 5.87 percent on Monday.

HEADLINE: Microsoft Management Tells Workers There Will Be No Breakup

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR and JOEL BRINKLEY 

 BODY:
As some industry executives declared that a government move to break up Microsoft could inject new competition into the software business, Microsoft's top management confidently assured its 34,000 employees yesterday that there was no chance the company would be split up.
And to further calm any anxious workers, Microsoft told them they would all receive new stock options to shield them financially from the recent slide in the company's stock price. 
 The assurances followed reports that the government would ask the federal judge presiding over the antitrust case against Microsoft to break the company in two. In Washington yesterday, the leaders of the Justice Department's antitrust division were summoned to the White House, where they gave President Clinton's economic advisers a detailed briefing on the case and their remedy proposal, which is to be submitted by Friday.
In the face of the government's apparent hard line, Microsoft's leaders were defiant. In a lengthy e-mail message yesterday morning to Microsoft employees titled "Bullish About the Future," Steven Ballmer, the president and chief executive, expressed unabashed enthusiasm for his company's business prospects.
"This company, which has done so many great things for consumers and for the American economy over the last 25 years, will not be broken up," Mr. Ballmer said. "No matter what the newspaper headlines say, absolutely nothing in the current case justifies breaking us up."
William H. Gates, the chairman, went even further in defending Microsoft's conduct, which Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson ruled earlier this month was "predatory" and illegal. In an interview on the public television program "Nightly Business Report," Mr. Gates said, "It's important to understand that Microsoft is very clear that it has done absolutely nothing wrong."
The Justice Department and 19 states suing Microsoft contend that the strength of their case and the unbending stand of Microsoft's management require strong remedies. The Justice Department's proposal, according to people close to the situation, calls for Microsoft to be split into two companies -- one with its operating-system business and one with its Office software and most other operations. It also calls for restraints on Microsoft business practices.
Under the government plan, each of the two companies would have an effective monopoly. Windows holds nearly 85 percent of the market for PC operating systems, and its Office programs, like Word for word processing and Excel for spreadsheet calculations, command more than 90 percent of their markets. But the government believes that creating separate companies would foster increased competition in the industry.
"That remedy would represent a big change in the software landscape," said Larry Augustin, president and chief executive of VA Linux Systems.
His company sells computer work- stations and data-serving computers that run on Linux, an increasingly popular version of the Unix operating system. Linux has gained ground as a robust operating system mainly used on so-called servers -- the hub machines in computer networks that send Web pages or other data to users' desktop machines. But most people use Microsoft's Office programs on their desktop machines, and Microsoft does not make a version of Office that runs on Linux, a rival to Windows.
As a separate company, the Office business, Mr. Augustin said, would have a powerful economic incentive to make its Office programs run smoothly on Linux. "Office on Linux would make Linux a very viable desktop operating system -- a real desktop alternative to Windows," he said.
Bob Young, chairman of Red Hat, a Linux company, agreed that the government's plan would orobably accelerate the advance of Linux. "There is no question that Microsoft's monopoly inhibits the ability to compete in parts of the market -- specifically on the desktop," he said.
Venture capitalists, who finance new companies, were guardedly optimistic that the government's plan, if approved by the court, might foster somewhat more competition. "If this happens, the effect would probably be to increase competitive product offerings -- and that's no small thing," said Richard Kramlich, general partner at New Enterprise Associates, a Silicon Valley venture capital firm.
Like many Silicon Valley executives, Mike Homer, an investor in start-ups who was formerly an executive vice president at Netscape Communications, the Internet pioneer whose upstart challenge to Microsoft was the focus of the antitrust case, said that much would depend on precisely how the government plan was carried out and enforced.
"It would probably make the world safer for some software companies," Mr. Homer said. "But the devil is in the details in all the conduct remedies."
Gordon E. Eubanks Jr., a veteran software industry executive who testified on Microsoft's behalf at the antitrust trial, said he did not think the industry would suffer from the remedy proposed by the government. The government, he noted, stopped short of the most sweeping remedy proposal that had been discussed in recent months of creating perhaps three competing Windows companies. As long as that step was not taken, he said, the industry would not be threatened by what he called a destructive fracturing of the Windows technology standard.
"And potentially, you could get more competition in desktop applications software with this approach," he said.
He said the government seemed to be focusing on the desktop software market, where Microsoft has already won. But the big future growth, he added, is not in PC software but in so-called post-PC computing on the Internet, where the new access devices will increasingly be television set-top boxes, hand-held computers and "smart" cell phones.
"The irony of this is that Microsoft has never been weaker in recent years," Mr. Eubanks said. "The future is Web-based computing, and that is not where Microsoft's core competence is."
Indeed, Wall Street's concerns that PC growth is slowing and that Microsoft is not making the transition to the post-PC era of computing fast enough have been perhaps the main reason -- more than the breakup proposal -- that the company's shares dropped so much on Monday.
Following Microsoft's report of disappointing revenue growth after the stock markets closed last week, several Wall Street analysts issued warnings early Monday.
To bolster the morale of its workers, Microsoft yesterday issued new stock options to all its employees priced at Monday's closing price, $66.625, compared with a recent high of just under $120 a share last Dec. 30. The one-time additional stock grant for workers, Mr. Ballmer told employees, will equal the size of the options each had received since last July. (Unlike most corporate executives, Mr. Ballmer and Mr. Gates, both multibillionaires because of their Microsoft holdings, do not receive stock options.)
"I think the grants since July will have value long run," Mr. Ballmer wrote, "but I want to pre-empt undue concerns by awarding these new grants that will let people see returns much sooner." Microsoft's stock rebounded slightly yesterday, closing at $69.375.
As Mr. Ballmer was reassuring his troops, officials, including the Treasury secretary, Lawrence H. Summers, were conferring at the White House on the Justice Department's approach to the antitrust case and its potential economic impact.
President Clinton did not attend the briefing, and the White House spokesman, Joe Lockhart, said Mr. Clinton "properly believes this should be handled at Justice." Another White House spokesman said the meeting lasted one hour and 40 minutes, and the White House team asked only "clarifying questions."
Another official said the White House advisers did not try to change the Justice Department's strategy.
Beyond that, officials from both the White House and the Justice Department said little and did so with carefully chosen language. Mr. Summers appeared ill at ease at a news conference as he explained the reasoning for the afternoon meeting.
"What is being discussed is an economic issue," he said, "and I think there's a feeling that it's appropriate to have a briefing on issues that clearly have important economic ramifications," namely the proposed breakup of Microsoft, one of the nation's most important companies with $23 billion in revenue last year.
Gene Sperling, the president's chief economic adviser, said the White House had received a similar briefing at the start of the government's case against Microsoft and believed another one was appropriate now, near the end. But he, too, said the meeting was simply "an informational briefing."

HEADLINE: Negotiators Report Progress Over Strike by Nyack Nurses

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: NYACK, N.Y., April 25

 BODY:
Officials representing both Nyack Hospital and nurses on strike said today that they were moving closer to a settlement of the four-month-long walkout. After the announcement, the nurses canceled a protest rally that they had planned for tonight.
Neither side would say what had led to the breakthrough in the talks. Negotiators for the hospital in Rockland County and for the nurses' union met for 20 straight hours before stopping for a break around noon today. Talks are scheduled to resume Wednesday at 3 p.m. 
 "We are very optimistic and continue to be so, but we don't want to say anything that could jeopardize the negotiations," said Nancy Kriz, a spokeswoman for Nyack Hospital.
On Monday, the deadline that the hospital had set for the nurses to return or face permanent replacement, the talks had seemed hopelessly deadlocked. Only four nurses went back to work, and two nurses quit, said Mark A. Genovese, a spokesman for the New York State Nurses Association, the union that represents 33,000 nurses statewide.
"We stuck together," said Eileen Duffany, a surgical intensive care unit nurse who spent several hours today picketing in front of the red-brick hospital. "I've been here for 20 years now, and I'm not going to let them take it from me. We want to go back, but we want to go back with a good contract."
The hospital has begun the process of recruiting nurses to replace those on strike, but no nurses have been fired, Ms. Kriz said. Even if replacements are found for each position, the striking nurses will be placed on a waiting list to get their jobs back once the strike is over, Ms. Kriz said.
On Dec. 21, all but 26 of the 450 nurses at the small community hospital went on strike over staffing, proposed changes in sick time and the hospital's effort to switch to a merit pay system. Since then, about 30 nurses have resigned, while others have taken temporary jobs at other local hospitals or agencies or gone on unemployment.
This is the third strike since 1993 for Nyack Hospital's nurses, Mr. Genovese said. In 1993 they went on strike for six and a half hours after contract negotiations took longer than expected. In 1995, they struck for 26 days after the hospital sought to replace 12-hour shifts with 8-hour shifts. Ultimately, some departments' shifts were shortened while others remained 12 hours.
Throughout the current strike, the nurses' union has contended that nurses are responsible for too many patients at once and have to work so much overtime that the quality of care is in jeopardy. The hospital says that staffing is adequate and that nurses were required to work overtime on only 44 shifts out of 85,000 in all of 1999.
Since the strike began, Nyack Hospital has used temporary nurses provided by an agency in Colorado.
"We have had no curtailment of any services or any facet of the operation," Ms. Kriz said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Gains in European Stocks Being Swept Away by the Sinking Euro

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Americans who have invested in European stock markets this year have been dealt a cruel blow by the euro, which seems to be on a relentless decline.
On the surface, the market news from across the Atlantic is good. While the major American equity indexes are down or flat for the year, some prominent European stock indexes have posted gains. Germany's benchmark DAX index has climbed 4.63 percent in local-currency terms, France's CAC has risen 6.08 percent, and a key Italian gauge is up 6.42 percent. 
 But the euro, the single currency introduced last year for 11 European nations, plunged more than 2 percent yesterday, bringing its decline for the year to 8.5 percent and souring those stock returns for Americans. When the European gains are translated into dollars, the DAX is down 4.24 percent, the CAC is off 2.92 percent and the Italian index is 2.61 percent lower.
The story is not a new one. A 13.8 percent decline in the exchange value of the euro in 1999 ate into European equity returns. But European stocks rose so sharply at the end of last year that American investors still came out well ahead. For example, a 39.1 percent surge in the DAX was tempered to a 20.3 percent rise in dollar terms. The 51.1 percent moonshot by the French index in euros became 30.7 percent in dollars. And in Italy, the 22.3 percent rise in euro terms was translated into a 5.7 percent gain.
But the euro's drop yesterday raised questions again about how low the currency can go. It settled in New York at 92.08 American cents, down from 93.98 cents on Monday and $1.0062 at the end of 1999. The average value this year is now 98 cents -- below the psychologically important level of $1, or parity.
Admittedly, the euro's decline this year is a little less than the 9.2 percent fall in the comparable period in 1999. And investors have said that the further the euro falls, the more likely it is to have a good rally -- eventually. But that hope has been dashed before. And those are pretty weak positives for a currency that was once seen as a challenger to the dollar.
With yesterday's decline, investors were reminded that the factors that have been conspiring against the euro are not going away soon. One is the strength of the American economy, which is proving more attractive to investors than are conditions in Europe.
A report released yesterday by the Conference Board showed that Americans' expectations for the next six months were better than expected, and it pointed to continued strong consumer spending. The report also indicated that this month's stock market gyrations, most notably the Nasdaq composite's 25 percent plunge in one week, had not dampened consumers' spirits.
Jeremy P. Fand, senior foreign exchange strategist at Fleet Global Markets in Boston, said that before yesterday "people still had hope that confidence in the United States would come off some with the volatility in the American stock market."
"You would have thought," he said, "that the euro would have done well, given the plunge in the Nasdaq and the volatility in the U.S. market."
The stock volatility does not appear to be driving away European investors. Since the Nasdaq reached its closing high on March 10, it has fallen 26.5 percent, with 15 days of moves of at least 3 percent up or down. Some might have pulled their money out of stocks and returned to the euro, driving the currency higher. But over the same period, the euro's value has lost 4.5 percent.
If European investors held on to American blue chips, they have profited. When the United States stock performance is translated into euros, the Nasdaq index is flat for the year while the Standard & Poor's 500 stocks are up 9.9 percent and the Dow Jones industrials, up 5.7 percent.
"If the stock market and the economy are not going to slide, the dollar, and American interest rates, are going to continue to climb," said Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at Hoenig & Company. The dollar, he said, has rallied against the Japanese yen in the last few days and American interest rates have shot higher in the last two weeks.
Despite the euro's accelerating decline, Mr. Fand considers it unlikely that the European Central Bank will raise interest rates to support the currency when officials meet tomorrow. Reports from Germany yesterday showed that inflation had eased, he said, so any rate increase would look like an attempt to defend the euro and invite speculative selling to test the central bank's resolve.

HEADLINE: Once Scorned, Far West 42nd St. Is Now Much in Demand

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Jules Demchick, the developer, is doing what even a few years ago would have been unthinkable: building a 17-story corporate office tower in a neighborhood of low-slung warehouses, lumberyards, parking lots and a horse stable on the far west end of 42nd Street, near the Hudson River.
For 50 years, developers have scorned the four long blocks of 42nd Street west of Eighth Avenue, which have everything from a bus terminal to a few lonely apartment towers. But now, with the resurgence of Times Square and the demand for office space and housing at a peak, an area long derided as scruffy may be entering a taller, more-affluent phase. 
 Mr. Demchick, president of the J. D. Carlyle Development Corporation, is beginning to demolish a single-story brick building on the north side of 42nd Street, just east of 12th Avenue, and an adjacent stable that is home to the Police Department's mounted patrol. He plans to erect a 565,000-square-foot office building on the site that he believes will attract some of the media companies, accounting firms and other businesses looking for offices around Times Square.
His project sits across the street from where the developer Larry Silverstein is building a 40-story brick-and-glass complex with 921 rental apartments. And there are a half-dozen other residential or commercial projects planned along 42nd Street at every intersection from 12th to Eighth Avenues.
Behind the shift is the rapid expansion in recent years of Wall Street, communications and dot-com technology firms, all of which have gobbled up much of the available office space in Midtown and have pushed into more industrial areas like the garment district and the far West Side of Manhattan. As a result, the Midtown vacancy rate has dropped below 6 percent and developers are building where no corporate tenants could be found a few years ago. That trend, developers say, is also increasing demand for housing nearby.
"For decades, developers and city planners have struggled to extend the boundaries of development from east to west along 42nd Street," said Ross Moskowitz, a real estate lawyer at Stroock & Stroock & Lavan who is a former city economic development official. "The biggest hurdle was crossing Sixth Avenue. Despite the naysayers and false starts, it finally appears that the two-mile stretch from river to river will be anchored at both ends."
Mr. Demchick, whose company owns 3.5 million square feet of office and retail properties, as well as 5,000 apartments, bought the property on 42nd Street nearly two years ago and, until two weeks ago, had planned to build a 49-story, glass-walled condominium.
But Mr. Demchick's company is used to holding on to property, not selling it. After talking with Mary Ann Tighe, vice chairwoman of Insignia/ESG, a commercial broker, Mr. Demchick said he became convinced that Carlyle could quickly build an office tower on the same site with the large floors and fiber-optic lines that would attract the corporate tenants that can no longer find adequate space in Midtown. While average rents have crept above $50 a square foot a year, he said that he could offer space in a new building for $45.
"I'd like to say that we're smart, but it's really market driven," said Mr. Demchick, whose partner in the project is the Feinberg real estate family. "I don't want to be out there selling apples when people are buying pears."
The demand for office space is so strong today that Mr. Silverstein is also considering building an office tower on his site between 11th and 12th Avenues, instead of a second 40-story apartment house.
At the southwest corner of Eighth Avenue and 42nd Street, the Ruben real estate family and Vornado Realty Trust plan to build a million-square-foot tower over the Port Authority Bus Terminal, although the project has been hampered by disputes within the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Across the street, the owners of a parking lot are selling the parcel for what will probably be another million-square-foot office tower.
Those office projects, coupled with the Reuters, Ernst & Young and Conde Nast towers in Times Square, have prompted other developers to plan for new apartment towers on the once-undesirable western end of 42nd Street. Even in the best of times, the neon lights of Times Square rarely illuminated the factories, freight yards, warehouses, stockyards and tenements on 42nd Street.
In the 1950's, the Port Authority Bus Terminal and the West Side Airlines Terminal were built west of Eighth Avenue. Still, in 1962, the editors of The New Yorker described the new Sheraton Motor Inn at the northeast corner of 12th Avenue and 42nd Street as "a startlingly classy pioneer in a somewhat declasse neighborhood." The hotel, which is now a consulate for the People's Republic of China, sits next to Mr. Demchick's site.
More than 25 years later, the handful of apartment towers built in the neighborhood during the 1980's real estate boom were left gasping for tenants when a recession hit.
This time it is going to be different, developers say. The boom in office construction in Times Square is feeding a demand for housing.
Harold Fetner, president of Sidney Fetner Associates, is planning to build a tower with 264 apartments at the southwest corner of 42nd Street and 10th Avenue. The developer Daniel Brodsky expects to begin construction in June of a 40-story apartment building, with 264 apartments over five theaters at 42nd Street and Dyer Avenue, the thoroughfare between 9th and 10th Avenues. And Douglas Durst is planning yet another apartment building at the northeast corner of Ninth Avenue and 42nd Street.
"We're filling in the blocks," said Kenneth M. Miller, vice president of the Gotham Organization, which two years ago opened the New Gotham, a luxury apartment house with 374 apartments between 10th and 11th Avenues, and 42nd and 43rd Streets. "It's becoming more mainstream, instead of out on the edge. Slowly but surely, the West Side will be anchored by a significant residential community."
