HEADLINE: A Bug That Can Fell a Horse;
Fighting Mosquitoes' Threat to Thoroughbreds

BYLINE: By SARAH KERSHAW 

 BODY:
In the feverish world of horse racing and breeding, mosquito season is about as welcome as a hurricane at the Preakness.
Especially this spring, given the prospect of a repeat of the West Nile virus -- which killed seven people and nine horses in New York last year, including a retired racehorse who was to breed thoroughbreds. The possibility that the mosquito-borne illness could destroy a multimillion-dollar celebrity like Fusaichi Pegasus, the Kentucky Derby favorite who spent four days training at Aqueduct before winning the Wood Memorial there on April 15, has track officials more hyper than in-bred thoroughbreds. 
 So, these days, there are some rather strange goings-on at Aqueduct and Belmont Park, both near the epicenter of the outbreak in northern Queens and both part of an industry that contributes more than $1 billion annually to New York State's economy.
Take the chickens at Belmont, the nation's largest track, on the Queens-Nassau border. Once welcome to spend all their days scuttling around the stables and barns there, they now have a $5 bounty on their heads and are being rounded up by the hundreds.
Horsemen brought chickens to Belmont soon after the gates opened in 1905 to calm the high-strung thoroughbreds by lending a barnyard feel to the stables. But erstwhile friends, the fowl, now known to help spread West Nile, are being trapped in padlocked coops and tested for the virus. So far, almost 500 have been shipped to a farmer upstate, racing officials said.
While kicking out the chickens, Belmont officials are bringing in fish. After investigating the behavior of various species to find some that eat mosquito larvae, racing officials last week dumped 4,000 goldfish and catfish into the two lakes in the main track's infield, and into a duck pond near the grandstand.
Then there was the pesticide deal with the Native American chief. Racing officials spent $10,000 on a latex chemical called Ultracide produced by the man's company, Native American Enviro-Tech. They were told it would kill the bugs but not harm the horses. But the state has blocked the use of Ultracide because it is not registered in New York.
The obsession with mosquito control at the two tracks is no surprise, given the routine frenzy surrounding the health of horses. In addition to the nine horse deaths, on a cluster of farms near Riverhead on Long Island, the virus infected 16 other horses, including 2 thoroughbreds that were racing at Belmont and another horse that raced at Yonkers.
At the track, a cough or a sneeze is cause for alarm; wobbling, twitching and circling, symptoms of West Nile infections in horses, sends veterinarians and trainers into red alert.
"The stars of this sport are the horses," said Francis J. La Belle Jr., a spokesman for the New York Racing Association, which owns and operates New York's three largest tracks, at Belmont, Aqueduct and Saratoga. "We go nowhere without them."
Horses, like humans, can recover from West Nile, which can be deadly if it leads to encephalitis, swelling of the brain. Infections can range from what looks like a minor flu to serious neurological illnesses; but three racehorses that were infected with the virus last year recovered, and, so far, two have gone on to race, according to the veterinarians who treated them. (Some horse owners take out health insurance that could cover illness or death from West Nile, but others do not, experts said.)
Officials at both Queens racetracks are also dropping doughnut-shaped "mosquito dunks" made of larvicide, which kills the eggs, into other bodies of standing water that are mosquito breeding grounds. They are also setting up mechanical mosquito traps across the 430-acre Belmont property, and the Nassau County Health Department plans to set up a mosquito-trapping station there to catch the bugs and test them for West Nile, officials said.
Amid all this, it is still unclear whether West Nile will reappear in the New York City area or spread to Long Island again. Recent tests on hibernating mosquitoes in Fort Totten, Queens, near the epicenter of the 1999 outbreak that infected 69 people, confirmed that the virus was still alive there. And In Westchester, a dead bird tested positive last month for the virus, raising fears that West Nile will reemerge this summer.
"You wouldn't even want to think about it," said John Dowd, a trainer, who was working with 10 horses at Aqueduct before the races there last Thursday. Among Mr. Dowd's charges that day were some racehorses, like Wires Crossed and Critical Thinker, worth up to $10 million.
Farm managers, particularly those on the East End of Long Island, where the virus struck last year, and other horse breeders said they were taking precautions similar to those at the racetracks, including using the mosquito dunks in standing water. Several said they were planning to stable their horses at night, spray them with pesticides and keep them in barns at dusk and dawn, peak mosquito hours. A few breeders said they were considering stabling their horses in upstate New York or in other states.
Jeff Raine, who manages the Big E farm in Jamesport, N.Y., where two horses, including a thoroughbred brood mare, succumbed to West Nile last year, said he was doing everything he could to prepare for mosquito season. The 120-acre breeding farm is owned by Robert Entenmann of the baked goods company, and is home to 15 horses that serve as Mr. Entenmann's private breeding and racing stock.
"I've had nightmares about it recurring," said Mr. Raine, who had to put to sleep the brood mare, Terroir, a retired racehorse who ran at Aqueduct and Belmont a year before she was sent to the Jamesport farm to breed. "We're very concerned about what's going to happen this year."
Terroir's illness was the first confirmed case of equine West Nile in last year's outbreak, said Dr. John Andresen, the veterinarian who treated her and diagnosed her as having the virus. Government scientists are using genetic material from Terroir for research on a possible vaccine, he said.
At Belmont and elsewhere, state officials are testing the blood of chickens, which carry the virus but do not get sick from it, for signs of West Nile. Chickens can spread the virus to horses if mosquitoes bite infected chickens and then bite horses. But horses, "dead-end hosts," cannot spread the disease to other horses or species, experts said.
A group of chicks from Belmont who were tested recently showed no sign of exposure to the virus, said Dr. Neil Cleary, a veterinarian with the racing association who treated one of the two Belmont racehorses who was infected with West Nile but recovered.
State agriculture officials said that since the outbreak, they have conducted blood tests on horses in the Riverhead area and across Long Island to determine how many were exposed to the disease, possibly making them immune. Results released so far showed that of 69 horses tested in the Riverhead area, 20 were exposed to the disease but did not get sick. The incubation period is up to seven days, so those horses would not be at risk for infection, veterinarians said.
It is still not known why the virus struck that cluster of Long Island farms, 60 miles from the Queens epicenter of the outbreak. But several experts said they suspected West Nile was carried to Riverhead, on the tip of the island, by birds.
Dr. Andresen and other veterinarians who have studied the virus since last year's outbreak, the first time West Nile was detected in the Western Hemisphere, said the newness of the disease here made it difficult to understand the risks and to calm nervous breeders and horse owners.
"It leaves the vets in a quandary," said Dr. Howard Flynn, president of the Long Island Veterinary Medical Association, who runs a clinic in Medford, N.Y. . "This is brand-spanking new around here, and that's part of the problem."
Only one other documented outbreak of the virus caused as many deaths among horses as the Long Island one, a 1996 outbreak in Morocco. It killed 42 of 94 horses confirmed to be infected, said Dr. Peter Timoney, director of the Gluck Equine Research Center at the University of Kentucky in Lexington. A smaller outbreak occurred in Tuscany, Italy, in 1998, Dr. Timoney said.
Dr. Timoney and other veterinarians said that only a few outbreaks of West Nile had occurred among horses since the virus was first detected, in Uganda in 1937. But they said they were concerned about the high mortality rate among infected horses. Almost half the horses with confirmed cases -- 9 of 25 -- either died or were so sick they had to be put to sleep, a mortality rate far higher than the 4 or 5 percent rate for humans.
"Statistically we haven't seen a major occurrence of this disease in horses," Dr. Timoney said. "Still, think about the stakes: these Kentucky Derby hopefuls. If that one animal becomes seriously infected and dies, that's one hell of an economic loss."

HEADLINE: The Big City;
Third Force In Race For Senate

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
JOHN CLIFTON faces certain obstacles in getting elected to the Senate, like persuading his mother to vote for him. But there may be no other candidate who can simultaneously appeal to such disparate blocs of voters.
Mr. Clifton is a Navy veteran who wants to slash the Pentagon's budget. He is an African-American who opposes government-mandated affirmative action, and a social worker in Bedford-Stuyvesant who wants to reduce government spending on social services. He is an advocate of drug legalization whose job involves helping drug addicts kick their habits. He is a beneficiary of the welfare system -- his mother received checks while she raised him -- who would like to dismantle it. He supports conservative gun owners upstate and sympathizes with liberal critics of police brutality downstate. 
 As Mr. Clifton puts it in his campaign literature: 'I am running against the Nanny State and the Police State, Hillary's Big Sister and Rudy's Big Brother philosophy and policies."
It would be hard to find a more determined contrarian in the state, but there are limits even to Mr. Clifton's contrariness. He does not challenge the conventional wisdom (shared by his mother) that his party affiliation makes him an underdog.
Mr. Clifton, the treasurer of the state Libertarian Party, is seeking the Senate nomination at his party's convention in Yonkers on Saturday. Victory would not guarantee much in November -- the Libertarian candidate for Senate last year received barely 8,000 votes. Mr. Clifton's supporters in the party hope that he'll do better, if only because his unusual background will attract attention. New York City has rarely been fertile soil for libertarian politicians.
Mr. Clifton, 41, grew up in a predominantly black neighborhood in Jamaica, Queens, and studied at the Parsons School of Design and the New School for Social Research. Then he served in the Navy as a technician on ballistic-missile submarines, and returned to New York to do social work with the homeless and the mentally ill.
He is now a case manager for a nonprofit group, Services for the Underserved, working with mentally ill patients in Bedford-Stuyvesant. The group is financed in part by city, state and federal government agencies -- precisely the sort of financing that Mr. Clifton would like to reduce.
"I'm in favor of social services," he said. "There are people who need therapy and other help. But I'd like to see programs like ours supported in the main by private donors. I'd rather see a system of voluntary cooperation instead of the compulsion we have now."
How does that idea appeal to his bosses? "I've discussed it with them," he said. "I've suggested that we might be better off privatizing so that we didn't have to beg each year from politicians. But the argument has more or less fallen on deaf ears."
Mr. Clifton would also like to dismantle the public welfare system. "The fact that my family benefited from it doesn't make it right or necessary," Mr. Clifton said. "It's legalized theft from taxpayers." He said that his mother could have relied instead on private charity, and that it was a mistake for black politicians to fight for expanded welfare benefits.
"African-Americans are suffering from a modern version of the 19th century plantation syndrome," he said. "Just as slaves stayed on the plantation even after they were freed, African-Americans have become dependent on the welfare state and the Democratic Party and are afraid to try alternatives. They've concentrated on seeking political empowerment instead of economic and cultural empowerment, as other ethnic groups have done."
That view is not shared by his mother, Maggie Clifton, who still lives in Jamaica, Queens, not far from Mr. Clifton's home in Rochdale Village. "I know welfare's not a good thing," she said, "but I don't know what I would have done without it. There was no husband to help me with three children. I could have gotten a job, but I thought it was better to stay home for the children. I can't understand why John says poor people don't need the government."
Mrs. Clifton said she was hesitant to vote for her son (she's leaning toward Hillary Clinton), but not because of his policies. "I'd vote for him if I thought he could win," she said, "but I'm afraid it would be a wasted vote."
Mr. Clifton hasn't given up on her. "What I'll do," he said, "is keep telling her, 'Mom, a vote for the Bill of Rights is never a wasted vote.' "

Renault to Sell Truck Unit To Volvo and Focus on Cars
Volvo is acquiring the truck unit of the French automaker Renault in a $1.5 billion deal that will create the world's second-largest maker of trucks and buses behind DaimlerChrysler.
The agreement, which came the same day that banks in South Korea agreed to sell the bankrupt Samsung Motor to Renault, signals Renault's intention to shift its focus away from trucks and commercial vehicles and to concentrate on the automobile business. Page C4. 

Competing Bid Made for Champion
International Paper offered to buy Champion International for a combination of cash and stock worth $6.2 billion, or $64 a share, just two months after Champion agreed to a lower bid from the Finnish paper giant UPM-Kymmene. Stockholders clearly expect a bidding war. Shares of Champion surged $12.8125, to $64.25, while International Paper fell $2.75, to $37.25. Analysts say the company's assets alone are worth more than $70 a share. C2.
 
Compaq Profit Meets Expectations
Compaq Computer posted first-quarter earnings that met analysts' estimates, but revenue fell short. Even so, its shares gained more than 12 percent as the company's executives gave a positive outlook for the rest of the year. C6.
 
New Chief Named at British Airways
British Airways, Europe's largest airline, appointed Rod Eddington, the former managing director of Cathay Pacific Airways of Hong Kong, as chief executive. C4.
 
Sotheby's Delays Annual Meeting
Sotheby's postponed its annual meeting as the embattled company's largest outside shareholder, the Baron Capital Group, pushed the board to distance itself from its former chairman, A. Alfred Taubman, who retains voting control of the company. Sotheby's and Mr. Taubman are both subjects of a federal investigation into allegations of price-fixing. C23.
 
Consumer Confidence Drops Again
Consumer confidence weakened in April for the third consecutive month, the Conference Board said, suggesting there could be some slowing in the nation's spending. C10.
 
A Career Choice Made at Age 7
Arthur D. Levinson, chairman and chief executive at Genentech, the biotechnology company, knew very early that he wanted to be a scientist. Among his influences were an uncle who was a librarian, the Seattle World's Fair in 1962, Longacres racetrack and the book "Intelligent Life in the Universe." Weird work and study schedules and an epochal meeting at Sunday school are also part of his life story. The Boss. C8.
 
Traveling the Old-Fashioned Way
It's easy to focus on the endless issues of flying and forget that most business travel is still done by car. Last year, more than half of business travelers said they used an automobile on business trips, according to a recent survey. Joe Sharkey: Business Travel. C10.
 
I.B.M. Pension Proposal Rejected
I.B.M. stockholders rejected a proposal that would have urged the company to back off from pension plan changes that critics said would cut the lifetime benefits of employees. But the proposal was supported by 28.2 percent of the shares voted, more than expected. C12.
 
Earnings Decrease 36% at Xerox
Xerox said its first-quarter earnings fell 36 percent but beat expectations. Its shares shot up by more than 10 percent. C6.

PUB-DATE: April 26, 2000

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1240 words

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Gore Says Top Goal Is Steady Reduction of Nation's Debt

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

 BODY:
Laying out his economic vision more fully than ever, Vice President Al Gore offered himself yesterday as a fiscal conservative and steward of the Clinton administration's economic formula and prosperity.
His primary goal, he said, was to reduce the national debt year by year -- barring an emergency -- and to set it on a course for complete elimination by the year 2013. 
 He pledged to use the Social Security surplus and savings in debt payments to shore up the retirement program. He also promoted tax cuts to help parents save for college tuition, job retraining, health insurance and long-term care and, for businesses, research and development. The total cost of the tax cuts over 10 years, aides estimated, was $250 billion to $300 billion.
His purpose, Mr. Gore said, was not only to maintain the nation's prosperity, but also to maintain consumer confidence in the economy.
"Moving purposefully to a debt-free America will be one of the best ways to sustain and increase the confidence that is the foundation of our present and future prosperity," he told more than 1,000 business, labor and civic leaders who are members of the Association for a Better New York, at the Hilton New York in Manhattan yesterday morning.
"We have to make America debt-free before the baby boomers retire, so we can pay our obligations to them in the form of Social Security and Medicare," he said, crystallizing a central tenet of his candidacy.
And though John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., was in the audience, Mr. Gore pledged an "aggressive" fight to open new markets, like China, to promote free trade.
With Mr. Sweeney sitting near him, Mr. Gore acknowledged that his views on China trade diverged with those of "many of my supporters."
Mr. Sweeney, who was briefed on Mr. Gore's remarks before they were delivered, said unions would continue to back Mr. Gore despite differences on trade.
"Trade is the most significant area of disagreement," Mr. Sweeney said after the speech. "But this was just one piece of a comprehensive economic policy, 90 percent of which we would solidly support."
Mr. Gore sounded familiar themes of the Clinton formula. But he made his first extended remarks tying his presumptive Republican opponent, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, with Mr. Bush's father, President George Bush, and painting both with the same brush of fiscal irresponsibility.
"We fell prey to the politics of illusion during the decade of amazing deficits," Mr. Gore said, referring to the Reagan and Bush administrations. "Now we have to avoid the politics of illusion in the decade of amazing surpluses."
"This is a test of our memory," he said. "Have we forgotten the dangers of irresponsibility? Have we forgotten the virtues of responsibility?"
Mr. Gore developed his economic strategy with President Clinton's top economic advisers -- Lawrence H. Summers, the Treasury Secretary; Robert Rubin, the former Secretary; and Gene Sperling, chief of Mr. Clinton's economic council. As a result, the Gore vision mirrors the Clinton approach of the last seven years, a period that extended a slow recovery into the longest economic expansion in the nation's history.
"If we stick with a disciplined fiscal policy and if we earn and maintain confidence through our decision-making," Mr. Gore said, "then low interest rates and capital costs will do more to promote growth and create jobs than deficit spending could ever achieve. This is the new understanding of our economic reality that has been patiently built up over these last seven years."
At the same time, Mr. Gore declared Mr. Bush would shatter that confidence and said that the governor's tax-cut plan was "politically driven," overly generous to the wealthy and would drive the nation into inflation and recession.
In criticizing Mr. Bush, Mr. Gore invoked President Bush, saying that his tenure was marked by "budget busting, runaway tax policy, runaway spending, without the responsibility to pay for it and without the basic respect for the American people to give even the barest indication of how the cost would be met."
Ari Fleischer, Mr. Bush's spokesman, said that Mr. Gore's speech revealed just how mired he was in old-style partisan attack politics. Mr. Bush, he said, spent the day with Democrats, underscoring his bipartisan approach to problem-solving.
"Al Gore today exaggerated and distorted the governor's balanced-budget proposal," Mr. Fleischer said. "According to economic experts, Governor Bush's tax proposal will cost $1.3 trillion over 10 years, $800 billion less than Gore claims. A new analysis of the Gore budget shows he has proposed $1.9 trillion in new spending on bigger government. Gore's spending plan is nearly 50 percent bigger than Bush's tax cut."
Mr. Gore said later that he was not attacking Mr. Bush as much as pointing out their differences, and that he would continue to do so. "Discussing the substance of the proposals made by him and made by me is a classic and healthy way to present the choice" that confronts the nation, Mr. Gore said in an interview with National Public Radio.
Mr. Gore's speech set the foundation for a series of addresses he intends to deliver in the next couple of weeks as he seeks to contrast his proposals with those of Mr. Bush.
It also represented a new beginning of sorts for Mr. Gore, who laid out most of his policy proposals during his primary contest against former Senator Bill Bradley.
By contrast, Mr. Bush has spent much of the last month offering fresh proposals daily, as Mr. Gore drew little attention, other than criticism over his call for a less active government role in the Elian Gonzalez case.
Yesterday, Mr. Gore came roaring back, not with any sharp departure from previous positions but with a comprehensive discussion of his view of the economy, the linchpin of all his other proposals.
He dismissed the governor's recent speeches, which have moved him toward the political center, as "his post-primary search for rehabilitation."
Concerning President Bush's economic policy, Mr. Gore could not have been more derisive.
"Confidence in America's economic policy-making was shattered," he said. "It lay in ruins. We had to get used to foreign leaders coming here and beginning their state visits with lectures on the fundamentals of economic policy and what a disaster America's economic policy was.
"We didn't get a dose of economic realism until August of 1993 when President Clinton and I fought for and won an economic plan built on the bedrock of fiscal responsibility."
Later, in the interview with National Public Radio, Mr. Gore was less quick to claim credit for the nation's soaring economy. "My task as I see it is not to try to get credit for what's happened but rather to present a vision for what will happen and what can happen if we keep our prosperity going," he said.
During his speech, Mr. Gore gave a strong endorsement of the bill for permanent normal trade relations with China, legislation that is headed for a showdown this spring.
"I will continue to do all I can to build support in Congress for it," Mr. Gore said. He has been reluctant to assert support for the agreement publicly because labor, which has endorsed him, so strongly opposes it.
"I understand their concerns," he said. "And I believe that trade must be a way to lift up living standards around the world, not drag standards down here at home."

HEADLINE: Administration Using Study To Push Elderly Drug Plan

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
Prices for the 50 drugs most frequently used by older Americans increased last year at nearly twice the rate of inflation, a study to be issued on Wednesday at the White House says.
The study found a similar trend over the last six years. 
 President Clinton planned to cite the data in arguing that drug costs constitute a growing burden for the elderly and that Congress should pass legislation to reduce the burden.
The Democratic leaders of Congress, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, intend to join Mr. Clinton at the White House. The three will press Republicans in Congress to reach a compromise and make drug coverage available to all 39 million Medicare beneficiaries.
The study of the top-selling drugs was done by Families USA, a consumer group, and by the Prime Institute at the University of Minnesota, which specializes in the economics of prescription drugs.
The institute is one of the nation's leading centers for research on pharmaceutical economics and has been tracking drug prices since it was established in 1991.
A White House official said the administration was giving its imprimatur to the study because "it's consistent with our findings."
But Jackie Cottrell, a spokeswoman for the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, a trade group, took issue with the report, which she described as "a political study by Families USA."
Government statistics suggest that the wholesale prices of prescription drugs rose less than did the wholesale prices of most other finished goods in 1999, Ms. Cottrell said.
Representatives for several drug companies did not deny increasing their prices, but said their products still offered excellent value.
The study makes these points:
*Prices of the 50 top-selling drugs used by the elderly rose an average of 3.9 percent from January 1999 to January 2000, or nearly twice the overall rate of inflation in that period.
*Prices for 16 of the 50 drugs rose at least three times the rate of inflation.
*In the last six years, prices for the 50 drugs most often used by the elderly rose an average of 30.5 percent or double the inflation rate for that period.
Ronald F. Pollack, who is executive director of Families USA and a co-author of the study, said, "Increasing numbers of elderly Americans will find prescription drugs unaffordable unless they gain access to drug coverage through Medicare."
The study said that new drugs to treat conditions afflicting the elderly often cost more than the drugs they replace. While the new drugs may be more effective, they also increased the share of an elderly person's income devoted to buying drugs, the study said.
The report said the price of Synthroid, a synthetic thyroid hormone, rose four times as much as the Consumer Price Index last year, while the price of Premarin, an osteoporosis drug, increased five times as much as the index, and the price of Pravachol, a cholesterol-lowering drug, three times as much as the index.
Veronica M. Apostolico, a spokeswoman for the Knoll Pharmaceutical Company, which makes Synthroid, said: "This product represents an excellent value. It costs only 30 cents a day. It's the least expensive of the top 10 most frequently dispensed prescription drugs in the country."
Audrey Ashby, a spokeswoman for Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories, which makes Premarin, said: "The percentage price increases are not as important as the daily cost. Therapy with Premarin costs a patient less than 60 cents a day. That's a small price to pay for preventing osteoporosis, which costs the U.S. health care system $10 billion a year."
Patrick D. Donohue, a spokesman for Bristol-Myers Squibb, which makes Pravachol, said, "This product is moderately priced, compared with other cholesterol-lowering drugs, and it has tremendous medical benefits."
Moreover, Mr. Donohue said, "Singling out this drug doesn't tell the whole story. If you look at our full portfolio of drugs, you'll see that the average price rose less than the Consumer Price Index in the last six years."
As drug prices rise, the study said, the demand for discounts by hospitals and health maintenance organizations increases, and this in turn tends to push up prices for individuals who are unable to get such discounts.
The difference in drug prices paid by people with and without insurance to cover drug costs has widened in the last three years, the report said.

HEADLINE: Administration Proposes Changes in Work Rules for Truck Drivers

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
To cut the number of deaths caused by sleepy truck drivers, the Clinton administration today proposed major changes in limits on working hours written in 1937.
But the draft rules, the government's third try at comprehensive change since 1976, were immediately criticized by safety advocates and the trucking industry. 
 The rules would be based on a 24-hour cycle instead of the current 18. And they would require some trucks to carry "black boxes," which the police could use to determine whether drivers were complying.
For long-haul drivers, the rule would set a maximum workday of 12 hours, with 10 consecutive hours off for sleep, and another 2 hours of breaks at other times, in blocks of at least 30 minutes. The current law limits drivers to 10 hours on and calls for 8 hours off. The new rules, then, would let drivers work two hours longer in a shift, but reaching 60 hours would take a minimum of five days, compared with four days under the current limits.
In addition, the rules would require a two-day "weekend," although that could come on any consecutive days.
"This will allow drivers to eliminate any sleep deficit they have built up," said Julie Anna Cirillo, the acting deputy administrator of the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration, an agency created last month within the Transportation Department to improve truck safety.
A 90-day public comment period will begin soon, and Transportation Department officials said they were determined to complete work by the end of the year. If a final rule is not published by mid-January, a new administration could start anew.
But officials conceded that achieving consensus might be impossible. "You won't find anyone who supports this draft," said Kenneth R. Wykle, the federal highway administrator, whose agency is also part of the Transportation Department. Each party will object to a different part, Mr. Wykle said.
He was right. At the industry's main lobbying group, the American Trucking Association, Walter B. McCormick Jr., the president, said in a statement today that if the rule took effect, the industry would need "as many as 180,000 additional drivers and trucks" to move the current volume of freight.
"D.O.T.'s proposal would force today's sophisticated e-commerce, point-and-click, just-in-time delivery systems back into old economy inefficiencies," Mr. McCormick said. He predicted that "warehouses would bulge with goods as the freight backlog ballooned due to massive shortage of trucks and drivers."
But Joan Claybrook, the president of Public Citizen, a watchdog group, said that lengthening the maximum work shift was a mistake. "Most research shows that after eight hours, the capacity to drive safely is drastically reduced," she said. But she said moving to a system based on 24 hours instead of 18 was sound.
Not all truckers agree. Keith S. Herzig of Willington, Conn., who owns three trucks that mostly haul cargo to Scranton, Pa., and back, said that at busy times he and the four drivers who work for him work to the current maximum, 10 hours on and 8 off, for several shifts in a row.
"When you become a professional truck driver, you don't naturally have a normal life, where you go to work at 8 a.m. and you're off at 4 in the afternoon," he said in a telephone interview. "You adapt to sleeping when you need to sleep, and working when you need to work."
Under the Transportation Department proposal, drivers in Mr. Herzig's category, people who stay within six hours of their base and return there at the end of each shift, would be allowed to work up to 12 hours, and then would have 12 hours off. But Mr. Herzig said that having a minimum break that was four hours longer than the current system's would cut his revenue in busy seasons.
Mr. Herzig said he had driven 1.5 million miles, accident-free, over 20 years, and had learned to sleep when time was available to do so.
Moving to a 24-hour system was recommended by the National Transportation Safety Board last year. So was the installation of data recorders, which the department said today would simplify paperwork for the trucking companies and drivers, and reduce fraud.
The requirement for recorders would be phased in, with smaller companies having later deadlines. But as an inducement to install them, companies would not be allowed to extend their drivers' shifts until the recorders were in place.
Some drivers have objected to the recorders as violations of their privacy or a sign that the government does not trust them. Transportation Secretary Rodney E. Slater said today: "We don't think it assumes that they're guilty. We think we're using technology to enhance the safety and efficiency and reliability of the transportation system."
The Transportation Department estimates that the new rule would cost the industry $3.4 billion over the next 10 years. But it would prevent approximately 2,600 crashes a year, reducing deaths by 115 and serious injuries by 3,000, the department says. In 1999, according to government statistics, there were 5,203 truck-related fatalities.

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
Florio Carries Big Baggage And a Lead

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

DATELINE: METUCHEN, N.J.

 BODY:
THE motorcycle club meeting was a collection of Harley hats and shaved heads, a suit jacket or two amid much leather, and one head of chemically assisted bright red hair. One sticker on the wall read "Support the Clinton Agenda," the C made into a hammer and sickle. Another read, "I'm a motorcyclist and I vote." The evening's featured speaker had an old boxing scar on his left cheek and brushed-back black hair, and wore a black mock-turtleneck shirt and dark pants.
"My story's about second chances," he told the 25 bikers. "My story is about opportunities. My story, I like to think, is about hard work." 
 This was not one man's painstaking tale of overhauling an aging Yamaha. This was Jim Florio, once the smelly cheese of New Jersey politics, trying to roar back out of the sunset on a mission that looks at once daring and driven.
His lead sizable, if shrinking, as the Democratic primary for United States Senate approaches, Mr. Florio is trying to turn to his favor all that is stacked against him. And there is much. He portrays the $2.8 billion tax increase that upended his governorship as a necessary policy that he explained poorly to voters. He says his cash-starved campaign is actually an opportunity to engage in the "retail politics" of smallish campaign stops rather than slick television ads. Powerful Democrats in northern New Jersey are supporting his wealthy opponent, Jon S. Corzine, the former chairman of Goldman Sachs & Company, simply because, Mr. Florio says, Mr. Corzine is a "walking A.T.M. machine" financing all their political ambitions.
But if Jon Corzine is a sugar daddy, Jim Florio is the vegetable man. He plies voters with policy the way parents push peas on children. There's a reason voters, and other politicians, sometimes find him arrogant: He was always more skilled at convincing himself which policy was correct than at than at bringing the people along.
When Mr. Florio was leaving Congress for the governor's office in 1990, he was asked what he would miss about Washington. Ignoring the cherry blossoms, he said, "the hearing process," meaning Congressional hearings.
Wrapping up a talk at a church lunch in Trenton on Monday, Mr. Florio said, with some excitement, that he wanted to mention one more thing. "Electric deregulation," he said. You could have heard an ohm drop.
After the talk, Nancy Orhun, who was there with her husband and young children, said, "I thought he did a pretty good job" as governor, but then added, "there was that toilet paper thing."
Toilet paper became a symbol of protest against Mr. Florio's tax measures, which, among other things, expanded the sales tax to include toilet paper, a change that was later repealed. Anger over taxes demolished Democratic power in Trenton, and Mr. Florio is still trying to outrun the shadow of that time.
I WAS governor for four years," Mr. Florio told the American Bikers Aimed Toward Education group here. "As I suspect you know, it was not pleasant all the time." Not waiting to be asked, Mr. Florio confronted the tax issue, saying he had faced an unexpected budget shortfall and a court ruling demanding increased education spending.
On the stump, Mr. Florio remains the familiar mixture of policy enthusiast and pugnacious campaigner. Like a practiced lounge act, he performs a medley of his greatest hits -- toxic waste clean-up, gun control, securing Social Security -- and then unfurls his high-school-dropout-makes-good autobiography before delivering a few zingers at Mr. Corzine.
With the primary six weeks away, Mr. Corzine's $1-million-a-week television campaign is turning negative today. His new commercial, titled "Remember," portrays Mr. Florio's tenure in Trenton as a time of tax increases and a faltering economy.
The election may hinge on whether voters care to remember those years. But surely Mr. Florio does, just as he remembers all the tough elections he has had since running for the State Legislature from Camden County in the late 1960's -- on his way to 16 years in Congress. He is now 62, a grandfather, professor, lawyer and even radio talk show host. So why is he back on the stump -- underfinanced, shunned by many party leaders, about to be the target of his opponent's treasury?
What is it that he wants back? His good name? The hearing process?
"Redemption is to go to heaven," he said, sitting on the steps of the church the other afternoon. "I'm planning on going to the Senate."

HEADLINE: Mayor Surprised About Possible Higher Rents

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani expressed surprise yesterday that the city's Rent Guidelines Board was considering proposals that could set off sharp rent increases for the residents of one million apartments covered by rent stabilization laws.
The mayor, who appoints the board members, called the projected figures "very, very high" but said he had not taken a position yet. He also emphasized that the board had not made a final decision, and he urged the public not to be alarmed. 
 The board's chairman, Edward S. Hochman, has proposed changes in methodology that could lead to increases of 8.5 percent for a one-year lease and 12 percent for a two-year lease. An alternative version calls for increases of 6 percent for one year and 10 percent for two years.
Such increases would be the highest in two decades and drastically higher than in recent times. In five of the last six years, the board has adopted increases of 2 percent for a one-year lease and 4 percent for a two-year lease.
Asked if he supports increases as high as those in the proposals, the mayor said at a news conference: "I think those increases sound very, very high. They were not discussed with me in advance. I had no knowledge of them. So anybody reading them should just calm down and wait. It was a leak of information that at least I didn't know anything about until I heard about it this morning, late last night I guess."
Mr. Giuliani also said, "The thing that was leaked yesterday to the press was not leaked with my knowledge or with the knowledge of City Hall, so nobody should read into that that we've made any decision or any choice about it."
Although by law the mayor has no official role in the annual rent increase decisions, tenant leaders say the Giuliani administration exerts pressure on the board it appoints.
"We've known for a long time that City Hall dictates the rent increases that the rent board promulgates," said Michael McKee, associate director of the New York Sate Tenants and Neighbors Coalition, an advocacy group. "I think they're trying to come up with something like 5 and 7 percent, which would be really excessive, but try to make it look like less because it's not 8.5 and 12 percent."
Earlier yesterday, the rent board had its first internal skirmishes over this year's rent increase proposals, at a meeting that lasted all morning, but no votes were taken.
One member, Agustin Rivera, opposed two of Mr. Hochman's proposals, which landlords favor. The board now imposes rent increases based partly on an index of landlords' operating costs compiled by the board. One proposal would grant inflation-indexed increases in net income for landlords, besides their existing allowances for higher operating costs. The other proposal would exclude from the calculations of landlords' income the 20 percent rent increases that can be charged to the first tenant after a vacancy.
One number that provoked dispute was the 54.8 percent increase in fuel oil prices. A designated tenant representative on the board, Jeffrey Coleman, said that granting a permanent rent increase based on a temporary surge in price would be wrong. But a landlord representative, Harold A. Lubell, said: "We shouldn't pooh-pooh that the numbers are significant. We can't just ignore that."

HEADLINE: Slaying Shows Police Efforts Are No Cure-All for Cabbies

BYLINE: By C. J. CHIVERS 

 BODY:
When a livery cab driven by Jose R. Olivares veered out of control and slammed into a building in the Bronx late Monday, it contained all the elements of a string of crimes that has confounded the police.
Mr. Olivares was dying, bleeding from a gunshot wound to the right side of his head. With him in the cab, a silver Lincoln Town Car that had no bulletproof partition and no security camera, were four teenagers who the police said had tried to rob him after he picked them up on the street. He had let one of the passengers get in the front seat beside him. A loaded .380-caliber semiautomatic pistol that the authorities said was used to shoot him was found tucked behind Mr. Olivares's back. 
 Mr. Olivares, 37, was the eighth livery cabby to be slain this year, the latest in a series of crimes that have mobilized the Police Department and drawn condemnation from community leaders and city officials. The four teenagers were charged in the killing last night. But in the details surrounding Mr. Olivares's death is an illustration of just how hard these crimes are to stop.
Even though the Police Department has deployed hundreds of officers each night on cabby-protection assignments, the officers remain frustrated enough that Police Commissioner Howard Safir faced a bank of television cameras yesterday and appealed to the drivers to take steps to protect themselves. "If you don't have a partition, please do not pick up hails, because you put yourself in great danger," Mr. Safir said. "And certainly do not let anybody in the front seat of your automobile."
In short, the authorities said yesterday, Mr. Olivares's death shows that no single response can protect the cabbies from those who stalk them.
In recent weeks, the police have increased the number of decoy cabs and have begun using the Street Crime Units to make random stops of livery cabs, in the hopes of deterring the killers. But the authorities said yesterday that two elements were still needed to complement their efforts: more safety equipment in the cabs, and changes in cabby behavior.
The death of Mr. Olivares, the authorities said, underscored the importance of both.
Unlike yellow medallion cabs, livery cabs are prohibited by city regulations from picking up passengers on the street, and police data show that more than 80 percent of the robberies this year and six of the eight killings occurred after drivers broke the rules. And yet, in addition to picking up passengers assigned by dispatchers, as they are allowed to do, drivers like Mr. Olivares have continued to stop for fares at the curb, even at night, and even as the homicide tally has been rising.
Moreover, although the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission passed a regulation last week requiring livery drivers to outfit their cars with partitions or security cameras by the middle of May, local glass shops are backlogged by as much as four weeks to meet the sudden demand. Mr. Olivares had a bulletproof partition on order, but even if it had been installed, it would not have protected him from a passenger he had allowed to ride beside him.
The Police Department's message, however, must contend with the realities of transportation in poor neighborhoods and the economics of the livery-cab industry, which all but assure that the drivers will continue to defy the rules.
"The drivers are serving under-served minority neighborhoods," said Fernando A. Mateo, president of the New York State Federation of Taxi Drivers. "They are minorities serving their own people because yellow cabs won't go into these neighborhoods, and because they need the money to put food on their families' tables. When they see someone who wants a ride, they are going to pull over and pick them up. It's going to continue happening."
Given these circumstances, and given the fact that the police have already stepped up their efforts, Mr. Mateo and city officials are holding out hope that the partitions, once installed in the roughly 46,000 livery cabs operating in the city, will slow the rate of killings.
Crime data suggest they might. In 1994, the Taxi and Limousine Commission passed a regulation requiring the fleets of yellow medallion cabs to install approved partitions in their vehicles. Since then, the yellow-cab homicides have virtually stopped. There were nine in 1993, none in 1994, and then one each year through January 1997. Since then there have been none. Yellow cab robberies have also plummeted, from 723 in 1994 to 181 last year.
Direct comparisons are impossible because livery cabs tend to serve neighborhoods that are more crime prone than those served by yellow cabs, and because overall crime rates have been falling since 1994, but officials say these statistics still suggest that partitions could help.
Allan J. Fromberg, spokesman for the Taxi and Limousine Commission, said the statistics were compelling enough that the commission was urging drivers to opt for partitions over the cameras. "We are strongly, strongly encouraging the partitions," Mr. Fromberg said. "Just by virtue of the fact that they are tried and true over the years."
Another element in the cabby-protection effort was proposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday at Shea Stadium. Mr. Giuliani said that ideally the livery cabs would not pick up street hails, but absent that, the city could create so-called green-light zones in which cabbies with partitions could pick up passengers.
These green-light zones, which Mr. Mateo has been pushing in meetings with city officials, would be selected along busy corridors, and would in all likelihood overlap areas where the police are concentrating their efforts. The mayor said he had asked the Taxi and Limousine Commission to consider two or three pilot zones.
"Obviously it would be safer if the livery-cab drivers did not pick up street hails," the mayor said, adding, "We are also realists."
While city officials talked policy, police officers continued to ponder what other factors had caused the killings to increase. William H. Allee Jr., the chief of detectives, said yesterday that detectives did not believe that the killings had been committed by a serial killer or were part of a gang initiation, as some people had speculated last week.
"Other than the fact that most of these appear to have started as street hails, this doesn't seem to have a pattern," the chief said.
Beyond that, the reasons for the increase in killings remain a mystery. The police have said they are puzzled because the rate of livery-cab robberies has not changed in three years, and has remained constant this year as the rate of homicides has surged.
So theories abound. Mr. Mateo and some Street Crime Unit officers said last week the killings might have increased because officers on patrol had been less aggressive since the public outcry last year over the fatal shooting of Amadou Diallo.
Deputy Chief Thomas P. Fahey said yesterday that killings might be on the rise because an inexperienced group of criminals had begun robbing cabs. "You get young people committing crimes with guns in confined spaces, and it is going to turn awful a lot of the time," he said. "Sometimes the people with guns are as nervous as the drivers who are getting robbed."
Some police officials also said that the increase in killings could merely be a statistical blip, for which no explanation would ever emerge. "It might be a blip, but blips can cause big problems," a senior supervisor said. "We're in the business of saving lives, so blips need to be dealt with."

HEADLINE: Two Families, Joined by a Death and Questions of Why

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN and WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM 

 BODY:
John Rivera struggled yesterday afternoon to understand how his son could have crossed over from hanging out with the wrong people to becoming one of them.
Hours earlier, at 10:15 p.m. Monday, yet another livery-cab driver -- the eighth in the city this year -- had been killed, just blocks from Mr. Rivera's Bronx home. 
 Hours later, Mr. Rivera's son, who was a passenger in the cab, was in police custody.
While each of the driver slayings, this one included, offered its own poignant tale of a life violently snatched, this one also may tell of a life indifferently given away.
The police said John Rivera Jr., 19, the son of working-class parents who pushed him toward rectitude, was one of four people involved in the slaying of the driver, 37-year-old Jose R. Olivares.
His father said he hoped it could not be true. "He's not like that; he's not that kind of person," Mr. Rivera said before his son had been officially charged. "I hope he didn't do it."
While Mr. Rivera worried yesterday, another Bronx family grieved for Mr. Olivares, including his sister Gladys, 34, and his three sons: Felix Jose, 9; Jose Renaldo, 12; and Jose, 18.
Ms. Olivares, one of the dead man's nine siblings, said in an interview at her Bronx home that her brother had lived with her for the last three months because he had separated from his common-law wife, Maritza.
Mr. Olivares, a driver for Excellent Car Service, always told people that he was taking extra precautions, his sister said.
"I don't pick up hails, I don't load more than two people in a car, and if I do there has to be a child involved," she remembered him saying.
But Mr. Olivares apparently broke his rule against picking up people who hailed his cab on the street. Just blocks from his home about 10 p.m. Monday, he stopped his car at East 170th Street and the Grand Concourse to let in a young woman and three young men.
A short time later, the police said, as Mr. Olivares was headed west on East 150th Street, one of the passengers shot him in the back of the head with a .380-caliber pistol. The silver 1996 Lincoln Town Car jumped the sidewalk and slammed into an apartment building, injuring all of the passengers, the police said. The car hit the side of 255 Morris Avenue with such force that it crashed through part of a brick and cinder block wall and knocked in a large heavy red metal door.
The gun was found behind Mr. Olivares's back.
All the passengers were trapped in the car, allowing the police to detain them for questioning.
And last night, the younger Mr. Rivera, his girlfriend, Jasmin Valentin, 16, and two of his neighbors at 3050 Park Avenue -- Norberto Hernandez, 16, and Ramon Anaya, 18 -- were charged with second-degree murder, attempted robbery and weapons possession, said Steven Reed, a spokesman for the Bronx district attorney's office.
Mr. Anaya and Mr. Hernandez were critically injured in the crash, and were in stable but guarded condition at Lincoln Hospital last night.
Mr. Olivares drove a cab only in the winter, and was set to switch to his summer job driving a beer truck in a few weeks, his sister said, adding that their mother had called from the Dominican Republic on Monday to say that she had had an odd feeling and was worried about him.
Fernando A. Mateo, the president of the New York State Federation of Taxi Drivers, said yesterday that Mr. Olivares had emigrated from the Dominican Republic a decade ago.
"One of the things that the family is asking themselves today is why him, a man that worked 15 hours a day, a man that worked to support his children, support his family, support his mother back home?" he said.
"They don't know how they're going to tell their mother that her son is going back in a box, in a wooden box, as if he was freight," said Mr. Mateo, who held a news conference at the accident scene.
Mr. Mateo praised the recent efforts by the Giuliani administration and the Police Department to respond to the recent spate of livery killings, by financing partitions and security cameras for some of the city's 41,000 livery drivers, and by setting up a police task force to prevent robberies and killings. But he called on the police to do more, particularly to increase patrols.
Mr. Olivares's car, which he had rented for about three years from the owner, Ramon Brito, 45, had no bulletproof partition to protect the driver. Mr Brito said yesterday that he was scheduled to have one installed on May 30, the earliest date he could get.
The elder Mr. Rivera said that he and his wife, Nydia, had seen their son on Monday night around 9, in the building's lobby. He told them he was going to play basketball.
Mr. Rivera was laid off from his job overseeing the loading dock at Salomon Smith Barney in February. So yesterday, while his wife went to her job as an administrative assistant in Manhattan, using work to distract her from worry, he sat at home, watching the news and awaiting word from the police. He had not yet been able to speak to his son.
It was not, he said, that his son had never been in trouble: he had been arrested twice for smoking marijuana in the back of the building. But as the father saw it, his son was a good kid influenced by bad peers.
"He knows right from wrong," Mr. Rivera said.
After learning at 10:30 last night that his son had been charged with murder, Mr. Rivera seemed to be in shock.
"I need to talk to them," he said haltingly, referring to the authorities. "I don't know what to say right now."
The younger Mr. Rivera was unemployed, and he had dropped out of the High School for Graphic Arts in Manhattan. But he had artistic talent, as evidenced by a scrap of graffiti his father showed, and he planned to start classes toward his general equivalency diploma next week.
Johnny Rivera had reached the age where a firm voice and a daily lecture could no longer corral him, his father said, but that did not stop the elder Mr. Rivera from trying.
Each day, Mr. Rivera said, he would lecture his son about hanging out with the wrong people. Each day, including Monday, he said, his son answered, "They're just my friends; they're not going to do anything."

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
Finding Drama in Life, and Vice Versa

BYLINE: By BEN BRANTLEY 

 BODY:
A lot of advice gets handed out in the thoroughly engrossing new staging of August Wilson's "Jitney," a play written two decades ago but never before seen in Manhattan. Some of that counsel, on subjects from how to treat a woman to how to get ahead in a white man's world, is sensible; some of it is crazy. But there's one bit of wisdom that you're especially glad the play's characters don't heed: "Don't put your business in the street."
As if that were remotely possible in the Hill District of Pittsburgh, the setting of Mr. Wilson's cycle of plays on the black American experience in the 20th century and a place where personal business is always on public parade. In this splendidly acted production, which opened last night at the Second Stage Theater under Marion McClinton's direction, the storefront window of the gypsy cab company that gives "Jitney" its title seems to stretch right up to heaven. 
 You feel as if any conversation, no matter how confidential, has got to include the scarred streetscape that pushes intrusively against the glass with tall-tale vividness in David Gallo's wonderful set. The breath of the city fills the room whenever the office's rotary pay phone rings, which it does with jangling frequency, and whenever a driver comes back from a job.
Real life, whether comic or tragic, is the best show in town in the Hill District. Mr. Wilson's characters get as much of a thrill from sitting in the audience of observers, kibbitzing and criticizing and retelling local dramas, as they do from being the major players. Set in the 1970's, "Jitney" could be described as just a lot of men sitting around talking. But the talk has such varied range and musicality, and it is rendered with such stylish detail, that a complete urban symphony emerges.
"Jitney," which Mr. Wilson has described as the work in which he discovered his dramatist's voice, has been much rewritten since it was first produced in Pittsburgh in 1982. (This latest revision has been seen, with some variations, throughout the country over the past several years.) It still hasn't found its perfect shape. Its sentimental ending feels hammered on, with the nails showing, and a couple of the work's pivotal confrontations have a whiff of assembly-line melodrama.
Yet under Mr. McClinton's sensitive and democratic direction, which treats all the performers equally as both soloists and members of a chorus, "Jitney" holds its audience in charmed captivity for its two and a half hours. And for those unfamiliar with Mr. Wilson, the author of masterworks like "Ma Rainey's Black Bottom" and "Joe Turner's Come and Gone," it offers a perfect introduction to a writer who never created a character who (to borrow an image from "Joe Turner") didn't have his own individual song to sing.
By Wilson standards "Jitney" is slim on plot. It is a rare work from this author that introduces a loaded gun, as this one does, and then doesn't use it. The principal sources of tension come from the threat that the makeshift taxi company may be shut down by the city, and from the implosive relationship between Becker (Paul Butler), who runs the company, and his son, Booster (Carl Lumbly), who has just finished serving a 20-year prison sentence.
The reciprocal guilt and needs of father and son, which Mr. Wilson has explored more subtly in subsequent works, are among the less persuasive aspects of "Jitney." What gives the play its extraordinary verve is how the characters define themselves -- and by extension, the hardscrabble world in which they exist -- through bristling dialogue and tasty anecdote.
In the first scene alone, two drivers return from jobs with stories that summon an entire ethos. Turnbo (Stephen McKinley Henderson), the company yenta, describes having driven a passenger who has just stolen his grandmother's television set; Youngblood (Russell Hornsby), the youngest of the drivers, speaks of having seen a woman known as Cigar Annie, who has just been evicted from her house, standing in the middle of the street cursing everyone from God to the gas man while holding up her skirt.
Doub (Barry Shabaka Henley), the quietest member of the group, offers an explanation for Annie's behavior that cuts through the lewd joking of the other men: "She was raising up her dress 'cause that's all anybody ever wanted from her since she was 12 years old."
These two stories, and the varied reactions to them, establish what twirls the world of "Jitney": economic anxiety and sexual attraction, both of which breed endless complications. The issue of whether anyone is fool enough to lend the alcoholic Fielding (Anthony Chisholm) the grand sum of $4 creates the play's first moments of conflict.
And the war, or alternately the armed truce, between men and women is manifested in everything from the usual lover's quarrels (which also involve money) between Youngblood and Rena (Michole Briana White), the mother of his child, to the story of the crime of passion that sent Booster to jail. The variations on the theme, which include a glorious monologue about a girlfriend's hex, delivered by Willis Burks II as a numbers runner, are delicious, always sparked by some skewed detail that turns the familiar into the memorable.
Mr. Wilson brings the same open-ended eloquence to both meandering monologues and terse chains of phrases. (Booster on his first day out of prison: "I don't know what to think. People going everywhere. All up and down. Dogs and cats.") The performers individualize that language with the personal rifflike deliveries of jazz artists.
These are all performances to savor, from the mannered rasp and baroque gestures of Mr. Chisholm's hard-drinking, slow-moving Fielding to the bass-voiced, anchoring authority of Mr. Butler's superb Becker. The ensemble members, who also include Leo V. Finnie III as a hotel doorman, have developed a feeling for one another's rhythms that usually comes only with long acquaintance.
The respect for both personal idiosyncrasy and a harmonic whole is confirmed in the production's every detail: from Susan Hilferty's expertly varied costumes to Donald Holder's emotion-enhancing lighting. And in the play's final scene, every time you think the dialogue is heading toward a foregone conclusion, Mr. Wilson spins it in another, perspective-changing direction.
Whether debating the subject of who is prettier, Lena Horne or Sarah Vaughan, or erupting into a fistfight, the inhabitants of "Jitney" nearly always act in exactly the way they speak. You seldom think of one of them, "Well, he wouldn't do that," which is less often true in theater than you might imagine.
If this is a play in which a significant artist was just learning how to make his characters talk, you rarely sense any corresponding uncertainty of tone in the current version. Mr. Wilson, Mr. McClinton and their excellent band of actors make us feel that we have known these people -- with whom we have spent only a couple of hours, after all -- for most of our lives.
 
JITNEY
By August Wilson; directed by Marion McClinton; sets by David Gallo; costumes by Susan Hilferty; lighting by Donald Holder; sound by Rob Milburn; fight director, David S. Leong; production stage manager, Narda Alcorn; stage manager, Mike Schleifer. Associate artistic director, Christopher Burney; general manager, C. Barrack Evans; production manager, Peter J. Davis. Presented by Second Stage Theater, Carole Rothman, artistic director; Carol Fishman, managing director; Alexander Fraser, executive director, and Center Theater Group/Mark Taper Forum, in association with Sageworks, Benjamin Mordecai, producer. At 307 West 43rd Street, Clinton.

HEADLINE: Rightist in Canada's West Has Eyes Set on Ottawa

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: CALGARY, Alberta, April 20

 BODY:
In Canada, a social welfare nation that has more tax collectors than soldiers, Stockwell Day has commanded a fiscal revolution in his province in the shadow of the Rocky Mountains.
Mr. Day, the treasurer of Alberta, has eliminated the province's net debt, cut provincial income taxes to the nation's lowest levels, and plans next January to put into effect Canada's first flat tax on income -- 11 percent. 
 "You could calculate your income tax on the back of your business card," said Mr. Day, an athletic 49-year-old who has a knack for being photographed playing volleyball, in-line skating or practicing tae kwon do kicks in a T-shirt with sleeves rolled up to display his biceps.
Now Mr. Day wants to bring his conservative revolution to the rest of Canada, hoping that next year he will become prime minister, only the second one from western Canada in nearly four decades.
In the past, such western dreams foundered on the rock of Ontario, a powerhouse province whose districts account for slightly more than one-third of the 301 seats in Canada's House of Commons.
In the last elections, in 1997, the Liberal Party won only 38 percent of the nationwide vote, but it won almost all of Ontario's seats because the conservative vote, also 38 percent, split neatly between the two right-wing parties.
But after a decade of stagnating spending power, rising taxes and a brain drain to the United States, Canada's frustrated conservatives are showing a greater willingness to unite. One month ago, the Reform Party, originally a western protest movement, voted to convert itself into a new national party, the Canadian Alliance.
Canadians complain that, largely because inflation brought people into higher tax brackets, average disposable incomes slipped to about two-thirds of American incomes, and some economists think they will drop to half American levels by the end of the decade. Canada's maximum capital gains tax, 38 percent, is almost double the American rate, discouraging investment.
The emigration of skilled workers to the United States has doubled from the rates a decade ago.
"We are tired of the brain drain," said Rod Love, a campaign adviser here for Mr. Day. "We are tired of our kids going to the States because of the high taxes." Referring to Ontario's traditional reluctance to embrace candidates from the nation's western "periphery," he added, "Central Canadians have gotten to the point where they say, 'If a western Canadian can fix it, we don't care if the next leader is from Tierra del Fuego.' "
So far, the two major candidates for leading the new party are both Albertans: Mr. Day, and Preston Manning, an owlish 57-year-old member of Parliament who founded the Reform Party 13 years ago. Although Mr. Manning is endorsed by half of the Alliance's 58-member parliamentary delegation, party supporters complain that in three national elections the Reform Party under Mr. Manning's leadership has failed to make electoral inroads in central Canada. In an Environics Research Group poll completed in mid-April, Canadian Alliance supporters backed Mr. Day over Mr. Manning 43 percent to 30 percent.
But on April 27 an Ontario candidate intends to throw his hat in the ring to lead the new party. He is Tom Long, a 41-year-old strategist who devised the two victories of Ontario's Conservative Premier, Mike Harris, in votes by provincial legislature members. The conservative political machinery in a province with four times Alberta's population comes with Mr. Long's candidacy.
"Long's presence is a huge asset for the Alliance, whether he wins or not," said Sid Noel, a political science professor at the University of Western Ontario. Joe Clark, western Canada's last Prime Minister, would be left behind in the merger, presiding over a shrinking rump of the Progressive Conservative Party.
With two months to go until the leadership vote, it seems unlikely that any candidate will win with 50 percent on the first round. Most political analysts predict that the future leader of Canada's right will emerge in a second ballot, on July 8.
If elections in Prince Edward Island on April 17 are any indicator, the Liberals' seven-year grip on power in Canada is slipping. There, in the smallest of Canada's 10 provinces, Progressive Conservative candidates won 26 of the provincial Legislature's 27 seats, up from 19 before.
With national elections believed to be one year away, the Alliance offers a conservative alternative to a nation often seen as being on an ideological plane with Scandinavian socialism.
In a nation where the top 12 percent of tax filers pay 57 percent of the tax revenue, the Canadian Alliance platform calls instead for a 17 percent flat federal tax and faster repayment of the federal debt.
Mr. Long's fiscal creed is "flatter, simpler, and lower taxes." Speaking to a founding conference of the Alliance, he said, "Trusting the Liberals to deliver real tax cuts would be like shipping lettuce by rabbit."
On social issues, the Alliance wants to toughen sentencing and parole requirements for criminals and curb the expansion of timber and fishing rights for Canada's aboriginals. Reform Party politicians have generally favored the death penalty, opposed gun control and opposed extending marriage rights and job discrimination protection to homosexuals.
One of the first politicians to appreciate the potential of the Alliance was Prime Minister Jean Chretien, 66, a Liberal who hopes to win re-election to a third term. Last month, he attacked Mr. Day as "an extreme conservative."
"We don't want a party that is very much in the hands of the fundamentalists of the right," he said in a veiled reference to Mr. Day, a former lay pastor at an evangelical church in Alberta. Referring to Alliance calls for a national referendum on abortion, he added, "Canadians do not want a party that threatens a woman's right to choose."
Apparently in response, Mr. Day seems to be trying to cultivate an image of tolerance. "Any church, any synagogue, any mosque, any casino, any beer hall, any dance hall where there are Canadians who want to talk about an agenda of respect, I'll be there," he said when announcing his own campaign.
On a recent visit to Montreal, he praised a cooking show host who campaigns against antigay prejudice, saying, "My beliefs don't stop me from respecting people who think in a different way, or who adopt a different life style."
A few days later, Mr. Day was on the nation's front pages, recalling that, 30 years ago, he smoked marijuana -- and inhaled. Mr. Day, who lived and went to high school in Montreal and is the only French speaker of the major leadership candidates, also appears to want to soften his party's anti-Quebec image.
But to some, Mr. Day is trying to camouflage deeply held right-wing views. "By Quebec standards, Mr. Day, with his antiquated views on gay rights, abortion and the death penalty, looks even more alien," Lysiane Gagnon, political columnist for the Montreal newspaper La Presse, wrote this week. "Quebec's politics are anything but religious, and evangelical ministers belong to another world."
Michael A. Phair, a city councilman in Edmonton, Alberta's capital, agreed. "His view of the world that we live in is very narrow," said Mr. Phair, one of Alberta's few openly gay politicians.
Last month, on his first campaign foray to Toronto, Mr. Day was greeted by a small group chanting: "Stockwell Day go away. Anti-choice. Anti-gay."
But as Mr. Day looks beyond his home district of Red Deer to the national stage, he plays down earlier conservative social stands, sometimes saying they are issues that should be decided in national referendums. His Web site biography emphasizes his political experience: 14 years in the provincial legislature and provincial ministerial portfolios in labor, social services and treasury.
While 30 percent of Americans describe themselves as born-again Christians, only 10 percent of Canadians do. Consequently, in this highly secular country, Mr. Day's biography makes no mention of his evangelical beliefs and religious work. He describes himself as "someone willing to take on the forces of political correctness in speaking for the silent majority."
While liberal journalists try to sink his candidacy with past statements on homosexuality and abortion, Mr. Day has proved to be skilled at reinventing himself. During the 15 years he spent between college and politics, he worked as a deckhand on his father's fishing trawler, cut trees as a lumberjack in British Columbia and drove heavy oil-field equipment in the Northwest Territories.
He has honed his skills as a persuasive speaker working as an auctioneer, a drapery salesman and, once, as a chicken peddler, selling from the back of his father's car. Although he is a college dropout, he recently gave a 21-page statistics-laden budget speech, without notes.
"Say this about Stockwell Day," Robert Lewis, editor of the nation's leading newsweekly, Maclean's, wrote recently. "Not since Pierre Trudeau dove into a swimming pool during an election campaign has an aspiring federal leader looked so good with his shirt off."

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about Stockwell Day, a conservative politician from Western Canada who hopes to become prime minister next year, misstated the precedent for Western Canadians. If elected, Mr. Day would be the fourth in nearly four decades, not the second. The article also referred incorrectly to Joe Clark, a former prime minister who would be left out of a proposed merger of conservative parties. He was not the last prime minister from Western Canada; Kim Campbell of British Columbia was, in 1993.

HEADLINE: NEWS WATCH;
An Otter Webcam, With Plenty of Cavorting

BYLINE: By HENRY FOUNTAIN 

 BODY:
Jeannie and Glenn Chambers have a day-care center of sorts operating in their Columbia, Mo., home. Their charges wrestle on a rug, climb on a plastic play set and cavort in a pool.
They also sleep in a box and eat off the floor, but the child welfare authorities will not be knocking anytime soon. The Chamberses are ardent conservationists, and their charges are two river otters, Splash and Slide, which they are raising as part of an educational campaign. 
 Web surfers can catch the animals at play via National Geographic's ottercam, www.nationalgeographic.com/ottercam. There are two cameras available at the site, one indoors and one outside, and visitors can zoom and pan both of them. Nimble mousework is required, though, as the otters move fast.
The site also features video clips of otters in the wild and a map showing where the otters are found in North America (and where they are being reintroduced). There are also electronic "otter postcards" ready for sending, and plenty of links to other sites containing lesson plans for teachers and other educational material about the animals. HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

THE AMERICAS
 
COLOMBIA: PEACE AIDE QUITS
The government's top peace official resigned after rebels of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia threatened to step up a longstanding campaign of extortion and kidnapping against the rich. Peace Commissioner Victor Ricardo, left, denied his decision was linked to death threats from rightist paramilitary gangs. But he voiced outrage at a communique announcing that the rebels would begin abducting millionaires and executives of companies worth more than $1 million who refused to pay tribute to the 17,000-strong rebel force. (Reuters)
 
MEXICO: U.S. OBSERVER DEPORTED
Ted Lewis, the director for Mexico of the San Francisco human rights group Global Exchange, was detained by immigration agents in Guadalajara and deported. Mr. Lewis was organizing 40 foreign professors to study election conditions before the July 2 presidential balloting. The autonomous Federal Electoral Institute had approved his credentials as an election observer. Sam Dillon (NYT) 

CHILE: PINOCHET HEARING
An appeals court opened a hearing into arguments about whether it should strip Gen. Augusto Pinochet of his legislative immunity as a senator before he can stand trial for human rights violations that occurred during his rule between 1973 and 1990. The three-day hearing is only the beginning of what promises to be a long legal battle. If General Pinochet loses his immunity, defense lawyers are expected to appeal to the Supreme Court. Clifford Krauss (NYT)
 
EUROPE
 
TURKEY: OPPOSITION TO CANDIDATE
The presidential candidate supported by major political party leaders, Ahmet Necdet Sezer, faced quiet but growing opposition before today's first ballot. Some members of Parliament, which must choose the next president, said they had been told Mr. Sezer was either too liberal, too sympathetic to Islam, or too critical of the military. The speaker of Parliament, Yildirim Akbulut, is his most prominent opponent. Stephen Kinzer (NYT)
 
BRITAIN: SELF-DEFENSE DISPUTE
The Conservative leader William Hague called for a radical overhaul of the law of self-defense after a public outcry over the murder conviction of a Norfolk man who shot an intruder at his farm. Chief Constable Crispian Strachan of the rural Northumbria police said the law permitting use of "reasonable force" worked well enough and that Mr. Hague's idea would generate American levels of violent assault and killing in Britain. Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
SPAIN: PREMIER WINS APPROVAL
Parliament voted 202 to 148 to approve a second term for the center-right prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, whom voters re-elected on March 12 with an unexpected outright majority. In the two-day investiture debate, Mr. Aznar, 47, promised more reforms to maintain economic growth and a firm stance against armed Basque separatists. (NYT)
 
SPAIN: 5 CONVICTED IN BASQUE DEATHS
Gen. Enrique Rodriguez Galindo of the Civil Guard and four other officials who also served under Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez were sentenced to up to 71 years each in prison for their roles in the 1983 murders of two suspected members of the Basque separatist group E.T.A. Two people were acquitted, including a former senior interior ministry official. It was the second major trial looking into a shadowy campaign blamed for the deaths of 27 suspected Basque rebels in the 1980's. (NYT)
 
KOSOVO: ALBANIAN PROTEST
Some 10,000 ethnic Albanians jammed Pristina to demand the release of thousands of Kosovo Albanians held in Serbian jails. More than 2,000 ethnic Albanians arrested in the 18-month Serbian crackdown on the Kosovo Liberation Army were taken to Serbia before NATO's bombing campaign forced Yugoslav troops and the police to withdraw and hand the province over to United Nations administrators and international peacekeepers. (AP)
 
ASIA
 
INDIA: DROUGHT RELIEF
The government has begun a large-scale relief effort for the drought-stricken states of Rajasthan and Gujarat. It will send wheat and rice, fodder for cattle and water to the hardest-hit areas. Officials say the country has ample grain stores to prevent a famine. No deaths have been attributed to the drought. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)
 
AFGHANISTAN: PRISONERS FREED
The ruling Taliban released about 300 opposition prisoners from jail under a decree by the movement's supreme leader, Mullah Mohammad Omar, officials said. The head of the jail said the freed men included those who had committed minor offenses and those who had promised to serve the Taliban, which controls most of the country. (Agence France-Presse)

Barbara Crossette (NYT)
