HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
'Remember' Florio, Foe Says

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:

 This 30-second commercial, titled "Remember," was released yesterday by Jon S. Corzine in his campaign for the Democratic nomination for United States Senate from New Jersey. It is being broadcast by television stations in New York and Philadelphia.
 
 PRODUCER Shrum, Devine & Donilon. 

 ON THE SCREEN The ad begins with unflattering close-up pictures of Mr. Corzine's opponent, Jim Florio, the former governor, giving a campaign speech with a scowl on his face. Because the speech is shown in slow motion, Mr. Florio appears to be shouting. Subtitles amplify the script: "$2.8 billion tax increase," "280,000 lost jobs." The ad then cuts to now-familiar scenes of Mr. Corzine, smiling genially, greeting and talking with a counterman and patrons at a diner.

THE SCRIPT Narrator: "Remember? When Jim Florio was governor? A $2.8 billion tax increase; 280,000 lost jobs; 200,000 more people without health insurance. Auto insurance rates out of control. New Jersey's economy left in shambles. Do we want to go back to that? Jon Corzine is a new voice for New Jersey. Welcome to the future. Jon Corzine. Democrat for Senate."
 
 ACCURACY Mr. Florio was governor from 1990 to 1994, during a brutal nationwide recession. Soon after taking office he forced a $2.8 billion tax increase through the Legislature, then controlled by Democrats, to increase aid to needy school districts. Mr. Corzine says that during such a deep recession, the tax increases were a terribly wrongheaded move.
 The ad's reference to 280,000 lost jobs is identical to a claim Christine Todd Whitman made repeatedly in defeating Mr. Florio in 1993, but in fact, the decline in nonfarm employment from January 1990 to August 1993 was 205,300 jobs, according to federal statistics. While the ad's claims about the number of people without health insurance and skyrocketing auto insurance rates are accurate, it is impossible to say to what degree Mr. Florio's administration was to blame.
 
 SCORECARD With this commercial, Mr. Corzine begins what his campaign has long promised: a direct assault on Mr. Florio's record. Mr. Corzine, a relative unknown, still trails the former governor in the polls. But Mr. Corzine's advisers say that when voters are reminded of Mr. Florio's tax increases, which set off a "Dump Florio" movement that swept him and hundreds of other New Jersey Democrats from office, they view Mr. Corzine much more favorably. For good measure, Mr. Corzine's ad casts him as the Democratic candidate of "the future," while linking Mr. Florio to New Jersey's unpleasant economic past. Meanwhile, Mr. Florio's underfinanced campaign has broadcast no ads and remains unable to respond in kind. DAVID M. HALBFINGER

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Union Wins, And 15 Lose Their Jobs

BYLINE: By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
EVERY workday for the last 12 1/2 years, Melida Thomas has been going to her job at 80 Centre Street in Lower Manhattan, to the State Office of Temporary and Disability Assistance, where she is one of 15 clerical workers.
In this office, which reviews city decisions about welfare and food stamp eligibility, she files, enters facts into the computer, looks up names and addresses. 
 By all accounts, Ms. Thomas and her co-workers do their jobs well. And they are about to be fired. A union has fought for 13 years to make the system work. The union finally won its argument. So these 15 workers lose.
Here is what happened. The state began, in 1987, to fill clerical jobs in this office with temporary workers hired through private employment agencies. The 15 workers have been on the job from 4 to 13 years.
Theoretically, people working in state offices would be members of the Civil Service Employees Association. But that would mean 15 more people on the state payroll, receiving benefits and a living wage.
Ms. Thomas, who is 49 and has two children, does not get vacations or sick leave, and her health insurance is Medicaid. "When we don't work, we don't get paid," she explained. "They promise us they will make us state workers. But they keep on extending the time."
The smaller its work force, the more government saves. Ms. Thomas and most of her co-workers earn $7.50 an hour and work 40-hour weeks. That's $300 a week before taxes -- $15,600 a year; the employment agency also gets fees from the state.
Equivalent unionized jobs pay $22,650 to $28,000 a year, depending on a worker's experience and other variables. The union workers get at least a week off every year, paid holidays and, after six months, medical and dental benefits and a pension.
Expensive. So until now, the state took advantage of a provision in its agreement with the union that permits the hiring of temporary workers, short term. Of course, 13 years is not short term. The union went to court. In February 1999, the parties settled: the 15 jobs would be unionized.
Obvious solution. But most of the 15 workers (who learned about the settlement just last month) had never taken the Civil Service test, and those who did last year failed. Maybe it's because they are all Hispanic, not fluent in English, suggested Stacy Kaufman, an administrative law judge who works with them.
"But they are doing the jobs," she said. "They are devoted. Each does the job extremely well. They work right next to people earning more. They've proven very competent to do their jobs."
Daniel D. Hogan, spokesman for the office in Albany, agreed: "These people have been in their jobs a long time, working in a tough area for us, and did a good job. We definitely feel for them."
But the state has no choice, he said. "We have to let them go. We think it's a shame."
Stephen Madarasz, a union spokesman, said, "Obviously we don't want to see anybody put out of work, but sometimes circumstances aren't black and white."
Several of the 15 workers took the Civil Service test again in February. They don't know the results yet, but even if they pass, they will probably not be hired.
"The way the union rules are, it will be hard for them to get into state employment," Mr. Hogan said. "There are other people on waiting lists who scored well on the Civil Service tests. It's a pretty tough situation for them."
THE workers will probably be let go soon, he and others said.
Asked why they didn't take the test earlier, several workers said they didn't understand that they had to be civil servants; after all, they were working steadily, some for years. "Nobody was talking to me about the test before," said Carmello O'Neill, 54, a messenger with the office for the last six years who once worked in a hotel kitchen. Before that, he was on welfare.
Mr. O'Neill, who came here from Puerto Rico and has three children, says he will look for another job, but is worried about finding himself on welfare again. "I don't want to go back."
Ms. Thomas says that if she loses her job, she will go on unemployment and look for a job.
The administrative law judge, Ms. Kaufman, said she understood the need to unionize the jobs, but was concerned about the workers: "This is exploitation by the state and the union. We're asking for an exception to policy."
Not likely, said Mr. Madarasz, the union spokesman. "We don't want to be cold about it, but we don't have an obligation to people who are not members of our union."
And that is how the system works. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Guyana Airline Owner Scents New Growth in Old Backwater

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: GEORGETOWN, Guyana

 BODY:
Flying over this country's bountiful rain forest in a noisy propeller plane seating nine people can unnerve the most seasoned traveler. And what if the pilot shows up wearing sneakers and a T-shirt?
"Not in this company, mister," said Gerald Gouveia, the owner of Roraima Airways, an upstart Guyanese airline. After Mr. Gouveia saw the unsettling effect such attire could have on foreign visitors, he decreed a dress code for his pilots: tie, slacks and black leather shoes. 
 "Even if we must sweat," said the 44-year-old executive, clad in such clothing because he sometimes pilots his company's planes, one hot day here in Guyana's capital.
Mr. Gouveia is one of the more outspoken business executives in Guyana, the only English-speaking nation in South America. Working to discard more than two decades of isolation after independence from Britain in 1966, Guyana's economy has slowly become more capitalistic over the last decade, and people like Mr. Gouveia are leading the way.
He got his start in aviation in the armed forces, where he spent 15 years, eventually rising to chief pilot of the army air corps. During that time he got some experience working under pressure after the mass suicide late in 1978 of more than 900 followers of Jim Jones, the doomsday cult leader who constructed a city, Jonestown, in Guyana's interior.
"The smell of the place was disgusting, but there I was -- flying the world's media into the middle of nowhere," Mr. Gouveia said in lilted Guyanese English that resembles the accent of Jamaica. "What a rush!"
After leaving the military, Mr. Gouveia moved north, like many of his countrymen, to Canada, where he worked as a flight instructor in Montreal.
In fact, more Guyanese still live outside the country than in it, leaving the population at little more than 700,000. The largest communities of Guyanese abroad are in Toronto and in New York, where as many as 130,000 people are largely concentrated in Richmond Hill, Ozone Park and Jamaica, Queens; and in Crown Heights and Flatbush, Brooklyn.
Although the financial stability to be found in North America was attractive, he returned to Guyana in the early 1990's to work for Golden Star, a Canadian mining company, organizing their transportation for a large gold-mining operation in the interior.
Then, in 1992, elections brought in a government perceived as more favorable than its predecessor to private investment. So after some market-friendly changes, like the privatization of the national telephone company and the awarding of a concession to a Malaysian concern for a large-scale timber operation, he started his own airline eight years ago.
Mr. Gouveia called it Roraima Airways after Mount Roraima, the remote peak that serves as the backdrop of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's adventure novel "The Lost World." It is also where the borders of Guyana, Brazil and Venezuela meet, a region of economic potential if Guyana chooses to forge stronger ties with its South American neighbors.
With that idea in mind, Mr. Gouveia initiated the first regularly scheduled flights between Guyana and Brazil, linking Boa Vista, a city in the upper reaches of the Brazilian Amazon, to Georgetown. But lack of passenger demand on the route soon made Roraima Airways drop it.
Mr. Gouveia attributed this lack of demand to concern among some Guyanese government officials over the possibility of their small country becoming a mere appendage to its neighbor to the south, with 170 million people.
Recently, though, progress has been made in strengthening Guyanese ties with Brazil with the forming of a tourism and trade commission headed by Mr. Gouveia. Although he is still critical of what he calls foot-dragging, he said that "Guyana is realizing that much of its future is linked to better Brazilian relations."
Commonly called Gerry, or Captain Gerry, Mr. Gouveia is known for his blunt criticism of Guyana's government. The country's politics remain polarized by race issues, and though people from different racial backgrounds mix freely on the streets of Georgetown, they tend to vote along ethnic lines.
Still, a vibrant democracy has emerged, enabling people to express their views. Since 1992, the Indo-Guyanese majority, descended from people from the Indian subcontinent, has governed the country, after more than two decades of rule by Afro-Guyanese -- those descended from Africans.
Mr. Gouveia is a member of still another minority, the Portuguese, descended from laborers from Portugal who came to Guyana more than a century ago.
Mr. Gouveia's biggest feud with the authorities came a year ago, after he acquired the country's first civilian helicopter. With the new machine, he hoped to organize tourist expeditions into rain forest lodges and to fly supplies to mining camps.
But soon, the army began competing with him, using its helicopters to organize sorties into the interior. And because the army did not pay taxes on fuel, it charged less, eventually squeezing Roraima Airways out of the helicopter business.
"Gerry's a little bitter about the helicopter issue," said Moses Nagamootoo, the minister of information. "But we're a very poor country. We encouraged our army to get into things like farming, or to use their helicopters to make a little extra money. What harm is there in having an army that is not in dire straits?"
Facing such obstacles, Mr. Gouveia does not expect to become another Richard Branson anytime soon. His fleet comprises three small planes, none of them jets. And his company is smaller than the country's two other airlines, Guyana Airways and Trans-Guyana. Still, that does not stop him from thinking big.
"We've got it all in Guyana for a big air travel market -- the preserved natural beauty, the natural resources, the exports," he said, counting on his fingers the nation's production of rice, sugar, timber and gold. "It takes a crazy capitalist like me to get off the sidelines and make sure we don't lose this chance."

HEADLINE: After 2 Months of Declines, Durable Goods Bounce Back

BYLINE: NYTimes.com/TheStreet.com 

 BODY:
Orders for big-ticket durable goods bounced back in March after two consecutive months of declines, the government said yesterday. The number was helped by a substantial rebound in transportation orders after Boeing reached a contract agreement with 17,000 striking engineers.
Orders for durable goods like appliances, vehicles and aircraft jumped 2.6 percent in March, compared with a revised decline of 2 percent in February and a 1.9 percent decline in January, the Commerce Department reported. 
 The report, showing growing capital spending by businesses, is the latest indication that the economy continues to enjoy robust growth.
"Competitive pressures are forcing businesses to maintain high levels of capital spending, and strong global growth spells strong demand for U.S. capital goods since over 40 percent of all U.S. exports are capital goods," said Anthony Crescenzi, market analyst and chief executive of fixed-income and economics analysis at the Bondtalk.com Web site.
The report comes a day before the government releases its preliminary estimate of economic growth in the first quarter. Economists expect the report to show that the economy grew at a 6 percent annual rate in the quarter, after the fourth quarter's torrid 7.3 percent pace.
Though the rebound in large part reflected a 1.8 percent jump in transportation orders, other sectors also showed healthy growth in orders. Orders for electronics and electric equipment were up 9.7 percent, while those for primary metals rose 0.5 percent. Within the transportation sector, orders for civilian aircraft were up 10 percent, after falling 25.9 percent in February.
Excluding transportation, durable goods orders were up 2.8 percent in March, and excluding military-related goods, orders rose 3.7 percent.
Orders for industrial machinery and equipment, which include personal computer orders, fell 2.1 percent in March after dropping 3.8 percent the month before.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Investors Retreat Fearing the Release of Inflationary Data

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks retreated yesterday as investors stepped lightly ahead of important economic data, overshadowing the positive effect of solid profit reports.
Although analysts said news of a 2.6 percent increase in March durable goods orders was not inflationary, the trend irked Wall Street a day before the report on gross domestic product, which is expected to show that the economy is still moving along at a rapid pace. 
 "There is a little bit of profit taking and a little bit of nervousness as we go into Thursday's number," said Barry Hyman, market strategist for Ehrenkrantz, King Nussbaum Inc. "The durable goods number was a little stronger than expected. That shows continued strength in the economy. That is not what you want to see right now."
The blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average lost 179.32 points, or 1.61 percent, to 10,945.50, a day after closing with a 218-point gain.
Interest-rate-sensitive financial stocks pressured the gauge after climbing higher for several sessions. American Express fell 3 3/8, to 154 5/8, and J. P. Morgan & Company slipped 3 3/8, to 134 9/16.
The Dow's manufacturing and consumer products names also moved lower, with Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing off 4 7/8, to 88 15/16, and Procter & Gamble down 3 3/4 at 60 9/16.
Technology stocks weakened despite pockets of strength in the computer chip and Internet sectors. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 81.14 points, or 2.19 percent, to 3,630.09, after surging 6.6 percent on Tuesday.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 16.45 points, or 1.11 percent, to 1,460.99, and the Wilshire 5000 index ended down 158.76 points, or 1.17 percent, at 13,449.27.
Before the market opened, the Commerce Department reported that orders for big-ticket items like airplanes and industrial machines picked up 2.6 percent in March, much higher than the 1.8 percent expected by economists polled by Reuters.
That pressured stocks as Wall Street awaited what market players said was more important economic data expected today, with reports on first-quarter wage data and gross domestic product, a crucial barometer of overall economic growth.
"It's very important because it shows you if this trend continues," Larry Rice, chief investment officer at Josephthal Lyon & Ross, said of the data due today.
Investors are becoming increasingly concerned about the threat of an uptick in inflation, with Federal Reserve policy makers set to meet again on May 16 to consider whether to raise interest rates. The Fed has increased short-term rates five times, by a total of 1.25 percentage points, since last June in an effort to keep inflation in check.
The pullback in the Nasdaq yesterday was largely expected by technical analysts who doubted that Tuesday's rally had legs, noting that the gauge had not bottomed out and should retest the lows hit during the slide of the last month.
Richard McCabe, chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch, said he saw resistance at the 3,800 to 3,850 levels for Nasdaq. If the gauge broke those barriers, it would again find resistance at around 4,100 to 4,200, Mr. McCabe said.
"This whippy action of the market is enough to break any investor's neck," said Robert Dickey, technical analyst at Dain Rauscher. "The difficult task is determining whether the market is still in a correcting period, or if it has bottomed and is now turning more bullish again.
"On the Nasdaq, the pattern is still that of lower highs and lower lows, which by definition is a downtrend," he said.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Fall
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Treasury bond prices fell yesterday on concern that five interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve had not slowed the economy enough to keep inflation from accelerating.
"With expected strong inflation numbers tomorrow, that's drawing the market's focus back to the economy" and away from trading off the stock market, said Dawn Baillie, who manages $1 billion at John Hancock Funds in Boston. Ms. Baillie has reduced her Treasury holdings since March to 60 percent to 65 percent from 70 percent to add higher yielding government agency and mortgage-backed debt.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 4/32, to 104 9/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.94 percent from 5.93 percent on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Vietnam Circles Slightly Closer to Military Ties to U.S.

SERIES: VIETNAM TODAY -- This is part of a series exploring aspects of Vietnam, 25 years after the fall of Saigon on April 30, 1975.

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26

 BODY:
Last November, on Veterans Day, Maj. Joseph M. Gaines of the Air Force circled the airfield at Hue, in central Vietnam, and then landed his military cargo plane filled with emergency supplies of plastic sheeting, blankets and water bottles.
On one level it was a standard relief mission, intended to help flood victims, and it was over in less than 12 hours. But it was also a milestone: Major Gaines and his team were the first uniformed members of the United States armed forces to undertake a mission in Vietnam since the last few American troops pulled out in 1975. 
 The visit represented the quandary that confronts Vietnam 25 years later: that the victor of the war now needs the loser to build the security and prosperity that have so long eluded it.
"The U.S. is the No. 1 country we want to help us in security issues, in military issues and in economic issues," said Le Van Bang, Vietnam's ambassador to the United States. "But the war is always in the background."
Despite the passage of time, Vietnam has remained reluctant to allow any American troops back into the country. Hanoi recently refused another American offer to help remove land mines and unexploded ordnance, saying it feared that too many American soldiers would be seen around the country and be heckled.
It is just as possible that they were afraid that American soldiers would be given a hero's welcome, like the one that greeted Major Gaines.
"When we touched down I stepped out, and people came up to me to give me flowers, stuff to drink," the major said. "They were really happy to see us."
He was just 14 when Saigon fell to Communist forces on April 30, 1975, ending a war that killed three million Vietnamese and 58,000 Americans.
Major Gaines's mission opened the way to the first visit to Hanoi by an American defense secretary: William S. Cohen went to Vietnam last month.
An impoverished nation with a shrunken army, Vietnam needs the access Washington could give it to the modern training and equipment that would put it on an equal footing with its more prosperous neighbors in Southeast Asia.
With the breakup of the Soviet Union in 1991, Vietnam lost its oldest military ally and patron, leaving it weak and alone as it faces a possible confrontation with China over competing territorial claims in the South China Sea.
But although the United States lifted a trade embargo against Vietnam in 1994 and the two countries established diplomatic relations in 1995, Vietnam has yet to approve a trade agreement and has hesitated at establishing fuller military-to-military relations, which might include regular port calls, weapon sales, training at top American military war colleges and joint exercises.
"We want to have full normal military relations, but we aren't ready yet," said Ambassador Le.
For its part, Washington would like to see Vietnam safely ensconced in an informal security community with the other members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, a goal often articulated by Adm. Dennis Blair, the commander of United States forces in the Pacific.
Apart from Vietnamese resistance to dealings with the American military, China has warned against any military partnership between Washington and Hanoi that might suggest a threat on its southern border.
Pentagon officials insist that they would never jeopardize relations with China to get closer to Vietnam, which today has little strategic importance for the United States. But that assessment could change.
"Good relations with Vietnam will be important if China ever got aggressive, but those are things we don't want to talk about," said Michael O'Hanlon, a military analyst at the Brookings Institution.
Even if barriers remain, Major Gaines's breaching of the one last fall represents a significant accomplishment, one that took 20 years to achieve, as well as $500 million and the disparate efforts of American veterans.
In the aftermath of America's military defeat, it became a point of honor and a political requirement in Washington that neither diplomatic nor military relations could be opened with Hanoi until questions about missing Americans were resolved. But it was that search that ultimately proved to be the key to opening the door between the American and the Vietnamese militaries.
In the late 1970's, President Carter explored the possibility of opening diplomatic relations, but he gave up when Vietnam asked for the equivalent of war reparations. During the 1980's there was no question of negotiations, because President Reagan was convinced that Hanoi still held American prisoners.
But there were other, unofficial contacts. Bobby Muller, an early leader of Vietnam Veterans of America, whose anti-land-mine group was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1997, went to Hanoi in the 1980's to press for an accounting of the American missing. He got a cold response until he met face to face with the men he had fought against.
"No one could raise the theme of reconciliation without the veterans who paid the price of the war," said Mr. Muller, a paraplegic. "The veterans wanted relations, and we knew it was incumbent upon us to extend a hand of friendship and move on."
In 1988 Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and himself a Vietnam veteran, was sent by President Reagan to persuade Vietnam to help in the search for America's missing.
General Vessey's first breakthrough was at a meeting with Gen. Vo Nguyen Giap, the legendary hero of Vietnam's wars against France and the United States. In a private meeting in 1988, the former enemies fell into an animated, two-hour conversation that "covered the waterfront," according to General Vessey.
They talked about how the war had been fought, the high cost in human lives and what could be done to bring the countries together again.
"After that conversation I sensed an almost immediate improvement in relations with the government," General Vessey recalled.
Since that meeting the Pentagon has sent 100-member teams every other month to Vietnam -- though not in military uniform -- to scour the countryside for the remains of Americans. So far, 554 remains of military personnel have been identified, and the missions have concluded that there are no live American prisoners held by Hanoi. About 1,400 cases are left to be investigated.
In 1991 Senator John F. Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, led a Senate committee to report on the missing in action. A veteran who became a national antiwar figure, he teamed up with Senator John McCain, the conservative Republican from Arizona and a former prisoner of war.
"I was driven by the sense that we really needed to end the war," Senator Kerry said. "We Americans were acting and behaving as if the war was still going on and Vietnamese were holding Americans as prisoners." The committee determined that there were no live prisoners, and four years later the two senators flanked President Clinton when he announced the establishment of diplomatic relations with Hanoi.
From the Vietnamese perspective, the Pentagon has opened up its considerable trove of maps, documents and other archival material to help Hanoi find the more than 200,000 Communist soldiers it still lists as missing.
For the Vietnamese military, the problem is not only to find its missing. Since the end of the cold war, the country's economic plight has forced it to reduce its armed forces by more than half, from 1.2 million to 480,000.
"In the past few years the Vietnamese armed forces have gone through a harsh change," said Capt. T. McCreary of the Pacific command. "They have moved to self-defense completely, to a small armed force that's not bad and can still defend the country and territorial waters."
The search for the missing in action has developed into regular exchanges of American and Vietnamese officers and military officials and invitations to Vietnamese officers to attend seminars and conferences in the United States -- though not training or access to modern equipment.
It also created the spirit that made Major Gaines's relief mission possible, and that, in turn, led to the defense secretary's visit.
Mr. Cohen promised the Vietnamese government help in dealing with issues left over from the war, including joint research into the effects of Agent Orange, the defoliant that American forces sprayed from the air across the south during the war, which has been blamed for many health problems and birth defects.
He also helped persuade the Vietnamese to reopen negotiations on a trade agreement with Washington to open up Vietnamese markets, said Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative.
"The United States believes that the security of both of our nations can be enhanced by working together," Mr. Cohen told the Vietnamese.

HEADLINE: Knight Errant Or Erring? Sotheby's Tale

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
Sometimes fairy tales do not have happy endings, even for knights in shining armor. That lesson should come as no surprise to A. Alfred Taubman, the shopping mall magnate who has made a second career out of rescuing companies in distress from the arms of unwelcome suitors.
Nobody, however, could have dreamed up a tale like that of Sotheby's, the venerable auction house that Mr. Taubman saved in 1983. As if by magic, it recovered and prospered under Mr. Taubman's reign as chairman. It hit a rough patch in the early 1990's, along with the rest of his empire. Then, Sotheby's rebounded once more -- until federal investigators intervened. 
 Mr. Taubman, 75, resigned in February as chairman and is now stepping down as a director of Sotheby's, with his armor tarnished. The Sotheby's story threatens to overshadow a life that might well qualify as a Horatio Alger story come true.
Government prosecutors are investigating whether, in 1995 and perhaps as early as 1992, Sotheby's conspired with its chief rival, Christie's, to split business and fix commissions. Christie's has as much as acknowledged antitrust violations by entering a government program that promises leniency to the first conspirator in antitrust cases to confess. Scores of customers who contend that they were grossly overcharged have sued both companies.
And fingers are being pointed at Mr. Taubman. Prosecutors have been told that he and the former chairman of Christie's dreamed up a commission-fixing scheme and ordered their executives to carry it out, according to people involved in the case. No one, however, has been charged, and much about the investigation remains murky.
Mr. Taubman, while declining to be interviewed, has adamantly denied any wrongdoing.
His son Robert was to replace him as a director at a shareholder meeting that was set for today in London. But the meeting was suddenly postponed on Tuesday because the company's largest outside shareholder, Ronald Baron, objected to the continuing Taubman influence. Mr. Baron's firm, Baron Capital Management, owns about 38 percent of Sotheby's; the senior Mr. Taubman still owns about 22 percent of Sotheby's and has so-called supervoting rights that give him control of the board.
This is not the first time that Mr. Taubman's knight errantry has landed him in trouble. His rescue of the Washington department store chain Woodward & Lothrop cost him hundreds of millions of dollars and ended in bankruptcy in 1994. Macy's, the department store in which he had a major stake, also went bankrupt, in 1992. And he went into New York City real estate in the late 1980's just before the local economy swooned.
Nationally, the early 90's recession hurt his department stores and shopping malls and slammed Sotheby's, where auction sales, and profits, plunged. In 1992 Mr. Taubman began trying to raise cash, selling some of his depressed Sotheby's stock, some artworks and, eventually, a major stake in his malls. All this occurred during the period now under investigation by prosecutors.
But whatever the financial pressures he faced, Mr. Taubman's friends and business associates say they cannot believe that he would have done anything illegal.
"I don't recall a single instance in which anyone has said that he cut a corner or did anything inappropriate," said Richard A. Manoogian, chairman of the Masco Corporation in Detroit. "I just can't believe that Sotheby's was that important in the overall scheme of things that it would be the one area in which he would do something improper."
The son of immigrants from Germany (his A. stands for Adolph), Mr. Taubman studied architecture at the University of Michigan but never graduated from college. In 1950, he borrowed $5,000 and began building on a small scale, a bridal shop here, a shopping strip there.
Over the next two decades, the shopping centers grew bigger and grander until they turned into glossy regional malls. Peter Linneman, a professor at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, said that it was Mr. Taubman who "took the shopping center from a sort of schlocky product in the 1950's and 1960's into very creative and exciting places of business and of suburban activity."
He became famous in the business world for his good eye, his attention to detail -- and his bluntness. Leslie H. Wexner, founder of the Limited, tells the story of the first time they met when Mr. Taubman summoned him to Detroit in the early 1970's.
They climbed aboard a helicopter and visited one mall after another. Over lunch, Mr. Taubman ordered Mr. Wexner to fix up his stores, which he called "a blight on my shopping centers." Mr. Wexner says now that he was "really mad," but eventually realized that Mr. Taubman was right.
It was not until Mr. Taubman reached his 50's, though, that he developed a reputation as an investment whiz after putting together what turned out to be one of the real estate deals of the century: the purchase of the Irvine Ranch, then being developed in Southern California.
Mr. Taubman was invited by some members of the Irvine family to come in as a white knight and rescue the 77,000-acre property from the Mobil Corporation, which had won a bidding war for it. He assembled a band of his rich friends, who bought it for $337 million in 1977. When they sold out six years later, Mr. Taubman and his friends had scored a profit of more than $400 million.
That was where the cash came from to buy Sotheby's, the English auction house, which was founded in 1744. Having expanded too rapidly in the late 1970's, it was forced after an art market slump to fire half its staff and it started losing money. A pair of American corporate raiders began to buy up shares, sending shudders though the ranks of the titled gentlemen and Old Etonians who had always run the place.
Mr. Taubman, once again, looked like a white knight. He may have been another rich American businessman, complete with a perpetual tan, constant cigar and a beautiful young second wife, but at least he wasn't a breakup specialist. And he had artistic connections. A collector himself, he had been a Sotheby's customer, a force at the Detroit Institute of Arts and a patron of the Whitney Museum of American Art.
Asked to bid by Sotheby's directors, Mr. Taubman once again put together a group of friends, including Mr. Wexner, to buy the auction house and take it private.
The new owners were surprised to find how antique Sotheby's practices were, Mr. Wexner said. Records were kept on file cards and legal pads, the London offices were a rabbit warren, and nobody could explain exactly how the business operated. "It was incredibly goofy," he said.
Mr. Taubman did not simply drag Sotheby's into the computer age. He also used his retailing talent to change the very nature of the business. Sotheby's clients were no longer art and antiques dealers, they were the collectors -- the shoppers -- themselves.
"It was a chance for people to get involved with the auction social swim," recalled John H. Gutfreund, the former chairman of Salomon Brothers. "The old money dominated the sellers, and the new money dominated the buyers."
To get buyers and sellers in the door, the company added more cocktail parties, glossy catalogs and blockbuster auctions of celebrity collections like those of Andy Warhol and Claus von Bulow. Selling art, Mr. Taubman famously said, was not too different from selling root beer. (And he knew; until 1994 he owned the A & W restaurant chain.)
Not everyone was pleased. Dealers, in particular, said that the art world was being commercialized and that the auction houses were now competing with them.
And there were missteps, some involving a rapidly expanding lending program. Sotheby's was embarrassed when it became known that in 1987 it had put up about half of the record-setting $54 million an Australian financier paid for a Van Gogh painting. The buyer promptly defaulted; Sotheby's eventually resold the painting. And it stopped lending to buyers without other collateral.
Still, Mr. Taubman's methods seemed to work, and his timing was good. The art market rebounded, and sales began to soar. Profits rocketed, too; Sotheby's, which had lost more than $6 million in 1984, earned almost $113 million in 1989.
Things were so good that Sotheby's sold shares to the public again, in May 1988. Mr. Taubman made millions of dollars on the sale and still owned about half the company's increasingly valuable stock.
His takeover of Sotheby's turned Mr. Taubman into a mover and shaker in New York's social scene, a paradoxical position for a gregarious man who nevertheless had always said he cherished his privacy. His wife, Judy, was on the cover of Town & Country magazine; his perfectly appointed homes in New York; London; Palm Beach, Fla.; Southhampton, N.Y.; and Bloomfield Hills, Mich., attracted attention.
He endowed government-studies programs at Harvard and Brown, donated millions to the University of Michigan and the Detroit Institute of Arts and was active in Jewish philanthropy.
As the 1990's began, real estate tanked. Mall sales slumped. And the art market went into a recession as the rich suffered from a global downturn. Sotheby's shares lost two-thirds of their value in 1990. Auction sales dropped, and so did profits, falling to less than $4 million in 1992. It was that year, prosecutors have been told, that Sotheby's and Christie's may have began to collude; it is certainly the year that they raised the commissions they charged buyers, by exactly the same amount.
Mr. Taubman's friends repeatedly say that it would be out of character for him to have done anything improper, no matter what his financial difficulties.
There appear to have been some. In 1992, Mr. Taubman was trying hard to raise money. He sold a third of his stake in Sotheby's, even though the share price was low, and he had borrowed against much of his remaining stake.
He tried to sell stock in his malls, a deal that was completed the following year and brought in a lot less money than originally hoped. The transaction was complicated because Mr. Taubman and his family had earlier borrowed hundreds of millions of dollars from the giant corporate pension funds of AT&T and General Motors, secured by a stake in the shopping centers. The G.M. pension plan ended up owning so much of Mr. Taubman's company that in 1998 it swapped its shares for 10 of his malls.
Despite all these pressures, Mr. Taubman remained the model of a modern mogul, with all the lavish living that entails. Indeed, he partly inspired a major character in a modern sort of fairy tale, Dominick Dunne's novel "People Like Us." In the book, about the clash of old and new society in New York, the Taubman-like character is a rich trader who ends up in jail. (Some details were so apt that Mr. Taubman demanded changes by Mr. Dunne.)
But not entirely apt, Mr. Dunne says now. When he wrote the book, he said, he had watched Mr. Taubman only from afar; they have since met and he has grown to like Mr. Taubman. "I have never heard of a stain on his reputation," Mr. Dunne said. "Sure he's a tough guy; if you're going to be a billionaire, you've got to be a tough guy."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Children smart enough to get into elite schools may not need to bother.

BYLINE: By Alan B. Krueger; This column appears here every Thursday. Alan B. Krueger is the Bendheim Professor of Economics and Public Affairs at Princeton University and editor of The Journal of Economic Perspectives. Four economic analysts -- Professor Krueger, J. Bradford DeLong, Jeff Madrick and Virginia Postrel -- rotate as contributors.

 BODY:
YOUR son or daughter has just been accepted to both the University of Pennsylvania and to Penn State. The deadline for decision is May 1. Where should he or she go?
Many factors should be considered, of course, but lots of parents and students are particularly interested in the potential economic payoff from higher education. Until recently, there was a consensus among economists that students who attend more selective colleges -- ones with tougher admissions standards -- land better paying jobs as a result. Having smart, motivated classmates and a prestigious degree were thought to enhance learning and give students access to job networks. 
 But is it true?
A study that I conducted with Stacy Dale of the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, "Estimating the Payoff to Attending a More Selective College" (available online at http:// papers.nber.org/), has unintentionally undermined this consensus.
It is easy to see how one could think that elite colleges enhance their graduates' earnings. According to the College and Beyond Survey, data collected by the Mellon Foundation, the average student who entered a highly selective college like Yale, Swarthmore or the University of Pennsylvania in 1976, earned $92,000 in 1995. The average student from a moderately selective college, like Penn State, Denison or Tulane, earned $22,000 less.
The problem with this comparison is that students who attend more selective colleges are likely to have higher earnings regardless of where they attend college for the very reasons that they were admitted to the more selective colleges in the first place.
Trying to address the problem, earlier studies compared students with similar standardized test scores and grade point averages who attended more and less selective schools. But this approach takes account of much less information than admissions committees see. There is no guarantee that all the relevant differences among students have been held constant.
This problem is known as selection bias. More selective schools accept students with greater earnings potential, and students with greater earnings potential are more likely to apply to more selective schools.
To overcome the problem, Ms. Dale and I restricted the comparison to students who applied to and were accepted by comparable colleges. Some students chose more selective schools; some less selective ones.
College selectivity is based on the average College Board score of the freshman class. We used data from the College and Beyond Survey of 14,239 full-time workers who had been freshmen in 1976. Their earnings were surveyed as of 1995. Although the data came from only 30 moderate to highly selective colleges, results are similar if a smaller, but nationally representative sample, the National Longitudinal Study of the High School Class of 1972, is used.
Our research found that earnings were unrelated to the selectivity of the college that students had attended among those who had comparable options. For example, the average earnings for the 519 students who were accepted by both moderately selective (average College Board scores of 1,000 to 1,099) and highly selective schools (average scores greater than 1,275), varied little, no matter which type of college they attended.
One group of students, however, clearly benefited from attending a highly selective college: those from lower-income families -- defined approximately as the bottom quarter of families who send children to college. For them, attending a more selective school increased earnings significantly.
Restricting the comparison to those with similar choices helps solve the selection bias problem because these students were equivalent in the eyes of the admissions committees.
More important, students who applied to equally selective schools revealed that they had similar aspiration levels and self-confidence. If the comparison is restricted to students who applied to equally selective schools -- regardless of whether they were admitted -- attending a more selective school is still unrelated to earnings.
Although the selectivity of a school does not appear to influence the typical student's economic success, our analysis finds that the resources schools devote to instruction, which are related to tuition costs, do influence it.
No study is definitive. Here's one unresolved issue in ours: Why did 40 percent of students turn down the most selective school that admitted them? Although it is possible that those with greater earnings potential chose a less selective school from their menu of choices, this seems unlikely.
There are several reasons that college selectivity might have little impact on post-college careers. First, even elite colleges have diverse student bodies, and it is possible for apathetic students at elite schools to find other apathetic students with whom to play Nintendo and guzzle beer. By contrast, a good student can get a good education almost anywhere.
Second, about a third of college graduates earn higher degrees, whose prestige is often more relevant to professional or business success than undergraduate degrees.
Third, a student who goes to Penn State instead of the University of Pennsylvania, is more likely to end up near the top of the class. Employers and graduate schools may not adequately adjust for the competition.
My advice to students: Don't believe that the only school worth attending is one that would not admit you. That you go to college is more important than where you go. Find a school whose academic strengths match your interests and which devotes resources to instruction in those fields. Recognize that your own motivation, ambition and talents will determine your success more than the college name on your diploma.
My advice to elite colleges: Recognize that the most disadvantaged students benefit most from your instruction. Set financial aid and admission policies accordingly.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Isles' New Ownership Hopes to Reinvent the Team

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
A new chapter in the epic of Islanders ownership began yesterday when Charles Wang and Sanjay Kumar vowed to revive a storied franchise tainted by losing records, slashed payrolls and one former owner who sits in jail.
Wang and Kumar, the chairman and president, respectively, of Computer Associates International of Islandia, N.Y., are paying $187.5 million to three owners led by Howard Milstein, whose reign featured $40 million in losses, a brief abandonment of Nassau Coliseum and dwindling crowds at home games. 
 "We want to make the New York Islanders the world-class sports franchise that our community deserves, wants and needs," Wang, 55, said. "This is no easy task. We are not medicine men promising a very quick cure."
They insisted that they have no deal with SMG, the Nassau Coliseum's tough landlord, to modify the team's unfavorable lease, and have not analyzed deeply the possibility of a new arena to replace the creaky 28-year-old Coliseum.
"We are not committed to building anything anywhere," Kumar said.
SMG has not talked to Wang or Kumar, said Wes Westley, SMG's president, but to another Computer Associates executive. "I've tried to send indications that we'll be cooperative," Westley said.
Wang and Kumar's purchase, which requires National Hockey League approval, is not a guarantee of free spending, even for a team with the league's lowest payroll.
"Whether you have to have a bigger payroll, less payroll, I don't know," Wang said. "Just because you may have the lowest payroll doesn't mean you have the worst team."
But Mike Milbury, the Islanders' general manager, who had to shed numerous high-priced players to accommodate the team's losses, sounded hopeful. "It's nice to know that we'll be able to compete with our colleagues and know that the money will be there for a free agent if it makes sense," he said.
Kumar and Wang gently chided the Rangers, the league's freest spenders, and Charles Dolan, the chairman of Cablevision, which owns the Rangers. "It's been demonstrated," Kumar said, "that having the highest payroll in the league doesn't buy you much either."
"Ooh, that's mean to Chuck," Wang said, with a gleeful smile.
Wang said that Dolan, a friend, gave him a Rangers umbrella and that he nearly brought it yesterday. "Wrong umbrella to take to this conference," Wang said.
"We wish him well, but we won't be going to any more Rangers games," Kumar said of Dolan.
"We'll go to Rangers games," Wang said, "but root for the Islanders. And we're going to have the better team."
Wang and Kumar, 38, share a jovial relationship. They also present one of the sports world's most diverse pair of owners: Wang was born in Shanghai and Kumar was born in Sri Lanka.
They are also hockey novices. Basketball is their preference. Kumar said he has read seven hockey books lately, including "Hockey for Dummies" by John Davidson, the Rangers' TV analyst.
The arrival of Wang and Kumar, whose Computer Associates stock is worth $2 billion, is a balm for fans who reviled the Milstein group's running of the team and scorned Nassau County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta and Alfonse M. D'Amato, the former United States Senator who advises SMG, sits on the Computer Associates board and is on retainer to Milstein (for non-Islanders issues).
"I'm totally elated," said Robert Ceparano of the Save the Islanders Coalition. "This is the end of a surreal ride. This couldn't be better."
In 1997, John Spano agreed to pay John Pickett, then the Islanders' owner, $165 million for the team and its cable television contract. But Spano was later sentenced to prison for bank and wire fraud, having illegally obtained loans to buy the team. Then Milstein, who acquired the team with his brother Edward and Steve Gluckstern, feuded with Gulotta in 1998 over a county promise to ease the way to build a new arena. And the Milstein group's austerity payrolls angered fans.
The last piece of the team's sale to Wang and Kumar occurred Tuesday, when Milstein settled financial and legal issues with Class B shareholders, who include the Picketts. The Picketts will receive an unspecified payment from Wang and Kumar if a new arena is built within 10 years.
Wang and Kumar resisted two previous attempts to interest them in buying the Islanders, but their pursuit accelerated with D'Amato's guidance.
D'Amato privately supported Wang and Kumar for the past three months to counter the only other bid, from a group led by Bob Gutkowski. "I knew this group could do something Mr. Gutkowski could not," D'Amato said.
Wang said: "When we first looked at it, it just didn't make any economic sense. But the counsel from the senator was, 'You can't look at it as a business.' He said, 'It ain't going to make money the same way your business does.' And once we stopped looking at it as a business, it was easy then."
Wang and Kumar said the team would be an extension of their charitable involvement, mostly in children's causes. But they are paying a steep premium for a losing team because of the lucrative Fox Sports New York cable contract.
"I don't think we overpaid," Kumar said. "We're paying fair value. We're paying for the legacy, the demographics and the future franchise potential."
The Devils recently cost the YankeeNets $175 million. Last year, the Penguins sold for about $75 million; the Blues for $100 million, and the Lightning for $110 million, 10 months after selling for $117 million.

HEADLINE: Corzine Attacks Florio's Lead by Attacking His Tax Rise

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 26

 BODY:
Jon S. Corzine dropped any pretense of remaining above the fray today in his campaign for the Senate from New Jersey, as he began running a new television commercial attacking his opponent, Jim Florio, for raising taxes as governor in 1990 during a deep recession.
Mr. Corzine, the former co-chairman of Goldman Sachs & Company, still trails the much better-known Mr. Florio in the polls. But Mr. Corzine's advisers have long maintained that he can narrow Mr. Florio's lead, or even pull ahead, merely by reminding the voters of his rocky four years as governor, and particularly the $2.8 billion tax increase, which gave rise to "Dump Florio" bumper stickers that can still be seen on the New Jersey Turnpike. 
Still, the harsh tone of the ad, complete with a grainy close-up of a frowning Mr. Florio in slow motion, represents a departure for Mr. Corzine, who had presented himself as a reluctant combatant since entering the Senate race. In November, for example, he said that he would not bring up Mr. Florio's 1990 tax increase, though he did not object when his aides and supporters did so.
Of course, neither Mr. Florio nor just about anyone else expected that Mr. Corzine would leave Mr. Florio's greatest vulnerability unexploited much longer, particularly now that the Corzine campaign has begun running commercials at a cost of more than $1 million a week. And in recent weeks, as the former governor has braced for the inevitable onslaught, the Corzine campaign has seized on every possible justification for mentioning the tax increase.
Mr. Florio had less than $1 million in the bank on March 31 and is not likely to broadcast his first commercial until the last week in May. So he has been trying to taint Mr. Corzine's ad campaign in the so-called free media -- the newspapers -- while inoculating himself against it. On Tuesday, for example, he said that if he were elected, his first legislative proposal would be campaign finance reform with strict spending limits for federal candidates, and likened Mr. Corzine to a "walking A.T.M. operation."
But he has also been defending the 1990 tax increase, which increased aid to the state's poorest school districts, as an example of courageous leadership, albeit poor salesmanship.
That, however, was enough for Mr. Corzine to claim that Mr. Florio had, in effect, asked for it. "Jim Florio has extended an invitation to Jon Corzine and everyone else in New Jersey to talk about his tax increase," said Steven Goldstein, a co-manager of the Corzine campaign. "Invitation accepted."
The new ad reminds voters of the economic troubles that plagued Mr. Florio's administration. "New Jersey's economy left in shambles," a narrator recalls. "Do we want to go back to that?"
Aides to Mr. Florio called the ad mudslinging and said it neglected to mention that New Jersey, like the rest of the nation, was in the throes of a recession that began before he took office. "It's a desperate attempt to find blame where it doesn't exist," said Jim Lanard, a Florio spokesman.
The ad also omitted any mention of Mr. Florio's reasons for raising taxes, Mr. Lanard said. "This ad reflects Jon Corzine's opposition to equal educational opportunities for everyone, his opposition to property tax relief, and his opposition to a balanced budget that is required by the New Jersey Constitution," he said.
But Mr. Corzine himself asserted that the tax package should have been avoided or mitigated at all costs. "I think raising taxes in the middle of a recession is not one of the smartest things ever promoted as public policy," he said. "Certainly not record levels of increases."
Political analysts said they had been wondering when before the June 6 primary Mr. Corzine would get around to taking on Mr. Florio more directly.
"I've always said this was a contest between Florio and anti-Florio," said Gerald M. Pomper, a professor of political science at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University. "I think Corzine has probably established himself as a credible alternative, with all of his advertising and endorsements. So attacking Florio is probably tactically the right thing to do, because it's taking the basic issue that's there and highlighting it."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by B. Drummond Ayres Jr.

 BODY:

THE ISSUES
 
SUPPORTER OF BATTLE FLAG SWITCHES
Last week, it was Senator John McCain who changed his mind and said the Confederate battle flag should no longer fly atop the South Carolina Capitol. This week, Mr. McCain's best-known supporter in the state, Representative Lindsey Graham of the Third Congressional District, ventured the same opinion, saying he now supports the State Senate's proposal to remove the flag and put a smaller version on a Confederate monument in front of the Capitol. But Mr. Graham, a flag supporter who had urged Mr. McCain to stay away from the issue in the South Carolina primary, lest it cost him votes, added a qualifier to his change of mind. The flag, he told The Associated Press on Monday, should stay where it is if the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People continues its economic boycott of the state. Still, said Mr. Graham, who has his eye on a Senate seat, the flag is eventually going to come down. David Firestone (NYT) 

SIERRA CLUB WEIGHS IN
The Sierra Club has begun an $8 million television and radio campaign aimed at 17 House and Senate races. The commercials, mostly praising Democrats, are focused on tight races in which the club believes it has the best chance to make a difference. The commercials will be combined with other campaign efforts, the club officials say, including mass distribution of voter guides and fliers. The officials say they also plan to run presidential campaign commercials that criticize the environmental record of Gov. George W. Bush in Texas and may throw in advertising that praises Vice President Al Gore. The club has not made public where it got the money to pay for the advertising campaign and under federal tax and election regulations is not required to do so. B. Drummond Ayres Jr.(NYT)
 
THE MONEY
 
BUSH TOPS $78 MILLION
Continuing his record fund-raising pace, Gov. George W. Bush pulled in an additional $6.4 million in campaign donations in March, bringing his total for the race to $78.6 million. But at the same time, new campaign finance figures show, he spent $10.2 million and ended the month with $6.8 million in the bank. Vice President Al Gore pulled in $4.4 million in March, bringing his total fund-raising for the campaign to $40.4 million. He spent $4.7 million and ended the month with $3.8 million on hand. Mr. Gore has aggressively used the Internet as a campaign financing tool, raising slightly over $1.1 million online through Feb. 15. By comparison, Mr. Bush has raised $350,000 online. Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, remains the most successful online presidential fund-raiser, pulling in $4.3 million electronically, followed by former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey with $1.7 million. Leslie Wayne (NYT)
 
THE STATES
 
RACE FOR NEBRASKA SEAT As the May 9 primaries approach for Nebraska's open United States Senate seat, fund-raising figures for the two leading Republican contenders show that in the first half of April, Secretary of State Scott Moore raised more than twice as much as Attorney General Don Stenberg -- $51,000 to $24,000. For the year, Mr. Moore now leads Mr. Stenberg $224,000 to $144,000 in fund-raising. But polls have Mr. Stenberg running ahead in the race itself, and over all in the campaign he has raised more than Mr. Moore -- $399,000 to $224,000 -- in part because he started a year earlier. Still, Mr. Moore now says he has the momentum in the contest on the basis of his latest fund-raising effort. On the Democratic side, former Gov. Ben Nelson faces no serious opposition in his nomination quest and, despite a late entry in the race, is well ahead of both Republicans in money raising, having taken in $129,000 in the first half of April, for a total of $763,000 for the campaign. More to the point, he also leads both Republicans in the polls. The incumbent senator, Bob Kerrey, a Democrat, is retiring. Pam Belluck (NYT)

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Retiree With High Drug Bills Lends a Hand to Gore

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: EAST HARTFORD, Conn., April 26

 BODY:
Shirley Kindle, a 65-year-old retired clerical worker, played a bit part in Al Gore's presidential campaign today, but it was enough to win her over to the vice president's side.
Ms. Kindle needs a dozen prescription drugs each month for diabetes and other ailments. All told, they cost more than $500 a month, which is more than her Social Security check. To keep up her regimen, she has borrowed money from her family, although, like many other elderly people on fixed incomes, she sometimes skips certain drugs altogether because she cannot afford them. 
 She likes Vice President Gore's proposal that Medicare cover the cost of prescription drugs. And so today, after a magazine, to which she had written a letter about the high cost of prescription drugs, arranged with the campaign for a "photo op," she posed with Mr. Gore at Pelton's Drug Store here to illustrate her problem.
Usually, she shops around at different pharmacies in her hometown, and she had already bought her drugs for the month. But to accommodate the vice president's presidential campaign, she and her son drove 40 miles from her home in Ansonia to East Hartford, and she re-enacted her purchases at Pelton's, a quaint family pharmacy.
Still, the drug store filled a dozen orange prescription bottles with pills, rang them up at the cash register and declared to the assembled cameras that her total came to $506.34, more than her monthly Social Security check of $496.
The event was part of a coordinated effort with the White House to demonstrate their concern that drug prices are soaring out of control and that they are more attentive than the Republicans to the real-life needs of the elderly.
Mr. Gore said only that Mrs. Kindle was helping him to illustrate a larger problem and that "as a courtesy" she had "aggregated" her purchase at Pelton's.
In any case, Mrs. Kindle said she did not mind being a prop in the campaign, even after several calls from Gore aides who were fretting that she might be overcome with "stage fright."
She is registered as an independent. But as she and her son sat in a hallway outside the vice president's holding room at a center for the elderly, she said she decided then and there that she would vote for him.
"The Democrats usually handle the issues that I believe better pertain to the average citizen," she said.
Her son, Joe, 31, who had taken time off from his job as an apprentice optician to accompany his mother, said that he was a registered Republican but that Mr. Gore had won him over, too. "It's amazing how he's taken an interest," he said. "This is something that's important to me because it's important to my family. He definitely has my vote."
Mr. Gore used the event to promote his proposal for offering the elderly a prescription drug benefit through Medicare, costing $200 billion over 10 years. He also took a jab at the drug industry, calling it "out of control."
"They're going to the point where the margins are way out of line with what most other industries and most other lines of business believe is normal and adequate," he said, "and they're using the market power to dictate prices that are way above what the competition would set them at."
This month's Fortune magazine reports that the pharmaceutical industry has yielded the highest profits of the nation's top 40 industries. But it also notes that the industry's stock prices are off considerably, and that this has been the source of considerable concern at the drug companies -- that any Medicare plan to offer a prescription drug benefit would ultimately constrain drug prices and cut into profits. The drug industry worries that whatever it might gain in new consumers who buy drugs because they are covered under a government plan, it would lose in profits because the government would pay less than the prices the companies charge now.
At the White House today, President Clinton issued a study saying that prices of the drugs most widely used by older Americans had increased more than consumer prices in general. The study, by Families USA, a consumer group, said prices of the 50 top-selling drugs used by the elderly rose at nearly twice the overall rate of inflation from January 1999 to January 2000.
Mr. Clinton said a proposal outlined recently by House Republicans did not go far enough. He said it would "do nothing" for those with annual incomes below $50,000.
Mrs. Kindle and her husband, Joseph, 70, a retired painter with a union pension, earn less than half of that amount.
"We created Medicare in the first place because we knew it was wrong for our parents' basic health to be decided by their wealth," Mr. Gore said.
His plan would allow those ages 55 to 65 who have no health insurance to buy into Medicare, providing free coverage for low-income recipients and some benefits for those who would pay $44 per month.
Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, his Republican rival, contends that the Gore plan would force families into a bureaucratic government program. Mr. Bush instead offers low-income families a refundable tax credit to buy private health insurance.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Amgen Wins Early Ruling In a Drug Patent Dispute
A federal judge in Boston ruled that two companies, Transkaryotic Therapies and Aventis, had infringed on an Amgen patent covering its leading drug, an anemia treatment for patients undergoing kidney dialysis or chemotherapy for cancer.
The ruling, at a pretrial hearing, was an early victory for Amgen, but analysts differed on how significant it was because the trial will proceed, with Aventis and Transkaryotic having a chance to prove that Amgen's patents are invalid. Shares of Amgen jumped $2.9375, to $57.25. Transkaryotic fell $4.125, or 17 percent, to $28. Page C6. 

New Chief Seeks to Revamp Aetna
William H. Donaldson, the new chief executive of Aetna, is driving hard to transform the insurer into a consumer-friendly company that makes more profits and fewer enemies. But he is under pressure from shareholders who want quicker action to bolster the stock. C6.
 
Most States Back Microsoft Split
A majority of the 19 states that have sued Microsoft in the antitrust case plan to back the government's proposal to break the software giant into two companies. But several states plan to file minority opinions -- something the trial judge, Thomas Penfield Jackson, has said he does not want. Some of the states may still be persuaded to join the majority. A1.
 
Stocks Fall Ahead of New Data
Stocks retreated as investors awaited important economic data. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 179.32 points, or 1.6 percent, to 10,945.50. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 81.14 points, or 2.2 percent, to 3,630.09. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 16.45 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,460.99. C12.
 
Snag Appears in Nuclear Waste Plan
The Energy Department's plan to hire a British company to solidify liquid radioactive waste that has been leaking from storage tanks in Washington State stumbled when the energy secretary said an increase in the company's price estimate was unacceptable. C4.
 
Orders for Durable Goods Up 2.6%
Orders for big-ticket durable goods bounced back in March, rising 2.6 percent, after two consecutive months of declines, the government said. The number was helped by a substantial rebound in transportation orders after Boeing reached a contract agreement with 17,000 striking engineers. C27.
 
Building Business Slowly in Guyana
Working to discard decades of isolation after independence from Britain in 1966, Guyana's economy has slowly become more capitalistic, and people like Gerald Gouveia, the owner of Roraima Airways, are leading the way. Mr. Gouveia is one of the more outspoken executives in Guyana, the only English-speaking nation in South America. C4.
 
Amazon Loss Widens as Sales Grow
Amazon.com said that it lost $308 million in the first quarter, five times its loss a year earlier, but that its sales rose 95 percent, beating forecasts. Excluding the cost of stock options, merger costs and some other items, Amazon lost $122 million, or 35 cents a share, which was a penny less than expected. C2.
 
Viacom Posts 69% Rise in Earnings
Viacom, owner of the MTV cable channel and the Blockbuster video chain, said that its first-quarter profit increased 69 percent and that the Justice Department had given approval to the proposed acquisition of CBS. C11.
 
Three Seats Sold on the Big Board
Three New York Stock Exchange seats were sold, one for $1.65 million and the other two for $1.7 million each. C14.

HEADLINE: 67.1% of Americans Own Their Homes, a Record High Level

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26

 BODY:
The percentage of Americans who own their homes rose to a record 67.1 percent in the first three months of the year, as ownership among blacks and inner-city residents also climbed to all-time highs, according to the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
Homeownership among blacks rose to 47.8 percent, from 47.3 percent in the fourth quarter of last year, the department said. Ownership in the nation's central cities increased to 51.2 percent, from 50.9 percent. The nation's overall homeownership rate in the fourth quarter of 1999 was 66.9 percent. 
 In March, sales of previously owned houses rose 1.5 percent, to an average annual rate of 4.83 million. And sales of new homes in February were higher than expected, at an annual rate of 919,000 for the month.
Mortgage interest rates on fixed loans have declined from a mid-February peak, according to Freddie Mac, the No. 2 buyer of home loans. The contract rate on a 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage was 8.12 percent last week, down from 8.38 percent in the week ended Feb. 19.
The report said 45.7 percent of Hispanics owned their homes during the first quarter of this year. Still, minority and inner-city ownership rates lag behind those of whites, H.U.D. said. In the first quarter, 73.4 percent of whites were homeowners.

HEADLINE: THE ELIAN GONZALEZ CASE: COUNTING THE COST;
Castro Emerges as Conflict's Clear Winner

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: MIAMI, April 26

 BODY:
At the corner of Flagler Street and 22nd Avenue, a procession of cars filled with teenagers, salsa music blaring, crawled slowly across the intersection with Cuban flags fluttering from radio antennas and a big American flag flying upside down, in scorn.
In Little Havana, in the days since Elian Gonzalez was taken from his Miami relatives' home in a blur of tear gas and armed federal agents, upside-down flags and disdain for the United States are fashionable. 
 As a city, "we are more divided than we have ever been," said Max Castro, the senior research associate at the Dante B. Fascell North-South Center at the University of Miami, and an expert on the exile community.
Almost everyone involved in the case lost something in the five-month standoff and the three-minute raid on his relatives' home, say legal, immigration and political experts, including his Miami family, the exiles who made Elian a symbol of freedom, the two mayors who sided with the exiles over the government, and -- because of the nature of the raid -- the government itself.
And the clear winner, said the experts, is the man exiles here see as the devil himself. "Fidel Castro has taken great advantage," said Osmel Lugo, a political dissident jailed in Cuba until 1999.
It is not that Mr. Castro did very much to profit from the case. Others, even those who hate him most, did his work for him, said experts on Cuba and the exile community.
The exiles and the family that could not bear to give up the child, no matter how well-intentioned their refusal, gave Mr. Castro material to prop up his sagging revolution and have turned American support from their cause.
And Mayor Alex Penelas of Miami-Dade County and Mayor Joseph Carollo of Miami, though they may have heartened many of their constituents by siding with the exile community against the government, stumbled on the national stage.
"The clear losers are the hard-liners in the Cuban exile community who conducted themselves in such a way as to antagonize and alienate U.S. public opinion," said Wayne Smith, a senior fellow at the Center for International Policy in Washington who served as a diplomat in Cuba.
"They seemed to believe they could take the law into their own hands, defy the law, defy the federal government, and get away with it."
Few people doubt, political and immigration experts said, that Elian's great-uncle Lazaro Gonzalez and the boy's cousin Marisleysis Gonzalez both loved Elian and were heartbroken when he was taken. But, even if a last-minute compromise was close, as the Miami family and others said, the family clearly had little credibility with a frustrated Attorney General Janet Reno.
"Lazaro Gonzalez said a number of times they would have to take the boy by force," Mr. Smith said. "Well, they did. I think U.S. public opinion was turned off by them."
Despite criticism that the government used excessive force in the raid, Americans have overwhelmingly approved of it in poll after poll.
A USA Today/CNN/Gallup Poll released on Monday showed that 60 percent of respondents approved, and 62 percent believed that the Miami relatives would not have turned the boy over peacefully if the agents had not been armed.
Only 28 percent of respondents said that Congress should hold hearings on the raid, and only 25 percent said they believed that Elian should remain in the United States.
Mr. Penelas and Mr. Carollo had, before and after, harshly criticized efforts to remove the boy, refused to let their police help in the effort and made speeches that left no doubt they would not cooperate with the government, drawing condemnations from around the country.
So, in a startling snub, federal officials did not alert them to the raid, apparently because those officials felt they could not trust them. For the top elected officials in an American city to be so ignored is unusual, said political experts.
"The government just went around them," said Lisandro Perez, director of the Cuban Research Institute at Florida International University.
If the two mayors plan to seek office only in South Florida, where Cuban-Americans remain the dominant cultural, political and economic force, they probably did not hurt themselves, political experts agree.
Mr. Carollo, in a city dominated by Cuban-Americans, "solidified his position," said Dario Moreno, an associate professor of political science at Florida International University.
But, said political experts, television images of smoking tires and trash bins burning in the streets and the police scuffling with violent demonstrators may halt any larger political ambitions at the Miami-Dade County line for both mayors.
Mr. Penelas, the young mayor of Miami-Dade County, had seemed destined for a political career beyond Miami, but was condemned by dozens of editorial pages around the nation, and by whites, blacks and other Hispanics in his own county. "He hurt his political career," Mr. Moreno said, though he added that it was too soon to write the mayor's political obituary.
Both mayors have said over and over they did what was right, what the majority of constituents wanted. But in doing so they ignored almost everyone except Cuban-Americans.
"Some people really became invested in Elian remaining here," Mr. Castro, the researcher, said. "Other people felt alienated, felt the city was being taken over by one case."
The long-standing power in the Cuban exile community, the Cuban American National Foundation, and its chairman, Jorge Mas Santos, tried but failed to broker a deal for a more peaceful transfer of Elian.
And, the foundation had a less visible presence at street level than the much less powerful Movimiento Democracia, led by Ramon Saul Sanchez. Mr. Sanchez was slammed in the head by a rifle butt in the raid.
"At this point it means that they, the hard-liners, do not have the monopoly on Cuban policy, do not have the influence they had," said Mauricio Font, director of the Cuba Project at the Graduate Center of City University of New York. But Mr. Mas Santos said the Elian case helped the exile's fight, because "people now have a better understanding about what life is like in Cuba. Fidel's tyranny had been exposed."
Gov. Jeb Bush, who insisted that family court should settle the issue, had no real presence in the case and should not be affected much by it one way or another. Political experts said Mr. Bush, a Republican, was supportive of exiles but was not bloodied because he was never a real factor in how the drama played out.
But votes, power and public opinion aside, Elian's father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, seems to have won the ultimate battle, for the child.
The United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit is expected to rule on May 11 on the Miami relatives' appeal of a lower court ruling that Elian, at 6, is too young to ask for a political asylum hearing.
Experts on immigration law and child psychology say that, with a 6-year-old boy, whoever exercises influence over him will ultimately win the custody battle, which is really what the asylum hearing is about.
"The power of persuasion is now in the hands of the father," said Pamela Falk, a professor of immigration law at the City University of New York. That, Professor Falk said, was why the government had to act so drastically to remove Elian from the Miami family.
The Miami family lost a child. Elian's father was without his son for five months. And Elian endured a nightmare when armed agents took him from the home and into the chaos of the street outside.
Fidel Castro, in a time when he needed a shot of power, has it now.
"Every three or four months, Fidel has a speech and talks about the same thing," Mr. Lugo said.
Elian's story has given him a passionate topic that appeals to the nationalism of the Cuban people.
He will talk about it, experts on Cuba said, forever.
