HEADLINE: Clearest Picture of Infant Universe Sees It All and Questions It, Too

BYLINE: By JAMES GLANZ 

 BODY:
Scientists yesterday released the clearest pictures yet taken of the infant universe, before stars and galaxies had formed and when space was filled with hot turbulent gases. The images confirm one major prediction of the leading theory of the explosive birth of the universe, but they failed to reveal another crucial feature that scientists had hoped would buttress that theory.
It is uncertain how sharp a revision, if any, will be needed to account for the new evidence. 
 The images -- actually imprints of sound waves that cause ripples in the cosmos' temperature -- were collected using a balloon-borne telescope named Boomerang by a multinational collaboration led by Dr. Andrew Lange of the California Institute of Technology and Dr. Paolo de Bernardis of the University of Rome.
The images, released at a NASA briefing yesterday, are being published today in the journal Nature.
"They're essentially snapshots of the universe when it was 300,000 years old," said Dr. Wayne Hu, a cosmologist at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J., who wrote a separate commentary on the results in Nature.
In trying to understand how the universe came about in what they believe was a giant explosion, called the Big Bang, some 13 billion years ago, scientists focus on ripples, or variations, in the temperature of the primordial gas. These can be used as a measuring stick to gauge the large-scale geometry and overall contents of the universe.
The size of the ripples observed by the Boomerang experiment indicates that the universe contains just the right amount of matter and energy to make space "flat," meaning that parallel rays of light never cross or diverge, just as predicted by the reigning "inflation" theory of how the Big Bang started. A preliminary analysis by Boomerang and other experiments first revealed that flatness last fall.
To the untrained eye, the images in question resemble little more than ill-defined blotches. And in fact, the very notion of measuring ripples from the Big Bang or determining whether space is curved or flat is likely to baffle most lay people. But for cosmologists, the measurements provide an unparalleled opportunity to test their theories, which are built largely upon abstract mathematical models, against something they can actually detect in the real world.
"Inflation, our boldest and most promising theory of the earliest moments of creation, passed its first, very important test," said Dr. Michael Turner, a cosmologist at the University of Chicago.
A number of cosmologists were surprised by what the new images were expected to reveal but did not: fainter ripples of smaller size on the sky.
Just as an organ pipe resonates with its main note and higher harmonics, the early universe should have contained the smaller ripples, according to inflationary theory. Scientists had regarded Boomerang as the first experiment that could see the smaller ripples, but it did not produce clear evidence of them.
The mixed results have turned the images into a sort of cosmic Rorschach test, with some scientists seeing confirmation of existing theories, and others seeing the first dark hints that those theories are -- if not entirely wrong -- at least in need of serious revision.
"Whatever you do, you're going to have to kill one of the holy cows of cosmology, throw away one thing that people believe a lot in," said Dr. Max Tegmark, a cosmologist at the University of Pennsylvania.
Dr. Lange cautioned that the team was presenting only 5 percent to 10 percent of its data in the Nature paper and that the theoretical implications were still subject to revision. But cosmologists said that if the higher harmonics did not eventually emerge clearly from the data, all bets would be off.
"That, I think, would require a radical revision of cosmology as we know it," said Dr. David Spergel, a cosmologist at Princeton University.
According to Einstein's general theory of relativity, the gravity of all matter and energy in the universe can warp space and bend light rays. Generally speaking, this means that initially parallel light rays eventually cross or diverge. Only in a "flat" universe, containing a precisely defined amount of matter and energy, do the rays remain parallel.
That precise amount is predicted by inflation, a theory first proposed in 1980 by Dr. Alan Guth of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Inflation predicts that during the Big Bang a tiny mote of space became drastically stretched by fields of energy that are predicted by advanced theories of particle physics. Minute fluctuations in the amount of energy in different places would eventually have generated sound waves, or ripples, in the primordial gases.
Radiation, or light, emitted from those gases in the early universe arrives billions of years later at Earth still retaining the imprint of the sound waves. These imprints can be compared to theoretical calculations of the early universe.
Their apparent sizes on the sky give a measure of whether the radiation from them traveled to Earth on straight or curved lines, giving a gauge of cosmic geometry, as if an optician was trying to estimate the power of a lens by measuring the size of newsprint seen through it.
Because the Boomerang experiment saw the most pronounced ripples at about 1 degree on the sky, as expected for a flat universe, "this is looking like a big triumph for inflation," Dr. Tegmark said.
But Boomerang was also designed to look for some of the more subtle predictions of the theory. To study the cosmic radiation, the experiment used 16 ultracold detectors that look like tiny spider webs, said Brendan Crill, a collaborator at Caltech.
The detectors were placed in an instrument package and carried to 120,000 feet, high above the warm glow of most of Earth's atmosphere, by a balloon during a 10-and-a-half-day flight in Antarctica beginning in late December 1998. The radiation fell on the detectors, which heated up and cooled down by fractions of a degree as they were directed toward warmer and cooler parts of the cosmic ripples.
"It's kind of like holding the back of your hand into the sun," Mr. Crill said. "You can detect the light by feeling your hand warm up."
Each of the 16 detectors made 54 million separate measurements during the flight, said Dr. de Bernardis, a principal investigator of the experiment at La Sapienza, the main campus of the University of Rome.
Yesterday's briefing presented a fraction of the data that has so far been subjected to the analysis required for precise conclusions, according to Dr. Richard Bond, a Boomerang collaborator at the Canadian Institute for Theoretical Astrophysics at the University of Toronto.
"The buzz on the street is going to be that there is no second 'Doppler peak,' " as the harmonics are known, Dr. Bond said. But with more data to be analyzed, he said, it was too soon to say whether there was a discrepancy with inflation.
If the peaks fail to appear, however, cosmologists said that revisions to the theory ranging from mild to radical might be necessary.
One solution, the scientists said, would be to adjust what seem well-established ratios in the universe of ordinary matter, dark or unseen matter, and a kind of static energy permeating space called the cosmological constant. Such adjustments would mean other astronomical observations are somehow wrong.
Or, Dr. Paul Steinhardt of Princeton said, the energy could be something else entirely: a bizarre, flowing substance called quintessence.
Still another possibility would be that inflation did not produce structures in the early universe after all. Dr. Spergel said he still considered that possibility a longshot. But he said most cosmologists expected the Boomerang measurement "would fit bang-on the standard model. But it didn't. This will make things interesting."
Dr. Turner of the University of Chicago said that "this could be the thread that unravels the whole tapestry." He added, "That's not where I'm betting."

HEADLINE: A New Campaign Approach for Mrs. Clinton: The Town Meeting

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

DATELINE: AMHERST, N.Y., April 26

 BODY:
Answering questions on topics ranging from economic growth and agriculture to health care and the fate of Elian Gonzalez, Hillary Rodham Clinton held the first of a series of town hall meetings tonight that her aides said would be a new way of bringing her campaign directly to New Yorkers.
Appearing relaxed, with her hands frequently clasped in front of her, Mrs. Clinton stood to respond to questions from an audience of 350 students, faculty members and residents at the State University of New York at Buffalo. The first hour was broadcast live on CNN, but she continued to take questions for 40 more minutes. 
 For the most part, she offered responses that have become part of the stock of her campaign appearances. At the outset, for example, Mrs. Clinton faced the question that has been frequently raised, when Wolf Blitzer, the program's moderator, asked her to respond to criticisms that she was a carpetbagger.
"For more than 30 years, I've worked on issues concerning children and families," Mrs. Clinton said. "Those are the concerns of my lifetime. As I've visited with thousands of New Yorkers, those are their concerns. To me, it's a commitment to continue a life's work."
She also said that, if she won the Senate race, she would not run for president in 2004 and that, if she lost, she would continue to make New York her home. Some conservative groups and her Republican opponent, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, have said that Mrs. Clinton is using the Senate campaign as a stepping stone to be president.
"I am going to serve my six-year term as senator," she said. "I owe it to the people of New York. I want to help make things happen in the state. That's what motivates me."
In many instances during questioning, Mrs. Clinton was able to showcase her growing knowledge of the state's characteristics, rattling off, for example, the names of highways or companies in western New York.
She repeated her proposal to make the cost of college tuition tax-deductible up to $10,000 and reiterated her support for creating a national program that would offer scholarships for students who agreed to teach upon graduation in schools facing a shortage of teachers.
Asked whether her views had changed from her first years in the White House, when she championed a health care plan that critics called nationalized medicine, she said she had learned from those days, "and I'm now from the school of smaller steps."
She then listed several measures she favored, including prescription drug coverage for Medicare recipients and having more children and more of the underinsured covered by health care plans.
Mrs. Clinton reiterated her support for abortion rights, but also said she could support legislation backed by President Clinton that would outlaw a procedure that critics call partial-birth abortion, except in cases where the woman's health or life was at stake. She said that Congressional Republicans have refused to let that legislation come up for a vote.
She also reiterated her support for Attorney General Janet Reno's decision to use armed law enforcement officers to enter the home of Elian Gonzalez's Miami relatives. Mrs. Clinton said, "I think everyone would agree that it was unfortunate that that kind of activity had to take place." But then she added, "I understand the concern and the frustration of the Justice Department when faced with continuing recalcitrance."
Mr. Giuliani has repeatedly criticized the Clinton administration this week for its handling of the situation, calling the agents who took the boy last Saturday "storm troopers."
Even before the meeting began, Mr. Giuliani's aides were attacking it, asserting that the crowd and questions had been fixed to spare Mrs. Clinton from any difficult moments, pointing to an article in The Buffalo News that suggested the event had been carefully controlled. "Her whole campaign is so heavily scripted and staged that Mrs. Clinton's handlers must be confident that tonight's event is safe," said Bruce J. Teitelbaum, Mr. Giuliani's campaign manager.
But Mr. Blitzer said in an interview before the show that Mrs. Clinton had not requested, and CNN would not have permitted her to have, any control over what questions would be asked or who would be admitted to the hall.
Mr. Blitzer said that CNN reviewed questions from audience members only to ensure variety and to avoid repetition, and screened the audience to make certain that it included only registered voters who lived in New York.
"Mrs. Clinton has no ideas what the questions are," Mr. Blitzer said. "She has had no role in this whatsoever."

HEADLINE: The Cost of Medical Innovation

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Drug Makers Reap Profits on Tax-Backed Research" (front page, April 23), which focused on the Pharmacia Corporation, said that "there are other, unseen, partners in the creation of Xalatan: the American taxpayers," who supported research on this glaucoma drug with $4 million from the National Institutes of Health but "have reaped no financial return on their investment." 
 In the marketplace, companies place research and development bets every day, losing most and winning the few that presumably improve the quality of life for many of us. Why not apply this logic to the national institutes' allotments for university research?
When profits are clearly exorbitant, as they are for Xalatan, the N.I.H. could be reimbursed by the company, at inflation-adjusted rates. Those taxpayer dollars could then be recycled for other worthy recipients.
 
LAWRENCE MALONE
Oneonta, N.Y., April 24, 2000
 
The writer is a professor of economics at Hartwick College.

HEADLINE: Hopes Are Raised, Then Dashed, Over Stalemate at Port Authority

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

 BODY:
It looked yesterday as if the yearlong impasse that has hobbled the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey might finally ease a bit, as board members from the two states gathered for their monthly meeting. Thick ring binders of agenda items were placed around the table, and privately, agency officials had said that the annual budget -- already four months late -- would come up for a vote.
But while the commissioners huddled in a closed session before the meeting, agency staff members swept into the room and began frantically removing items from the binders. After starting 40 minutes late, the board met for 10 minutes, approved only minor items and then bolted as a group from the room without explanation. 
 Later, New Jersey representatives said that their New York counterparts had reneged on an agreement to pass a budget, while New York officials disputed that there ever was any such agreement.
Regardless of which version is correct, the day's events at the agency's headquarters in the World Trade Center left bitterness among board members and aides to the two states' governors. And those developments may have raised new hurdles to ending the impasse over the allocation of agency money. The stalemate has blocked agreement on a number of major initiatives that both sides privately agree are crucial to the port system and the region's economic development.
Reacting to the abbreviated meeting, Rick Mroz, counsel to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, said that aides to Gov. George E. Pataki who serve on the board had engaged in "bizarre behavior" and had caused a meltdown in the negotiations that were intended to end the impasse.
Charles A. Gargano, Pataki's appointee as vice chairman of the Port Authority board and the chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, countered that that there had been no budget deal and that Mr. Mroz's indignation amounted to a smoke screen for New Jersey's "unconscionable" refusal over the last year to approve projects favored by New York.
The Port Authority board has not approved any major projects since last June. At the heart of the dispute is New York's contention that New Jersey will get much more than its fair share of Port Authority resources if the agency approves a 30-year lease to the Maersk Sealand shipping line. The lease is meant to ensure that the Elizabeth Marine Terminal in New Jersey remains the major Northeast cargo port.
New Jersey representatives have countered by refusing to allow votes on projects New York badly wants: efforts to sell or lease the World Trade Center and lease air rights for development atop the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Midtown.
The board's failure to approve a spending plan for this year does not completely hobble the port agency, the chairman, Lewis M. Eisenberg, said. A resolution adopted last year when the board approved its $3.1 billion budget for 1999 authorized the executive director, Robert E. Boyle, to continue contractual commitments and spend money on continuing operations. Major projects like the port lease and the privatization of the World Trade Center do not figure in the annual budget and must be approved separately by the commissioners.
Mr. Eisenberg. who was appointed by Governor Whitman, said: "Still, I was disappointed that we were not able to move the budget forward yesterday. But I also believe that there is positive dialogue that is continuing that will bring this to a successful conclusion."
Nevertheless, former governors of the two states have lamented the impasse and called it an embarrassment to the region and the port agency, which in its 79-year history had developed a reputation for efficiency and rising above politics and provincialism. As recently as a week ago, Democratic Senators Daniel P. Moynihan of New York and Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey wrote to both governors, voicing their concerns about the long-term effects of the standoff.
They warned that "this rancorous and unproductive" period in the agency's life threatened to make the regional port "an unattractive place to do business."
Mr. Gargano, Mr. Pataki's appointee, denied New Jersey's claim that New York board members had no objections to the budget when the meeting agenda was being set earlier in the week.
He said New York members wanted to look at a five-year capital spending plan for the agency and get a sense of the balance in spending between the two states over time. There was no such balance, he said, in the proposed one-year budget that has been pending before the board.
"For this year there is a lot more spending in New Jersey than in New York," he said, "and a lot less income from New Jersey than from New York. We didn't reject the budget out of hand. We just wanted to see a five-year spread."
While agency officials insist that all of their spending benefits both states, a Port Authority study of spending since the agency was created in 1921 showed that 45 percent went to projects within New York and were seemingly more beneficial to it while 27 percent was spent in New Jersey. The remainder was spent on projects that the study deemed of regional benefit.
Mr. Gargano and other New York representatives dispute this accounting.
Mr. Mroz, Governor Whitman's aide, said that New Jersey was also willing to examine longer-term spending, but he said he was suspicious of the New Yorkers' motives, given their actions over the last five months of the impasse, including holding up votes of most actions and even boycotting a board meeting.
"This has been the classic M.O. of the New York commissioners, and it has continued to befuddle us on what will settle the impasse, short of giving New York a windfall from agency revenues for no reason," he said. "It is bizarre and it is no way to do business."

ASIA
 
CHINA: NO PAROLE FOR RESEARCHER -- The Chinese government rejected a request for medical parole for a Chinese-born Stanford University researcher who has been jailed in Beijing since 1998 on charges of revealing military secrets, a Hong Kong human rights group said. Hua Di, a former Chinese weapons scientist who is serving 15 years, has a rare form of breast cancer that strikes men. A Beijing Court recently ordered that Mr. Hua be retried, saying that his conviction was based on "unclear facts." Elisabeth Rosenthal (NYT)

Mr. McCain toured the so-called Hanoi Hilton, where he was held for five and a half years, with his 13-year-old son on Wednesday, and said that he still bore his guards "ill will" for killing some American prisoners there. (Reuters) --

MEXICO: AUTO AMNESTY -- Congress passed a bill allowing owners of some two million American-registered cars brought illegally into Mexico to register them in Mexico, for a fee. The bill awaits Senate consideration. President Ernesto Zedillo criticized lawmakers who voted for the law as pandering to owners of illegal vehicles two months before general elections. But his government recently decreed a similar measure legalizing American-registered pickup trucks, most owned by governing-party supporters. Sam Dillon (NYT)
 
PERU: POSSIBLE BERENSON REVIEW -- Without promising to release her from prison, the opposition presidential candidate Alejandro Toledo held open the possibility of a legal appeal for Lori Berenson, the American convicted four years ago of helping the Tupac Amaru guerrillas. In New York, Mr. Toledo said that under judicial reforms he favors, Ms. Berenson's lawyers would be allowed to present evidence that she was judged unfairly. Ms. Berenson's parents say she was convicted in a sham proceeding. Anthony DePalma (NYT)
 
CANADA: CONTEST TO LEAD RIGHTIST PARTY WIDENS -- Tom Long, a conservative strategist from Ontario, Canada's most populous province, joined the race for the leadership of the new opposition conservative party, the Canadian Alliance. Mr. Long promised to cut taxes as part of a campaign to reverse Canada's brain drain to the United States. The first round of balloting for party members is June 24. James Brooke (NYT)

ZIMBABWE: PHOTOGRAPHER HELD -- An Associated Press photographer was arrested after the police said he matched the description of a person seen leaving the scene of a firebombing at the country's only independent daily newspaper. His lawyer said the photographer heard the blast, went to investigate and then went to get his cameras. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

ISRAEL: WITHDRAWAL COSTS -- Israel's withdrawal from southern Lebanon and redeployment along its northern border will cost about $250 million, a senior Israeli official said. That does not include the cost of relocating and compensating officers of the Israeli-backed South Lebanese Army, said Amos Yaron, director general of the Defense Ministry. Deborah Sontag (NYT)

NETHERLANDS: LOCKERBIE TRIAL NEXT WEEK -- A court set May 3 as the opening date for the trial of two Libyans accused in the 1988 bombing of a Pan Am jet over Lockerbie, Scotland, killing 270 people. Prosecutors had asked for more time to study new plans presented by the defense, but the judges refused, noting that the trial was postponed twice before. The Libyans will be tried under Scottish law in the Dutch city of Zeist.

Britain suspended the power-sharing assembly in February, blaming the Irish Republican Army's failure to begin disarming.
 Warren Hoge (NYT)

Known as Tarzan for his flowing hair and robust oratory, Mr. Heseltine led the 1990 Tory revolt that toppled Margaret Thatcher but then failed in his bid to succeed her. Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
TURKEY: REFORMIST CANDIDATE HOLDS LEAD -- The reformist presidential candidate favored by political party leaders, Ahmet Necdet Sezer, finished far ahead of other candidates in the first ballot in Parliament, but fell short of the necessary two-thirds majority. He did not mention the environment, a sensitive topic since one Green leader, former Environment Minister Edo Ronchi, declined on Wednesday to enter Mr. Amato's shuffled cabinet after the environment post was awarded to another party. Approval of Mr. Amato's government hangs on a few votes. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

HEADLINE: When Will Stocks Really Crumble? After the Dollar Does

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
THE money managers panicked. The people bought.
That is the real story of the wild month that ends today. After the worst week in Nasdaq history ended two weeks ago, Wall Street braced for a wave of selling that did not arrive. Instead, there was a rebound. 
 That has happened time and again in recent years. Just as market fundamentalists take heart from the collapse of highflying stocks and proclaim that value now matters, the fall ends. The bears are vanquished.
If that pattern is repeating -- as I believe it is -- the most interesting question for investors is how they will be able to tell if the next plunge, whenever it comes, is the real thing or just another buying opportunity.
The answer is: Check the dollar and the economy. One or both of them are likely to get into trouble before the stock market suffers a prolonged downturn.
Why? Because professional money managers really don't matter much in the current environment. They can move money from stock to stock, but they cannot stay out of stocks for very long. The pressures to be fully invested are too great. The managers may fear the Federal Reserve, which is more likely than ever to raise interest rates after the report yesterday that consumer spending is rising at the fastest rate since 1983. But their customers are not worried. The Nasdaq market fell yesterday morning because professional investors feared rising interest rates. But the amateurs were buying, and soon prices were up nicely.
American investors are certain that stocks are the best long-term investment. That lesson, learned over many years, will not soon be unlearned.
A recession would operate on many investors as margin calls operated on some during the Nasdaq swoon this month; it would force selling by people who needed to raise cash. The selling would be slow and prolonged, bringing a gradual market erosion rather than a crash. The stock market would follow the economy down.
The other group of investors worth watching is foreigners, particularly Europeans. If they were not eager to invest in this country, the huge trade deficits caused by all that consumer spending would have led to a dollar crisis. If foreign investors turned negative, or even if they invested less than they are now, a falling dollar would provide a warning of stock weakness.
That is not happening now. Instead, it is the euro that is weak, despite Europe's strong current account surpluses. For a variety of reasons, few want to invest in Europe.
Europeans worried about their own currency have bought American stocks, thus pushing up our stock prices and supporting the dollar. Someday, perhaps when European investments begin to look more attractive -- or American ones less so -- the circle will reverse, and selling American stocks will damage the dollar, which will damage the stock market, and so on. The euro is likely to rally markedly at some point, to well above the current level.
In the long run, those who argue that technology stocks still reflect ridiculous optimism may be proved right. But most investors have not been scared off even as some Internet wonders have collapsed. The Nasdaq composite is down 17 percent for April, and its volatility -- measured as the standard deviation of daily percentage changes -- is the greatest in Nasdaq history, surpassing October 1987. But the Dow Jones industrial average is off less than 1 percent for the month, and Nasdaq is higher than it was in mid-December. Investor faith is still alive.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Latin America's Main Markets Mirror Nasdaq's Bumpy Ride

BYLINE: By JENNIFER L. RICH

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, April 27

 BODY:
With the Nasdaq oscillating sharply this month, Latin America's two principal markets, the Bovespa of Brazil and the Bolsa of Mexico, have gone along for the ride.
Emerging markets have always been buffeted by instability in the United States as anxious investors pull out of what are considered high-risk positions elsewhere. But because Latin American markets have been dominated by brick-and-mortar companies, they have usually been linked to the Dow, not the technology-heavy Nasdaq. This new relationship has confounded investors, particularly now that the Brazilian and Mexican economies are booming. 
 Since the beginning of the Nasdaq swing, the Bovespa index has dropped to 15,440, after rising to a high of 19,046 in March. In Mexico, the Bolsa index has fallen to 6,844, from a high of 8,417, also in March. Some of the current downward pressure can be directly linked to the market in the United States.
"It was Nasdaq euphoria that fueled the markets in the fourth quarter," said David Chon, Latin America equity strategist for Bear, Stearns. "After running up significantly, some of the froth is now coming off of the telecom-media-technology sectors."
Indeed, the telecommunications sector, which makes up about 50 percent of the Bovespa, has led Brazil's downward trend. The shares of CRT Cellular, for example, which is controlled by Telefonica de Espana, fell from a high of 899 reais ($499.20) in March, to 609 reais at today's close. CRT is one of the cellular companies in Brazil that plans to start wireless Internet services by June.
"The telecom companies are all earning revenue from the Internet," said Julio Zeigelmann, director of equity funds at BankBoston Asset Management in Sao Paulo. "It makes sense that decreasing optimism in the Internet would affect us locally." In Mexico, Telefonos de Mexico has also taken a hit, closing today at 28.4 pesos (3.01), 22 percent below its 52-week high of 36.2 pesos on March 7.
But since technology is still a nascent industry in Latin America, most companies -- including telecommunications concerns, which are still trying to meet demand for regular fixed-line service -- are still squarely part of the traditional economy. That makes for a tenuous connection between Latin American stocks and the Nasdaq.
"This correlation doesn't have much logic," said Octavio de Barros, chief economist of BBV Argentaria in Sao Paulo. "When the market realizes that the Bovespa is not linked to the Nasdaq, we could have a rally."
Many companies in Latin America, and particularly in Brazil, are undervalued now that stock prices have fallen, with many trading below book value, according to many analysts. They say that the flight to quality that normally occurs during market turbulence should reverse once the value of Latin American stocks becomes widely known.
Quarterly reports released this week have also animated investors. On Tuesday, for example, the Mexican cement company Cemex announced that operating profit rose 22 percent in the first quarter compared with the 1999 quarter, beating analyst's expectations. The positive news follows impressive results announced last week by the Brazilian steel company CVRD, which increased profits 98 percent in the first quarter over the comparable period last year.
The earnings reports followed positive economic news coming out of Latin America. Since the Russian debt crisis in 1998 sent investors running from Latin America and forced Brazil to devalue its currency, the region has had a quick recovery. Latin America is expected to grow 3.7 percent this year, up from 0.2 percent last year, according to estimates from ING Barings.
Inflation has also shown some decline this year. The region should finish the year with inflation at 6 to 8 percent, compared with 8.8 percent last year. The International Monetary Fund recently revised its inflation target for Latin America this year to 7.7 percent from 8.4 percent on strong economic activity coming out of the region.
Brazil's Congress also recently passed important legislation, the Fiscal Responsibility Law, which establishes austere spending and indebtedness limits for the local, state and federal governments. The Brazilian government has been battling large deficits for years, and indebtedness was a primary cause of investor uncertainty in the devaluation last year. The budget deficit now stands at 3.6 percent of the country's gross domestic product, but with the new law and the economic recovery, the government expects the deficit to fall to about 2 percent of G.D.P. in 2001.
In Mexico, investment activity, which has been strong this year because of ties to the United States through the North American Free Trade Agreement, is expected to slow before the presidential election scheduled on July 2.

HEADLINE: TENNIS;
Other Side of Tracks To Other Side of Net

BYLINE: By TOM SPOUSTA 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, April 26

 BODY:
Growing up in the projects of East Las Vegas, Claudia Meza wore black lipstick, flashed gang signs and concealed knives and brass knuckles in her baggy pants.
At age 12, she endured depression that led to a suicide attempt, which failed when her cousin walked into the bathroom. At 14, she was sent to live with a grandmother in a tough South Tucson neighborhood where she heard gunshots again, got into fewer fights but also picked up a tennis racket and, in five years earned a half-scholarship and national collegiate ranking at Grand Canyon University. 
 In June, the 5-foot-10-inch Meza will take her fearless attitude and aggressive strokes to the Rick Macci Tennis Academy in Pompano Beach, Fla., for a summer of instruction. She was invited sight unseen, discovered over the Internet in a flurry of e-mail messages between a caring high-school coach and a tennis academy searching for the next Venus or Serena Williams. "I take a deep breath every time I think about it," Meza said.
"I always believed in myself, even though I was a thug," she said recently after her last home match at Grand Canyon University. "I always felt I could be something. I just didn't know how or when it would happen."
The Macci Academy is trying to hone the skills that will make it happen someday for Meza on the international tour. "In this business, sometimes you've got to gamble," said Greg Russell, the director of coaches and technical development for the academy, which produced Jennifer Capriati. "You've just got to have a gut feeling, and seeing her background, we decided to help her. Whatever happens, happens. At least we gave her a chance."
Meza, a 20-year-old sophomore, recently cracked the Intercollegiate Tennis Association Division II ranking, making her debut at No. 17 in the West. She hopes to improve on that at a tournament this weekend in Ojai, Calif.
"It's unbelievable," Meza said of her Macci invitation. "I'm still shocked, I guess, that they'd want to work with me. Tennis saved me. It gave me something to look forward to. I started a whole new life. It was a transformation, and it happened so fast."
Meza's choices had seemed to be jail or worse during a troubled home life. Her father, Amado, was in and out of jail for most of her childhood and spent little time with his family. Her mother, Maria, worked as a housekeeper at Caesars Palace to support Claudia and her younger sister, Crystal. Her mother found it increasingly difficult to control Claudia, whose problems eventually followed her home.
"They would come and break our windows and slash our tires," Maria Meza said of the gangs in an interview from Las Vegas last week. "They call and say, 'I'm going to kill your daughter, I'm going to kill you.' "
One night, a gang of about 25 young people chased Claudia to her house and stood outside yelling threats until the police arrived. Not long afterward, the family decided that Claudia should go to south Tucson.
"She had to go," Maria Meza said. "It was too much. So many fights. I was so scared. I thought she'd end up dead."
Claudia's new environment was not much different. Her grandmother, Guillerma Meza, lives near Irvington and South 12th Avenue, a flashpoint for violence in South Tucson. Early Easter morning, two separate shooting incidents within six blocks of her house left three people dead.
Guillerma's guidance, however, worked wonders on her granddaughter. Within one year, she got Claudia interested in attending church. She also thought modeling classes would help the girl's self-confidence. To help pay for those classes, Guillerma Meza traveled to Juarez, Mexico, to buy clothes in the open markets and sell them in Tucson for a profit.
"It broke my heart to see her like she was," Guillerma Meza said in Spanish over Easter brunch at her home. "I'm proud of her because we have had a struggle together. We fight hard, and I thank God for this."
Claudia, who was translating, stopped to wipe a tear from her eye, before her grandmother continued speaking.
"I can't believe how far she has gotten," Guillerma said. "I cry for joy, it's so unbelievable."
Across the table sat Stacy Haines, the tennis coach at Desert View High School, who first saw Meza's potential. Meza tried out for the team because a friend wanted her to. Rough as Meza was -- in her first high-school match, she threatened to beat up an opponent who was winning points on high, deep lobs -- Haines liked the athletic aggression she showed.
"I didn't have any strokes," Meza said. "I'd hit balls over the fence. I didn't know how to keep score or anything. I stereotyped it as a wimpy game.
"I never thought I'd do it."
On Haines, Meza said: "He was the first to actually believe in me and tell me I could do things. He made me feel worthwhile."
Haines eventually got Meza into the Tucson Racquet Club for instruction. "She didn't fit in, but she wouldn't quit," Haines said.
"Nobody in tennis has been nice to her," he added. "Part of it was probably racial, but it was also economic. Some of it was her feeling inferior, too, but she gradually got more confidence."
Meza recalled a conversation with a member on one of her first visits to the club.
"I walked by him, and he asked, 'Where are you from?' I said, 'South Tucson.' He said, 'What are you doing here?' I said, 'playing tennis.' He just said, 'Oh.' "
Haines has served as Meza's coach, defender, mentor and publicist. He initially contacted Gerry Roberts, the academy's former director of sports science and now a Macci consultant. Roberts passed the information about Meza to Russell, who sent the official invitation in March via an e-mail message.
"It's not her age, it's her motivation and how hard she works," Russell said, when asked whether Meza could overcome the late start and be successful on the tour. "The good thing about that is you don't have to teach an old dog new tricks.
"Kids who come here with an endless amount of money, and no matter what you do, you can't motivate them. Here's a kid with an unbelievable background, who's fought her way this far this fast and she really wants it. I love working with kids like that."
Meza, meanwhile, relishes the opportunity to break down stereotypes. "I have to make my people proud," she said. "There has to be somebody to step up and tell everybody they can do it."

HEADLINE: Reports Give Fed the Fodder for Higher Rates

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
The reports today that the economy is flirting with inflation were probably not enough on their own to lock the Federal Reserve into a more aggressive course of interest rate increases when it meets on May 16.
But the robust pace of growth in the first quarter and the clear warning signs of an acceleration in wage and price increases all but guarantee that Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, and his colleagues at the central bank will seriously consider raising rates by half a percentage point rather than by the quarter-point that investors and economists have been anticipating. 
 Instead of fighting a phantom -- the theoretical possibility of a pickup in inflation -- the Fed can now point to specific if early evidence that the economy is overheating.
"The economic data make an overwhelming case for picking up the pace of tightening," said James F. O'Sullivan, an economist at J. P. Morgan.
Still, the Fed has tended not to change policy because of one or two economic reports. Mr. Greenspan did not mention the latest indicators in a speech today on the rural economy. But he has long preferred to change policy in gradual, consistent steps that are well telegraphed to the markets, a practice he has followed faithfully over the last 10 months in raising rates five times in quarter-point increments.
Because Mr. Greenspan has given no public indication that he is ready to raise rates in bigger steps, some analysts think the Fed is unlikely to opt for a half-point increase in May. The Fed's benchmark federal funds target rate stands at 6 percent.
Some Fed officials have also emphasized in recent months that small rate increases are the most prudent course at a time when there are so many unresolved questions about how fast the economy can grow without igniting inflation.
Mr. Greenspan has expressed hope about improvements in productivity, the crucial factor in determining the economy's noninflationary speed limit. But he has also said that at some point even productivity cannot offset upward pressure on wages and prices.
"When you're in a fog, you take small steps," said Bill Cheney, an economist at John Hancock, the life insurance company. "One could argue strongly for a course of sticking to 25-basis-point increases." (A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.)
Yet even if Mr. Greenspan sticks to his gradualist approach, he will confront pressure from other members of the central bank's policy- setting Federal Open Market Committee, some of whom have been pushing for half-point increases since February.
The minutes of the Feb. 1-2 meeting, when the Fed raised rates by a quarter-point, indicated that a few members were pressing then for an increase of 50 basis points "in order to provide greater assurance against a buildup of inflationary expectations and inflation" in subsequent months. Other members, the minutes said, acknowledged that more aggressive action might be needed if the economy continued to roar along, as it has.
The minutes of the meeting on March 21, when the Fed voted for another quarter-point increase, have not been made public.
It is unclear how many of the committee's 10 voting members would favor a half-point increase. But they are almost certain to include Jerry Jordan, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, who is perhaps the most vociferous inflation hawk on the Fed. They are also likely to include Laurence H. Meyer, a Fed governor who has long warned that the current combination of 4.1 percent unemployment and strong growth cannot continue indefinitely without creating a cycle of rising wages and prices.
The uncertainties about the economy's capacity to grow without inflation have led to a monetary policy course that has been "somewhat more gradualist, in my view, somewhat less pre-emptive than it otherwise might have been," Mr. Meyer said in a speech several weeks ago. He added, pointedly, that "there are limits to monetary policy's tolerance for above-trend growth and for further labor market tightening."
Before making its decision, the Fed will have several more sets of economic data to consider, including a report on job creation and unemployment next Friday and the report on the Consumer Price Index, which will be released on the morning of the Fed meeting on May 16.
Another wild card for the central bank is the stock market. A stabilization or rebound in the market in coming weeks could add to pressure on the Fed to raise rates more aggressively. Should the market turn down again and stay down, it could help dampen consumer spending and overall demand, reducing inflation pressures.

HEADLINE: 300 People, 14 Dead, Found Stranded on Isle in Bahamas

BYLINE: By KATHERINE E. FINKELSTEIN 

 BODY:
NASSAU, the Bahamas, April 27 -- Fourteen Haitians died and 264 others were stranded on an uninhabited island for an unknown period of time after their overloaded 50-foot boat broke down at sea about 200 miles southeast of here, United States Coast Guard officials said today.
Bahamian and American vessels participated in the rescue effort, which began on Wednesday evening after passengers on three sailboats passing nearby spotted hundreds of dehydrated and weak people on Flamingo Cay. They radioed Bahamian authorities, who in turn requested the help of the United States Coast Guard, which maintains ships and helicopters in the region for drug interdiction and rescue operations. 
 Dozens of the weakest Haitians were rushed by helicopter to the nearest clinic, about 70 miles away at Georgetown, Exuma, while the others were evacuated from the barren island late today aboard the Royal Bahamas Defence Force vessel the Bahamas.
Michael Minns, who owns a market and a small marina in Georgetown, was among the first to be notified about the emergency on the island, and helped coordinate the rescue efforts at the request of the Bahamas Air Sea Rescue Association. He said that throughout Wednesday night, he fielded anxious mayday calls from the sailors who discovered the people on the island.
The calls quickly became urgent when a doctor who had been aboard a passing boat stepped ashore to tend to them, whom he described as being in desperate condition. When the first 11 of the most seriously ill reached the one-doctor clinic at Georgetown, he thought they were headed for the morgue.
"Some of them were comatose," he said. "I thought they were dead. They had on very little clothing, some were in their underwear and they were covered with dust and dirt. None of them could walk. Most had trouble even holding their heads up."
Mr. Minns said the 11 recovered after being given intravenous fluids, but communication was difficult, he said, because they only spoke Creole. He said 11 others arrived later that night. Authorities are unsure how they became stranded, but they assume they were being smuggled to the United States.
"'We don't know whether the vessel sank or it just dropped them off," said Petty Officer Gibran Soto, a Coast Guard spokesman in Miami. "There was no vessel nearby, and we don't know how long they were there."
Mr. Minns said he provided food and water from his store to be taken to the Haitians today. He said he had heard unconfirmed reports from some people involved in the rescue that the boat's engine had broken under the strain of its load, and that it might have drifted for as long as six days.
"The boat drifted to the shore and they were stuck," Mr. Minns said. "They were on a small, dry cay without much to protect them."
Because the Haitians were discovered in Bahamian territory, Bahamian authorities will have the responsibility of repatriating them to Haiti.
This is the largest such incident of intercepted or stranded immigrants, but it is hardly the first. Haitians have long come here to seek work in menial jobs in gardening, construction or housecleaning, fleeing the poverty and violence that has crippled their homeland for years. Others slip into the Bahamas looking for another smuggler to take them to the United States, paying a price that is dear, and sometimes deadly, for the privilege of packing themselves into rickety and creaky boats. In 1995, smugglers threw 100 Haitians overboard to lighten a boat headed for the Bahamas. All were believed to have drowned.
Political repression, violence and searing poverty have led Haitians to flee in great numbers. Last year the Coast Guard intercepted 480 Haitians trying to enter the United States, and 1,437 in 1998. The discovery of this latest group comes at a time when Haiti is confronting election-related violence as it prepares for next month's parliamentary elections, which have already been postponed several times.
Haitians are fearful that the violence, which has already claimed, among others, the life of a prominent radio commentator, will only increase as it heads towards presidential elections later this year. All the while, the nation has been at an economic and political standstill, with no legislature, almost no investment and even less foreign aid, and a devastated social and physical infrastructure.
Bahamian authorities told the Reuters news agency that several hundred Haitian immigrants were intercepted in Bahamian waters in recent weeks. Anywhere from 20,000 to 40,000 Haitians live illegally in the Bahamas, a nation of 700 islands that is home to 280,000 people.
"We are being engulfed," a Royal Bahamas Defence Force senior commander, Raymond Farqhuarson, told Reuters.
Mr. Minns said that he receives distress calls from Bahamian seamen who discover stranded Haitian vessels about every six weeks.
"It's constant," he said. "Some vessel with a broken engine, lost in the water. They put a whole lot of people on board and not enough food and water. They have no navigation aids, or even a compass."

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Dynamism, Put to Work for Livery Drivers

BYLINE: By JAN HOFFMAN 

 BODY:
"DO people think I'm a media hound? Really?" Fernando A. Mateo asks, just shocked. "But it's all about good issues, right?"
Mr. Mateo has been popping up everywhere recently as president of the New York State Federation of Taxi Drivers, representing livery drivers, who, unlike their yellow-cab comrades, routinely work the poorer neighborhoods in the boroughs other than Manhattan. 
 On Monday night, the eighth driver this year was killed. Early Tuesday, Mr. Mateo began fielding calls from reporters, politicians, the police, drivers. He demanded investigations. Safety measures. On Wednesday, he moderated a panel of Latino and black leaders about inner-city crime. And organized yesterday's funeral procession.
As it happens, Mr. Mateo, 42, neither lives in the city nor drives a livery car. Dominican-born (in this lifetime; he believes in reincarnation), he is a 10th-grade dropout who became a millionaire, lives in the Westchester suburb of Irvington and has an assistant who often chauffeurs him.
With three businesses and a foundation, he hardly needs to be consoling yet another family in raw grief until 3 a.m., only to be awakened two hours later by reporters. Yet stoked by adrenaline, outrage and, yes, all that attention -- "it's like an addiction, you know?" -- Mr. Mateo, who, a few years ago, unveiled the mediagenic Toys for Guns exchange, has given the mostly immigrant drivers visibility.
As a consequence, the city pledged $5 million for safety partitions. Moreover, Mr. Mateo has negotiated an affordable health care plan for 8,000 members, who are largely self-employed.
And attention is again being paid to Mr. Mateo, a short, piston-powered, fast-fuse charmer whose son calls him Jackhammer.
On Tuesday, the day after the killing, he was furiously working two cell phones. He put V.I.P.'s on hold, told the major news organizations to call back in 10 minutes and the minor ones in 30. His businesses -- carpets, sidewalk restoration -- had to fend for themselves.
"Is Charlie there?" he said, calling Representative Charles B. Rangel's office. "Hello, Bob!" he said over the phone to Robert T. Johnson, the Bronx district attorney. Senator Charles E. Schumer returned his call and got blasted with Mr. Mateo's blunt entreaty for federal resources.
Mr. Mateo, more polished and political than he was years ago, when he was known in the downtown projects as the relentlessly hustling Freddie the Carpet Guy, still excels in sizing up his customer: "Senator! At the press conference I'll say I just spoke with you and that you're going to try to do something. You'll hear that everywhere, all over the news! Thank you, senator."
HUNDREDS of livery drivers gathered for the South Bronx news conference. Mr. Mateo spoke in English, then Spanish. As drivers chanted "Justicia! Justicia!" Mr. Mateo, in suit and tie, clambered atop a sawhorse, clung to a street pole and articulated their sorrowful anger. He revved them, he calmed them. His performance was dynamic, eloquent, canny.
The impulse to be center stage has always been with him. When he was 5, his mother sent him, the youngest of nine, to parochial boarding schools in New England while his father toiled in a city bodega. Lonely, he learned self-reliance and to propel himself forward.
The family's finances foundered, and he went to a public high school before dropping out to apprentice as a floor installer. At 17, he had a storefront on Avenue A and a wife. (He has three children and has been with his second wife, Stella, who runs his trench-building company, for 20 years.) By the 1980's, he had moved Carpet Fashions to two glass palace showrooms and had become a carpet installer to the stars.
In 1989, he felt his marker had come due: in the Dominican tradition of "la promesa," he had promised to give back if his business flourished. He taught floor installation to nonviolent inmates at Rikers and persuaded other tradespeople to do so. The program was respected; his profile was emerging.
During the recession, his own fortunes tumbled. Pushy, proud, hard-headed, he fought back in the 90's by diversifying his businesses.
A casual conversation with his son near Christmas in 1993 inspired the gun-swap program. It would vacuum 3,000 guns off New York streets and be widely imitated. Mr. Mateo -- Oprah! Peter Jennings! -- became a media hero.
When, in the natural course of events, he became old news, he slipped into depressed seclusion. Stella and the kids dragged him out, shouting, "Your family thinks you're important!"
Recently, he butted heads with politicians in the Dominican Republic over absentee ballots. That and his leadership of the livery drivers -- they approached him -- have raised his profile, especially among New York Latinos, some of whose officials view him with wary admiration. A Republican, he is coy about a future in politics.
"There's nothing I've wanted that I haven't gotten," Mr. Mateo said with an exuberant earnestness. "I always thought I'd meet the president. Clinton invited 2,000 people to the White House for the signing of his crime bill. I sat in the audience thinking, 'I should be up on that podium!' Then I saw empty chairs behind him.
"I'll never let an opportunity go by when I can seize it. So I said to the Secret Service, 'Excuse me, sir,' and I stepped up and stood next to Janet Reno. Afterwards I shook his hand and said, 'Mr. President, thank you for having me here!' "

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Rate Increase Fails to Halt Euro's Slide Against Dollar

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, April 27

 BODY:
The European Central Bank raised interest rates today for the fourth time in six months but Europe's common currency, the euro, again defied its guardians and plunged to another record low against the American dollar.
The rate increase, from 3.5 percent to 3.75 percent, would normally tend to support the euro's value. But in a display of the gloom that now envelops the currency, the euro sank to less than 91 cents from 92.33 cents before closing in New York at 91.01 cents. 
 "The euro is now in uncharted waters, and you don't know how far it will go down," said Gerhard Grebe, an economist at Bank Julius Baer in Frankfurt.
Since its debut at the start of 1999, when it was worth $1.17, the euro's value against the dollar has slid about 21 percent.
Parity with the dollar, which once seemed to represent an unthinkable decline in the euro's value, now looks to many traders like an impossibly high target, at least for the next several months.
Until recently, the decline of the euro was more of a political embarrassment than an economic problem. Indeed, the weak euro has provided a major lift to European exporters by making their products cheap in terms of dollars and creating windfall currency profits from sales in dollars. But European officials have become increasingly concerned that the euro's weakness will fuel inflation here by raising the prices of imported goods.
The euro's plight has even begun to alarm some of its most ardent supporters. Norbert Walter, chief economist at Deutsche Bank, has long contended that the new currency would be a powerful challenger to the world dominance of the dollar.
But this week, Mr. Walter argued that European central bankers should intervene if the euro's value slips meaningfully below 90 cents. In an interview with the German newspaper Die Welt, he argued that European central bankers ought to sell their reserves of dollars, which now total about $250 billion.
"Why shouldn't they sell now?" Mr. Walter said. "It would simultaneously make an impression on international speculators and support the euro."
Adopted by 11 European countries at the start of 1999, the euro is on its way toward creating a single European economy as big as that of the United States. Though the countries will continue to have their own national currencies until 2002, their monetary policies are now locked together under the control of the European Central Bank.
But the euro has been anemic ever since its birth, and the problem has become more acute in the last several weeks. The German mark is worth about 46 American cents, its lowest level in 14 years.
The European Central Bank said its primary concern today was about inflation rather than exchange rates.
But inflation is closely linked to the weakness of the euro, which has started to drive up import prices.
Most economists and currency strategists had been expecting today's action, and most say that the central bank will raise rates at least once more in the months ahead.
Far more puzzling is why the euro continues to fall so sharply in value.
Economic growth in the 11-nation euro zone is expected to reach 3.4 percent this year, its fastest pace in years, and employment is climbing rapidly for the first time in a decade.
Inflation, meanwhile, is lower in Europe than in the United States. Investment and employment are both accelerating, and Europe has a big trade surplus while the United States has a mammoth trade deficit.
Yet the United States continues to grow faster. The United States Commerce Department reported today that the American gross domestic product increased at an annual rate of 5.4 percent in the first quarter. Beyond statistics, the mystique associated with American technology has made the country a magnet for foreign direct investment.
Most economists had been forecasting that the euro would climb by the second half of 1999. Then they predicted it would appreciate in the first few months of this year.
Jesper Dannesboe, a currency strategist at the Dutch bank ABN Amro, said part of the euro's most recent distress stems from the grievously optimistic views of many international fund managers.
Convinced last fall that the euro would recover after tumbling to $1.06 from $1.17, fund managers started buying euros and selling dollars.
But the United States and the dollar both defied expectations, as American growth accelerated rather than slowed, and direct investment continued to pour into the United States from around the world.
"By the end of the fourth quarter, international fund managers were massively overweight on the euros," Mr. Dannesboe said. The result is that investors are looking at any rise in the euro as a chance to sell their holdings, he added.
The difficulties were compounded earlier this month, after the Nasdaq market plunged.
Many investors viewed the turbulence in American stocks as a new reason for believing that European assets and the euro would become a safe haven. But that did not happen. When the euro barely budged against the dollar and then the Nasdaq market bounced back, the pressure to sell euros intensified further.
The entire life of the euro has left economists and currency traders bewildered. Ralf Schneider, an economist at Dresdner Bank, noted that the violent currency swings are hardly unprecedented.
Between 1980 and 1985, the dollar nearly doubled in value against the German mark -- the currency that continues to be at the heart of the euro. The mark went to $3.45 from about $1.70, largely because the American economy underwent a powerful growth spurt between 1983 and 1985. By 1988, the exchange rate moved back to about $1.70 a mark.
"This shows that growth differentials are very important," Mr. Schneider said. "My argument is that the euro has done better than the D-mark would have."

HEADLINE: Whitman Ends Plan to Shift 900 to Suburb From Trenton

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 27

 BODY:
Agreeing with critics who said the state was ignoring its own guidelines for so-called smart growth, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman today abruptly canceled a plan to move more than 900 state revenue workers from the capital to a neighboring suburb, even after the government had spent $3 million on preliminary construction of a new office building.
Trenton, like many other medium-size New Jersey cities, has been largely bypassed by the boom in the state's economy, and the governor said today that her administration would consider locations in cities for state offices before making such decisions from now on. "Keeping state jobs in cities is our first priority," she said. "That's smart growth." 
 Mrs. Whitman's action came a day after Trenton officials said they had completed $54 million in financing for what would be the city's only hotel -- this has long been the only state capital without one -- including $5 million in a no-interest loan from the state.
The mayor of Trenton, Douglas H. Palmer, expressed mixed feelings about the governor's decision, saying he was pleased that state workers would remain in the city but concerned that a move to another location within Trenton might ultimately remove another property from the city's tax rolls.
"We have to work out some of the details, and look at potential sites that would make sense for the state and for the city," he said. "It's important that while we welcome jobs staying in Trenton, we also look at losing ratables. It's not a tradeoff I'd like to make."
Officials in Hamilton Township reacted angrily to the news, saying they had cooperated with the State Treasury Department for more than a year on the project, in which the Division of Revenue was to have closed three office buildings in Trenton and moved to a new $55 million complex it would have shared with the state police.
"We've devoted a lot of time, effort and hours in assisting the state in fast-tracking this project out of the belief that it would be good not only for the community but for the whole state," said Glen D. Gilmore, the mayor of Hamilton, who said he learned of Mrs. Whitman's decision from reporters. "The governor just wakes up one morning and pulls the rug out from under us."
Mr. Gilmore, a Democrat, added, "This project has wasted not only our resources but the state's."
But Jayne O'Connor, a spokeswoman for the governor, said that, although the site had been excavated and a gravel road had been built, no foundations had yet been laid. She said the $3 million spent so far might not be a complete loss, depending on what the state eventually decided to do with the site.
In recent weeks, the proposed move had galvanized environmental advocates and business executives. The president of the New Jersey Builders Association wrote in an op-ed article that it was hypocritical for the state to ignore its own planning guidelines while expecting developers to adhere to them.

HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by B. Drummond Ayres Jr.

 BODY:

THE DEMOCRATS
 
GORE HELPS PARTY, TOO -- Less than 24 hours after criticizing Gov. George W. Bush of Texas for headlining a Washington fund-raiser that brought in a record $21.3 million for the Republican Party, Vice President Al Gore held bookend fund-raising events yesterday in Pennsylvania, helping the Democratic National Committee raise more than $1.2 million. Over lunch in Pittsburgh and then dinner in Philadelphia, Mr. Gore boasted about the Clinton administration's economic record and accused Mr. Bush of advocating a "don't worry about tomorrow" plan of "risky" tax cuts. James Dao (NYT)
 
THE POLLS
 

BOREDOM SETS IN -- The drawn out, sometimes hectic system for nominating and electing a president neither broadens the public's understanding of campaigns nor encourages involvement in them and in the end leaves many voters bored. That is the initial conclusion of the Vanishing Voter Project, a study being conducted by the Joan Shorenstein Center on the Press, Politics and Public Policy at Harvard University. In a series of weekly polls of voter perceptions last fall and this spring, the center queried voters about what political stories and issues they were following each day, if any, and how much, if any, they were discussing politics daily. The finding: Public interest and involvement in the campaign was very low throughout late 1999, built during the spring caucuses and primaries and then fell off sharply, and has remained very low since it became clear in early March who the nominees would be. Sixty percent of respondents said the nominating system was too hectic and drawn out and should be reworked. (NYT)
 
BUSH AHEAD IN OHIO -- A new presidential preference poll of Ohio voters by the University of Cincinnati -- Ohio is considered a state that could go to Mr. Bush or Mr. Gore -- has Governor Bush leading Vice President Gore by 8 points, about the same margin found by an Ohio State University poll taken a month ago. The Cincinnati poll, conducted April 5 through 22 and covering 531 likely voters, found Mr. Bush ahead of Mr. Gore 47 percent to 39 percent. Ralph Nader of the Green Party had 4 percent, Pat Buchanan of the Reform Party had 3 percent, and 7 percent of the respondents said they were undecided. The margin of sampling error for the poll was plus or minus 4 percentage points. In Washington State, originally assumed to be solid Gore territory, a newly released preference poll has Mr. Bush ahead by a single point, 39 percent to 38 percent, with 18 percent of the respondents undecided. The poll, conducted by Elway Research, a nonpartisan firm, surveyed 400 registered voters on April 11 and 12 and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 5 percentage points.
 B. Drummond Ayres Jr. (NYT)
 
THE CONVENTIONS
 
GROUPS ALLOWED TO PROTEST -- The City of Philadelphia reached an amicable settlement yesterday with a coalition of more than 50 groups that had said their right to public assembly would be violated during this summer's Republican National Convention. The groups initially were denied demonstration permits by the city, but yesterday it backed off and said it would guarantee them prime protest sites. "I applaud the city for reaffirming the notion that dissent is critical for a healthy democracy," said Stefan Presser, legal director of the American Civil Liberties Union, in withdrawing a federal lawsuit. The agreement, worked out through the office of the city solicitor, Kenneth Trujillo, allows a mass protest march along Benjamin Franklin Parkway on July 30, the eve of the convention, by Unity 2000, a coalition that includes the N.A.A.C.P. and the National Organization for Women. The city also approved a march on July 29 through Washington Square, near Independence Hall, by the Ad-Hoc Committee to Defend Health Care, a group of physicians and other medical professionals demanding government action on the issue.
 Francis X. Clines (NYT)

HEADLINE: Making Nike Shoes in Vietnam;
An Elusive U.S. Trade Pact Worries Workers and Bosses

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: BIEN HOA, Vietnam

 BODY:
Nguyen Anh Ha has never heard of the trade talks between Vietnam and the United States. But Mr. Ha, a 26-year-old migrant from northern Vietnam, knows all too well the fragility of life as a factory worker in the developing world.
"I have been worried ever since I came here," said Mr. Ha, as he rested after work in his bare one-room shelter, not far from the sprawling Nike plant north of Ho Chi Minh City, where he makes $120-a-pair athletic shoes. "We keep hearing rumors that they might reduce the number of workers." 
 Nike executives insist that they have no plans to cut back their work force in Vietnam, which numbers more than 45,000 at five factories owned and operated by contractors from South Korea and Taiwan.
Yet they acknowledge that the future here of Nike Inc. has grown cloudier because of the Hanoi government's reluctance to sign a breakthrough trade agreement with the United States. The deal, which was agreed to in principle in July, has stalled since Vietnamese negotiators began quibbling over various provisions.
"We're missing out on the biggest market in the world," said Lalit Monteiro, general manager of Nike's operations in Vietnam. "Our factories here are heavily dependent on the Asian and European markets. If those markets go sour, we're going to feel it."
It is not that Nike is banned from exporting products to the United States. Nor have the attacks by critics of labor practices in Nike's Asian factories played a role in blocking American purchases. But with Washington imposing import duties as high as 35 percent on all goods made in Vietnam, Nike says it is not economical to use this country as a manufacturing center for the American market.
The company, based in Beaverton, Ore., is one of dozens of foreign and local companies in Vietnam whose fortunes would be affected by a trade agreement. And as the largest private employer in the country, it illustrates better than most the huge stakes of the deal for many Vietnamese. It also illustrates the high price a country can pay if it chooses not to accede to the demands of the global economy.
Mr. Monteiro estimated that Nike would increase the portion of its shoes made in Vietnam to 15 percent from the current 12 percent if the deal was approved. That translates to nearly 20,000 new jobs. Other American executives in this country said the company has talked about shifting as many as 40,000 jobs from its plants in China. By contrast, some doubt that Nike will stay in Vietnam without an agreement.
"I think that is a risk," said Pete Peterson, the United States ambassador to Vietnam.
Mr. Peterson, a retired Air Force pilot who was shot down in Vietnam and spent more than six years as a prisoner of war, has been one of the trade agreement's most dogged proponents. In addition to promoting its merits to the Vietnamese government, he has lobbied with American business -- exhorting sometimes demoralized executives not to give up on the country.
"The biggest risk for Vietnam is the missed opportunity," Mr. Peterson said. "They have to find a way to create jobs. This trade agreement would be a major job-creation vehicle."
Like trade pacts with other countries, the deal would guarantee access to Vietnamese markets for American companies. In return, the United States would eliminate the stiff extra duties on imports from Vietnam. In Nike's case, that would cut 14 percent off the average cost of a pair of shoes made here.
The proposed agreement also has some new provisions, including a requirement that Hanoi disclose government procurement contracts. Vietnamese officials protest that no other country has been asked to do this. And they note that the World Trade Organization failed to approve such a requirement at its meeting in Seattle.
In a country where, 25 years after the end of the Vietnam War, suspicion toward Washington bubbles just under the surface, some people view the deal as a way for the United States to win economically what it could not win militarily.
"The Vietnamese are driven by fear," said Thomas J. Vallely, director of the Indochina program at the Institute for International Development at Harvard University. "They ask: 'Is globalization destroying us? Is this a political as well as an economic move on the part of the Western world?' "
In fact, Mr. Vallely and other experts said, a trade agreement would benefit Vietnam's exports far more than those from the United States. Vietnam sells $650 million worth of goods to Americans, while United States companies export $350 million worth to Vietnam. While Nike would be able to sell its shoes here, that would be a fraction of what Nike factories could export to the United States.
Access to the American market would expand Nike's business in Vietnam by more than just the athletic shoes shipped to California, Texas or New York. Because its Vietnamese factories now export only to Asia and Europe, they are limited in the number of models they make. A model popular in the United States as well as in Europe would be made in China or Indonesia, not Vietnam.
"We're losing orders because we don't have the flexibility to ship to the U.S. market," Mr. Monteiro said. Not surprisingly, Nike produces fewer shoes in Vietnam than in China, Indonesia or Thailand.
For Mr. Monteiro, who used to work in Nike's product development division, the delay in the trade deal has been a frustrating introduction to Vietnam. And it comes as Nike seems finally to have addressed another chronic problem in its operations here: labor conditions.
Late in 1997, the company was stung by the release of a report that documented unsafe conditions at one of its biggest plants. The report, prepared for Nike by the accounting firm Ernst & Young, said the factory, also situated 25 miles from Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, exposed workers to unacceptably high levels of toxic chemicals. It said 77 percent of the workers suffered respiratory problems.
Nike said it had been working to improve conditions in the factory before the report was publicized. And even the company's critics acknowledge that conditions have since improved. Dara O'Rourke. an environmental consultant who helped distribute the report to the news media, was allowed to conduct a follow-up inspection of the factory, known as Tae Kwang Vina, in March 1999.
"They felt the heat, which has motivated them to do things," said Mr. O'Rourke, an assistant professor of environmental policy at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "They switched away from the most toxic compounds. But they continue to work with organic solvents and glues."
Taking a visitor on a tour of Tae Kwang Vina recently, Nike officials pointed out improvements that had been made since Mr. O'Rourke's inspection. The factory, owned by a South Korean company, now uses water-based solvents, as opposed to chemicals, everywhere on its assembly line. It is introducing water solvents in the stitching area, where the leather parts of the shoes are pieced together.
Above workers' heads, powerful fans circulated the air, fans that Nike officials said had been installed since Mr. O'Rourke's visit. In noisy parts of the factory, a vast majority of workers used rubber earplugs -- addressing another of his worries.
Nike's contractors said they had been prodded to improve conditions by the storm of criticism in the United States. "I had pride in my factory," said C. T. Park, president of Tae Kwang Vina, which has more than 10,000 workers. "And then suddenly it was the worst factory in the world."
Nike has not been able to fix every problem in what are still monotonous, taxing jobs that can require handling hazardous material. Mr. Ha and two other workers in Nike's Chang Shin factory complained of runny noses, which they said began soon after they started on the job there. Their job is to press synthetic rubber into a heavy metal cast and heat it to create the contoured shape of a sole.
"Right now, I have good health," Mr. Ha said. "But in five years, I won't be able to work at this job anymore. It is too hard. I'll have to look for lighter work at another factory."
Mr. Ha works eight-hour shifts, six days a week, plus overtime, earning the equivalent of $50 a month. That is slightly below Nike's average monthly take-home pay of $55. But the company says this still compares well with Vietnam's per-capita income of $26 a month.
Labor laws in Vietnam are stricter than in many Asian countries, and Nike says it complies, or does even better, in every category. For example, the minimum age in this country for factory workers is 15. In Nike's footwear factories, workers must be 18; in its garment factories, they can be 16.
Employers cannot demand more than 48 hours a week from workers without paying overtime. But they can run their factories every day. Even so, Nike said it ordered its factories to close on Sundays.
Mr. Ha, however, said he had worked in the Chang Shin factory on a few recent Sundays. After an investigation, Nike confirmed that the plant had asked workers to do cleaning and maintenance on those days. Looking perturbed, Mr. Monteiro said he would discourage the practice.
Unlike previous Nike executives in Vietnam, Mr. Monteiro is neither secretive nor particularly defensive about the company's labor practices. He says he welcomes inspections of the factories by outside monitors like Mr. O'Rourke. "We closed down after the controversy," Mr. Monteiro said. "In retrospect, it was a mistake. But you learn and you move on."
Nike has also learned that there are some battles not worth joining. The Vietnamese government, for example, is considering whether to reduce the workweek to 40 hours from 48. The American Chamber of Commerce has urged Nike, as the largest foreign employer, to lobby against the change. While Nike holds that a shorter week would hurt Vietnam's competitiveness, it is saying little in the debate.
"I could never come out in public and ask the Vietnamese government not to have people work fewer hours," said Chris Helzer, Nike's director of government affairs. "We'd get strung up."
Besides, with the trade agreement hanging in the balance, Mr. Helzer noted that there were far worse threats to Vietnam's competitiveness.
