HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Fresh Evidence of Growth Stokes Fear of Inflation
The United States economy turned in another robust quarter, the government reported, as new evidence emerged that today's prosperity is finally pushing up labor costs, raising fear of higher inflation.
The gross domestic product, representing the value of all goods and services produced in the nation, rose at a 5.4 percent annual rate. A broad inflation measure published with the G.D.P. report rose by 3.2 percent, mainly because of higher gasoline and fuel oil prices. And a measure of labor costs, the Employment Cost Index, rose 1.4 percent. Page A1. 

The quick pace of growth and signs of an acceleration in wage and price increases all but guarantee that the Federal Reserve will seriously consider raising rates by half a percentage point instead of a quarter-point. C2.
 
Technology Shares Lead a Rally
Technology stocks regained market leadership, rising sharply and shaking off economic reports suggesting that more interest rate increases were on the way. The Nasdaq composite index rose 143.94 points, or nearly 4 percent, to 3,774.03. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 57.40 points, or 0.5 percent, to 10,888.10. Earlier in the session, the Dow was down as much as 197 points. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 3.93 points, to 1,464.92. C8.
 
AT&T Wireless Shares Rise 8%
The tracking stock for AT&T's wireless unit opened at $30.125 a share before closing up 8 percent, at $31.6875 in trading of 124.7 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange. That made for the second-busiest trading day yet for an individual Big Board stock. C8.
 
WPP in Talks With Young & Rubicam
In a deal that would combine two of the world's largest advertising companies, WPP Group of Britain, which owns Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide and J. Walter Thompson, acknowledged that it was in talks to buy Young & Rubicam. But Y.& R. is also discussing a combination with Publicis of France. Advertising. C6.
 
Ex-Keefe, Bruyette Chief Convicted
The former chairman and chief executive of the investment bank Keefe, Bruyette & Woods was convicted of leaking confidential financial information about a series of bank deals to an X-rated movie actress. B3.
 
Aetna Posts 16% Gain in Profit
Aetna, the nation's largest health insurance company, said that its first-quarter operating profit rose 16 percent, helped by reduced losses at its Prudential Health Care unit and a rebound in international business, including financial services in Asia and Latin America. The results strengthen the hand of William H. Donaldson, the recently appointed chief executive, who was expected to face sharp questioning by shareholders at the annual meeting today in Hartford. C2.
 
New Head Named for ABC Network
Walt Disney has placed Robert F. Callahan, the president of its radio and television stations division, in charge of the ABC Television Network, which has been without a direct leader for weeks but No. 1 in the ratings. C6.
 
British Auction Raises $35.5 Billion
An auction for licenses to operate a new generation of wireless devices linked to the Internet came to a close, reaping the British government a $35.5 billion windfall. C4.
 
Software to Protect Copyrights
Xerox and Microsoft said that they would create a company, ContentGuard, to produce and market software that protects copyrighted materials like books, music and video distributed over the Internet. C5.

HEADLINE: Janitors, Long Paid Little, Demand a Larger Slice

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 26

 BODY:
Amid a record economic boom, janitors some of America's lowest-paid, least-visible workers -- are taking to the streets and the picket lines from coast to coast to demand a bigger share of the nation's prosperity.
More than 4,000 janitors who clean office buildings in suburban Chicago have been on strike for more than a week, demonstrating downtown and blocking traffic to demand health insurance and a raise that would lift their families out of poverty. 
 The battle spread from Los Angeles, where a three-week strike by 8,500 janitors ended on Monday after Cardinal Roger Mahony gave them his outspoken support, helping them gain a raise of 26 percent over three years.
In San Diego, 300 janitors have been on strike for nearly three weeks to press their demand for health insurance. In New York, 10,000 janitors marched on Park Avenue two weeks ago to clamor for a raise. And more than 1,000 Silicon Valley janitors have held a series of rallies to hammer home their complaint that in cleaning offices for some of the world's wealthiest high-tech companies, they earn too little to afford decent housing or support their families.
The Service Employees International Union, which represents 185,000 janitors, most of them immigrants, has tried to make them the poster child for the gulf between rich and poor. Is it fair, the union demands, for suburban Chicago janitors, cleaning buildings for people who often earn hundreds of thousands of dollars a year, to get only $6.65 an hour, without health insurance?
"Symbolically, we as a union want to open this century focusing on the economic divide and bridging the income gap in this country," said Andrew Stern, the union's president. "That's what all these contract disputes are about. We want to make sure these janitors gain their fair share of a booming economy and a booming real estate market."
For nearly a decade the union has maneuvered to have most contracts covering janitors expire around the same time, enabling it to create a single nationwide campaign on their behalf. Although the number of strikes by American labor has been declining for half a century, the Service Employees view this as an ideal time to call strikes: the economic boom has left building owners and cleaning contractors well able to afford large raises, the union believes, and brought low-paid workers public sympathy.
Mike Garcia, president of the local in Los Angeles, said in the aftermath of the strike there, "With Los Angeles as the backdrop, with its huge disparity between rich and poor, with all the uninsured and immigrant workers, we wanted to show that a group of workers can organize and lift themselves out of poverty if they bring enough pressure."
Many building owners, under criticism that wages remain low during a soaring real estate market, say janitors' pay is not up to them, but to the cleaning contractors. And unionized cleaning contractors often say that if they raise wages substantially, they will lose their profit margins and be undercut by nonunion competitors.
The janitors of suburban Chicago began their strike on April 18, the day after 5,500 janitors who work in downtown Chicago office buildings had engaged in a daylong strike and won a contract that will raise their pay to $12.50 an hour from $11.40 over three years. Those janitors already have health insurance.
For the suburban janitors, the main question is why the downtown janitors have better pay and benefits. Barry White, chief negotiator for the suburban cleaning contractors, attributed the disparity to the competition that these contractors, unlike those in the heavily unionized downtown, face from nonunion companies. The unionized suburban companies, Mr. White said, fear that the price of family health coverage, about $1.78 an hour, might push costs so high that nonunion competitors will underbid them for contracts.
"We think the full family coverage the union is seeking is far too expensive a benefit for people earning $6.65 an hour," Mr. White said.
Among those people is Rosa Pederosa, a 30-year-old Mexican immigrant, who stood alongside hundreds of other striking janitors blocking traffic in suburban Oak Brook on Tuesday. Ms. Pederosa was excited, although also somewhat worried, about being part of a strike that seeks two things she badly wants: health insurance and higher wages. With a bugle blaring and janitors drumming on the bottoms of plastic wastebaskets, the strikers inched forward, next to an upscale mall, chanting, "Si, se puede" ("Yes, we can do it"), as Lexuses and BMW's backed up behind them.
Ms. Pederosa, who has three young children, takes home $440 every two weeks for dusting Venetian blinds at night in a luxury office tower.
"We earn very little," she said. "I don't feel comfortable working near all these really rich people. The owner and the tenants make a ton of money and dress really well, but earning $6.65 doesn't even cover expenses for my family."
Ms. Pederosa was taken to a hospital last month when she had problems breathing. Now she has two big worries: she may have asthma and, without health insurance or any wages coming in, she has to find a way to pay the $360 hospital bill and the $150 ambulance bill.
For Graciella Chagoya, things are much the same. Her 9-year-old son needed seven stitches after being hit in the head by a baseball bat. The hospital bill was $1,500, and the ambulance bill $470. Together, they amount to more than two months' take-home pay; she is trying to pay down the bill by $100 a month.
"I don't understand why they don't want to give us better wages or health insurance when I'm working so hard for them," she said.
Health coverage is the main issue in the strike in San Diego, where three janitors and the president of the local have been fasting for six days.
"We're fasting," said Mary Grillo, the president, "to focus on the choices that workers have to make every single day: Do I feed my family, or do I pay my rent, or do I take my child to the doctor? These are not civilized choices in a country like ours."
In all the disputes, the Service Employees union has worked hard to line up community support to pressure both building owners and cleaning contractors. In Los Angeles, the janitors received an anonymous $1 million gift to sustain them during their strike, and whenever they marched through the streets, workers came out of buildings, white-collar and blue-collar alike, to cheer them on.
Cardinal Mahony, archbishop of Los Angeles, symbolized community support by presiding over a Mass for the strikers. Describing the janitors as "faceless, nameless, voiceless," the cardinal said they deserved a share in "the wonderful fruitfulness of our economy." He praised them for making "visible in our city an invisible problem": the exclusion of many from the boom.
Labor leaders are looking for the success of the Los Angeles strike to take on symbolic importance. Their hope is that the Los Angeles janitors, by reminding the nation about the millions of people on the lower rungs, will galvanize hotel maids, hospital aides and other low-wage workers to join unions and fight for higher pay.
"Clearly the janitors won the hearts and souls and support of the overall community," said Mr. Garcia, president of the Los Angeles local. "It was definitely looked at as a David-versus-Goliath fight. We were in the right place and right time for a visible fight."

HEADLINE: Prices Spurt 3.2% As Economy Posts Another Big Gain

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
With lavish consumer spending providing the stimulus, the American economy turned in another very robust quarter, the government reported yesterday, as new evidence emerged that prosperity is finally pushing up labor costs, raising fears of higher inflation.
The inflation rate, as measured by the Commerce Department, rose to 3.2 percent in the first quarter, mainly because of higher fuel prices. But Wall Street expressed the worry that even as oil prices recede, labor costs will accelerate and keep the inflation rate rising. 
 "Either way, the economy is growing much too strongly to avoid inflation," said Richard Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities. "There are too many little signs out there that the Federal Reserve cannot ignore. It will have to continue to raise interest rates; the increases so far have had no effect."
The fresh warning signs of an acceleration in wage and price increases raised the possibility that the Federal Reserve might raise short-term interest rates by as much as half a percentage point next month. But most analysts expect the Fed to stick to a more modest quarter-point rate increase.
The stock market, reacting to the hints of rising inflation and the likelihood of more interest rate increases, plunged in the first hour or so of trading yesterday. It then bounced back as investors focused on the prospects for higher profits from the growing economy. The Nasdaq composite index rose a strong 143.94 points, or nearly 4 percent, to 3,774.03, and the Dow Jones industrial average finished at 10,888.10, down 57.40 points or about half a percent.
The gross domestic product, representing the value of all goods and services produced in the nation from January through March, rose at a 5.4 percent annual rate, the Commerce Department reported. Although that was down from the 7.3 rate of the fourth quarter, Americans showed no signs of tiring as the nine-year-old expansion became the longest in history.
Drawing on a variety of resources -- savings, bonuses and raises, stock options and market gains, wages from new jobs, as well as income tax refunds and more borrowing -- people piled into shopping at a pace not seen in 17 years. Showing confidence that the good times will continue, they spent most heavily on cars and trucks, but they also increased their spending on clothing, appliances, furniture, sports events, casino gambling, computers and software.
"The implication of all this is that people feel wealthier; their assets are going up in value -- their stock portfolios and their homes -- and they intend to spend more," said Robert Parker, chief statistician at the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis, which prepares the report on the gross domestic product.
The rise exceeded the increase in spending in any quarter since the spring of 1983. Then, the nation was just bouncing back from a recession; now the expansion is in record territory. Even politicians added to the bounty. The outlays by all the presidential contenders added more than $235 million to the gross domestic product from January through March.
Business investment grew with equal abandon. Construction of houses, schools, office buildings and highways rose by 12.1 percent. Spending for machinery and equipment, mainly computers and software, was up a stunning 23.7 percent.
"Firms rushed to purchase new computers last year in the run-up to Y2K," said Chris Varvares, a partner at Macroeconomic Partners in St. Louis, "and in the first quarter they resumed the process of upgrading their operations."
What most alarmed Wall Street, which is always fearful that rising inflation will undercut the public's enthusiasm for stocks and bonds, was a separate report issued yesterday by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Labor Department. It said that labor costs rose at a much faster pace during the quarter -- partly from growing wages but mostly from greater company outlays for employee benefits.
The bureau's Employment Cost Index increased 1.4 percent during the quarter, up sharply from the 1 percent increase in the fourth quarter. Much of the latest increase results from a big rise in health insurance costs, which have gone up gradually for two years. Company outlays for health insurance rose 7.6 percent in the year that ended last month, or three times the 2.5 percent increase in all of 1998.
"If you are looking for where the potential upward pressure on prices is coming from," said Jared Bernstein, a labor economist at the Economic Policy Institute, "it is energy and health insurance."
The broad inflation measure published with the G.D.P. report -- a gauge that the Fed now watches more closely than the more popular Consumer Price Index -- rose by 3.2 percent, compared with 2.5 percent in the fourth quarter. But when energy and food are subtracted, the index was up only 1.8 percent, down slightly from the fourth quarter's 2 percent rise.
Many experts argue that with the nation now operating at close to full employment -- reflected in a jobless rate of just 4.1 percent -- the economy cannot maintain a growth rate above 3.5 or 4 percent without subjecting the country to inflationary shortages. Yet there are indications that strong economic growth is likely to continue through the current quarter, which ends on June 30, some analysts said.
They noted that cars and trucks were high on the shopping list in the first quarter, but most were bought out of back lots, which now must be replenished by lifting production as robust vehicle sales continue. Further, a strike at Boeing temporarily interrupted production at its commercial aircraft operation, which contributes significantly to the nation's output and exports.
Federal spending might also rise. It fell in the first quarter, mostly because of a decline in military spending, which had shot up in the fourth quarter.
"We were told that the Defense Department had made advance payments in the fourth quarter for services like travel" and research and development, Mr. Parker said. "Now these outlays should return to more normal levels."

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 1184 words

HEADLINE: The Remedy for Microsoft

 BODY:
The Justice Department is expected to propose to Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson today that he break Microsoft in two -- a dramatic remedy for the antitrust violations that he recently ruled the company had committed. A breakup might seem to be overkill. But the inconvenient truth is that less drastic remedies are apt to be less effective and might involve government or court officials taking a permanent oversight role in the American software industry, hampering its evolution.
Microsoft is the latest target of antitrust laws designed to prohibit companies from conspiring by way of mergers, contracts or other forms of cooperation to reduce consumer choice. Though the laws do not outlaw monopolies, they do prohibit a single company from deliberately creating or maintaining a monopoly through anti-competitive practices rather than simply selling a product that is better or cheaper than someone else's product. The laws, which are generally stricter in the United States than in other industrialized countries, have been used with uneven results to go after industry giants like Standard Oil, Alcoa, I.B.M. and AT&T. 
 The federal proposal, which a majority of the 19 states suing Microsoft are expected to endorse, raises profound questions about the government's role in the new economy. Can, and should, laws designed to manage the emergence of industrial and natural-resource monopolies in the late 19th and early 20th centuries be applied to the technology and intellectual-property giants of the 21st century?
No one can answer that question with absolute certainty, but in our view American business and the nation's consumers would be ill served if the Justice Department abandoned the broad tradition of antitrust regulation as it has evolved over the past 100 years. That tradition teaches that government must sketch, with as light a hand as possible, the boundaries of fair competition. Microsoft insists, with some defiance, that it will defeat on appeal any attempt to restrict its marketing strategy. But it seems to us that Justice's proposal provides room for the Microsoft companies to prosper while creating enterprise space for competitors.
Judge Jackson embraced Justice's argument that Microsoft illegally entered into restrictive contracts with computer manufacturers and Internet companies that required them to favor Microsoft's browser over that of its chief rival, Netscape. The manufacturers were prevented from substituting Netscape's browser for Microsoft's browser on versions of Windows they installed on new computers. Microsoft also wrote contracts that required Internet service providers to steer customers to Microsoft's browser in exchange for favored access to Windows users. Microsoft's primary goal was to prevent Netscape's browser from serving as an alternative platform from which computer users could run word processors and other applications software, and thereby eviscerate the market power of Windows. The use of a monopoly position to insulate that monopoly from competitive challenge violates the antitrust laws.
So what is the best remedy? One approach would be to regulate Microsoft's future behavior. Under this remedy, the court would impose rules that prohibit Microsoft from entering into illegally exclusive contracts to box out its competitors. The problem with such behavior constraints is that it is hard to box a wily company like Microsoft. Justice signed a consent decree in 1994 that it thought would prevent Microsoft from wrapping its browser into Windows and selling the two as a bundled unit, but Microsoft found a way to achieve the same economic effect by cleverly designing its software. Besides, in a fast-moving industry, no one knows how to specify today the unforeseeable violations in the future.
Consider, for example, Judge Jackson's finding that Microsoft punished some computer manufacturers that cooperated with its competitors by, for example, charging them higher prices. To prohibit that behavior in the future would require the judge to anticipate all the ways that Microsoft could hassle manufacturers, such as by providing them belated or incomplete technical information. That approach would require a permanent army of officials to adjudicate every complaint against Microsoft, a task that Justice wants no part of.
Structural remedies might work better. The idea is to inject competition into the market for operating systems so that competitive pressures, not the courts, rein in Microsoft's behavior.
One option is to require that Microsoft license Windows to several other companies. Consumers could buy Windows from, say, three separate companies, each offering slightly different versions of Windows and its own brand of customer service. That proposal would create instant competition, insulating computer manufacturers from threats by Microsoft because they could always get Windows from another source. The trouble with this idea is that it could lead to fragmentation -- incompatible versions of Windows that would make swapping files between computers and lots of other everyday tasks needlessly difficult. Some economists doubt that rival companies could find customers for a version of Windows that was not backed by the technical experts working for Microsoft.
Several economists would go further and break Microsoft into three companies, each selling Windows and, perhaps, applications programs as well. This would solve the core antitrust problem by breaking apart the Windows monopoly. But this approach, like licensing, could lead to incompatible versions of Windows, and some experts believe the market might not accommodate more than one version of Windows, ensuring that two of the companies might fail. This approach would also be the most dauntingly difficult to pull off -- requiring, for example, a complicated parceling out of Microsoft personnel among the three offshoots.
Justice is choosing instead a less complicated breakup strategy. It would divide Microsoft into a company that sells an operating system (Windows) and a company that sells application programs -- word processors, spreadsheets and browsers. The idea is that the applications company would have financial incentive to make its products compatible not only with Windows but with other operating systems like Linux.
This is a plausible solution, though economists point to problems. The applications company might be unwilling to spend huge amounts to rewrite Word and other programs for operating systems that are currently used by very few people. That would still leave Windows as the overwhelmingly dominant operating system. Moreover, the company selling Windows could, after a transition period, engage in all the anti-competitive practices that Microsoft has committed in the past. But the great hope is that, by creating two powerful companies where there is now one dominant company, each will prosper, competition and innovation will increase, and the consumer will ultimately benefit. Among a set of flawed alternatives, the government's plan offers the best chance of success.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
PHILIPS TO CUT 1,500 JOBS IN OHIO, MOVING WORK TO MEXICO

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
Philips Display Components, the world's largest maker of picture tubes, said yesterday that it planned to lay off 1,500 workers at a plant in Ottawa, Ohio, beginning in 2001 and move most of the work to Mexico. Philips, a division of Royal Philips Electronics, said the cuts would take place over a three-year period starting next year. The Ohio plant will remain open to make large picture tubes, but most of its work will be moved to Mexico, the company said. About 300 of the plant's 1,800 workers will remain. The plant makes 4.2 million picture tubes each year for television sets made by Philips and other manufacturers.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 33; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 4594 words

HEADLINE: ON THE ROAD;
Booming In Size And Brio

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
More than 150 years ago, San Antonio gave Texas its enduring symbol of us-against-them pride and courage, the Alamo. Austin's moment in the sun is now. Its technology boom has generated fortunes that surpass even the staggering riches earned by the state's cattle and oil barons.
The two cities are only 80 miles apart, not much more than an hour's drive down I-35 for lead-footed local drivers, and their metropolitan areas are slowly growing together. They share the equable south-central Texas climate; close proximity to the Hill Country, an area of easy, unspoiled rustic beauty; a compactness envied by sprawling Dallas and Houston; an unhurried approach to life, and an unusual ethnic flavor, arising from the interaction of Hispanic culture with that of the early settlers from Germany. 
 Both take much of their character from modest rivers that they have turned to great effect. But no one would ever confuse them.
Austin is defined by the enormous University of Texas, with 50,000 students on a single campus, and by the state government, headed at the moment by an up-and-coming politician named George W. Bush. Plus the vast chip and computer plants just outside the city and one of the country's liveliest, most varied popular music cultures.
Willie Nelson lives here, and Lady Bird Johnson, the president's farsighted widow, who has enriched Austin, Texas and the whole nation with her beautification projects. So do Ann Richards and Molly Ivins, a pair of bright, witty women, one a former governor, the other a syndicated newspaper columnist, who find plenty of targets hereabouts for their barbs.
Austin's population has grown by a third and its work force by almost two-thirds in the last decade. But George Christian, Lyndon B. Johnson's press secretary, who was born here, said that the city retains its essential character, despite traffic jams and rocketing real estate prices.
"It's still a tolerant, casual, laid-back place, different from most of the rest of the state," he told me over a lunch of meat loaf, black-eyed peas and deep-fried pickles at Threadgill's, Janis Joplin's old hangout. "Nothing changes that."
San Antonio is older, poorer and slightly larger, with 1.5 million people vs. Austin's 1.1 million -- a margin that is shrinking fast. It is a city of fiestas, especially the nine-day Fiesta, an annual wingding every bit as flamboyant as, if somewhat less boozy than, Mardi Gras in New Orleans. This year's edition comes to a clamorous conclusion on April 30.
The city has turned its evident charms into a significant economic asset, luring dozens of big conventions every year. It earns further millions from three major Air Force bases, including Randolph Field, where many pilots were trained in World War II, and from the Army's Fort Sam Houston.
San Antonio is also much more heavily Hispanic. It is, in fact, the largest Hispanic-majority city in the country, represented in Congress for 37 years by Henry B. Gonzalez, a power on the House Banking Committee who brought home plenty of federal bacon, and now by his son Charles. Much of its modern momentum was imparted by another Hispanic politician, Henry G. Cisneros, who served as mayor from 1982 to 1990, before heading to Washington, where he served the Clinton administration as secretary of housing and urban development. He later resigned during a scandal involving a former lover.
"San Antonio," Graham Greene wrote in 1939, "is more Mexican than American -- not quite genuine Mexican (it is far too clean for that) but picture-postcard Mexican."
 
An 'Enchilada Red' Library
Neither city, in truth, can claim to be a national or even a regional cultural capital. Neither has a museum in the same league as the Kimbell in Fort Worth or a symphony orchestra that can compete with the excellent ensemble built in Houston by Christoph Eschenbach. But scratch the surface a little, and you will discover that Nelson A. Rockefeller's wonderful collection of Latin American art has found a home in San Antonio, and that the University of Texas houses one of the world's greatest troves of 20th-century manuscripts, including important items by Joyce, Shaw and Waugh.
San Antonio boasts a stunning new library designed by the Mexican master Roberto Legorreta. A series of boxes piled one on another, with a breathtaking six-story atrium, it is painted an eye-popping color known to locals as "enchilada red."
Austin's own architectural spectacular, a new building for the university's Jack S. Blanton Museum, was stalled when hidebound members of the Board of Regents raised so many objections that the architects, Herzog & de Meuron, probably the hottest firm in the world at the moment, threw up their hands and quit. The dean of the architecture school resigned, too.
For the moment, while the search for a new designer continues, the Blanton's interesting collection is split between two campus buildings, neither of them adequate. The most important holdings are the 20th-century American pictures donated by the author James A. Michener and his wife, Mari (ranging from the Ashcan School through a jaunty yellow oil by Arthur G. Dove called "Good Breeze" to Sam Gilliam and Larry Rivers), and the recently acquired Suida-Manning collection, parts of which had been on long-term loan to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Among its notable paintings are works by Poussin, Guercino and Simon Vouet, plus a Veronese "Annunciation" showing the virgin, swathed in luminous pink, turning modestly away from the Angel Gabriel.
The Austin Museum of Art, which is still amassing a permanent collection, is moving ahead with its new building, to be designed by Richard Gluckman, the New Yorker who adapted older buildings for the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh and the Georgia O'Keeffe Museum in Santa Fe. And the small but solid Austin Symphony Orchestra and Austin Lyric Opera (13 performances of three productions this season) continue to thrive.
Residual conservatism and insularity have done nothing to inhibit the development of dozens of active theater companies in Austin. Nor has it slowed the seemingly unstoppable expansion of the popular music business here, which now extends to 810 recording artists and 150 clubs and other stages, featuring everything from rockabilly to Texas swing to Tejano. Every March, music journalists and record-company executives flock here for the Southwest Music and Media Conference, known as SXSW, to look for future stars. This year almost 1,000 acts from all over the world showed up, each allotted a mere 40 minutes to sell itself to the bigwigs.
In San Antonio, a significant effort has been made to build artistic links to Mexico and Latin America as a whole, as Ron Bechtel, a local architect and food critic, explained to me.
The commission for Mr. Legorreta, who won the American Institute of Architects Gold Medal for 1999, is one instance; another is a continuing effort by Christopher Wilkins, the music director of the 60-year-old San Antonio Symphony, to program works by Latin composers, often interpreted by Latin conductors or soloists. Works by many contemporary Hispanic artists are displayed in galleries in the old warehouse district that is anchored by the Blue Star Art Space.
 
A Converted Brewery
The strongest element in this linkage, however, must be the Rockefeller Latin American Art Center at the San Antonio Museum of Art. The main part of the museum is housed in a castellated converted brewery dating from 1904, a fine example of the city's unusually imaginative reuse of intriguing old buildings. The Rockefeller center, which includes not only the collection of the onetime New York governor but material from other sources as well, was opened in October 1998, in a well-conceived addition.
In addition to Aztec, Mixtec and other pre-Columbian art, Spanish colonial silver and altarpieces and contemporary Latin American painting, the Rockefeller wing owns a riotously uninhibited collection of Mexican folk art, including dozens of masks, an elegant crane fashioned from a gourd and brightly colored ceramic churches, trucks, trains and planes.
A highlight of the museum's other collections is Martin Johnson Heade's tiny "Passion Flowers and Hummingbirds," which a wall label aptly described as "a very private vision of the Garden of Eden." He painted it, appropriately enough, in Latin America.
Texas is full of small museums too little known outside the state, like the Ima Hogg decorative-arts collection in Houston and the Trammell Crow Museum of Asian Art in Dallas. In San Antonio, the sleeper is the McNay Art Museum, in a parklike sitting on the north side of town, where the Richie Riches of San Antonio live.
It has one of the nation's premier theater arts collections, which is augmented this spring by a special showing of treasures from the St. Petersburg State Museum of Theater and Music. The splendor of Aleksandr Golovin's costumes for "The Firebird" came as no surprise, but I was amazed to see the sketches by Kasimir Malevich done in 1913 for a production of the now-forgotten experimental opera "Victory Over the Sun," and the captivatingly witty Constructivist costumes designed in 1931 by Tatyana Bruni for an early Shostakovich ballet, "Bolt." Keen Shostakovich fan though I am, I confess I had never before encountered the ballet or Ms. Bruni.
If you go to the McNay, don't miss the permanent collection, especially the van Goghs and Gauguins, Matisse's "Red Blouse" and a memorable Redon, but also superb graphics by Edward Hopper and John Marin.
Finally, if you happen to be a circus junkie like me, you will enjoy the Hertzberg Circus Museum, which houses the 20,000-object collection of a former state senator from San Antonio. What might be called, in circus-speak, A Peerless Panorama of Posters, recalls a simpler, more credulous era: Frank Buck ("Bring 'em Back Alive"), Gargantua the Great and the Giraffe-Women of Burma! The best carries a portrait of P. T. Barnum himself -- without his name, just the words "I Am Coming."
 
High-Tech Texas
A quarter-century ago, Austin was a sleepy town, about as vibrant as Carson City, Nev., with a couple of enormous buildings -- Texas Memorial Stadium, where the Longhorns roam, and the pink granite state capitol, the largest and the most southerly in the United States, except of course for Hawaii's, with a dome that looks uncannily like the one in Washington. The political carnival inside is similar, too.
Quite a few one- and two-story cow-town buildings still stand on Congress Avenue and along the streets running off it, but that's not where the action is. The action is out along Loop 360 and Loop 1, at the region's 2,100 high-tech companies. Austin's Entrepreneurs' Association had 476 members at recent count, and the entrepreneur-in-chief has to be Michael Dell, 35, the youngest chief executive to lead a company onto the Fortune 500; the sixth-richest person in America, according to Forbes; and the richest Texan ever. No, that's not a misprint; Mr. Dell is richer than the Basses of Fort Worth and the DeMenils of Houston, and richer by far than H. Ross Perot.
He made his money by grafting an old idea to a new business: he eliminated the middleman (and avoided the inventory costs of his rivals) by building computers to order and selling them direct to consumers.
That simple scheme made millionaires of many of Mr. Dell's early employees, even secretaries and clerks, and it made billionaires of some. Aided by Federal research dollars funneled into the area by its former Congressman, the legendary J. J. Pickle, and by the talent pool at the university, new companies sprang up like wildflowers after a spring rain. Soon all of Austin was gossiping about the new "Dellionaires."
 
Spam Foo-Young
Which represents a big change, because until recently Austin was a stranger to Dallas-size bankrolls. During the 1960's, in fact, it was a counterculture center, a Haight-Ashbury with 10-gallon hats, and some of that individualism lingers.
"It's a funny, funky, outrageous town," said Ms. Ivins. "Where else do they have Spamarama? Spam with Chinese food, Spam foo-young, for goodness sake. Where else do people celebrate Eeyore's birthday?
"We do."
But Austin doesn't have bats in its belfry. It keeps its bats under the Congress Avenue Bridge, or rather they keep themselves there: 1.5 million Mexican free-tailed bats, who live beneath the bridge's concrete arches from March until November, streaming out at dusk to eat.
The bridge crosses Town Lake, an idyllic sliver of water formed by a dam on the Colorado River (the Texas Colorado, not the longer one farther west). By some miracle of good sense, all motorboats are banned, so the waters are roiled by nothing more modern than sculls, canoes and a poky little excursion stern-wheeler.
Austin climbs from the lake to the university, centered on the 307-foot tower of the Main Building. One of the richest state universities, the fortunate owner of extensive oil lands in the Permian Basin, U.T., as the students call it, has attracted distinguished faculty members from other campuses. Steven Weinberg, a physicist, won the Nobel Prize in 1979 and left Harvard for Austin in 1983; now "you couldn't blast him out of here with a howitzer," a friend says.
"Michigan and Berkeley are the ideals we aspire to," said James S. Fishkin, ex-Yale and now a U.T. professor of ethics and American society, with a chair improbably named for Darrell K. Royall, an old Longhorn football coach. "We're already there in some areas, and we undoubtedly have the resources to get there in most others."
At the edge of the campus stands the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library and Museum, an exemplary institution of its kind, which is just one of the monuments, all well worth visiting, to the former president and his family in this area. Another is the Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center, where the magnificent bluebonnets (Lupinus texensis) and the Indian paintbrush are ankle deep this time of year. A third is the L. B. J. Ranch, out in the Hill Country near Stonewall, Tex., hard by the Pedernales River (which Johnson, in keeping with the local usage, always pronounced as "Purdenales").
 
Missions and Victoriana
San Antonio is drenched in history. Its Hispanic past is exemplified by the 18th-century missions along the San Antonio River south of the center, notably Concepcion, a starkly beautiful, twin-towered building that retains traces of its original frescoes, and San Jose, with exquisite Churrigueresque ornamentation around its windows and doors.
San Jose gives a good impression of the privations of life in what was then the wilderness, with its gun ports and defensive walls, and of what must have been, then as now, the pleasures of spring in the Southwest, with its feathery mesquite trees and flame-colored pomegranate blossoms.
Closer to downtown stands the King William District, full of Victorian houses built of beautifully dressed pale limestone blocks by German burghers in the mid-1800's. Once known for obvious reasons as Sauerkraut Bend, the neighborhood is remarkably intact, although some houses have been lovingly restored while others in the same block remain decrepit. It reminded me a bit of Georgetown in the late 1950's before it became compulsively chic.
Both the Steves Homestead at 509 King William, with a fine Mansard roof, and Groos house, an Italianate villa at 335, are very handsome.
San Antonio boosters will remind you that theirs is a big-league town; they are proud of the Spurs, National Basketball Association Champions in the 1998-99 season, led by a pair of walking skyscrapers named David Robinson and Tim Duncan. Me, I'm pretty excited about the Class AA San Diego Missions, and especially their mascots, the Puffy Taco and Ballapeno, a hot pepper with a baseball-shaped head.
For the average visitor, though, San Antonio is synonymous with the Alamo and the Riverwalk. The former, where 188 heroic Texans, including Jim Bowie and Davy Crockett, held off 5,000 Mexicans under Santa Anna before perishing on March 6, 1836, is a shrine to the Texas nationhood that for many Texans has never ceased to exist. The Alamo itself, which was once a mission church, has a somber dignity that quiets even the hordes of schoolchildren who troop through every day. But the "museum shop" next door is a travesty that sells Alamo butter-spreaders and other equally tasteful goods.
The Riverwalk, fashioned with W.P.A. funds during the Depression, consists of paths along the downtown reaches of the San Antonio, overhung with cypresses, crossed by humpbacked footbridges, sparklingly lighted at night. Hotels, restaurants and clubs, like the Landing, where the joyously old-fashioned Jim Cullum Jazz Band toots every night, open onto it. Commercial the walk may be; resistible it isn't, not to the hardest of hearts.
 
Details of 2 Cities
 
 Austin is about 1,745 miles southwest of New York City and San Antonio is about 80 miles southwest of Austin. Here is a sampling of attractions, along with travel information:
 
Where to Stay
 
 DRISKILL, 604 Brazos Street, Austin, (512) 474-5911. A survivor from the old Austin, the Driskill was the press headquarters during the Johnson years. The old-timers wouldn't recognize it. A skillful restoration effort has wiped away the wens and wrinkles of a century, leaving a Richardsonian Romanesque landmark for all to admire. Cast-iron columns, beaten copper ceilings, stained-glass skylights, Arts and Crafts lighting fixtures and sofas upholstered in pony hides recreate the original 1886 ambiance. Double rooms: $185 to $225.
 
 FOUR SEASONS, 98 San Jacinto Boulevard, Austin, (512) 478-4500. In its way, this shining palace on Town Lake is a perfect symbol of Austin's emergence from small-town torpor into the big time. The decor is chic and Southwestern; the bedrooms come with marble bathrooms and down-soft sheets. Every service imaginable is close at hand here, from a lending library of books by Texas authors to a rental fleet of 24-speed bicycles. Car parkers, bellmen and chambermaids alike are cheerful and hyperefficient. Double rooms: $195 to $325.
 
 LA MANSION DEL RIO, 112 College Street, San Antonio, (210) 518-1000. Most hotels along the Riverwalk are cattle cars, and one has more than 1,000 rooms. The Mansion is a smaller, much more atmospheric alternative, built into the shell of an old boys' school, with an unusually friendly staff. The best rooms, with balconies, overlook the river, as does the subdued, softly lighted Las Canarias, probably San Antonio's best hotel restaurant. Double rooms: $254 to $414.
 
 MENGER, 204 Alamo Plaza, San Antonio, (210) 223-4361. Built in 1859, expanded and renovated a dozen times, the Menger embodies Texas history; Teddy Roosevelt recruited some of his Rough Riders in the cherrywood-paneled bar. You can swim in a courtyard pool shaded by a loquat tree or eat lunch beneath the palms of a second courtyard. The moderately priced bedrooms, old and new, offer modern comfort -- just "across the alley from the Alamo." Double rooms: $155 to $175; suites from $275 to $475.
 
 WESTIN RIVERWALK, 420 West Market Street, San Antonio, (210) 224-6500, is San Antonio's newest hotel (opened November 1999) and its most luxurious. Only big panes of plate glass separate the marble-floored, flower-filled lobby from the Riverwalk and the river. The 473 "Texas-size" rooms, as the hotel describes them, have large marble-top working desks, hypoallergenic pillows and in-room safes. The lounge serves a mean margarita. Double rooms: $189 to $239.
 
Where to Eat
 
 BIGA ON THE BANKS, 203 South St. Mary's Street, San Antonio, (210) 225-0722. Bruce Auden, a lean, earnest Englishman, has been San Antonio's culinary star for years; now he has a handsome, high-tech stage on which to do his thing. Open only a week when we visited, the dining room was still shaking down, but not the kitchen. Mr. Auden's sure hand with spices showed in the minced game in radicchio packets, and his meticulous timing showed in a pork loin as well as the calamari in a stew. The toffee pudding had our fellow diner Tim Zagat, the guidebook man, begging for seconds.
 
 HILLTOP CAFE, 10661 Highway 87, Doss, (830) 997-8922. Even in Texas, who would believe a onetime gas station, festooned with old license plates, game trophies and other junk, serving top-notch Greek, Cajun and cowboy food? C'mon. But there it is, out near the LBJ Ranch. The chicken-fried steak is a cardiologist's nightmare, a glutton's dream, and Miss Gladys's amazing pecan and blueberry pies take the blue ribbon for paper-thin crusts.
 
 JEFFREY'S, 1204 West Lynn Street, Austin, (512) 477-5584. Jeffrey's has grown up with Austin. The hippie atmosphere of its youth has given way to smooth service, subtle decor and superb cooking by David Garrido, a protege of Stephan Pyles, the Dallas superchef. His food is easily Austin's best, from gently fried oysters to foie gras in a puddle of fruity sauce to a tender yet robustly flavored venison chop. The lighting is needlessly dim.
 
 KREUZ MARKET, 619 North Colorado Street, Lockhart, (512) 398-2361. Here's the drill: You drive an hour from Austin or San Antonio, head into the pit room, order your sausage, brisket (a bit fatty) or shoulder of beef (very lean), barbecued over post oak. They pile it onto a sheet of brown butcher paper, along with a stack of white bread. You carry that to one of the 710 seats at communal tables and pick up pickles, raw onions and a Shiner bock beer. For this elemental feast, you get a plastic knife, no fork, no sides and no sauce. The luscious, deeply smoky meat doesn't need it; this may be the state's best 'cue, and the locals rip into it like cave men.
 
 LAS MANITAS, 211 Congress Avenue, Austin, (512) 472-9357. The food is better, or at least more authentic, at Fonda San Miguel. But the smoky, spicy enchiladas rojas and the milder enchiladas verdes at Las Manitas are Tex-Mex classics, and the scene -- the funky old lefty Austin scene -- can't be beat. Is that Bobby Ray Inman and Bob Gates, the C.I.A. honchos, dining with their wives on Formica in the second booth back? Yep.
 
 EL MIRADOR, 722 South St. Mary's Street, San Antonio, (210) 225-9444. The Trevinos have been here for 32 years, and they know what they're doing. They made their name with meal-in-a-bowl soups like menudo, with tripe, and chicken cilantro, packed with chunky vegetables. I was especially impressed by the supremely tender cabrito (goat), roasted for eight hours and liberally dusted with pepper, and ravishing sweet-potato flan (custard).
 
 HUDSON'S ON THE BEND, 3509 Ranch Road 620 North, Austin, (512) 266-1369. Ever-expanding Austin has devoured the countryside in which Hudson's sat a decade ago, but it retains the feeling of an old Hill Country ranch house. Jeffrey Blank's menu emphasizes game -- elk, axis venison, boar, quail and pheasant -- boisterously but expertly cooked; an old smoker outside is used to good effect. Try crunchy pheasant with a jicama and tomatillo salad.
 
 SILO, 1133 Austin Highway, San Antonio, (210) 824-8686. You ride an elevator up to the dining room, just as you do at the Tour d'Argent, but there the similarity ends. This ain't Paris, Hoss. Mark Bliss has plenty of lively ideas, some of them superbly executed (an eastern Mediterranean take on osso buco, with couscous and Lebanese spices), some of them much less so (chicken-fried oysters on spinach). Service is sweet but slow-witted.
 
 ZOOT, 509 Hearn Street, Austin, (512) 477-6535. Steamed clams and lamb sausage ladled over linguine in a garlicky broth are one palate-pleaser here; another is deftly cooked sweetbreads, unbreaded but nicely crusty, served on sweet-and-sour red cabbage. One tasted Portuguese, the other German, a welcome relief after a week of Tex-Tex, Tex-Mex and Mex-Mex. You'll find them in a charming cottage on the west side of town.
 
Attractions
 
 JACK S. BLANTON MUSEUM OF ART, University of Texas, (512) 471-7324. The permanent collection is at the Harry Ransom Center, 21st and Guadalupe Streets. Temporary exhibitions are shown at 23rd and San Jacinto Streets. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays until 9 p.m.; weekends, 1 to 5 p.m. Free.
 
 AUSTIN MUSEUM OF ART. AMOA Downtown, 823 Congress Avenue, (512) 495-9224. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Thursdays to 8 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $3; $2, students and the elderly; $1 on Thursdays. AMOA Laguna Gloria, 3805 West 35th Street, (512) 458-8191. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays to 8 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $2; $1, students and the elderly; $1 for everyone on Thursdays.
 
 AUSTIN SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA, Bass Concert Hall, University of Texas, East Campus Drive and 23rd Street, (888) 462-3787. The next performances, concluding the season, are at 8 p.m. on May 12 and 13. Peter Bay conducts a program of Vivaldi, Mozart and Respighi, with the violinists Pamela Frank and Alexander Simionescu. Tickets: $14 and $30. The fall season begins Sept. 22.
 
 AUSTIN LYRIC OPERA, Bass Concert Hall, University of Texas, East Campus Drive and 23rd Street, (800) 316-7372. The fall season begins Nov. 10.
 
 LYNDON BAINES JOHNSON LIBRARY AND MUSEUM, 2313 Red River Street, University of Texas, (512) 916-5137. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Free.
 
 LADY BIRD JOHNSON WILDFLOWER CENTER, 4801 LaCrosse Avenue, Austin, (512) 292-4100. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 9 a.m. to 5:30 p.m for the grounds and the store; to 4 p.m for the gallery and cafe. Admission: $4; $2.50, students and the elderly; free, under age 5.
 
 SAN ANTONIO SYMPHONY, Majestic Theater, 224 East Houston Street, (210) 554-1010. Enrique Diemecke conducts a program of Diemecke, Villa-Lobos, Revueltas and Ravel on May 5 and 6 at 8 p.m. Tickets: $13 to $46.
 
 SAN ANTONIO MUSEUM OF ART, 200 West Jones Avenue, (210) 978-8100. Hours: Sundays, noon to 5 p.m.; Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Tuesdays, to 9 p.m. Admission: $5; $4, students and the elderly; $1.75, ages 4 to 11.
 
 MCNAY ART MUSEUM, 6000 North New Braunfels Avenue, San Antonio, (210) 824-5368. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Free. "Spectacular St. Petersburg: 100 Years of Russian Theater Design," through May 14.
 
 HERTZBERG CIRCUS MUSEUM, 210 West Market Street, San Antonio, (210) 207-7810. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m (Sundays from 1 to 5 p.m. beginning June 1). Admission: $2.50; $2, the elderly; $1, ages 3 to 12.
 
 THE ALAMO, 300 Alamo Plaza, San Antonio, (210) 281-0710. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 9 a.m to 5:30 p.m.; Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Free.
 
Getting There
 
 CONTINENTAL, (800) 525-0280, offers nonstop flights from Newark to San Antonio and Austin. Fares to either city range from $447 round trip for a 14-day advance to $851 round trip for a 7-day advance. Advance fares require a Saturday night stay. The last-minute midweek fare is $782 each way.
 
 AMERICAN AIRLINES, (800) 433-7300, offers nonstop flights from La Guardia to Austin. Fares range from $381 round trip for a 14-day advance to $936 round trip for a 7-day advance. Advance fares require a Saturday night stay. The last-minute midweek fare is $780 each way. R. W. APPLE Jr.

 CORRECTION:
An On the Road article in Weekend on Friday about visiting Austin and San Antonio, Tex., misstated the name of San Antonio's Class AA baseball team. It is the San Antonio Missions, not the San Diego Missions.

PUB-DATE: April 29, 2000

SECTION: Section C; Page 3; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 619 words

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Nasdaq Rises Again as It Ends Its Worst Month Since '98

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Nasdaq composite index rose for a second day yesterday, while completing its worst month since 1998. Qualcomm, Oracle and Intel gained.
American Express, J. P. Morgan & Company and other financial stocks dragged down the Dow Jones industrial average on concern that accelerating inflation would prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates a half-point in May to keep inflation in check. 
 "People are coming back" to the Nasdaq "knowing the earnings have been tremendous," said Guy Truicko, who helps manage $1 billion at Unity Management Inc. "Rates are going to have to go much higher to slow the economy down, and that's spooked people out of financials."
Merck & Company also weighed on the Dow industrials after a report that one of its most important drugs might face safety questions from the federal government.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 86.63 points, or 2.3 percent, to 3,860.66. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 154.19 points, or 1.4 percent, to 10,733.91. The Standard & Poor's 500 index slipped 12.49 points, or 0.9 percent, to 1,452.43.
The Nasdaq's 15.6 percent drop in April was its biggest since August 1998, when stocks plunged on concern about economic growth worldwide. This April also provided the index's worst and best one-week performances, and on April 4, it fell as much as 13.6 percent before recovering four-fifths of the plunge.
The Standard & Poor's 500 fell 3.1 percent in April, while the Dow lost 1.7 percent.
For the week, the Nasdaq gained 6 percent and the S.& P. 500 advanced 1.3 percent. The Dow lost 1 percent this week.
"The volatility is just incredible," said Don Ross, chief investment officer with National City Investment Management Company, which oversees $24 billion in Cleveland.
Some 970 million shares changed hands on the Big Board, down from the three-month daily average of 1.1 billion.
Qualcomm gained 4 15/16, to 108 7/16, and Oracle rose 2 5/8, to 79 15/16. Intel advanced 1 1/2, to 126 13/16. The semiconductor maker, at a meeting with analysts and investors in New York on Thursday, said demand for personal computers was better than expected. The company said it was increasing production by adding plants and using a more efficient chip-making process.
Microsoft, which gained 5/8, to 70 3/8 in extended trading, was the most-active United States stock. The Justice Department and the 19 states in the antitrust suit against the company filed with the judge their recommendations for remedies he should impose for Microsoft's violations. The government recommended splitting the company in two.
Merck fell 2, to 69 1/2, after reports the Food and Drug Administration is concerned about cardiac problems related to the drugmaker's Vioxx painkiller. Merck, which said it sees no signs of heart problems related to Vioxx, was the third-best performer in the Dow average this month.

Treasury Prices Gain
(By Reuters) -- Treasury bond prices bounced higher yesterday, but shorter maturities suffered their fifth consecutive day of losses on fears of inflation and higher interest rates in response to recent economic data.
"The market's just moved from 25 basis points to 50 basis points," said Chris Rupkey, senior financial economist at Bank of Tokyo/Mitsubishi, referring to market speculation on the magnitude of the interest rate increase that is expected when Federal Reserve policy makers meet on May 16. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 12/32, to 104 2/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.96 percent from 5.98 percent on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Personal Income Jumped 0.7% In March, Faster Than Spending

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 28

 BODY:
Americans' personal incomes rose in March at a faster rate than spending for the first time in five months, paced by wage gains and census hiring, government data showed today.
Incomes grew 0.7 percent in March after rising 0.4 percent in February, the Commerce Department said. Spending rose 0.5 percent, smaller than expected, after a February increase of 1.4 percent. 
 The income gain did little to raise the personal savings rate, which is still close to the lowest level since monthly record-keeping began in 1959. The savings rate rose to 0.4 percent from February's record low 0.2 percent.
"This speaks of a consumer that is comfortable enough not only to spend heavily but to use liberal amounts of debt to do it," said Christopher Low, chief economist at First Tennessee Capital Markets in New York.
Manufacturers were expecting additional growth, too. The National Association of Purchasing Management-Chicago said today that its index of new orders rose to 60.5 in April from 59.2 in March. The inventories index dropped to 47.4 from 58.8, a sign that factories will have to step up production. The overall index was 56.5. While down from 57.4 in March, a reading higher than 50 indicates growth in manufacturing.
Incomes in February were bolstered by stronger growth in hourly earnings and in jobs, including hiring by the Census Bureau, which has added almost 500,000 temporary workers for its count of the population. Census hiring alone added $1.3 billion at an annual rate to federal civilian payrolls.
Today's Commerce Department report reaffirmed that spending was growing at a faster pace than Federal Reserve policy makers would like to see.
"We're seeing very large increases in consumer spending in the fourth quarter and in the first quarter, even taking out auto sales," Michael Moskow, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, told reporters last week. "You're still seeing a very large rate of increase we believe is beyond the rate the economy can produce."

HEADLINE: Old Wounds Slow U.S.-Vietnam Reconciliation

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

DATELINE: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam, April 28

 BODY:
In the run-up to the 25th anniversary of the end of their war on Sunday, Vietnamese and American officials traded bitter gibes today over whose side had behaved worse during and after the conflict.
On a private visit here, Senator John McCain mounted a harsh attack on Vietnam's Communist government for everything from its ideology and economy to its corruption and the fact that it displays the hammer and sickle on its banners. 
 A government spokeswoman dug into Vietnam's well-honed arsenal of political oratory and fired back, accusing the United States of "horrendous crimes against the Vietnamese people" and Mr. McCain himself of violating "the norms of morality."
The undiplomatic exchange revealed the extent to which the resentments of the past remain alive despite the elaborate expressions of friendship with which both sides had approached the anniversary.
It underscored the continuing suspicions that have slowed the flow of normal relations and created difficulties in the conclusion of a trade accord that most economic analysts say would benefit both countries.
Though both sides today flung their charges widely, a central dispute seemed to be over who had caused the most suffering to the Vietnamese people.
"I think the wrong guys won," said Mr. McCain, a not-so-surprising statement from a Vietnam veteran and former prisoner that still had the ring of an accusation. "I think that they lost millions of their best people who left by boat, thousands by execution and hundreds of thousands who went to re-education camps."
The Foreign Ministry spokeswoman, Phan Thuy Thanh, gave as good as she got in a statement that was carried today in the government-controlled press. "It is the United States, initiator of the war of aggression in Vietnam, which has committed horrendous crimes against the Vietnamese people," she said.
It all started on Wednesday when Mr. McCain, a Republican from Arizona, toured a small museum in Hanoi on the location of the prison where he was held for nearly six years after being shot down as a Navy pilot in 1967. He is in Vietnam with his wife, Cindy, and son Jack, 13, at a time when a number of other veterans are visiting, many of them trying to heal wounds, make amends and lay the past to rest.
Mr. McCain, who revels in a reputation for straight talking, found it appropriate -- on what was his sixth visit to the prison -- to get angry once again at the guards who had held him. "I still bear them ill will, not because of what they did to me, but because of what they did to some of my friends, including killing some of them," he told reporters.
It was a comment, paraphrased in a photo caption in the International Herald Tribune on Thursday, that government censors carefully obliterated, copy by copy, with black marker pens.
And it seemed to infuriate Ms. Thanh of the Foreign Ministry. "It runs counter to the norms of morality that those people who brought bombs and shells to sow death among our people and wreak havoc with a country now pass themselves off as having the right to criticize their victims-cum-saviors," she said.
As if egged on by her comments, Mr. McCain widened the scope of his criticisms today, accusing Vietnamese officials of only pretending to want to improve relations.
"The object of my relationship with Vietnam has been to heal the wounds that exist, particularly among our veterans, and to move forward with a positive relationship," he told reporters as he toured Ho Chi Minh City, the former Saigon. "Apparently some in the Vietnamese government don't want to do that."
In the last month or more, as the anniversary has approached, the Hanoi government has indulged in a mood of triumphalism, parading everything from war veterans to elephants to show how it defeated the world's most powerful nation. It is an attitude that could well get under the skin of an American veteran.
In addition, the hundreds of reporters who have gathered here for the anniversary have had little news to report so far and have pursued Mr. McCain eagerly for colorful comments. He has obliged.
"There's a difference in the attitude here of the government towards foreign investment, towards a trade agreement," he said. "I see the hammer and sickle out there on banners. I'm a bit concerned about both the policies and attitudes, and the increase in corruption in this country."
Still, Mr. McCain made it clear today that there are things in Vietnam that he does like. He took his wife and son shopping for traditional rice wine with a snake in the bottle.

HEADLINE: U.S. VS. MICROSOFT: THE INDUSTRY;
Rivals Cheer, Saying a Breakup Would Reignite Competition in Software

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 28

 BODY:
The government's proposal to break up Microsoft and force it to adhere to a stiff set of sanctions limiting its power would reignite competition in the software industry, a variety of computer industry executives said today.
The Justice Department's plan, outlined in a 17-page filing this afternoon with Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, would create two powerful companies, one with the world's dominant operating systems, covering a variety of different types of computers, and one with a wide range of software applications and development tools. 
 Both companies, though, would be forced to adhere to strict rules intended to rein in the way they wield their power in the marketplace.
"This will give the industry the kind of start it needs to restore competition," said James L. Barksdale, who testified against Microsoft while serving as chief executive of Netscape Communications.
He said that in theory he was not enthusiastic about the prospect of a corporate breakup dictated by the government, but saw no alternative in Microsoft's case because of its repeated antitrust violations.
"Almost all of us react negatively to the idea of breaking up a company," Mr. Barksdale said. "However, this is a shock to the system that will have the overall benefit of healing and curing in the marketplace."
Other executives who are Microsoft competitors said they were guardedly optimistic. "This proposal is good for Novell," said Eric Schmidt, chief executive of Novell, the San Jose, Calif., maker of networking software. "For a long time there have not been any rules about how to engage with Microsoft. This proposal gives us some rules with which we can judge whether competition is increasing and openness is preserved."
Other software executives said the payoff from such a change might take years but would push the industry toward renewed competition. "In the long term this is very meaningful," said John Chen, chief executive of Sybase, the Emeryville, Calif., maker of database software, which Microsoft once invested in and now competes with. "Microsoft is on every desktop, and that has given them an unfair advantage which is not related to the strength of their products."
In addition to forcing Microsoft to reorganize into two companies within 16 months after a final court ruling, the proposal made by the Justice Department and state attorneys general would impose a variety of restrictions, including a ban on exclusive agreements with partners, a ban on the company's ability to force buyers of certain operating systems to purchase other Microsoft products as well, and a restriction on the binding of "middleware" products like browsers and e-mail programs to its operating systems.
Microsoft would also be required to install a chief compliance officer reporting to the board to insure that the company complies with antitrust laws and the court's dictates.
The reorganization and the restrictions would have a direct impact on their businesses, several Silicon Valley executives said.
"This is a good remedy and it's doable," said Mitchell E. Kertzman, president and chief executive of Liberate Technologies, a San Carlos, Calif., developer of interactive television systems. A breakup, he said, would make it possible for Liberate to sell its software to work with Windows CE on next-generation set-top boxes.
"We would love to run our software on Windows CE," he said. "If Microsoft is broken up, I expect the Windows CE guys to come knocking on my door asking me to do business."
At the same time, he acknowledged that the breakup would make it possible for the new Microsoft applications company to compete with Liberate in its current markets.
"This is what the Government intended," he said. "More competition."
In Silicon Valley, some of those most pleased with the proposed breakup were venture capitalists. For a number of years during the 1990's, Microsoft executives would travel to Sand Hill Road in Menlo Park, Calif., where many venture capitalists have their offices, to make annual presentations.
Many venture capitalists who attended those presentations felt that Microsoft was in effect redlining the computer industry, telling its competitors where they had opportunities and where they would be limited by Microsoft competition.
"We're restructuring the computer industry," said one venture capitalist, who has been in close contact with the Justice Department in recent weeks as the agency worked to complete its proposal.
There was not universal confidence that the plan would accomplish its goal, however.
"There is all kinds of gobbledygook coming out of the Justice Department," said Randy Komisar, a longtime Silicon Valley executive who was a co-founder of the Claris Corporation, now called Filmaker, and was later chief executive of LucasArts Entertainment. "They are hoping that by creating an applications company as aggressive as the OS company, the new company will do things like make bets on Palm and Linux. That way they will crack open the operating system market."
It will not have an immediate impact on the computer industry, he said. "This is like Reagan's trickle-down economics," he continued. "It may work, but it won't happen any time soon."
The industry's reaction -- or lack of it -- also gave an indication that Microsoft was still an intimidating force in the computer world.
Chief executives at rivals like Adobe Systems; Filemaker, a unit of Apple Computer; Intuit; and Symantec all said they were not willing to comment on the proposed breakup.
"These are tricky waters to navigate," said Steve Ruddock, a Filemaker spokesman. "I'm not sure it's intimidation, but there are a lot of companies who work with us who also partner with Microsoft."

SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 401 words

HEADLINE: Decline of the Euro

 BODY:
The value of the euro has plunged more than 20 percent against the dollar in the 16 months since its adoption by 11 members of the European Union. The drop, from almost $1.20 in January 1999 to about 90 cents today, upsets Europeans who find a falling currency embarrassing. A deeper issue is that some Europeans fear the euro might be on the verge of free fall, which would raise the price of imports, thereby reducing living standards and adding to inflationary pressures. To keep inflation in check, the European Central Bank might decide to raise interest rates to slow the economy. American exporters worry that a falling euro -- which means a rising dollar -- will turn Europeans away from American products.
These fears are exaggerated. Currencies rise and fall. Fluctuations of the euro are far from alarming. Indeed, the basket of currencies that make up the euro rose in value before its formal introduction. Between the summer of 1998 and now, the value of those currencies has hardly budged. The United States has been growing at a fast rate, attracting a steady inflow of European capital. Europe has grown more slowly, leading to an outflow of capital. The imbalance has more people wanting to sell euros than buy them. These trends are likely to prove temporary. 
 The impact on the United States and Europe of ordinary fluctuations in the euro-dollar exchange rate is modest. Both import relatively few goods, compared with the overall size of their economies. The impact of a falling euro on the living standards of Europeans is small. Nor does a falling euro raise import prices enough to substantially affect inflation. The danger is that the European Central Bank will raise interest rates anyway, just to maintain the value of the euro high enough for Europe to keep bragging about its new currency -- a dangerous trap for a Continent whose unemployment rates hover at more than twice the American level.
Europe appears to be making more of the euro's problems than its fluctuations deserve. Most of the Continent is recovering well. Inflation is subdued. When the euro was born, many Europeans boasted that it would challenge the dollar for international supremacy. Those hopes have been temporarily dashed. But the euro is young. As the European Union expands, so too will use of the euro. The euro is here to stay, though its value will continue to move up and down. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: U.S. VS. MICROSOFT: THE COMPANY;
At Microsoft's Home Base, Vitriol and a Sense of Unfairness

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, April 28

 BODY:
"Very disturbing," "unprecedented," "out of bounds," "extreme" and "radical" were a few of the angry words that came out of William H. Gates's mouth shortly after the government's formal proposal today to break up Microsoft, the software company he co-founded 25 years ago and built into a high-technology giant.
"This was not developed by anyone who knows anything about the software business," Mr. Gates said. 
 Microsoft's chief counsel, William Neukom, assailed the sweeping proposal from the Justice Department and 17 state attorneys general as a "regulatory death penalty," with demands that were "out of all proportion to the case itself."
And the company's president and chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer, said he was "disappointed beyond belief" by the government's recommendations.
With settlement talks having dissolved in failure a few weeks ago and the judge in the landmark case, Thomas Penfield Jackson, having ruled that Microsoft illegally put its "oppressive thumb" on competitors, the company once again came out swinging today.
Its executives repeatedly said that any breakup would be a terrible thing for customers and promised that the proposal would never survive an appeals process that could well reach the United States Supreme Court.
Mr. Gates, in a telephone conference call the company arranged shortly after the government's filing became public, emphatically rejected the idea of some on Wall Street that Microsoft might be worth more broken up in parts than intact. And he said that the regulatory curbs the company wanted to place on his company would stifle innovation as the company works on its next generation of software products.
"These proposals would block us from doing new product work," said Mr. Gates, Microsoft's chairman and now its chief software architect. "Microsoft could never have developed Windows under these rules. We couldn't have developed Windows because without the great work of the Office team and the Windows team, it never would have come together."
"This proposal," Mr. Gates asserted, "takes away any incentive for us to do new work by saying that the intellectual property has to be given away to other companies."
Across the company's campus in the Seattle suburb of Redmond, seemingly ever expanding and now up to 41 buildings, employees continued to express frustration at the way Microsoft had been depicted in court.
"The reality is not what I'm seeing played out in Judge Jackson's court," said Bruce M. Brooks, a former deputy mayor of Seattle, who is Microsoft's director of community affairs. "The reality is what I see here every day with our employees. It just doesn't square with this idea of an evil empire, a big predator."
Company leaders continued to reassure employees that Microsoft would never be broken up, and that seems to remain the prevailing opinion on the Microsoft campus.
"I believe it's more likely that we would get acquired by some other company than that we would ever get broken up," said Tod Nielsen, a 12-year Microsoft veteran who is vice president for product and business planning in one of Microsoft's major groups.
Asked what company might ever be in a position to acquire Microsoft, Mr. Nielsen replied: "That's the point. It's not going to happen."
But even as many executives said they were continuing to focus on their particular work projects and had faith that the company's legal team would prevail, the case remains an obvious distraction here.
And it is widely seen as the prime culprit in the drop in the company's stock price, which has wiped out more than $250 billion worth of market value in the last four months. From an record high of nearly $120 a share on Dec. 30, the stock recently reached a 16-month low near $65. It ended regular trading yesterday at $69.75, down 6.25 cents, then edged up after hours.
Mr. Ballmer provided employees with a big morale boost this week by announcing that Microsoft would give workers options to buy shares at about $66, allaying concerns for those who hold other options pegged to much higher market prices.
He is going on a public relations offensive, appearing in a television advertisement scheduled to be broadcast starting this weekend that is similar to one in which Mr. Gates spoke a few weeks ago.
"When I joined Bill Gates and Microsoft 20 years ago," Mr. Ballmer says in the ad, "the PC was very new. This year, three people buy one every second. Now I'm the president of Microsoft and we're still focused on innovating, delivering value and listening to customers. Technology is fueling America's economy; our next generation of software will do even more."
And in what is becoming something of a slogan for the company, Mr. Ballmer, who met Mr. Gates in college, concluded, "The best is yet to come."
While Attorney General Janet Reno today called the government's proposal "the right remedy at the right time," Microsoft said it would file its objections to the proposal on May 10. In offering a long catalog of grievances with the government's approach in the antitrust case, Mr. Gates argued that the Justice Department was trying to apply an old- economy approach in a new economic era.
"It's not, you know, a company that owns mines or resources or anything like that," Mr. Gates said. "What we have are smart people who work together as a team, and it's only by working as a team that we've been able to do our great work."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk
