HEADLINE: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Toby Young;
A Way With Words

BYLINE: By NANCY HASS 

 BODY:
TOBY YOUNG was due at his own bon voyage party at 6:30 p.m. Thursday, but at 7 he was battling the British Invasion in his small Greenwich Village apartment.
Mr. Young, 36, is the English journalist who was brought to town with much fanfare five years ago by the editor of Vanity Fair, Graydon Carter, and has, in his own words, "been failing in a devastatingly public way" ever since. Oddly, failure seems only to have enhanced his popularity. As he shined his shoes with old underwear, his pal Sophie Dahl, the Ford model, was in the spare bedroom primping. Euan Rellie, who was just brought over from London to work at Talk and is Mr. Young's houseguest, was in the shower. Mr. Young is ostensibly leaving New York to live in London with his girlfriend, Caroline Bondy, 25, who was also there, squeezing into a bustier. They were readying for a party given by Nadine Johnson, a publicist, and her husband, Richard Johnson of Page Six of The New York Post, who has often used Mr. Young's exploits as column fodder. 
 "I really do need to shower myself," Mr. Young called to Mr. Rellie through the bathroom door.
"Good for you, mate," Mr. Rellie replied cheerfully.
Mr. Young, who is balding and trim, handled the brushoff with his signature sigh of acceptance and a vaguely embarrassed air, a pose that has earned him a following of media luminaries who treat him as a kind of hangdog mascot. In fact, among British journalists here, Mr. Young has become an ever-present icon of defeat. But in typically British fashion, that is regarded as its own sort of success, especially because Mr. Young has catalogued his fall from grace unstintingly in print.
"Americans are always touting their success," he said, "whereas we are much more interested in talking about what losers we are."
Mr. Young, who came to New York after running the trendy Modern Review, said he spent his time here "acting inappropriately." When Vanity Fair sent him to interview Nathan Lane, he promptly caused the actor to stomp out of the room when he bluntly asked: "Are you gay?" Soon after, he booked a stripper for a colleague on "Take Our Daughters to Work Day."
Mr. Young lasted three years at the magazine, though he wrote only 400 words. The articles he wrote elsewhere were questionable career moves: a chronicle in The Mail on Sunday of his 48-hour affair with a Venezuelan heiress who dumped him for Mick Jagger, and an attack in The Spectator on Harry Evans, the former editor of Random House, and his wife, Tina Brown. Mr. Evans threatened publicly to sue him but never did. "I've really given myself a remarkably bad time here," Mr. Young recalled during the cab ride to the party in his honor at the Johnson town house on East 18th Street. He arrived more than an hour late.
Mr. Young had invited about 150 people, and by 8:30, at least that many showed up to toast his leaving. "There are people here who have not returned my calls in two years," he said. In the spirit of Mr. Young's self-deprecating style, everyone had something cheerfully nasty to say about him. Plum Sykes, a Vogue fashion writer, noted that Mr. Young had, in fact, been living in London with Ms. Bondy for the last three months and had flown in expressly for the good-bye party. "Typical," she said with a sniff.
Mr. Carter agreed, saying Mr. Young "lingered like gum on your shoe." He denied that he had fired Mr. Young, but conceded that he was "eminently fireable."
"You take one look at him," Mr. Carter continued, "and say, 'He's out of here.' "
John Cassidy, who writes about economics for The New Yorker, noted that Mr. Young had wound up getting paid "several hundred dollars a word" at Vanity Fair. "His output was laughable," he said.
As the party peaked, around 9:30 p.m., Mr. Young got up on a chair and announced that Ms. Bondy had agreed last week to marry him. (He also made clear that she had originally turned him down.) The crowd cheered.
Mr. Young left shortly after midnight. Only the next day did he learn of his final missed opportunity: meeting Quentin Tarantino, who showed up at the party a half-hour after Mr. Young had left.

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 2; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2949 words

HEADLINE: Bridging a Divide

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
CYNTHIA WANG and her husband were on a train out of New York, headed upstate with another couple, their three children and the children's French au pair. Ms. Wang is Asian-American. The other wife and mother was a half-black woman who is sometimes assumed to be white but is darker than her children. The two husbands were white.
"This little white boy came over and stared at us," recalled Ms. Wang, a 46-year-old real estate banker, sitting in the Upper West Side apartment that she shares with her husband and their 3-year-old daughter, Lucy, who is adopted from China. 
 "He came up to me and asked me point-blank if I was the nanny because I was the only visible person of color in the group and I guess I was more nannylike," Ms. Wang said. "The other mother laughed and said: 'Cynthia, I always want to travel with you. It's the first time I haven't been taken for the nanny.' "
The vaunted melting pot that is New York City is home to a growing number of interracial families like Ms. Wang's and her friends. It is, however, a pot that incubates racial divisions as well as racial blending. In any mixed family, people tell stories ranging from Ms. Wang's comedy of errors to awkward moments and ugly slights that testify to a city that is less racially sophisticated than its image.
In interviews with dozens of New Yorkers from interracial families, most said they live in communities in which they feel accepted and their families are thriving. The tragic mulatto is a myth. In Park Slope, Brooklyn; Flushing, Queens, and the Upper West Side, interracial families are found in abundance.
Still, people will stare at a black man, a white woman and two biracial children because although the city's sidewalks and the subways are truly international, many people go home to separate neighborhoods and separate realities. The pockets of tolerance and diversity are celebrated because they are the exception rather than the rule, even as more racially mixed workplaces and schools give people more chances to meet and marry.
Emotional paper cuts are what most racially blended families face as they navigate the city. Mothers of racially mixed children talk about being mistaken for nannies (if they are not white) or teachers (if they are white). Store clerks approach mixed couples as individuals and seem startled when they say they are together.
People tell of attending parties or school events at which strangers insist that their child or spouse is not present because it is assumed the child or the spouse is the same race. In a restaurant, a waiter may ask a mixed family if they want more than one doggy bag because of the assumption that these different-looking people do not live under one roof.
Behind closed doors, the main issues for most mixed families are acceptance by the interracial couple's parents and extended family, an understanding of how their spouses and their children see the world and how to help their children feel comfortable in a race-obsessed world.
Yet most of the mixed families said that while theirs is not the easier choice, their lives are enriched by diversity. And their conversations in their homes are more often about dinner plans than about color because many take the new racial frontier for granted. This year's census, for example, alllows people to check more than one box for race.
"To say I'm half-black and half-Italian would not have been possible when I was a kid," said Roger Sanjek, a 55-year-old professor of anthropology at Queens College and an editor and contributor to the book "Race," a collection of articles by social scientists (Rutgers University Press, 1994). "Now, people talk like that.
"New York has always been a more ethnically, racially diverse area than any other part of the country," Dr. Sanjek said. "There are more possibilities and more combinations for interracial marriage. And perhaps the whites who come here are more willing that others to see race and ethnicity as not fixed."
Ms. Wang's husband, Daniel Sedlis, an assistant commissioner at the city's Administration for Children's Services, said he certainly looks at himself differently because of his marriage.
"The struggle I had to go through had to do with my Jewish identity with both my parents being Holocaust survivors," he said. "The growth for me, with a Chinese wife and a Chinese daughter, was to embrace not just the survival of the Jews but the survival of the human race.
"It's crossed my mind that one day I'll be in public with Lucy and she'll throw a tantrum and deny I'm her father," Mr. Sedlis said only half facetiously. Mostly, he said, people ask, "Does she look like her mother?"
Members of mixed families often develop a thick skin to shrug off the random strange comment or unsettling situation. Ms. Wang, for instance, said she feels happily embraced by two cultures even as she tells stories about mistaken identity or about people who compare her Jewish husband to Woody Allen because of Lucy. She has learned to put people in their place, she said, because these issues are recurring.
Because of the legacy of slavery and enduring racial prejudice that included anti-miscegenation laws that survived in some states until 1967, the issues are especially pronounced for black-white couples.
"I used to think he put too much emphasis on race when something went wrong at work," said one white woman who lives in Park Slope with her husband, who is black, and their baby son. "But the more I started noticing the way people treated me with my son and the comments I got when they found out I was married to him, the more I realized that black and whites really do have that separate reality thing going on."
The degree of separation varies greatly. More people have friends, colleagues and neighbors of other races. And some families were fine with the notion of their children marrying someone from another race and everyone got along well.
Those who felt that people of other races were essentially different or inferior were more likely to cut off contact or go for long periods without communication. One white grandmother bristled when her half-Hispanic grandchildren spoke Spanish. A black uncle made fun of how his niece's white husband danced.
Most couples recalled that when they announced their plans to marry, their parents worried about prejudice against the couple or any future grandchildren.
When it comes to dual-heritage children, parents take different approaches. Some tell their children they are "mixed." Others tell their children that if one parent is white, society will see them as members of the minority race. Still others insist there is no such thing as race. And there is a growing movement by biracial children to identify themselves as belonging to both races.
Clara Rodriguez, a Puerto Rican woman who lives in the Bronx with her husband Gelvin Stevenson, who is half-white and half-Cherokee, recalled how he learned to speak Spanish and dance salsa. Now married 30 years, the couple raised their son and daughter in the south and central Bronx, where the children learned Spanish and English and participated in Native American naming ceremonies.
Dr. Rodriguez said her children, who are now young adults, identify more as Puerto Rican. But at Fordham University, where she is a sociology professor, many biracial students refuse to be put in one category.
"It's not a zero-sum game," Mr. Stevenson, an economist who does investment consulting, said of the question of biracial identity. He added that through his marriage he has come to identify more as Native American. "Because they're proud of being Puerto Rican doesn't mean they're less Cherokee."
Jane Lazarre, a white woman who has been married for 30 years to Douglas White, a black man, and who has written extensively about mixed families, said the identity question is not resolved by using the term "biracial."
"The quick desire on the part of the white parent to identify a child as biracial is a way to distance themselves from racism," Ms. Lazarre said. A writing teacher at the New School who lives on the Upper West Side, Ms. Lazarre wrote about her family in "Beyond the Whiteness of Whiteness: Memoir of a White Mother of Black Sons" (Duke University, 1996).
Ms. Lazarre, who is Jewish, said that she had hoped their two sons would see themselves as black and Jewish, but that as brown-skinned men in a racist society they are considered "black" first.
"There is a tremendous amount of discomfort and ignorance on the part of white people about black people," Ms. Lazarre said. "I don't think white people want to face up to the enormity of their ignorance about slavery or the way black people think and how they feel.
"I'm asked all the time, 'Isn't it difficult that your children don't look like you?' " she said. "My sons do look like me. The problem is what when white people see even a very light-skinned black person, they see something very, very different. That inability to see physical similarities is a metaphor for an inability to connect on a deeper level."
At the same time, Mr. White, a lawyer, said that the black partner in a black-white marriage cannot be as quick as other black people to assume that all whites are unable to connect.
"You develop a different consciousness about white people," Mr. White said. "I understand a lot about Jewish culture because of Jane and getting close to her father. I've even picked up some Yiddish. I think I'm much less likely to dismiss someone because they're white. I've been too close to too many members of her family to be otherwise."
Ms. Lazarre and Mr. White, who are in their 50's, disagreed on whether their son Adam, who is 30, would face a more accepting society in his marriage to a white woman than they did. When they married, people questioned why they were together and warned that their children would have problems. Mr. White thought it would be easier for Adam. Ms. Lazarre said racism was too deeply entrenched.
Although the divorce rate nationwide is the same for interracial couples as it is for others, people often assume that the relationships are problematic. They cannot imagine that two people of different races are together for the same reasons as anyone else or that racism does not poison the relationship.
"An aunt once said to me, 'Has he ever called you a nigger?' " said Lisa Whitfield, a black woman whose husband, John Congdon, is white. They live in Inwood with their 2-year-old daughter, Imani. They were both 13 and in the eighth grade in Philadelphia when they met, and they attended Oberlin College at the same time. Now she is a teacher of violin and viola, and she sings and plays viola in a band called Hue; he is a furniture salesman.
"Sometimes friends have asked me, 'Why did you marry a white guy and what are you going to tell your kids?' " Ms. Whitfield said. "I've met some people who've expressed some real disappointment."
Imani's skin is white and she has blond hair. Ms. Whitfield said most people don't comment when the family is together but some women have made pointed remarks about Imani's "delicate features." Or they say, "Her hair is so different from yours," when she is with Ms. Whitfield, who has dark, curly hair.
On the census form, the family checked two races for Imani. At this point, Ms. Whitfield is using basic colors to teach her child about her heritage, although she said she thinks of her as black. She knows Imani will confront a world obsessed with figuring out her race.
"I like it when people are honest," Ms. Whitfield said. "Just say: 'What's up? Is one of your parents white?' Don't make little quips that are meant to break the ice. I don't want to be talked to like I'm some kind of freak.
"Or say: 'I know your husband's white and you're not. Is life hard because of that?' "
Because Imani is so light-skinned, when Mr. Congdon is with her, the only question they get is the origin of her name (it means faith in Swahili). When he tells white people that Imani has an African name because his wife is black, he gets murmurs of approval or a blank stare. Black people seem less surprised to learn that Imani is biracial.
As a result, Mr. Congdon has developed a dual consciousness.
"If I have a son, my son will have to deal with many of the things black men have to deal with in this country," he said. "Giuliani goes on about how everyone should get along with the police. I know on the one hand that's a really white thing to say and I can understand where he's coming from.
"The problem is that you have a society, a culture, with a set of mental constructs to deal with the world," he said. "You're saying there is an 'us' and there is a 'them.' To let go of that, you have to let go of a lot. I've dealt with black people who've been just as unhappy I've taken one of 'theirs' away as I have white people who don't get it or are offended."
Mr. Congdon spent his early childhood in an all-white New England town. "I didn't decide to marry someone black," he said. "I decided to marry Lisa. The fact that she was black didn't matter."
Michel Gelobter, a racially mixed college professor who lives in Harlem, said people are curious about interracial families because they represent a baffling intimacy in a society where people have a hard time getting along across lines of race.
Mr. Gelobter, who teaches public administration at Rutgers University in Newark, has a Jewish father from Poland and a black mother from the Caribbean. He will tell you that he is Jewish by religion and black by race.
He knows many biracial people who speak glowingly of being voyagers in two worlds and who bring special sensitivity to issues of race. The reality is not that simple, he said, because most people categorize anyone with any visible heritage other than white as belonging to the nonwhite group. And a being a symbol or a bridge to two communities can be hard.
Mr. Gelobter, who is 38, said the tolerant and even self-consciously racially sensitive New York of his youth no longer exists.
When he was growing up in the 70's in Flatbush, Brooklyn, and the Upper West Side, black men used to approach his father on the subway to compliment him for having a beautiful black wife. And Mr. Gelobter's biracial friends from that era never felt their heritage represented a special problem.
But the other day, at Symphony Space on the Upper West Side, Mr. Gelobter said he was the target of bewildered stares and a palpable discomfort as he held the white child of a white friend. And sometimes heads turn when Mr. Gelobter's father is out walking or playing with Mr. Gelobter's older daughter, who is almost 3.
"We've lost the language to talk about the problem," Mr. Gelobter said. "I can be very angry at white men who historically raped black women without being angry at my father. The sad thing is, people let politics rule their responses. The one thing that biracial people can bring in is the response that I'm not born of politics. I was born of two people who love each other."
Suzanne Rust, an African-American writer who is married to Marco Khelo, a white man from Italy who develops Web sites for a living, said that even she stares at interracial couples. She and her husband have two young children and live on the Upper West Side.
"Sometimes I stare just because people look interesting together," Ms. Rust said. "This is silly, but sometimes I smile because I want people to feel acknowledged and accepted."
Many mixed families do avidly seek others like themselves because their numbers are still small. According to the 1990 census, 3.5 percent of all marriages in New York were classified as mixed race, although many experts believe that the 2000 census will show markedly higher numbers. In the nation as a whole, 2.9 percent of all marriages are interracial.
Census data show that of new marriages, about half of Asian women marry outside their race and half of Hispanic women (who can be any race) marry outside their ethnic group. The rates were slightly lower for men in the two groups.
A national study of black-white marriages in 1993 found that of all new marriages by blacks that year, 12.1 percent were to white spouses, up from 2.6 percent in 1970. That study, published in New Democrat magazine and based on census data, also found that in 1990 there were four times as many children living in homes where the primary adults were of different races that there were in 1970.
The real question, said Dr. Sanjek, the Queens College anthropologist, is what forces conspire to keep the intermarriage rate so low even in an international city like New York? Notions of race, he said, are shaped by politics and social factors like class, with immigrants to the city like the Irish, Italians and Jews considered nonwhite at various times.
The future for intermarriage is unclear, Dr. Sanjek said. There could be continued emphasis on broad racial categories, new categories or an abandonment of the very concept of race. Blacks could become just another ethnic group. Or, as other groups meld at ever higher rates, blacks could continue to be outsiders -- seen but not seen.
Mr. Gelobter, the college professor who is black and Jewish, tells this tale. Strolling around the Upper West Side, he often saw an elderly black woman pushing an elderly white man in a wheelchair. Mr. Gelobter wondered if it was difficult for the woman to work as the man's caretaker.
"I talked to her one day," Mr. Gelobter said. "It turned out they had been married for a long time and he had become ill. She was very devoted to him. It seemed like love, more than anything else."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BENDING ELBOWS;
Finally, the Teamsters Have Something to Toast

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LEDUFF 

 BODY:
Something is happening with big labor. Union men and women are starting to feel good about themselves again.
After the rank and file of Teamsters Local 282 met Thursday night at their union hall in Lake Success, N.Y., members moved on to J. J. Peabody's to drink from the well of their hard-earned success. 
 Peabody's is tucked away in the deep recesses of Glen Oaks, Queens, off the Union Turnpike. The bar is one of those brick-and-paneling jobs you're likely to find in rural Michigan. Teamsters are a clannish lot, and they stood six deep in the corners, bickering for the privilege of buying the drinks. They exchanged hugs and genteel kisses, as if they were on the receiving line at a debutante cotillion. Others leaned on the rail like dusty cowboys.
"Is that a woman?"
"Don't know. Sex change, maybe?"
"In this bar?"
"Hey, be a trucker and roll with it."
Things have changed around here. Local 282 was once Gambino property, and members outside the wise guy clique got little work and were afraid to complain.
Nothing of any significance gets built in New York without the 4,000-member local, whose drivers deliver building materials. But under mob control, the union threatened slowdowns to extort money and women and beach houses from contractors. In 1995 the government stepped in and threw the leadership out.
The men and women of Local 282 have not had a democratically elected board since 1990, a stain of shame and embarrassment for these workers, who wear the American flag on their sleeves. But under the appointed trusteeship of Gary Labarbera, the union's dealings have become transparent, work is plentiful, and the books are balanced. The feds are expected to grant a general election in November.
This is cause for celebration and loud music. But, as in any good roadhouse, when the customers get tired of hollering and hell-raising, they sit down to talk, and they usually have something to say.
"Underneath the economic boom, something's rotten," said Joe Lehrer, who has 32 years in the local, 24 behind the wheel of a cement mixer. He bought a house in the burbs and a Lincoln, and fed two kids. "Nice and middle class," he says. "Nothing rich, just American."
Joe is 63. He spoke matter-of-factly. "When the smoke clears on this stock market, we are going to wonder what happened to the jobs with the benefits," he said. "You can't have an economy based on data entry and wiping old people's behinds. America needs unions again."
Something is happening, and you can feel it from these people. They were among the protesters at the world trade meetings in Seattle and Washington. They were part of the 40,000-man hard-hat march in Midtown two years ago, in which several people were arrested and a police horse was slugged -- all because the Metropolitan Transit Authority awarded a nonunion contract of $180 million.
That M.T.A. contract eventually went to the union. "That was a sign that we're back," Nick Spinelli said. "We're taking it to the streets." A fellow Teamster drained his beer. "I got to go home, guys. I got to build those streets in the morning."
 CHARLIE LEDUFF

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST SIDE;
A Site With No Commitments Draws Eyes of 7 Eager Suitors

BYLINE: By DAVID KIRBY 

 BODY:
The city must choose among seven competing plans for a two-square-block site of prime East Side real estate.
Last November, the city's Economic Development Corporation and the Health and Hospitals Corporation sought proposals for developing the 3.5-acre city-owned site on the Bellevue Hospital campus. The parcel, bounded by First Avenue and the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive and 28th and 30th 
 Streets, includes the former psychiatric building, a nine-story structure built in the 1930's, which now houses a homeless men's shelter that is closing, along with a smaller building.
The request elicited seven responses for renovating the psychiatric building and building new structures on the rest of the site. One developer, A&R Kalimian Realty, wanted to build apartments. Castle Senior Living proposed subsidized housing for the elderly. The Related Companies, a major real estate developer, suggested some combination of apartments, a medical school and a biotech research center. Others proposed a mix of subsidized housing, student housing and community facilities.
New York University, whose medical school is just north of the Bellevue complex, proposed housing for post-doctoral students, doctors' offices, conference space and a child care center. It also proposed building several commercial biotechnology research facilities on the rest of the property.
"I have several grave concerns about the proposed sale," said Assemblyman Steven Sanders, whose district includes Bellevue. "To begin with, we only found out about it through an ad. The community should have been consulted from the beginning."
Mr. Sanders said he feared that additional housing would increase congestion, especially if Con Edison sells land it owns nearby to housing developers, which seems likely.
Edward Rubin, chairman of the land use committee of Community Board 6, added: "It's not fair to go direct to contract without giving people a chance to comment. It's not the way you do things, but that's they way they did it. There is a lot of suspicion that this was a done deal in advance, and that N.Y.U. will get the site."
Martin Begun, a lawyer who represents Castle Senior Living, said he was so convinced that N.Y.U. would get the property "that I told my client to forget about it, at least for now."
Janel Patterson, a spokeswoman for the Economic Development Corporation, said that the city was free to sign a contract with any of the respondents but that no decision had been made. DAVID KIRBY

HEADLINE: Investing;
Out on a Limb, and Carrying an Ever-Heavier Bag of Stocks

BYLINE: By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
THOMAS GALVIN'S voice never wavers as he describes the view from out on the lonely end of a limb.
Mr. Galvin, the chief investment officer for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, edged his way out there on the morning of April 17 when, following one of the scariest days in the stock market in 18 months, he recommended that clients put 90 percent of their assets into stocks. Even for a staunchly bullish investment strategist at a firm whose clients are mostly institutions and wealthy investors, it was a daring move. 
 Most strategists on Wall Street never set the stock portion of their asset allocation at more than 75 percent and, lately, they have been more inclined to advise reducing stock holdings rather than raising them. Mr. Galvin, 39, is the only prominent strategist who has run against the herd and not turned back. Thomas McManus, the strategist for Bank of America Securities, also raised his stock allocation on April 17 -- to 80 percent from 75 percent -- but reversed that call a week later.
"Taking this position was not without career risk," Mr. Galvin acknowledged. "It's much easier to be bearish than to be bullish right now."
But Mr. Galvin said he saw much more risk in missing the rebound from the technology-stock sell-off than in suffering through any further declines. With the Nasdaq composite at 3,321 after its 10 percent plunge on April 14, he said he thought the index would fall no more than another 200 points. But he thought it could rise 2,000.
Charles Larsen, a managing director of Trust Company of the West in Los Angeles, met with Mr. Galvin April 17 and liked what he heard. "When there's panic in the streets, he has the demeanor of never being flustered and sticking with his guns," Mr. Larsen said. Since Abby Joseph Cohen, chief strategist for Goldman Sachs, trimmed her stock weighting to 65 percent, from 70 percent in March, Mr. Larsen said, Mr. Galvin "has kind of taken her mantle as the positive strategist."
AT the time, Mr. Galvin was reluctant to say that technology stocks had hit bottom. Since then, the Nasdaq index has risen 16 percent, and now Mr. Galvin says he believes the index bottomed out on April 24 when it dipped below 3,250: "I just think it's time to be in there buying with both hands."
Sure, but 90 percent stocks and no bonds? Who puts 90 percent of assets into stocks when the market is swinging wildly?
"I do," Mr. Galvin said, adding that he has more than 90 percent of his own assets in stocks and has been buying more technology shares in the last two weeks. "I don't manage my mother's portfolio this way, but I manage my own portfolio this way."
That attitude distinguishes Mr. Galvin from his more conservative counterparts at firms that cater to a wider range of investors. Strategists at those firms, like Merrill Lynch, tend to maintain a balance of stocks and bonds, and to see their recommended asset allocations as the most important guidance they can offer for broad groups of small investors. David Bowers, Merrill Lynch's global strategist, recommends 50 percent stocks, 30 percent bonds, 15 percent cash and 5 percent in commodities.
Compared with them, Mr. Galvin is a radical. He argues that the crucial decision now is choosing the market sectors in which to invest. During the long bull market for United States stocks, the lion's share of investment gains have come from particular sectors, like financial stocks in the early 1990's and technology stocks in the late 1990's, Mr. Galvin said.
The widely held belief in the importance of diversification is "a bunch of hogwash," he said."If you'd been able to pick one or two sectors," he added, "you did a lot better by being overly focused."
For now, he said, investors should focus on technology and telecommunications stocks. His asset allocation calls for a 41 percent weighting in technology and 10 percent in communication services. Among his favorites are Veritas Software, Amdocs, Digex, Nokia and Siebel Systems.
Investors should look for companies whose sales are rising fast enough to offset the sharply rising labor costs that were shown this week in the employment cost index, he said. "I try to find industry groups or stocks that have an opportunity to gain market share and sustain profit margins," he said.
Mr. Galvin also contends that most investors spend too much time fretting about high price-to-earnings ratios and whether stocks are too expensive or cheap enough to buy. Valuation accounts for just 10 percent of investment decisions, he said, and is far less important than the economic climate and market conditions. He believes investors are holding a lot of cash that they intend to pour into stocks as soon as they think the sell-off is over.
"Sometimes the catalyst is just a recognition that the market has just digested some market-unfriendly news," he said. That is exactly what happened on Thursday, he said, when technology stocks bounced back strongly after a government report that showed labor costs rising unusually fast. That afternoon, he told the firm's sales staff to ask themselves, "If this didn't take the market down, what will?"
Boldly calling for a market resurgence has become a hallmark of Mr. Galvin's brief tenure as Donaldson Lufkin's chief strategist. He joined the firm in early 1998 from the New York-based securities unit of Deutsche Bank of Germany; for his first four months, he held to a moderate allocation of 65 percent stocks, 30 percent bonds and 5 percent cash.
In early August 1998, as an economic crisis was spreading from Russia through Asia, Mr. Galvin began his gradual shift further into stocks and away from bonds. In a move that did not pay off for several weeks, he shifted 10 percent out of bonds and raised his stock allocation to 75 percent.
Six months later, in January 1999, he went another step, moving an additional 5 percent out of bonds into stocks. He held that mix -- 80 percent stocks, 15 percent bonds, 5 percent cash -- for 15 months before making the leap completely out of bonds, with 90 percent in stocks.
Bonds have outperformed stocks so far this year, but Mr. Galvin says that will not continue. And the idea of owning bonds as a hedge against rising inflation is a mistaken one, he said. The major stock indexes will recover and will be higher at the end of the year than they were at the start, Mr. Galvin said.
And if they don't? "I'll be a laughingstock," he said. "People will say, "Didn't he know P/E's were high? Didn't he get that letter?' "

HEADLINE: SPORTS BUSINESS;
Newest Game Is Buying and Selling Teams

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir 

 BODY:
Get out the tote board: another local team has been sold.
Since 1997, the Islanders have been bought three times -- once, briefly, by a now-convicted felon -- the latest by Charles Wang and Sanjay Kumar last Wednesday for $187.5 million. The Nets have been sold twice, the Devils and the Jets once. 
 The Yankees, once chased by Cablevision, turned into the hunter last year and merged with the Nets, then snapped up the Devils last month.
Cablevision may still be wooing the Mets, who may be waiting for a dot.com gazillionaire to pay a half-billion to them into software.
With the Knicks and the Rangers secure under the Cablevision umbrella, only the Giants have eluded the local auction block.
Since 1991, when Bob Tisch paid the Mara family $75 million for 50 percent of the Giants, nine National Football League teams have been sold, including the Jets last January. Four expansion teams were added in those nine years.
"If the Jets went for $635 million, the Giants would be worth $750 million or $800 million," Tisch said. Despite the overheated appetite for teams, he said he had not received offers for his half of the franchise.
"Never," he said. "They know I'm not selling. I don't know if I should feel bad or not, but everybody knows we're in it for the long haul."
Plenty of selling is going on nationally. Since 1998, 26 major league teams have changed hands in whole or have sold large minority stakes. Last week, Stan Kroenke, who owns 40 percent of the St. Louis Rams, agreed to pay $450 million for the Denver Nuggets, the Colorado Avalanche and the Pepsi Center in Denver, beating out a group that included John McMullen, the departing owner of the Devils, who was part of groups that tried to buy the Jets and the Washington Redskins.
Since the start of the year, the Vancouver Grizzlies have sold for $165 million, the Dallas Mavericks for $280 million and the Kansas City Royals for $96 million (less than one-third of the $322 million paid last year for the Cleveland Indians).
The national trend has created a Wal-Mart sports bloc -- the blue light special owners. Bill and Nancy Laurie, a daughter of Bud Walton, who founded Wal-Mart with his brother, Sam, bought the St. Louis Blues last year for $100 million ($10 million for the team and $90 million for the debt on the Kiel Center). Kroenke's wife, Ann, is Bud Walton's other daughter. And David Glass, a retired chief executive officer of Wal-Mart, is the new Royals owner.
"The skyrocketing asset values of teams make them attractive to sell, even with operating losses," said Marc Ganis, president of Sportscorp Ltd., a Chicago consulting firm. "Teams are also selling when their owners die. But there is also a new breed of owner, the technology entrepreneurs, willing to buy teams. So you have a Mark Cuban spending a huge amount of money for the Mavericks. It may be worth a lot in the future, but not now."
Cuban is a billionaire through his Broadcast.com Internet company. Ted Leonsis used his AOL wealth to buy the Washington Capitals and a minority interest in the Wizards, and Paul Allen spent a bit of his Microsoft billions for the Seattle Seahawks and the Portland Trail Blazers.
Wang and Kumar built their technoriches through software at Computer Associates International, and used it to keep the Islanders on the sports world's most-sold list.
From John Pickett, the team went to John Spano, who loved hockey but loved a scam more and sits in prison for defrauding banks to lend him the money to buy the team. Pickett took the team back, got $25 million more from a group led by Howard Milstein, which said it has lost $40 million over 28 months before Wang and Kumar developed a sudden hunger for hockey.
Wang really wanted the Nets, then tried to join Robert Wood Johnson IV's bid to buy the Jets, but backed away last year when he found that he would get no control for his investment.
So Wang and Kumar overpaid to get the one New York team left -- and because Milstein wouldn't cut his price.
The Pickett-to-Spano-to-Pickett-to-Milstein-to-Wang daisy chain showed that a team could lose games and cash in mass quantities, become a political hot potato but maintain its sale value. What a country!
Wang and Kumar deflected questions about a new lease, a new arena or future cash losses by saying they weren't buying the team as a financial investment or even because they love hockey, which they don't. Their mentor was Alfonse D'Amato, New York's renowned former "Senator Pothole."
"Once we stopped looking at it as a business, it was easy then," said Wang, whose Computer Associates stock is worth $1.7 billion.
Wang's view expands on the prevailing wisdom that a mogul can earn better financial returns from Treasury bills or Beanie babies than with a sports team.
"But you can't watch T-bills play," Alfred Lerner said when he agreed to pay $530 million in 1998 for the renascent Cleveland Browns.
The Islanders' demise as a competitive team in the past decade pegged them as an almost irretrievable charity case. Wang and Kumar hope to deploy the team in the service of their charitable goals.
That's admirable and works for the best community-minded teams, like the Jacksonville Jaguars. But National Football League economics are far healthier than the N.H.L.'s It will be instructive to see how long Wang and Kumar view the Islanders as a noneconomic endeavor if their player investments do not yield victories and a new arena remains an unfulfilled dream.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1873 words

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
He Didn'tSay It. He Knew It All Along.

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
THEY last spoke four years ago, when Alan Greenspan, worried that stock prices might be getting too high, invited eight experts to Washington to hear their views. That was when Robert J. Shiller, a Yale economics professor, warned unequivocally that American investors, caught up in their own fervor, were creating a dangerous bubble.
In his 10-minute presentation, Mr. Shiller said, he never uttered the words "irrational" or "exuberance." "I liked the word 'zeitgeist' in those days, and I probably used it," he recalled. But two days later, on Dec. 5, 1996, Mr. Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, wondered in a now-famous speech whether "irrational exuberance" might be infecting the stock market. And Mr. Shiller saw his influence at work. 
 "He may have had elements of my way of thinking already in his mind, and when he heard my presentation, he may have been persuaded to say a little more in that speech than he would have otherwise," Mr. Shiller said. "That could be how 'irrational exuberance' got from me to him."
Now, though, the phrase has migrated back to Mr. Shiller, who made it the title of a book on the emotional nature of the stock market, written for a popular audience and published just as technology stocks tumbled, launching the markets into their wild April swings. Suddenly, Mr. Shiller, 54, found himself elevated to the status of Wall Street guru. His view that investors are driven by impulse, herd behavior, dinner party chatter, intuition, media hype, fear of being left out -- everything, in short, but informed, reasoned analysis -- offered a timely explanation for the spreading uneasiness about stocks.
An irony is that Mr. Greenspan, despite having introduced the notion of overexuberance into the national dialogue, increasingly sees high stock prices -- a lot higher than they were in 1996 -- as a rational appraisal of corporate America's profitability and prospects.
Technology is transforming the American economy, he says in his speeches and Congressional testimony. Productivity is rising, along with profits. And so investors are logically investing with enthusiasm in companies that are likely to grow in value. What's more, Mr. Greenspan notes, computer technology has increased the amount of information available to investors, and has thus reduced their risk of overpaying for stocks. "Because knowledge once gained is irreversible, so too are the lowered risk premiums," he declared in one recent speech.
Bulls are always more popular than bears -- and most people would rather be regarded as rational than irrational -- but Mr. Shiller's book has nonetheless given voice to an anxiety that clouds today's zeitgeist. "Shiller has managed to pluck an emotional chord," said James Grant, publisher of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, himself a Wall Street pessimist whose fame has waned as stock prices have kept rising.
THAT might be Mr. Shiller's fate, too, if the market recovers from its springtime stumble. Even now, Mr. Shiller's fellow economists are in no rush to take his advice. Spiritually, at least, they seem more in the camp of Wall Street strategists like Abby Joseph Cohen of Goldman Sachs, who for years has encouraged investors to buy into a rising market and a prosperous economy.
"I can present my research and findings to a bunch of academics and they seem to agree," Mr. Shiller said. "But afterward at dinner, they tell me they are 100 percent in stock. They say: 'What you argue is interesting, but I bet stocks will go up. I have this feeling.' "
If Mr. Shiller turns out to be right about the markets, tens of millions of American families will have invested their savings too thoughtlessly and emotionally in stocks. And over the next 10 to 20 years, their retirement incomes will turn out to be a lot smaller than they now anticipate -- not to mention the value of their stock options, the pleasure they get from feeling wealthy and the amount of money they therefore spend.
If Mr. Greenspan -- with his faith that markets, even exuberant markets, essentially reflect the logical and sensible behavior of investors -- is right, then the nation has ahead of it years of strong economic growth and high stock prices. There will be the usual, periodic recessions, of course -- and immense volatility in stocks as the markets sort out winners from losers in the new economy -- but no serious setbacks.
Mr. Shiller is no Jeremiah, raging at the markets. Rather, he is a courteous, even-tempered Midwesterner, raised in Detroit, educated as an undergraduate at the University of Michigan, with a Ph.D. in economics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He is reluctant to stray far from mainstream economics, with its emphasis on rational behavior. And the conviction in his cautious, almost diffident comments takes a moment to sink in.
"Over the last 100 years," he asserted in an interview last week, "aggregate stock prices have either gone up too much or down too much."
His argument is that stock market indexes -- the Dow Jones industrial average, the Standard & Poor's 500, the Nasdaq composite -- are almost always too high or too low. An individual stock price is often an accurate barometer of a company's earnings prospects. But only occasionally, on their way up or on their way down, have the indexes in this country accurately reflected true corporate value. They have more closely resembled a stopped clock that cannot help but be accurate twice a day.
Right now, he says, the indexes are reaching a peak, for the fourth time since 1901. And if history is a guide, this latest peak -- the highest of all -- will be followed by a decline that might last for years before stocks turn up again into a new bull market.
Just when the next downturn will begin and how it will unfold, Mr. Shiller says he does not know. He is confident, though, that after the fact, the experts will offer all sorts of rational -- and incorrect -- explanations.
One will undoubtedly have to do with corporate earnings. Falling market indexes should reflect a fall in average corporate earnings, or at least the expectation that they will fall. But that has seldom happened, and right now corporate profits are doing quite nicely, Mr. Shiller notes. When the turn comes, the irrational reason will be that all the group reinforcement that now drives the market up will go in reverse, and people will convince one another that stocks are a bad deal.
"People are smart, but they tend to make big errors, and they do it in groups," Mr. Shiller said.
OF MOST economists don't get this -- beyond the small group of behavioral economists to which Mr. Shiller belongs -- that is because they don't pay enough attention to psychology, sociology and history. These disciplines, he says, offer more accurate descriptions of human behavior than the models of rational, sensible human beings at the heart of mainstream economic theory.
Psychology is particularly important, and ignored. Walking toward his office in the Cowles Foundation for Economic Research on Hillhouse Street, in a neighborhood of old mansions now mostly owned by Yale, Mr. Shiller points to the brick Victorian headquarters of the economics department and, a block away, the psychology department's building.
"The economists never visit with the psychologists and hardly know where they are located," Mr. Shiller said.
He attributes his iconoclastic economics at least in part to the influence of his late father, Benjamin, described by the son as a fiercely independent engineer, inventor and entrepreneur who never achieved much success. Outside academia, the son had not made much of an impression, either.
And then last summer, he decided to offer his research in a hurriedly written popular book. On Friday, April 14, when the Nasdaq index fell almost 6 percent, "Irrational Exuberance" (Princeton University Press) jumped to 13th place on Amazon.com's sales rankings, from 43rd place the day before. (It will rank 22nd on the expanded hardcover nonfiction best-seller list to be published next Sunday on The New York Times on the Web.)
Suddenly, Mr. Shiller had captured the success -- or at least the public attention -- that had escaped his father.
"Being a best-selling author is a different thing than being a professor," he said. "It seems my social status has climbed. Neighbors ask me to sign copies of the book, and students come by my office, wanting to give signed books to their fathers. My college roommate, whom I have not seen in 20 years, called me. And my wife is saying that it will all go to my head."
On sabbatical this semester (though he still tends to his graduate students), he is away so much that his wife Virginia, a psychologist herself, says that when she and their two teenage sons want to see him, they turn on the television.
At a book signing at a New Haven bookstore, Dr. Shiller recounted, the audience was invited to talk to her husband. "My son said, 'Wow' and rushed up," she said. "Maybe it was a joke, but it was not funny."
Over the last week, Mr. Shiller has appeared on more than a half dozen radio and television programs. Mid-week, he taped an interview for Time magazine with James K. Glassman and Kevin A. Hassett, co-authors of another big seller, "Dow 36,000" (Times Business/Random House); its thesis is that as investors come to understand the true value of stocks, the Dow should more than triple.
"I have debated them before, on television," said Mr. Shiller, who is out of the market himself, without regrets. "They say people have learned that stocks are not risky. I don't think people have learned anything, or will learn anything."
But he is careful in public appearances. He is not comfortable being cast as a Wall Street wise man, a calling that in his view requires constant forecasts of what the market will do in the next few days or weeks. He does not know, he says. An overly upbeat mood can last for months -- or years -- before the exuberance inevitably reverses. So he generalizes.
"If it is an up day in the markets," he said, "I talk about how exuberance forms and why we have it. And if it is a down day, I talk about how markets drop because of negative feedback."
MR. SHILLER stands very nearly alone in his relentless insistence that markets move on feelings and herd behavior, not corporate fundamentals. Many experts agree that stock indexes are now too high. "But if you wait long enough," said Albert Wojnilower, a Wall Street economist, "you will find some conformity between stock prices and true value."
Markets, in sum, do get it right, and the excesses in between are mostly noise; dangerous noise, to be sure, subjecting markets to sudden crashes when investors temporarily panic, but noise nonetheless.
That is a view that Mr. Greenspan seems to hold, too, and he offers the reassurance that the Fed can end a panic and restore confidence through timely cuts in interest rates and plenty of support for the indebted. Rational solutions thus restore rational behavior.
Mr. Shiller describes public moods that are more ingrained, harder to rout, resistant to reason. "I have never been satisfied that markets are rational," he said. "It is not my experience."

HEADLINE: Investing;
In Asia, Picnic Was Over Before It Began

BYLINE: By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI

 BODY:
ASIA'S Internet boom had really only just started when America's dot-com deflation sent the region's technology share prices crashing. But analysts say the shake-up will mean an earlier-than-expected shake-out of the industry and leave investors with healthier companies to choose from later.
"A year ago, nobody in Asia was talking about the Internet, so there hasn't been time for many of these guys to mature and go public," said Jay Cheng, an Internet analyst at CS First Boston in Hong Kong. So the best companies are still waiting in the wings. 
 Many of the companies that have listed shares, he added, are opportunists without a viable business plan or substantial operations. Rather than ride higher and higher on general Internet euphoria, as did stocks in the United States for the last couple of years, these companies are coming under closer scrutiny and paying the price if their businesses are found wanting.
As a result, some once-hot Internet stocks may be headed for oblivion. "The compression of dot-com concept valuations is unlikely to reverse," said Andy Xie, a regional economist for Morgan Stanley in Hong Kong.
Many Asian Internet companies, analysts say, fail to offer any real innovation: they copy Western e-commerce models, put together with off-the-shelf technology instead of the proprietary software at the core of the most promising Internet companies in the United States. Many managed to raise funds during Asia's brief boom, but "when the market turns bad, as it has, they all become questionable," said Dong Tao, senior regional economist at CS First Boston.
The doomed may include many of Asia's portal companies, which operate Web sites that offer a variety of services to consumers. Many of Asia's listed Internet plays are portals, among the easiest e-businesses to assemble though among the most speculative in terms of future profitability. Few are expected to survive, in part because investors have learned that the Internet's low-margin, high-volume world will only support a few companies of any one type.
Already, early portal entrants are turning into money drains: shares of Nasdaq-listed China.com, which operates portals focusing on China, Hong Kong and Taiwan, are trading at half of what they were at the beginning of the year and about one-third of their highest close, on March 3. Competition in the sector is rising, while profits remain a distant dream. And it is easy to argue that there is still plenty of air left in the stock price: at $48.625, it is still nearly quintuple the July 1999 initial offering price.
Sina.com, which also operates portal sites for China, Hong Kong and Taiwan, closed on Friday at $19.625, or $2.625 above its April 13 Nasdaq offering price of $17 a share, but that is little consolation for investors who bought near the peak of its post-offering run-up, when the stock reached $29.125.
That is not to say that Asia's Internet investing opportunities are gone. For one thing, strong companies with capital are well-positioned to pick through the carnage for the industry's best bits. Already, Japan's Internet giant Softbank, which bankrolls dozens of new-economy ventures, has stepped up its aggressive investment program and even plans to acquire one of Japan's nationalized banks. Though the company's shares have plunged from a 52-week high of 60,666.67 yen (about $560) on Feb. 18 to 26,600 yen ($246) on Friday, analysts still like the stock.
Pacific Century Cyberworks of Hong Kong is another company building a critical mass of strategic investments and alliances with blue-chip companies like Intel, which has invested $50 million and is providing technology to help Pacific Century with its plan to build a network of broadband Internet service providers linked by satellite and spanning Asia. If it succeeds in its current bid to buy a stake in Hong Kong Telecom, it will have serious revenue, too. The company also has a venture capital arm that is looking at acquiring other Internet ventures. It closed Friday at $14.50 (Hong Kong), or $1.86 (United States), 45 percent off its peak close on Feb. 15.
In general, companies providing the nuts and bolts of the Internet economy are the surest plays, analysts say. Among them are companies that tie disparate networks together -- so-called systems integrators -- or companies that provide the software and hardware for things like billing systems that will allow the region's e-commerce to work. "Companies providing these services have sounder business models and are likely to report profitability ahead of others in the industry," said Sohaib Umar, an Internet analyst at CLSA in Hong Kong.
One of the most promising is AsiaInfo, a company based in Beijing that is building Internet backbones for Chinese telecommunications companies and providing e-mail software to Internet service providers. While many Chinese Internet companies are little more than experiments in the new economy, much of the country's export machine is scrambling to get online, creating a huge market for AsiaInfo's services.
The company's stock price briefly spiked over $111 after it went public on Nasdaq March 3 at $24 a share. But the shares then went into a free fall, hitting a low of $29.125 earlier this month before rebounding. The stock closed at $43.50 on Friday. Still, AsiaInfo has most of the $138 million it raised in the share offering and, like Softbank and Pacific Century Cyberworks, is on the acquisition trail.
Mr. Xie of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter calls dot-com mania "the briefest financial phenomenon in East Asia's history," but that does not mean the Internet won't continue to transform the region's economies. It does mean that financing for the most speculative of companies probably won't come from the region's stock markets, though. A result may be less of a bubble and more for investors to chew on.

HEADLINE: Investing;
Wireless Choices Rise Over the Static in Europe

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
WHEN Europeans talk technology stocks, they are wont to refer to T.M.T. -- for technology, media and telecommunications. And these days, many are pinning their hopes on the third one -- the titans of telecommunications, particularly the wireless market.
The business of snazzy handsets and mobile phone networks, after all, is an area where Europe has the lead. 
 As fund managers and investors are painfully aware, the broad technology sector that has seen such dazzling growth in both Europe and the United States -- far more than old economy stocks -- is part of a global phenomenon that takes its lead from Wall Street. Since early March, however, that has caused convulsions. From its high on March 6, the Dow Jones Europe Stoxx Technology index fell 25.9 percent to its trough on April 14, and has since risen 20.1 percent from there.
With the Nasdaq's fall, even such monuments to European wireless advances as Vodafone AirTouch took nose dives. Vodafone fell from a high of 399 pence on March 6 to 294.50 on Friday. And highflying Psion, whose stock rose tenfold on hopes of its capturing the market for operating systems in next-generation wireless devices, has fallen from a 52-week high of 72.70 on March 2 to 38.37 on Friday. And that included a bounceback on news that Sony would license its software for new mobile devices.
What is happening, said Anna Mackman, European equity strategist with Credit Suisse First Boston, is that a "a big wall of money" that started flowing into technology sector funds last November has begun to recede.
"The thing that has really been affecting European investors has been the volatility, which has injected a need for caution and realism," she said. "Everybody has been buying these stocks in the expectation of doubling their money. Now we have to get back to a situation where that doesn't happen."
Some fund managers see investors moving funds out of smaller, riskier technology companies and into blue chips like the mobile phone makers Nokia and Ericsson, along with proven network providers like Vodafone. Nokia closed at its high of 63.10 euros on Friday and Ericsson closed at 810 euros, just 12.9 percent below its peak. Increasingly, too, chip-makers like STMicroelectronics, which have largely weathered the collapse, are being seen as good long-term bets.
"If investors are going to keep money in technology then they'll typically put it into a blue chip," said Adrian Brass, a manager with Investec Guinness Flight's Wireless World fund, which has assets of $25 million.
The hardest hit among the European technology stocks, he said, are pure Internet plays. "People have started to ask questions about fundamentally how much money they can generate," he said.
The sell-off also spread to companies like Baltimore Technologies of Britain, which provides Internet enabling technology. It closed at 64.63 on Friday, versus a 52-week high of 137.50.
But the rapid decline also provided some opportunities among quality companies with superior technologies. Sonera of Finland, a leading wireless company that fell from a 52-week high of 95.49 euros in March to 60.50 euros on Friday, "was sold off to such an extent that it did not look overpriced," Mr. Brass said.
Just last week, the market seesaw seemed to bear out the idea that a flight to quality was under way. Nokia, which earns 80 percent of its revenue from the mobile handsets that are continuing to boom with Europe's much-vaunted wireless revolution, produced soaring growth figures last week that bolstered its stock price.
The macroeconomic view may be the most bearish. Trevor Greetham, a global strategist at Merrill Lynch, said recent history has shown that riskier stocks take off when central banks free up liquidity, as occurred just after the 1998 Russian meltdown and during the run-up to Year 2000. But with higher interest rates likely, he said liquidity is "being driven out of the system." And, Mr. Greetham added, defensive stocks begin to look better when economic growth looks as if it's peaking. "What I'm saying is: diversify away from technology-media-telecommunications towards value and defensive stocks," he said.
But others see more transitory factors at work. William Lovering, a manager of the $150 million Legg Mason Europe fund, reckons that some of Vodafone's recent retreat could be attributed to investors' selling it to buy into the initial offering of AT&T Wireless, but he said that by the end of the year, the stock would be back near its previous high of 399 pence, on March 6.
He also figures that STM could hit 250 euros by the end of the year, up from 209.9 euros on Friday. Other chip makers like Infineon could also perform well, because semiconductor demand now looks less cyclical and more like a fact of life in the wireless era.
Unlike some American investors, whose European gains were wiped out by the recent fall of the euro, Mr. Lovering is not too worried about the currency. "It's hard to see the euro falling as much again as it has fallen," he said. "And a low currency makes for competitiveness" among European exporters.

LENGTH: 1409 words

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS: Going Places;
Defining the Target in the Battle for Votes

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

 BODY:
LOOK closely at a few typical events on the campaign trail these days and the true targets of this presidential election quickly emerge.
For example, Al Gore recently talked about education (a major concern to suburban mothers) in Columbus, Ohio (the swing city in a swing state). George W. Bush unveiled his new "compassionate conservative" agenda on health care, home ownership and tax cuts (another bid for the center, especially women, who rank health care high) in Cleveland and St. Louis (both in traditionally swing states with a combined total of 32 electoral votes). Mr. Gore went to the drug store with an older woman who lacks prescription drug coverage (big, big issue with the elderly). 
 Every presidential candidate at this stage of the game swears he would fight for every state and every vote in this richly diverse country. But the ugly little truth is that some states are more important than others, not just because they are big (with a lot of electoral votes) but because they are up for grabs.
As the primary season was dominated by New Hampshire, the general election campaign will most likely be ruled by an arc of big industrial states, including Pennsylvania, Ohio, Michigan, Illinois and Missouri. Or, as a gleeful David J. Leland, chairman of the Ohio Democratic Party, puts it: "Bush was here yesterday and Gore was here last week. I suspect we'll see a lot of both."
There is a demographic corollary: Some groups of voters will get more attention than others -- like elderly voters, the legendary 800-pound gorillas of politics, who used to be reliably Democratic but in recent elections have swung toward the Republicans; married suburban mothers, an important part of the Clinton vote but now a battleground between Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore; and Catholics, once the quintessential Reagan Democrats, pulled one way by their cultural conservatism and another by their instincts on domestic policy.
Much of the strategic thinking in the parties these days revolves around these groups and these states. For example, Celinda Lake, a Democratic pollster, talks about "the Reagan seniors, aged 60 to 70," who tend to be more affluent than older retirees but also very responsive to the idea of expanding Medicare to cover prescription drugs -- which many of them suddenly need.
Put the geography and the demographics together, and a 65-year-old woman (a high likelihood of voting) in a Macomb County, Mich., suburb, with an affection for the Bush family (a Republican advantage), a concern for the country's values (ditto) and mounting medication bills (a Democratic advantage) can look like ground zero in the 2000 campaign.
This targeting also explains why some candidates for the vice presidential nomination become so compelling -- like Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania, the popular Catholic governor of a battleground state, who suddenly appeals to so many Republicans. Some Democrats say Mr. Bush has a problem with white Catholics, not just because of the criticism over his visit to Bob Jones University in the primary season, but also because of the Southern conservative dominance of the party's leadership.
Mr. Ridge would neatly provide geographic and cultural balance, although his support for abortion rights carries risk for Mr. Bush.
Not all the effort will be confined to those states in the middle, of course. For some time to come, each candidate will be probing for weaknesses and targets of opportunity in the other's base. Most notably, Mr. Bush is making forays into California, which the Democrats carried by wide margins in the last two elections; the Republicans are running advertising aimed at Hispanics, hoping that Mr. Bush's appeal to that voting bloc in Texas is transferable. And Mr. Gore is paying attention to Florida, a Republican-leaning state whose governor, Jeb Bush, has a personal stake in the election.
But most experts see the electoral map as pro-Republican in the South and Mountain West, pro-Democratic on the West Coast and Northeast, and up for grabs in much of the industrial heartland. Charles Cook, who publishes a nonpartisan political newsletter, said, "They don't have strong liberal tendencies like the Northeast or the West Coast and they don't have strong conservative tendencies like the Southern and Rocky Mountain states."
Bob Teeter, a pollster long active in Republican politics, said of that arc of battleground states: "Because they're big, they have all the elements in them that the country has -- they have rural areas that are Republican, small towns that are Republican, suburbs with a lot of swing votes, big cities with union members and blacks that are Democratic." This long-running role in presidential politics, he added, has given rise to the axiom that no Republican has ever been elected president who didn't win Ohio.
This political map can change, and has. Most notably, the once solidly Democratic South realigned to the Republicans in presidential voting in the late 1960's. For much of the 1980's, the Republicans were considered to have an "electoral lock" on the presidency because of their strength in the South and California. But California, which has 54 electoral votes, began turning to the Democrats in 1988, when Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic nominee, lost it narrowly in what was nationally a sweeping defeat for the Democrats. In the last two elections, Democrats have anchored their victories on the coasts.
The important demographics can also shift. The over-60 vote went to the Republicans by a surprising margin of 10 percentage points in the 1998 midterm elections, according to the exit polls. "Senior women are anywhere from 12 to 15 percent of the electorate," said Linda DiVall, a Republican pollster. "They will vote at an 80 to 85 percent clip."
MANY pollsters say the tug of war for older voters will be between their attraction for Republican leadership on values -- including Mr. Bush's promise to "uphold the honor and dignity of the office" and a general concern over the country's moral direction -- and Democratic promises to protect Medicare and Social Security. "Once very specific Medicare and Social Security issues go off the table, values concerns come back," said Stan Greenberg, a Democratic pollster.
Glenn Bolger, a Republican pollster, grumbled that at the height of the campaign, "Democrats wake up every day saying, 'What is it we gotta do today? Oh, yeah, scare seniors and make sure the black vote gets out.' "
"Soccer moms" have become almost a cliche in presidential politics, but married mothers are, if anything, likely to be more important in this election than in years past. In large part, this reflects Mr. Bush's greater personal appeal to this group and his careful courtship on issues and style; from the start, his promise of compassionate conservatism and emphasis on issues like education showed his determination to close the gender gap.
A poll by the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press showed how much better Mr. Bush was doing among mothers than the last Republican nominee. In April 1996, 60 percent of mothers said they were backing Mr. Clinton, while 37 percent said they were backing Mr. Dole. Last month, 41 percent of mothers said they were backing Mr. Gore, while 52 percent were backing Mr. Bush.
"I hate the soccer mom cliche," Mr. Cook said, "but I have to tell you that middle- and upper-middle-income white women who economically ought to be Republicans but on social and cultural issues -- abortion, guns, education and health care -- gravitate to the Democrats, will be important."
For all the demographic trends that cut across state lines, states also have their idiosyncracies. The auto industry's dominance in Michigan, for example, makes it almost inevitable that the Bush campaign will try to paint Mr. Gore there as an environmental extremist.
AND for all the focus on swing voters, the cardinal rule of politics is to cultivate your base. Still, as this unusually long post-primary, pre-convention political season drags on, the battlegrounds are clear. And assuming the election stays competitive, it will only get worse. "If you want to know what hell is like for a voter, it's a swing presidential state with a key Senate race and an open Congressional race," Mr. Bolger said. "They're going to see so many political messages that there won't be any actual news -- just 30 minutes of 30-second spots."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 19; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 1121 words

HEADLINE: The Bad Guys Are Always With Us

BYLINE: By Ronald Steel; Ronald Steel teaches international relations at the University of Southern California and is the author, most recently, of "In Love with Night: The American Romance with Robert Kennedy."

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
They may hate each other, but Lazaro Gonzalez and Fidel Castro have one trait in common. They both drive Washington crazy.
And American officials, for all their huffing and puffing, don't really know what to do about either. First they issue ultimatums to the Miami family and no one pays any attention. They send in a commando team to seize a 6-year-old boy, and outraged congressional Republicans schedule hearings. And Fidel Castro orchestrates another rally in Havana to celebrate his victory. 
 To make matters worse, the Cubans -- in Miami or Havana -- aren't the only ones thumbing their noses at the single superpower. Saddam Hussein is still in power nine years after we sent an army of half a million men against him; he blithely brushes off, like pesky flies, the wannabes we hope will replace him in his palaces. There is the nasty Slobodan Milosevic, whom we bombed into withdrawing from the rebellious province of Kosovo, but whose hold on power in Serbia is stronger than ever. And North Korea is another place we seem to be able to neither buy off nor intimidate.
We call them "rogue states" because they are bad places, but also because they won't play by our rules. We are even debating whether to spend some $60 billion to build a leaky Star Wars umbrella in case one of them is tempted to lob a missile against us. It would probably be cheaper, and safer, to buy off rogue dictators at, say, $1 billion each (and maybe a house in Malibu).
Is this any way to treat a global hegemon that can blow any country off the map, send bombers halfway across the world to take out a bridge, and devastate a country's economy just by blocking a loan?
Well, what we're learning about the new blueprint for global peace and prosperity under America's helpful guidance is that the rules of proper behavior apply only to those willing to observe them. In the cold war, countries played the Great Power game -- they built big armies and fancy weapons, bought allies and worried about making a good impression on hard-to-get bystanders. In the world of triumphant global capitalism, the small countries line up for handouts at the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, then meekly follow orders. They, too, want to make a good impression by showing that they know the rules.
But there are always a few outsiders who play a different game. Bosses like Fidel Castro don't care about impressing their well-behaved neighbors or maintaining a good credit rating. They store wrecked cars in their front yards and refuse to clean up their trash. They make noise all night long, and their kids steal your kid's bicycle. And if you try to do anything about it, they'll slash your car tires and then sue you for harassment. And there is not much you can do about it -- unless complaining to other law-abiding people makes you feel better.
That is why -- after more than 40 years and nine presidents who have tried to get rid of him by fair means or foul -- we are still driven nuts by Fidel Castro. The recent melodrama in Miami is not, as so many have said, just a cold war hangover -- a kind of geocultural lag. Rather, it is a distressing reality of today's world.
For those who care more about wielding power than being loved, more about their own ambition than their countries' welfare, America's rules are merely an inconvenience to be circumvented or ignored. Like Slobodan Milosevic and Saddam Hussein and even Osama bin Laden, Mr. Castro perplexes us because he manages to survive everything we throw at him. We've tried assassination teams, proxy invasions, sabotage, financial strangulation and economic boycotts. Nothing has worked.
Such men survive because they are willing to pay a higher price to stay in power than we are to get rid of them. We try dirty tricks and are so embarrassed when caught that we apologize and promise to lay off. Since for them power is an end in itself, they see no reason not to lie and cheat, and they honor only those agreements that suit their purposes. When we try to hold them to our rules, they rev up their populations against us with patriotic rallies, strengthening their grip on power. Instead of bending to our will, and to our lectures on morality, they jeer us.
What makes them so infuriating is that we cannot respond in kind. We held back our military forces at the Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961 for fear that Latin American governments friendly to us would be toppled by their own people, cheering for the underdog. Though we destroyed Saddam Hussein's army in 1991, we did not invade Baghdad to get rid of him from concern that without him Iraq might fall apart. In the war over Kosovo we didn't demand that Mr. Milosevic resign before we stopped bombing Serbia because we knew he wouldn't.
Likewise, when somebody (maybe a member of Mr. bin Laden's team of zealous volunteers) blew up two United States embassies in East Africa, we were so eager to find someone to punish (and to avoid looking like a "pitiful, helpless giant," in Richard Nixon's memorable phrase) that we bombed a chemical plant in Sudan and some mountain caves in Afghanistan. The backlash against us by our client states in the Arab world was so strong that it might have been better to have done nothing at all.
This is hard to take. We've spent the Soviet Union into oblivion, turned China into a capitalist bazaar, made American English the world's lingua franca, turned the dollar into the universal currency and discouraged any other state from even trying to challenge us for the title of king of the mountain. But we reign supreme only among those who play the same game that we do. The others, like Mr. Castro, laugh as we squirm. Unforgivably, they have taken all the fun out of running the world. Instead of being the revered monarch collecting tribute from distant tribes, we are tormented by a plague of fleas and grasshoppers.
So what can we do about it? Nothing in our arsenal works against the resentful weak. Eventually they pass of their own accord -- only, of course, to be replaced by other rogues.
Some problems, like dandruff, acne and arthritis, have a way of defying all solutions. People learn to live with them, just as they do with unpleasant neighbors. Maybe we should try a different strategy with the rogues -- slapping them down, of course, when they get too far out of line, as Saddam Hussein did in invading Kuwait, but giving up on trying to get rid of them. Getting hysterical does not make them go away -- it only makes them seem like victims.
Being rich and strong does not mean you always get your own way. And when you fall on your face, nobody feels sorry for you. The sad fact is, hegemony just isn't what it's cracked up to be.
