HEADLINE: All the World's a Mall

BYLINE: By David E. Sanger; David E. Sanger is a White House correspondent for The Times.

 BODY:

The Challenge
 of Global Capitalism
 The World Economy
 in the 21st Century.
 By Robert Gilpin
 with the assistance
 of Jean Millis Gilpin.
 Illustrated. 373 pp. Princeton, N.J.:
 Princeton University Press. $29.95. 
 Late in the afternoon in early December, on the first day of the antiglobalization demonstrations in Seattle, I scrambled through the tear-gas-filled streets, and marveled that a deadly dull meeting of the World Trade Organization had suddenly turned into a riot of strange bedfellows. Here were environmentalists dressed in sea-turtle costumes marching arm in arm with Teamsters, who until now have not been known for their concern about the fate of tortoises. A few blocks away, self-described anarchists ran circles around a befuddled police force, kicking out windows in a protest against -- well, they weren't quite sure just what. (At a coffee bar near the chaos -- this was Seattle after all -- one of the more aggressive protesters acknowledged to me that he was not quite sure what the World Trade Organization did, but he was angry about "the way rich people run the world.")
Just as I was taking all this in, my cell phone rang. It was one of this country's top trade negotiators, locked in a hotel room high above the melee and barred by the Secret Service from venturing out. "What's happening down there?" he inquired. I filled in the details. "You think that's chaos?" he said. "The Pakistanis just told us, 'We will blow up the negotiations,' and the Indians, who are usually talking about blowing up the Pakistanis, say they are going to help." Indeed, to many in the developing world, the whole effort to start a new round of global trade talks was part of a plot by the United States to set rules that would make the developing world's economy more expensive -- under the guise of preventing child labor or stopping pollution. Or, as Youssef Boutros-Ghali, the savvy Egyptian trade minister, asked at the end of the Seattle debacle, "Why, all of a sudden, when third world labor has proved to be competitive, do industrial countries start feeling concerned about our workers?"
All this calls out for explanation. Robert Gilpin, an emeritus professor of public and international affairs at Princeton and a man who has written often about markets and economic institutions, offers a comprehensive take on this new world of economic conflict. Unfortunately, he finished "The Challenge of Global Capitalism" before all those emotions erupted in Seattle. But he understands, at least intuitively, that the wheels may be coming off the post-cold-war roller coaster that the United States rode to great heights in the 1990's.
Like many economists, though, Gilpin appears a bit perplexed about how to handle the politics of it all both at home and abroad. And the battle over who gets gored by the consequences of economic globalization is, after all, entirely about politics. It is about whether the rules of free trade should protect tortoises and set minimum wages, even if that means that the World Trade Organization overrules the governments of India or Egypt or even the United States. It is about who sets those rules and about brewing resentments among winners and losers. Wander anywhere abroad, from Malaysia to Japan to France, and it does not take long to find raw resentment that the world economy is now run by "international standards" that look and feel suspiciously American. After all, isn't it Washington that pulls the strings of the International Monetary Fund? Isn't it the United States that is using the Internet to spread American-style capitalism? And aren't global trade talks an effort to rig the rules to benefit the most technologically advanced and the most competitive?
Early in his book Gilpin notes that "rejoicing in their own good fortune, Americans failed to appreciate that the country's prosperity was highly dependent on the global economy and that, in international economic affairs as in other aspects of life, no person or country is an island." And throughout the 1990's, he adds, few noticed that "although global capitalism has indeed triumphed, the larger global economy was in serious trouble." Stranger yet, even citizens of the countries that have been the biggest winners of economic globalization are complaining. After all, virtually all of those protesters in Seattle were Americans, many of them taking time off from jammed docks and overworked factories. Prosperous times have treated them well but have not alleviated their sense that the global economy can, in the click of a keyboard, move a good job in Seattle to Bangalore. The result is more suspicion than ever about the wisdom of open markets. In fact, it is questionable whether the North American Free Trade Agreement would pass in Congress today, even though economic conditions now are far stronger than they were in 1994. And there is doubt that Congress will agree to normal trade status for China this year, even though the accord that ushers China into the World Trade Organization requires China to open its markets, but essentially contains no concessions on the part of the United States.
"All the political elements that have supported an open global economy have considerably weakened," Gilpin concludes. "Despite the huge benefits" of the system, he argues, "an open and integrated global economy is neither as extensive and inexorable nor as irreversible as many assume." In other words, even as nations around the world race to embrace free-market capitalism -- or at least talk a good game -- their political systems convulse at its ramifications. The result is a search for a new protectionism. Europe uses dubious science to keep genetically modified farm products, chiefly from the United States, off its shelves. China woos investors but at the same time is desperately attempting to regulate access to the Internet, for fear that the Communist Party will lose even more control over the country. Japan discovers, to its horror, that years of sharply limiting foreign investment and immigration to retain control over its economy have deprived it of both foreign innovation and foreign innovators; after a lost decade, it cannot bring itself to break old habits. All this has turned American foreign policy on its head. Negotiating the number of warheads that the former Soviet Union could keep on top of a missile was a breeze compared with trying to negotiate an accord among 160 nations about a set of minimum rights for workers that makes sense in both Brussels and Shanghai. Gilpin, alas, does relatively little to parse the political complexity. "Most Western economists are very dubious about making workers' rights a part of the trade regime, as this would unduly complicate trade negotiations," he writes. It is in this territory where the interests of individual nations come into direct conflict with America's sense of how the post-cold-war world should be molded that a whole new world of foreign policy is being created.
Atop that is added another layer of complexity: at what point does the rest of the world have to step in to save a country from its own failed economic policies before the infection spreads? This was the question raised by the Mexican peso crisis and then, in much more urgent terms, by the Asian financial crisis. Here Gilpin has some stronger insights. He quotes Walter Wriston, the former Citibank president, who once famously declared that nations "don't go bankrupt." "Unfortunately, Wriston was wrong," Gilpin writes. The Asian crisis proved the case. He describes how a series of bad decisions in Thailand and Indonesia -- from linking their currencies to the dollar, then failing to supervise their banks, then letting political cronies rule some of the world's most promising economies -- led to disaster. In came the International Monetary Fund, followed by the United States Treasury. There was talk of the need to stop "systemic risk" -- banker talk for a problem that leaps, like a wildfire, from one nation to another. On the other hand, Gilpin notes, "the Clinton administration did not want to be viewed as rescuing foreign bankers from the consequences of their own greed and foolishness."
In the end, Gilpin appears to side with those who believe there was some American greed and foolishness at play as well. The Treasury, influenced by American financial interests, used its clout over the years to force open economies around the world, so that American banks and companies could spread their wings around the world. "Unfortunately, the international community, which had pushed for openness, failed to push for regulation of the financial sector, and the governments were too inexperienced to appreciate the dangers of an unregulated financial market," Gilpin concludes. The Asia crisis touched off a debate over whether institutions like the International Monetary Fund and its biggest shareholder, the United States, should get more deeply involved in the way countries run their economies or stand back and let the market apply its own disciplines. No one won that battle -- it was called off as Asia recovered. Even while the street protests continue, like those in Washington in mid-April, the whole debate over creating what President Clinton called a "new international financial architecture" has faded. Politicians cannot apparently sustain interest in the question in the absence of a raging crisis. But financial crises, like volcanoes, do not stay dormant forever. The problem will be back -- along with the guys in the tortoise suits.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Volunteering On Vacation

BYLINE: By MARTHA STEVENSON OLSON; MARTHA STEVENSON OLSON is a freelance writer living in San Diego.

 BODY:
AH, vacation. If lounging next to azure water -- breeze in the coconut palms, cool drink in hand -- sounds boring, maybe it's time for something completely different. That's the opinion of an increasing number of altruists who are spending weeks on volunteer or service vacations, performing tasks from clearing waste ditches in Mexico to reintroducing Przewalski horses in Mongolia. Among them are college students seeking an inexpensive, meaningful summer abroad, professionals on sabbatical and retirees and others who want a grass-roots sense of the cultures they visit and an engagement that can't be had from a cruise ship or tour bus.
As these "vacations" become more popular -- Habitat for Humanity fielded 700 volunteers in 1994 and expects 3,000 this year -- more options become available and the possibilities can be bewildering. 
 Service can be a weekend or two years; lodging can be in tents or in a villa; volunteers may get a small living expense, along with free room and board, or they might pay a fee (possibly tax-deductible) that approaches the cost of a regular tour.
A good primer is "Volunteer Vacations," a guide by Bill McMillon (1999), published by the Chicago Review Press, that lists organizations and agencies, cross-referenced by expense, region and type of project. Most riveting are returned volunteers' articles, ranging from a witty account of helping to restore Stowe Landscape Gardens in Britain to wrenching memories of the Home for the Dying and Destitute in Calcutta. Many found their service rewarding. "I received much more than I gave," was the echoing summary.
The Coordinating Committee for International Voluntary Service, created in 1948 under the aegis of Unesco, helps coordinate voluntary service, especially the work camps, worldwide. It publishes a guidebook, "How to Be a Volunteer in Europe, Africa, Asia and America," and recently opened an information center at the Unesco offices in Paris.
The Internet has several useful sites. One of the best is idealist.org, with links to many United States and global agencies; it freely accepts listings; another is www.avso.org, which has a youth orientation.
Many organizations' Web sites offer links to accounts of returned volunteers, or to the volunteers themselves, so it's worth checking and researching as much as possible in advance. And, although here as elsewhere the level of comfort and security most often rises with the amount of money expended, the mantra of this kind of experience is: "Keep your sense of humor, learn to operate as a group, and don't expect everything to go exactly as planned."
 
Building Projects
Since 1976, with former President Jimmy Carter and his wife, Rosalynn, as high-profile participants, Habitat for Humanity, an ecumenical Christian organization, has built more than 85,000 houses, with "sweat equity" from the prospective residents, in more than 2,000 communities around the world. Some projects operate in partnership with Elderhostel, the educational agency for those 55 or older that includes service options in its own programs.
Habitat's Global Village program now mixes tourism with its missions: For example, a 19-day Botswana trip includes side trips to Victoria Falls, white-water rafting, a game drive and cultural exchanges, along with the building activities, for about $4,000. This covers a donation to the building fund in Kasane, medical insurance, housing, ground transportation, meals, administration fees and round-trip air fare to Africa.
The American Friends Service Committee has projects around the United States. It also provides links to service organizations with long- and short-term volunteer opportunities. Quaker Workcamps International specializes in rebuilding burned churches in the United States. This summer the group will continue work on the Community Baptist Church in Cedar Heights, Md., which was destroyed by fire just before Christmas 1997, with weeklong work camps.
 
Culture and Conservation
Other programs focus more on cultural exchange and economic self-sufficiency; participants might help teach English, refurbish school rooms, assist in vocational programs or engage in agricultural or community development or environmental awareness. During a stay of several weeks, participants are immersed in the local culture, with weekends and time at either end of the trip spent sightseeing. Costs, about $500 to $1,000 depending on whether the destination is domestic or international, include most expenses but not air fare.
Two of these organizations, the Global Citizens Network and Global Volunteers, are headquartered in St. Paul, Minn.; each sends small teams of volunteers to help communities on projects they initiate. These might include helping Tibetan refugees in camps in Nepal, refurbishing a preschool in Guatemala's highlands, or teaching English and helping build a school in Ecuador.
Similarly, the Global Service Corps, an adjunct of the San Francisco-based Earth Island Institute, helps local agencies in Costa Rica, Kenya and Thailand with sustainable development projects. A new Global Service Corps project, Global CPR, developed by the conservationist David Brower, will field volunteers for a year's service in Kenya, Costa Rica or Thailand.
Amizade began with an orthopedic shoe workshop in Santarem, Brazil, in 1995; its programs have grown to include building a vocational school for Santarem street children, as well as projects in the Korrawinga aboriginal community of Queensland, Australia.
Another group of agencies serve as clearinghouses for voluntary service worldwide, often for college students or youths who are willing to rough it in exchange for a meaningful experience abroad in relatively secure conditions. These generally charge an administrative fee of $500 or less, and require participants to pay their way to and from the work site and serve two to three weeks, mostly during the summer months, with basic room and board often provided free or at less than $10 a day. Most camps are limited to those over 18 years old, although some projects accept those as young as 15, and older volunteers are welcome.
One of the largest, oldest and best known of these is the Council for International Educational Exchange, which claims an international staff of nearly 800 in more than 30 countries. One returned volunteer, Vicky Huey, said of her 1998 experience at an environmental work camp in a Japanese forest: "I honestly cannot think of any negatives. The greatest thing was meeting so many people from around the world." In her group of about 25, half were from Japan and the rest from the United States, Germany, Korea, France and the Czech Republic. "To this day I keep in touch with people from the trip."
Volunteers for Peace, founded in 1982, originally focused on exchanges across the Iron Curtain. It now has more than 1,800 programs in over 70 countries; in 1999 it placed more than 1,300 volunteers in its various work camps. Listings range from looking after children orphaned by AIDS in Thailand to helping stage a music festival in Denmark.
"Peace through deeds, not words" has been the mission of Service Civil International since 1920, when its founding members in Europe conceived the idea of a work camp to help reconstruct villages damaged in the First World War. Its work camps, developed in conjunction with local grass-roots organizations, include the Balkan Sunflowers project of volunteers in Kosovo, Albania and Macedonia, and an interesting range of projects in Germany, including maintenance of the Buchenwald concentration camp.
 
Whales and Snow Leopards
Other organizations combine volunteerism with eco-tourism. Earthwatch is probably the best known, with expedition teams of scientists, educators and the public. Offerings can range from a Discovery Weekend cataloging plant specimens at Kew Gardens in London ($150) to a two-week expedition to Ladakh, in India, tracking snow leopards ($2,495); neither price includes air fare. The organization estimates that more than 4,000 Earthwatch volunteers will join 720 research teams in the year 2000, about one-third of them returning volunteers.
UREP, the University of California Research Expeditions Program, partners university scientists with interested members of the public on research expeditions, which are tax-deductible and can also provide scholastic credit. As an example, a study of the grasshopper population of the African plain of Kenya scheduled for this summer costs $1,575 a person for a two-week land program.
The Oceanic Society offers expeditions to research sea birds and marine mammals including whales, dolphins and sea turtles worldwide, from the Amazon basin to Monterey Bay.
Researching and saving coral reefs is the mission of Cedam, or Conservation, Education, Diving, Awareness and Marine Research, which organizes expeditions to coral cays in the Caribbean and Pacific regions, with volunteer divers (and nondivers, should they wish to sign up) helping researchers document reef life.
The Sierra Club has a large listing of domestic and international trips, including "service trips" often geared to clearing or building trails in the wilderness; some of these are directed at teenage girls and their mothers, or to women or single hikers. Arguably more rugged but much cheaper are the American Hiking Society's volunteer opportunities, also clearing and building trails, in some of the most beautiful natural areas of the country. Most national and state parks welcome volunteers as campground hosts, who help educate and aid the public in exchange for free campsite and hookup.
Interested more in the planet's past than its future? A range of agencies fields archaeology volunteers. Passport in Time, a program of the United States Forest Service, welcomes people who want to help excavate and preserve historic and prehistoric sites on public land. One project is restoration of the OTO Ranch, one of Montana's original dude ranches, now part of the Gallatin National Forest. A biannual newsletter describes the programs.
Historical sites in the Caribbean are the focus of volunteers with Caribbean Volunteer Expeditions, who work with local museums, universities and national parks on the islands; Elderhostel also participates in some of these trips. The British National Trust is known for its whimsical rental properties, historic houses and manors. It also sends teams of volunteers to work on restoration and preservation; they pay a small fee for a week's lodging and food. Other programs can be found through the Archaeological Institute of America, which publishes a yearly bulletin of excavations needing help worldwide.
Mobility International USA aims to assist people with disabilities who want to teach, study, research, work or volunteer overseas. Its affiliate, the National Clearinghouse on Disability and Exchange, can help plan programs to fit a volunteer's interests and resources.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 10; Column 4; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 2475 words

HEADLINE: WEEKEND GETAWAYS;
By Pedal and Paddle In Arkansas

BYLINE: By LUCY FERRISS; LUCY FERRISS, a novelist, teaches English at Hamilton College.

 BODY:
REMEMBER: your wheels will follow your eyes," Steve Shepherd tells me. I'm one of 10 early-morning Fossil Flats bicyclists heading up a 60-degree incline over shale and baseball-size lumps of limestone, and my wheels are following their own minds. They slide into the Arkansas mud, taking me with them. "Right," I say. I execute a downhill mount, train my eyes on the terrain five feet in front of me, and crank into first gear. I am being indulged, I know, but not pampered, and I am determined to make it across the hillside straightaway known as the Bench.
Devil's Den State Park in northwest Arkansas, where I took part in this spring's two-day, 11-ride recreational Mountain Bike Festival, has been an advocate for mountain biking since 1989, when it ran its first combined Festival and Race Weekend. "A study found that biking does no more harm to the environment than hiking, so we allowed it, and then we promoted it," said Tim Scott, assistant superintendent at Devil's Den. The high points of biking are now split into the festival, which draws hundreds of enthusiasts the first weekend in April, and the race, which brings serious competitors from all over the country to this 2,200-acre park in September. With its ready conveniences and miles of roughly cut paths in the rolling, wooded foothills of the Ozark Mountains, the park lends itself to the gadgetry-based wilderness explorations of the amateur bicyclist. 
 Descending the rough path toward a spring stream, I try Steve Shepherd's instructions. He is an expert, after all -- slim and yellow-goggled, a leader in the sport since he brought the first mountain bike to Little Rock more than 30 years ago. Sure enough, I spot a six-inch path between two large rocks followed by a small fallen branch and then a trickle of mud toward the stream. So long as I don't look down, I can pedal and steer my way between obstacles at the same time. My teeth chattering with the descent, I splash into the water, downshift and pedal furiously to make it up the clay embankment, which I almost do.
The trail we are on, Fossil Flats, has just been spruced up and lengthened by expert bikers, one of whom is in our group of 10. Slim, baby-faced and ponytailed, he asks us gently to let him know if there are any patches too difficult for novices. Pedaling across the Bench, overlooking the teal-green Lee Creek far below, I dig into red Arkansas mud and leap over sharp-edged mini-boulders. I slide off my bike only once (at which point my forgiving companions agree it was worth stopping, for the view) and assure the young expert that the stretch is perfect for beginners like me, with nerves of steel.
But the great advantage of mountain biking is that you can get off the bike. No one seems in a hurry; the point of wheeling rather than walking is not the speed but the challenge of navigating and the occasional thrill of a swift descent and a muddy, cool stream crossing.
We rest against hickory trees and regard Lee Creek far below while Steve's daughter Stephanie, a geology student at nearby University of Arkansas at Fayetteville, explains that its iridescent green is caused by free-floating minerals, especially limestone, that are awakened by the spring current and subside in summer. We stop near the end of the trail to watch the more daring of our crew take on the Pipe, a rust-colored bowl that the biker descends at top speed in order to make it up the other side and maybe pop a wheelie at the top. Returning to the campground from which we began, we hoist our space-age bicycles and balance across a rock bridge, and I miraculously do not tumble into the frigid creek.
Devil's Den, miles south of Fayetteville, is largely the product of the Civilian Conservation Corps, a New Deal agency that put unemployed single young men to work developing the nation's natural resources. The C.C.C. blazed many of the trails, built cabins, and even hewed the furniture for the homey restaurant next to Lee Lake. The origin of the park's name is obscure; some attribute it to early Christian suspicion of local Indians, others to illicit goings-on in the cave of the same name, which extends 535 feet into the mountain from a narrow aperture on Devil's Den Trail. Recovered from my bike ride, I thankfully took to my own feet on this path and on the longer Yellow Rock trail, which culminates in a high bluff stained with yellow iron oxide and looking across the valley cut by Lee Creek to the Ozark Plateau.
With fewer fellow trekkers on these foot trails -- and none of them in helmets or Spandex leggings -- I slowed my pace and stretched out on Yellow Rock to watch a dozen circling birds. I first mistook them for eagles but they turned out to be turkey vultures, their red heads tucked and their wings extended with an elegant flip at the end. Catching the warm drafts from the valley, they choreographed an air show, which one ranger told me was just play. "They'll head over to the highway for lunch," he said. "Here, they're just showing off."
Plenty of campsites are available at Devil's Den, both with hookups and primitive, but having arrived from a grueling conference in Kansas City, I elected to stay in one of the private C.C.C.-built cabins, furnished structures with fully equipped kitchens, fireplaces, original webbed-seat chairs, and patios for cookouts. Most of the comments in the cabin's guestbook came from members of church groups who retreat to this den of the devil and remark on the divine presence they find in a pileated woodpecker, a carpet of wildflowers or the myriad streams that lace the park.
To balance the workout of my legs, I took off next day for the Buffalo River to work my arms on a canoe trip. The drive from the university town of Fayetteville, home base for excursions in northwest Arkansas, took just over an hour through misty green hills to Ponca, home of the Buffalo Outdoor Center and its enthusiastic proprietor, Mike Mills.
From a start as Arkansas's director of tourism under Bill Clinton, Mike has taken over as one of the Buffalo National River's dozen or so concessionaires, who rent canoes, cabins, horses, gear and, in Mike's case, the occasional ride in the Miss Arkansas, a hot-air balloon that floats over the Ponca Wilderness Area or wherever else the wind blows it. Designated a national river in 1972, the Buffalo comprises 135 miles of seasonally floatable river and the surrounding protected wilderness. A group I met from Minnesota was taking the week to canoe the whole distance, from Ponca to Buffalo City, but for weekenders there are ample shorter options.
Mike and I put in at Steel Creek on the Upper Buffalo, on a Sunday predicted for rain that turned out balmy and sunny. "People phone me up a week ahead and want to know what the weather'll be," Mike said, "but whatever anyone says, they're bound to be wrong." The best months for floating the shallow Upper Buffalo -- May and June and November and December, when the water flows readily from the surrounding watershed -- are also the least predictable. But I happily stripped off my rain gear as we made it downstream past the towering limestone bluffs that the area is renowned for.
My canoeing skills, like my biking, are those of an able child. I know the draw stroke, the J, the C; I execute a passable rudder; I look for the upside-down V in negotiating a riffle. To my relief, the Buffalo presented a surmountable challenge. Stretches of rocky riffle were nicely spaced by smooth, clear flow with smallmouth bass racing the canoe downstream. Each time we rounded a bend away from a set of 500-foot bluffs on the right, another appeared on the left. Pebbled bars afforded stopping points for views and lunch. About midway to our destination, Kyles Landing, Mike suggested we stretch our legs and make our way inland to one of many hidden waterfalls.
As we pulled the canoe ashore, we heard a shout from the bluff. "Seen a white husky down there?" We hadn't. Elk, yes; turtles, coyote, deer, woodpeckers, but no dog. "Folks think their domestic pets like it out here," Mike said. "They do not. After a day they are frightened and hungry and possibly injured, and it's me who has to fish them out."
Aside from instructions to leash dogs, the Buffalo is relatively unregulated. Camping is first-come at official sites and permissible anywhere a half-mile from developed areas in the park. A hundred miles of hiking and horseback trails crisscross the park and are mostly "left natural and unmarked," according to the visitors' guide. From our canoe, we had a spectacular view of the great bluffs; from the bluffs, hikers had an unrestricted view of the river.
We reached the waterfall in about 20 minutes, passing Dutchman's-breeches, jack-in-the-pulpit, moss and phlox, as well as the elusive morel, a treat for savvy foragers here including armadillos, whose tracks we saw. Our land legs recovered, our spirits refreshed by a light beer, we pushed off again. "Making good time," Mike said, and then gave me my greatest compliment of the weekend: "Of course, you're an above-average paddler."
As at Devil's Den, cabins are available along the Buffalo -- primitive huts from the National Park Service and more elegant accommodations from concessionaires like Buffalo Outdoor Center, which rents, among other offerings, the Presidents' Cabin, a lofty retreat with a Jacuzzi, a stunning view and framed photos of Presidents Johnson, Kennedy and Clinton, not to mention letters from Bill Clinton and clippings from his early run to the governorship.
Now food, as we all know, tastes best in the outdoors. Campers may enjoy fresh bass and griddlecakes; cabin dwellers have charcoal grills as well as kitchens. But for soft city folk like me, the second or third night of the outdoors weekend deserves a shower, a wrinkle-free dress and a glass of cabernet that I don't pour myself. For that restorative, I followed the advice of Ann Osborne and Jerry Edwards, gynecologists from Little Rock who were staying with their family near the river at the Azalea Falls Lodge.
Azalea Falls is the brainchild of Alf Carter, an Ozark guide and rock-climbing instructor, and his wife, Kathy Trimble, who decorated the three-bedroom, three-bath, Frank Lloyd Wright-style getaway with antiques and artwork. I found Jerry on the deck overlooking the "hollow" below the secluded house, tapping out bird calls on his laptop. "And there he comes," said Ann, pointing as we heard an answering call. "Male finch in full plumage." Ann and Jerry were dining in -- Azalea will stock your kitchen prior to arrival -- but recommended Chez Charles in nearby Eureka Springs for my "civilized" evening.
Eureka Springs, according to a West Coast friend who's settled into Fayetteville, is "our Carmel" -- an overpriced, overbusy cluster of Victoriana on Beaver Lake, just north of the Buffalo. But the owner, Charles Clark, serves such fare as escargot in pastry and smoked quail, followed by desserts that win awards as much for their delicate architecture as their sinful taste.
Glutted, then, with the Azalea's art and the river's rapids, with chocolate cream and caves, with the flash of sunlight on water and the splash of mud on bare legs, I made my way into the red Arkansas sunset out on State Highway 62, stopping here and there for views of river gorges and the Ozark Plateau. I let my wheels follow my eyes this time, too, but already I missed the trails and the rocks, the water and bluffs, even the circling vultures.
 
In the den of the devil
 
Getting There
The closest airport is Northwest Arkansas, near Bentonville just north of Fayetteville. There is more frequent service to Little Rock, two and a half hours southeast, and Tulsa, three hours west. From Fayetteville, Devil's Den is 25 miles south and Buffalo River 70 miles east.
 
Where to Stay
Devil's Den has 14 rustic cabins, with one to three bedrooms and prices from $65 to $85 a night (two-night minimum on weekends). The cabins have fully equipped kitchens, air-conditioning and heat; (800) 264-2417 for reservations or send e-mail to devilsden@arkansas.com for information on availability.
Devil's Den also has 97 campsites, many with electric and water hookups, ranging from $8.50 to $15.50 a night. Hike-in campsites are plentiful, and a horse camp near riding trails is available. Rental backpacks are available for those who arrive without equipment. For $21 a day, they include a tent with stakes, rain fly, pad, ground cloth, gas stove, mess kit and sleeping bag.
Buffalo National River has 14 designated campgrounds with varying amenities. Group reservations are accepted; otherwise, it is first-come first-serve. Camping is also allowed in the back country. Rustic cabins are available March 15 to Nov. 30 at Buffalo Point, for $63 a night for a double and $5 for each additional person; (870) 449-6206. Fully equipped cabins are available from the Buffalo Outdoor Center, from $90 to $175 for two people; (800) 221-5514, or visit www.buffaloriver.com.
Azalea Falls Lodge, on 90 acres off Highway 21 between Boxley and Kingston, rents for $160 a night for two plus $20 for each additional lodger; (870) 420-3941 or visit the Web site www.azaleafalls.com.
 
Where to Eat
Devil's Den cafe and store are open seasonally. The cafe serves buffet breakfast and lunch as well as menu items.
Alf Carter and Kathy Trimble will stock groceries for residents of Azalea Falls Lodge as part of certain weekend packages.
Chez Charles, 37 North Main Street, Eureka Springs, serves menu entrees from $19 to $38 plus monumental $10 desserts; after June 1, they will switch to a $55 prix-fixe menu with a vegetarian version available. Reservations required; closed Monday and Tuesday. Phone (888) 253-1003 or visit www.usabest
.com/chezcharles.
 
Activities
Mountain biking, horseback riding and hiking are the main activities at Devil's Den. Bikes and helmets can be rented at Highroller Cyclery, 322 West Spring Street, Fayetteville; (501) 442-9311. Canoe rentals are available in the park. Special events for 2000 include a Birders' Weekend May 6 and 7, Bat-o-Rama June 9 to 11, Mountain Bike Championships Sept. 16 and 17 and the Fall Backpacking Trip Oct. 14 and 15. Contact the park for details.
Canoes, horses and balloon rides on the Miss Arkansas are available from the Buffalo Outdoor Center and other concessionaires; a brochure is available from the Department of the Interior, National Park Service, Buffalo National River, Suite 136, 402 North Walnut Street, Harrison, Ark. 72601; (870) 741-5443. Hiking and climbing tours, including gear, are led by Alf Carter at Ozark Wilderness Works; (870) 420-3941 or e-mail acarter@yournet.com.
The Eureka Springs Chamber of Commerce is at (501) 253-8737 or www.eurekaspringschamber.com.

HEADLINE: A Haider In Their Future

BYLINE: By Roger Cohen; Roger Cohen is the Berlin bureau chief for The New York Times.

 BODY:
The best-known Austrian since Freud and Hitler has an evident interest in gear. His tight cords, polo shirt and jacket come in soigne shades of gray, conveying an image at once businesslike and casual. Jorg Haider is an image merchant; he is also Europe's most successful politician of the past decade. Briskly, he emerges from the lights beamed on him for a television interview, bids farewell to each and every member of the TV crew and takes messages from a bevy of acolytes before bringing the unstinting gleam of his gray-blue eyes to bear on his next visitor: "Yes, Mr. Cohen, please come in, and do forgive this stupid, noisy scene."
Life is hectic, celebrity sometimes burdensome -- or so Haider intimates -- but he remembers names. Politics is also that: getting to know everyone, pushing their buttons. With a sprinkling of revisionist remarks praising the Waffen SS and Nazi labor policy, zealous physical fitness, an American-style political machine, a trash-the-politically-correct style of straight talk and a reworking of Robin Hood in mildly xenophobic guise, Haider has contrived to propel Austria's far-right Freedom Party from political irrelevance to power in less than a generation. Europe, land of ghosts, is aghast. 
 On one level, the Haider story is an Austrian story -- that is to say, a story of the little lies and large frustrations of a small country that was once a big empire. Such a yarn would be titillating, a divertissement light as a Strauss waltz, but a sideshow. Yet on a deeper level, Haider speaks of the European zeitgeist, for it is on this that he has conjured part of his success.
He has emerged in a Europe uncertain what place, if any, nations and national identity should command as the attempt to build a federal United States of Europe is pursued. A continent worried by immigration and the idea that calls to Islamic prayer will drown out church bells. An uneasy polity that is growing increasingly Americanized and has swapped the Communist threat for fears of globalization.
In this context, Haider is more than a provincial curiosity from a country still dyspeptic over its exit from history; he is a possible taste of the future. That future has an easy smile and a tight waist; it is telegenic or it is nothing at all. Haider, 50, knows the glib, politics-as-pop-culture temper of his times. His governor's office in Klagenfurt, the stiflingly picturesque capital of the southern Austrian province of Carinthia, is testament to the 360-degree Haiderian political wink.
It contains some figurative art, some abstract art, a photograph of the American football club he founded called the Carinthian Cowboys and a discreet print of a proud German knight on horseback. Tradition, modernism, Americana, pan-Germanism -- nothing has been forgotten. "Wherever you have a notional concentration of votes, he goes for it," says Friedhelm Frischenschlager, a former Freedom Party member.
And why not? With the reconfigured, Blairian European left straddling the center, the moderate right unsure what terrain to occupy and the angst of losers from Internet-driven modernization seeking scapegoats and political expression, the times are propitious for a politician who mocks and twists the old labels.
"What is a populist?" Haider asks with a bloodless smile that creases skin of a leathery hue, aging his boyish face abruptly. "Everybody who is a good democrat is a populist. If you keep an eye on the people, consider their problems, then I'm a populist. That is my opponents' problem. They don't take care of their voters. People always ask if I am to the left or right of my opponents. I am ahead of them."
Certainly, Austrian voters think so. They have been migrating en masse to the Freedom Party since 1986, when Haider took over a tired movement featuring a motley crew of ex-Nazis and free-market reformists. The party then had 4.98 percent of the vote. It now has 27 percent. Although other rightist parties in Europe have also made substantial headway of late, no other has made such a decisive breakthrough. So decisive that the cordon sanitaire that -- with a brief exception in Italy in the mid-1990's -- has kept far-right parties from European political office since the Second World War broke earlier this year with a loud snap.
The reverberations linger. Consider the scenario. The people of little Austria -- factory workers, secretaries, hoteliers, burghers in their lodens -- vote for Haider in large numbers. His party comes in second and in February joins a coalition government with the conservative People's Party. Democracy at work, bringing change after decades of Social-Democratic-led rule. And what happens? Some bureaucrat in Brussels or Berlin or Paris decides this is not kosher.
Austria is informed that all bilateral contacts between its government and the 14 others in the European Union have been frozen and is warned that there can be "no business as usual" with such a coalition. Yet Austria has broken no law, infringed no treaty, curtailed no liberties. Imagine an American president sanctioning Texas over the results of a state election. And the United States, unlike the European Union, is a federation in fact.
"This cannot be accepted by Austrian democrats," says Haider, who uses the word "democrats" a lot. "We take decisions. We vote as we want. Not the way foreign countries tell us. We do not accept pressure from outside. In Austria, we had socialist-led governments for 30 years, and these socialists have mobilized their friends around the world to attack us because we took their votes. But this is a dangerous course Europe has taken. There is a huge reaction. I get 15,000 e-mails a week of support to my Web site."
Haider, online and off, has clearly become a lightning rod for Europe's disenchanted. He likes to compare himself to a wolf; certainly he inspires fear, some of it irrational. He has a six-letter name beginning with "H" and ending with "er"; he hails, like Hitler, from northern Austria; and his apologies for his past Nazi apologias have seemed more dutiful than heartfelt. Europe has not forgotten that its mid-20th-century descent into ruin gathered pace with its acquiescence to Hitler's absorption of Austria into the Reich in 1938, a nonreaction that gave the Fhrer a green light to pursue more "Lebensraum." So there is no doubt something subliminal, compensatory, in the unusually swift European reaction to Haider, a pursuit of retroactive redemption by getting ahead of the game this time.
Yet there is no solid evidence that Haider is an anti-Semite, and Austrian threats to European peace and stability today do not exist. What does exist is a pivotal battle for Europe's identity -- between federalists and nationalists, between globalist dot-commies and territorialist fly-the-flaggers, between multiculturalists and defenders of what Germans still call the "Volk."
Freedom Party posters in Vienna last year attacking "berfremdung" -- a word dear to Goebbels that roughly means "overforeignization" -- struck enough of a chord to win the party more than one-quarter of the city's votes in the national election in October. The theme was the same as that of an earlier poster proclaiming "Vienna must not become Chicago," a city used here as a preposterous shorthand for a den of mixed-race gangsterism.
The "foreigners" being attacked lie without and within. The fall of the Iron Curtain has opened the gates for more than one million immigrants, many from central and southeastern Europe, to enter the European Union every year. At the same time, the end of the cold war has revived old dreams of a United States of Europe as cohesive as the United States. The question of the long-term survival of the European nation-state has thereby been posed. This is the new landscape of perceived external and internal threats to national identity that has helped breed Haiderism.
"The cold war ended in Germany in 1989, but in Austria it is happening in 2000," says Robert Menasse, an Austrian writer. "We were a predemocracy, a state without opposition, nestled by the Iron Curtain, where only stability counted. And when a system implodes, you can't choose the form the implosion will take. This is a crisis of transformation. Everyone wants a simple picture here. But Austria is not a videoclip. Nor is Europe. They are murky. And Haider learned that with his mother's milk."
Haider's mother, Dorothea, was an enthusiastic Nazi, a member of the League of German Maidens. So, too, was his father, Robert, a shoemaker who joined the Nazi Party years before the Anschluss. In this they were by no means unusual. But postwar politics dictated another version of history.
Austrians, it is said, have convinced themselves that Hitler was a German and Beethoven an Austrian. That is the least of the national delusions. The myth to which the postwar Second Republic hitched itself was initially foisted on the Austrians by the Allies. As early as 1943, in the so-called Moscow Declaration, they described Austria as the "first victim of Nazi aggression" -- a half-truth at best.
The purpose, during and after the war, was to place Austria in the Western camp. But more than one million Austrians -among them Haider's father -- fought for Hitler; enthusiasm for "Dolfi" (an affectionate diminutive for Adolf) was widespread; and Eichmann, another Austrian, spent what he called the happiest year of his life in Vienna taking care of the logistics of expelling, and fleecing, Jews.
In this way, a double life took hold in the land where Freud discovered the secrets of dreams. Many of the "first victims" knew that they were in fact perpetrators. But that truth was a private one, alien to public discourse, where the miraculous myth of Austrian victimhood prevailed.
"We convinced ourselves we'd won freedom by being the first victims," says Oscar Bronner, the publisher of Der Standard, a Vienna daily. "But we loved the German occupation. In fact, the real occupation here is widely seen as having ended in 1955, when the Allies left!"
Many prominent Nazis recycled themselves as prominent postwar Austrian politicians. Among them was Friedrich Peter, a member of the Waffen SS, who went on to lead the Freedom Party. Bruno Kreisky, a Jewish survivor and the longtime Social Democratic chancellor, aware of the silences and evasions on which his support depended, included several former Nazis in his cabinets of the 1970's. As for Kurt Waldheim, the former president and United Nations secretary general, he was the Austrian everyman: a soldier who had labored in Hitler's army only to suffer amnesia about that period of his life. Hence his domestic popularity through thick and thin.
Unlike Germany, driven to confrontation with its past, Austria tended to bury itself in a folkloric provincialism. All the creamy Hapsburg palaces, so out of proportion to the modern state's modest role, abetted the flight from reality. So did a postwar economic boom that suggested all was well in a never-never land of waltzes and Sacher tortes. Meanwhile, the Social Democrats and the People's Party brought political stability in the form of a stranglehold on office, handing out jobs and apartments under a so-called Proporz system that made party membership a key to advancement.
Marcus Marageter, a 30-year-old musician, recalls a teacher telling his class at engineering school that a "little bit of anti-Semitism is de rigueur." Snide references to money-grubbing Jews remained socially acceptable in many circles. The phrase "Wir brauchen einen kleinen Hitler" -- We need a little Hitler"- never went entirely out of fashion in Austria. "Naja" ("No-yes" or "Well-yes"), a frequent verbal reflex, caught all the Austrian psyche's curious ambiguities.
Nobody understood these equivocations, evasions and elisions better than Haider. Born in 1950, reared in the small northern Austrian town of Bad Goisern, not far from Hitler's beloved Linz, he digested all the resentments and secrets of the war generation. After 1945, his father was forced to work as a gravedigger and his mother was banned from teaching because of the couple's former Nazi sympathies. At the same time, more prominent ex-Nazis found ways to thrive.
No wonder, then, that Haider favors the little man and barks at privilege. A gifted debater from an early age, a talented actor at school, handsome, quick, he clearly intuited that his parents' story was common enough to carry important political lessons. "My parents," he says, "are decent persons. After the war, they learned from history and contributed to the re-establishment of Austrian democracy."
The truth is rather more complex. "Haider is from a Nazi family, and he is proud that his parents were Austrian Nazis," says Lothar Hobelt, a historian who knows Haider well and is sympathetic to him. "He accepts that Austria was in it as much as the Germans because, let's face it, we are Germans. But if you follow the guidelines set by the state, if that is the law of the land and you have to obey, can you be said to be evil?"
Certainly Haider has never been ready to regard his parents, now in their 80's, or the myriad Austrians who behaved similarly as evil. As he said in 1996, "I have always fought against dismissing the war generation as a whole as criminals." At the same time, he has, more than once, called the Third Reich the most heinous of criminal regimes.
This back-and-forth evidently creates some psychological strain. If Haider castigates Hitler, he also calls Churchill "one of the greatest criminals" of the 20th century for his decision to firebomb Dresden. For to be absolutely unequivocal in his condemnation of Nazism is to engage in an act of basic filial disloyalty.
Haider's instinct was always to be loyal. By the age of 16, he was active in the youth movement of the Freedom Party, then led by the ex-SS man Peter. After military service and law studies in Vienna, he landed in 1976 as an assistant professor in a Carinthia law school where his mother had some relatives and where, more important, the political climate offered intriguing possibilities.
Lying just to the north of the former Yugoslavia, Carinthia marked the border of the German-speaking and Slavic worlds and was heavily steeped in Germanic national sentiment. It was provincial enough to suit Haider's anti-urban, anti-intellectual message. With its pine-clad slopes, little family-run factories and soaring peaks to lift the soul, it offered picture-postcard images of the good, clean, physically active life.
At the time of Haider's arrival, the Social Democratic governor of Carinthia was Leopold Wagner, a man who liked to boast of his former senior position in the Hitler Youth and inveigh against the Slovene minority in the province. Haider proceeded to outflank him. He satisfied nationalist sentiment in stirring speeches while presenting a new face of youth and economic renewal. By 1989, he was governor.
"Carinthia was a propitious climate for Haider," says Rudolf Vouk, a lawyer and leader of the 15,000-strong Slovene community. "You see, Slovenes have always been seen here as wanting to prize Carinthia from Austria and attach it to Slovenia. To the Nazis, we were ersatz Jews. And after the war, Slovenia was part of Communist Yugoslavia. So ex-Nazis here could see themselves again standing up to Communists."
Haider understood in his bones the political value of a nod in the direction of these old sentiments. His problem was fine-tuning the nod. In June 1991, he went over the top. Always an opponent of what he calls "the collectivist welfare state," he allowed himself to be provoked in the provincial assembly into declaring, "They had a sound employment policy in the Third Reich." A motion of "no confidence" obliged him to quit.
But as with Dr. Strangelove, that arm kept popping up -- whether through emotional instinct, political calculation or, most likely, some combination of the two. Addressing war veterans in 1995, including members of the Waffen SS, Haider said they had "risked" their lives so that "the younger generation should have a future in which order, justice and decency are still principles."
On the same occasion, he called the former soldiers in Hitler's ranks "decent men who have character," and he thundered: "Anyone who today says that the members of the war generation, the Wehrmacht, were all criminals are in the end besmirching their own parents, their own family and their fathers! And a people who does not hold its forefathers in honor is condemned to doom."
In Germany, these words alone would have doomed Haider. But Austria has largely evaded what Germany has confronted, so Haider bounced back. And where does he really stand? The chameleonic charmer of Austria eyes me coolly and says: "I have made clear in statements that I know I was wrong when I said these things and I apologized. We have many young supporters and must establish a strong democratic system that makes impossible a repeat of such a dark period."
But then something stirs in him, the old Austrian "Naja." "Of course the remarks, for instance on Nazi employment policy, were taken out of context," he says. "If you read the whole debate, there is nothing, really nothing, that could be attacked. But my opponents took this one sentence and made a campaign out of it. And this was my mistake. I have to know that this was dangerous."
Evidently, Haider is learning. Whether he is changing is another matter.
Mario Urschitz, 18, sports a Tommy Hilfiger jacket, a fila shirt and low-slung jeans and sneakers. He has recently returned from a year at a high school in Florida, an experience he loved. Like all Klagenfurt kids, he spends a lot of time on his cell phone, talking and sending messages. And like many of them, employing a German assemblage of English words, he calls himself a "Haiderfan." Haiderfans sometimes hang out at Jorg's Treff -Jorg's Meeting Place" -- a Freedom Party joint where they can play video games, surf the Net and have questions answered by party officials.
If Haider understands the "Kriegsgeneration" -- war generation -- he has an even better feel for the young, whose world is not one of ideology but image. "Haider looks so good, he makes you a fan," says Nina Kulterer, 17. "I saw him selling lottery tickets, and he was very friendly. He's always at events for young people, and he remembers you."
The Freedom Party has more support than any other political movement among Austrians under 30, taking more than 35 percent of their votes at the last poll. Haider's designer labels, mountain-climbing, bungee-jumping, chin-jutting, Porsche-driving rock-star air and provincial-Hollywood glitz are all tailor-made for what Anton Pelinka, a political analyst, calls "the sound-bite MTV voter with an attention span of three minutes -- and there are quite a few of them in Europe today."
Haider's sound-bite skills were sharpened during extended sojourns in the United States during the 1990's, in California and later at Harvard, where he took seminars on privatization, tax reform and public budgeting. "A beautiful time, the best time of my life," Haider calls it in his good, American-accented English. "A country where people can use their freedom."
There is no question that the American experience had a profound effect on him, producing some oddball ideas like a flat tax that he continues to push. But also, at a deeper level, it led to the bizarre Euro-American cultural amalgam central to his broad appeal: a sort of rugged Marlboro Country hero, conversant with e-commerce even on his stallion, pushing the creation of a high-tech "Silicon Alps" in Carinthia, yet ready to crack the whip in the good old Teutonic style of his forbears.
It makes little sense, of course, if sense is defined as coherence. But perhaps that is part of the point: it is a world without a dialectic now that capitalism has won. Haider is aware of the unbearable lightness of modern political being. Call him the first post-politician. Post-Nazi. Post-conservative. Post-socialist. Post-xenophobic. Post-just-about-everything.
He is not a Nazi, but he plays on Nazi themes. He is not a conservative, but he wants to deregulate and slash taxes. He is not a socialist, but he wants to hand out fat maternity checks and oblige party members to limit their monthly income to $4,000, giving anything over that, Robin-Hood style, to the less well off. He is not in favor of privilege, but he lives off the income from a vast Carinthian estate called Valley of the Bears, inherited from a great-uncle whose family picked it up for a song from Jews fleeing the Nazis. He is not, he insists, a xenophobe, but is ready to use bigotry to deliver votes.
"On the one hand, I'm a kind of Margaret Thatcher, because I want lean government," Haider says. "But then again, I am a new Social Democrat because I defend programs for young mothers. I'm also for law and order, which is a program of the right. And immigration is a general problem, not right, not left." Blah-blah, blah-blah.
"Haider's is a post-ideology that eliminates rational discussion," says Andre Glucksmann, a French writer and philosopher. "He is this, he is that, and in the end he is nothing, so what is left is the image onto which people project. Haider knows that if he were merely peddling the old ideology of his father, he would be a marginal figure."
Glucksmann sees a sort of Putin-Haider contemporary school of politics. The new Russian president says Russia might join NATO. The next day he says NATO stinks. Haider apologizes for revisionist remarks only to turn around and say he can't abide the German mania for apologizing. He laments the fate of the Jews in the Holocaust, then says the Sudeten Germans driven from Czechoslovakia in 1945 also deserve money. The message: I may not have a program, but see me move; I look good and understand you all.
The technique seems to be winning Haider astonishingly broad support. Mario Urschitz's great-uncle, Julius Urschitz, is 84 and has known Haider for more than 20 years, supporting him because "he goes to the little people and gives to them." Julius, who supplements his pension by working part time doing menial cleaning jobs, is a veteran of the Nazi forces who fought on the Russian front. "Look," he says, "we had no choice. Tall people, like my brother, were drafted into the Waffen SS. Shorter ones, like me, into the Wehrmacht. The alternative was to be shot."
And how was the war? Well, not so bad. "It was only after everything was over that we heard about Auschwitz. I was in Warsaw in 1943. I saw some Jews being taken away, but I had no idea where. Maybe to work camps. You know, the Jews should have waited until the Russians came, but they were shooting at the Germans."
There they stand -- the Florida-loving youth in his gear, the war veteran who knew nothing of the fate awaiting the deported Jews of Warsaw, Haiderfans all. It is quite a coalition of forces that Haider has assembled, one new to postwar Europe. As I rise to leave, Julius Urschitz eyes me up and down. "You would have been in the Waffen SS," he says with a warm smile. "You're tall enough."
European integration was first pursued in the 1950's as a way of forestalling the 20th-century wars that had scarred the continent so badly. Stage 1, the merging of the French and German coal and steel industries in 1951, was designed to ensure that the two countries would never fight again. A united Europe was a political and moral endeavor as well as an economic one. Then there were the details: freeing markets, opening borders, harmonizing legislation, setting wheat prices, creating a customs union, introducing a common currency. At Europe's stop-and-go pace, they took a half-century.
So it was only recently, with "economic Europe" in place, that European leaders began to look in earnest at the other aspects of the project. Hence the sudden push to develop a credible European military force (within NATO), coordinate foreign policy, move toward decision-making by majority vote, balance what the French now call "American hegemony." Hence, too, the addition last year of a clause to the European Treaties saying any member-state found guilty of a "serious and persistent breach" of the principles of liberty, democracy, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms could be punished.
Enter Haider to spoil the party of this new "moral Europe" that had fought a war for human rights in Kosovo. Beaming, provocative, in a curious embrace with Wolfgang Schssel, the bow-tied People's Party leader and now Austrian chancellor. The coalition of their parties was, of course, no "serious and persistent breach" of anything. Haider has never passed from word to deed. But the symbolism could scarcely have been more ill timed for a union bent on expanding to include the ex-Communist states of central Europe, where rightist movements are often virulent.
For bigotry has been an intermittent trademark of Haider's party. In its literature, the party has warned of "black African asylum seekers with designer suits and mobile phones" who "deal in drugs undisturbed." It has also said that "a return to the nation" must be a founding principle of the "Third Republic" (eerily named) that it proposes. "Anti-immigration posters were produced because we are building ghettos that are not accepted here," says Thomas Prinzhorn, a Freedom Party member and close associate of Haider. "So we say stop, or severely limit, immigration until we can integrate the foreigners we have. Let's take a breath. Our phone book in Vienna looks like New York's!"
With 14 percent of Austria's population of eight million now made up of foreigners, many of them recent arrivals from the Balkans, this sort of message has played well. It has provided the third peg of Haider's support, besides the veteran nationalists and the MTV crowd: blue-collar workers afraid their jobs might go to foreigners and those generally seeking a scapegoat for the threats, real or imagined, of globalization. In the last election, 47 percent of young, male, blue-collar workers voted for Haider.
The resentments behind this vote pattern are by no means confined to Austria. Christoph Blocher's Swiss People's Party became the country's largest political force last year, taking 23 percent of the vote with a campaign equating immigration with criminality. In Belgium, a slogan of "Our People First" propelled the Vlaams Blok to 29.6 percent of the vote in the country's second city, Antwerp, last year. In Denmark, the Danish People's Party of Pia Kjaersgaard recently gained new prominence with a welfare-mocking poster saying, "When I become a Muslim, I'll have a home." And in France, Germany and Italy, issues of immigration and national identity have moved to the center of political debate.
"Europe has a past that tells us we have to draw a line," says Michael Steiner, the chief diplomatic adviser to Chancellor Gerhard Schroder and a chief architect of the European sanctions against Austria. "We cannot accept the legitimization of the far right. Haider is not just about Austria." But whatever the justifications offered for Europe's move to punish Austria, the sanctions unquestionably represent a quantum leap in the union's intrusion in the affairs of a member state.
George A. Bermann, a professor of law at Columbia, questions on what basis European states can "collectively punish a sister state, given the language in the E.U. treaty on human rights and the fact that any violations on Austria's part are purely anticipated." Taking the opposing tack, Andrei S. Markovits of the University of Michigan compares the situation to the United States in the early 1960's, when "the federal government took it upon itself to force its morality on racist Southern states. Then Alabama and Mississippi also railed -- like Austria today -- against outsiders' intervention into states' rights. Only under pressure from outside did George Wallace mutate from a rabid racist into an acceptable politician."
Haider as Wallace? A European country comparable to a state in the United States? Such references offend Haider. A disgruntled-little-boy look can cloud the chiseled features of Europe's most talked-about politician, and it hovers there as he insists that his party's immigration policy is "moderate," designed to ensure only that foreigners already in Austria have adequate housing and schooling and to head off a flood. As for European integration, Haider says he is for the Europe proposed by de Gaulle, "a Europe of fatherlands, not a federalistic structure with a huge bureaucracy in Brussels."
Those almost imploring Haider eyes and the level tone of voice combine to bleat, Believe me, I am a reasonable, much maligned man. "He wants to be loved by everyone," says Klaus Lukas, a former Freedom Party member who left when the party's antiforeigner tone became more strident. "It's almost childish. The only person I've seen who always gets her way with him is his wife, Claudia, who runs the business at the estate. Others say, Jorg, this is wrong, and he does not like it. He wants to be the best speaker. The fastest runner."
Haider, who has followers rather than partners or colleagues, makes no secret of where he would like his run to end. "Yes, I would like to be chancellor," he says. For the moment, he has taken a back seat, resigning the leadership of the party, but the ultimate aim remains clear enough.
Of course, now that it is in government, the Freedom Party will no longer be able to grow by railing. It will have to deliver. Businessmen, who constitute the fourth and last bastion of Haiderism, are waiting for the free-market revolution he has promised, even as Austria's powerful unions gird to resist it. "We want to break the rules blocking entrepreneurial spirit," says Karl-Heinz Grasser, the 31-year-old Freedom Party finance minister. "Cut taxes. Privatize. Free people. That is what we are about, not this Hitler talk."
Down the road from the Klagenfurt office of Haider-the-democrat is a small restaurant, owned by Sukhwinder Singh Mehal, an Indian who has lived in Austria for 19 years. The other day he was in a favorite pizzeria with friends when two young men at the bar started shouting: "You pig foreigner, you'll be out of here soon now that Haider's in power. Pig foreigners out."
Mehal ignored the taunts, but as he walked out, one of the men kicked him. A brawl ensued that left Mehal severely bruised. When police came to investigate, they found that the two young men were off-duty policemen. Outraged, Mehal sent a letter of complaint to Haider. The reply from the governor's office was prompt: such behavior was outrageous, would be investigated and could not possibly be the work of anyone identifying with the Freedom Party.
Haider is conscientious. He is concerned. He is a democrat, a freedom lover, a man with the flag of California adorning his Vienna office. He would never hurt anyone; he knows images are merely playful and magnetic things. But, as Mehal's fate shows, sometimes in the real world people have gotten hurt by real racists who somehow got the wrong idea about where the gregarious governor of Carinthia stands.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 46; Column 1; Magazine Desk
