HEADLINE: Q&A/Harry Phillips 3rd;
New Member of Regents Explores Role

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
IF Harry Phillips 3rd of Greenburgh, the newest member of the State Board of Regents, had to take an exam about his new job, he would be leaving a lot of questions blank.
Mr. Phillips says he has much to learn before he is ready to make grand pronouncements about what should be done to improve New York's schools. Generally, he likes the track the Regents are on under Richard Mills, the state commissioner of education, demanding higher standards of all students. But how should the state deal with disruptive students, failing schools, school financing? These are the questions he says he must consider. 
 A graduate of Harvard College, Mr. Phillips was named by the State Legislature in April to a five-year term on the Board of Regents, representing Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Dutchess, Orange and Ulster Counties. Before the appointment, he was chairman of Westchester Community College for five years and a trustee of the college for 11 years. In his professional life, he is managing director of Winged Keel Group, a financial security management company in Manhattan, and president of Phillips Compensation. He and his wife, Marjorie, have three grown children. Here are excerpts from a recent conversation:
Q.: What do you want to accomplish as a Regent?
A.: Because my daughter is a principal of a public school in Brooklyn, we've talked about all the issues confronting the public schools, especially in New York City: the implementation of the Regents' standards, problems with disruptive kids and the fact that we seem to be falling behind in our education compared to the rest of the industrialized world. It kind of requires the system to be shaken up some.
Of course, I should preface all this by saying I am new to this, I have so much to learn, so much to read. The scope of the Regents job is so much bigger than I thought. They have a $16 billion budget, and most people are not aware that in addition to supervising both public and private education from pre-k to graduate school they license and discipline all the professions except lawyers. And they supervise the public radio and TV stations in the state and all the public libraries.
So it's so hard for me as the new kid on the block to tell you what I'm going to do. I'm going to listen a lot. And I have some concerns about charter schools. I am hopeful that the innovations that they present will be helpful to the whole public school and private school system. There are dangers -- they siphon money from the rest of the public school system, and it could siphon role models.
Q.: What about proposals for renewable contracts for teachers instead of tenure?
A.: The point is moot. The Democratic majority in the Assembly is certainly not in favor of changing those rules. I think everybody agrees there has to be streamlined procedures for removing teachers who become incompetent, paranoid or dangerous, but have tenure. I'm told the Legislature did institute such a system four or five years ago, and I will be looking carefully to see if it works.
Q.: In Westchester, there are some schools that make "top" school lists and others that are in trouble. What should be done?
A.: It's a dilemma. You don't want to create a self-fulfilling prophecy by labeling those other schools as failing when they might be improving. So far, test scores have correlated closely with the average income of the district, and someone said maybe the best way to raise the test score is to raise the minimum wage.
Be that as it may, I am very sympathetic to that point of view. More and more, I'm seeing a desire to make people accountable. You can point to a district somewhere in the city where a great administrator has come in and turned a school around. So you can't give up and say low income, low scores.
Q.: Some critics say that the state should take over financing of education from property taxpayers. What is your position?
A.: There is a school on Long Island that is economically not viable, that has a population that has no economic base and the tax rate is the highest in the state and they owe the state money. And you can only ask: Is that fair? How can these kids get a decent education? And some states have chosen to have some form other than local property taxes to support their schools, and there is some of that in New York as well through grants, and so on.
That is in the hands of the Legislature. But clearly you can make the case that poor districts are being shortchanged. Maybe there is something that can be done short of a drastic change.
Q.: What about the quest for high educational standards? Are you pleased with the approach of the commissioner of education?
A.: I am happy there was a shaking up of a complacent system. Should there be some form of alternative assessment? Maybe. But I think there are many more concessions that have been made by the Regents already that the public may not be aware of. Dropping the passing grade to 55 on a Regents exam is a major concession. And there are great concessions for people with learning disabilities.
Q.: Do you think it was wise to lower passing grades on Regents exams to 55?
A.: Again, I do not know how to deal with this yet. I think it's possible the Regents exams have become harder. It's possible dropping the passing grade to 55 really was not the change it looks like. And the 55 is meant to be temporary. The reason is that students taking the exams now have not had the benefit of universal pre-k education, which is going to happen, I hope. They haven't had the advantage of the much stricter fourth- and eighth-grade requirements and tests that will get them in the swing of these new standards.
Q.: New York is in the minority of states that do not mandate gifted education. What is your position on that?
A.: I really don't know. I really need to learn more about that. It sounds like a good idea; on the other hand it has not been proven in the lower grades that homogeneous grouping does a better job than heterogeneous.
Q.: Sports programs in schools have become bigger and take up more time. Does this detract from studying?
A.: I have a granddaughter who was captain of the tennis team and a grandson who was a left-handed pitcher. They were all recruited by every college. It is one of what my son-in-law calls the last bastions of affirmative action. It would be wonderful if the brightest kid in school were given the kind of recognition that the best athlete is given. I think sports are overemphasized, but it's hard to change.
There are priorities, and I'd like the priorities to be education and have athletics be secondary. But I can't change the world. However, I think some progress is being made, especially because there is a drive in black churches to recognize the importance of education.
Q.:You've mentioned concern about disruptive children in the classroom. Describe the problem as you see it.
A.:The disruptive child is a big issue. It is very difficult to know the answer. There are legal ramifications and all kinds of things. I was at Newburgh Free Academy, which is a large public high school, and if I have the numbers right there are about 2,250 students. There is an alternative school for people who are disruptive, and there are only 30 kids there and they have to earn their way back into the main operation.
There needs to be some solution where you don't continually send a kid down to the principal's office every few days and the most the principal can suspend is for five days and the kids are taking up the time of the assistant principals. There has to be a better way to handle the problem. Again, as the new kid on the block, I don't know that way, but I will be looking at it.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Regional Plan Association Assembly;
Economics of New York Area

 BODY:
The steps needed to maintain the New York region's status as a worldwide center for finance, media, marketing and the Internet will be discussed on Wednesday at the Grand Hyatt Hotel, 42nd Street and Lexington Avenue, as part of the Regional Plan Association's 10th annual assembly.
Among the issues to be discussed are the changing nature of urban manufacturing and land use, finding financing to repair the damage done to waterfront docks by marine borers (an estimated $1 billion), and using the EZ-Pass system to improve traffic flow by increasing tolls at the most congested hours. 
 The keynote speaker will be Robert D. Hormats, the vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, who will discuss how the New York region can be more effective as a global economic center. Also speaking will be William J. McDonough, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, who will assess the outlook for the national and regional economies.
The Regional Plan Association is an independent nonprofit organization that has developed policy initiatives and recommended infrastructure investments for the 31-county New York-New Jersey-Connecticut region since 1922.
The Wednesday meeting, from 7:30 a.m. through lunch, will include 10 workshops in two sessions. Admission is $120 for members and $130 for nonmembers.

HEADLINE: Benjamin Zwirn: Once More, for the Greens

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
THERE is a deadlock in the Nassau County Legislature. Party lines are sharply drawn. Nine unyielding Republicans confront nine intransigent Democrats. The county is on fire with trouble and Wall Street is watching, but nobody is budging.
The outcome of a crucial vote -- one, perhaps, that will decide how the county will try to resolve the worst financial crisis in its history -- is in the hands of an independent who is friend to neither side. 
 And, if he is in fact elected in a special vote in the 11th legislative district on Tuesday, the man on center stage in that scenario will be Benjamin L. Zwirn, the original world-shaker of Nassau politics, the enfant terrible from North Hempstead, the abrasive political fighter, and, some say, the very person to force the doing of what must be done to right dangerously listing Nassau.
One who says so is Mr. Zwirn, 48, of Port Washington, the former North Hempstead Town supervisor, who is running on the Green Party line with a reputation more closely associated with fiery red.
"It's the perfect race at the perfect time," Mr. Zwirn said last week. "The Republicans and the Democrats haven't got the guts to cut personnel and reduce the size of county government."
If elected, Mr. Zwirn said, he would either compel legislative action or ask Albany for a state fiscal control board. "If they can't take care of their own mess, then someone is going to have to come in and do it for them," he said.
With strong name recognition and intense door-to-door campaigning, Mr. Zwirn is a longshot whose chances cannot be ruled out. In a political career that began in 1987, when he ran unsuccessfully for supervisor of North Hempstead to oppose the building of a garbage incinerator, he has pulled off a few upsets.
Most notably, in 1993, Mr. Zwirn, then a rising political star but already controversial for his combative manner, defeated Richard M. Kessel in a Democratic primary for county executive.
Mr. Kessel, now chairman of the Long Island Power Authority and then head of the State Consumer Protection Board, was backed by Governor Mario M. Cuomo and the Nassau Democratic Party.
Mr. Zwirn had at first said he would support Mr. Kessel but then called him "a marshmallow" who would be eaten up by Republicans.
The father of two, Mr. Zwirn was born in Bayside in 1951 to a middle-class Jewish family. He attended Earlham College, a Quaker college in Richmond, Ind., where he was an opponent of American involvement in the Vietnam War. He received a law degree from St. John's University, worked briefly for a New York City real estate law firm and was an assistant district attorney in Nassau County for three years.
During the 1980's, Mr. Zwirn, then a Republican, ran the family import and export business, Fiesta Nut in Port Washington. He was known to friends as the Pistachio King for his habit of handing out pistachios. By the mid- 1980's, he was involved in opposing the incinerator, switching his party enrollment to Democrat in anger over Republican refusals to heed opposition to the plant.
Beginning then and in all the years since, Mr. Zwirn, though inactive politically after losing as an independent candidate for North Hempstead supervisor in 1995, has been a constant critic of patronage, which he has described as the root of current financial problems.
With Democrats, in his estimation, now playing the same games he detested Republicans for, he said, "Wouldn't it be the best situation for Nassau County that I would be voting on the side of the taxpayers, and not on the basis of who is going to be the next head of O.T.B.?"
Moderate opinions about Mr. Zwirn are hard to find. Over the years he has been called brilliant, idealistic, dedicated and passionate, but also volatile, self-righteous, ruthless, vicious and dangerous.
A colleague on the Nassau Board of Supervisors, Bruce Nyman, a Democrat, has likened Mr. Zwirn to a "T. rex totally focused on his prey." Another one-time Democratic colleague, the former Oyster Bay supervisor, Lewis J. Yevoli, went further last week at the mention of Mr. Zwirn's name.
"Just look in the dictionary under evil and you'll find it," Mr. Yevoli said. "He is always angry at someone or something. I would not want the misfortune of serving with him again."
The special election -- in the North Shore district that includes Manhasset, Port Washington, Sands Point, the Plandomes, Old Westbury, Roslyn and other solidly affluent areas -- is to fill the legislative seat left vacant by Barbara J. Johnson, a Democrat, who died from breast cancer earlier this year.
A political analyst, Arthur J. Kremer, a lawyer and former state assemblyman, said, "I see Ben as a spoiler but not a victor." He added, "And if he won he would be a thorn in the sides of both parties."
Mr. Zwirn explains some of the enmity by pointing to cost cutting during his time as town supervisor.
"I downsized the government and it ran better than ever," he said. Most who lost their jobs were Republicans.
But his successor, May W. Newburger, a Democrat, said a hidden $3 million deficit she found compelled higher taxes and took years to close. "The deficit was a result of his administration," said Ms. Newburger, now in her fourth term.
Still, even critics credit Mr. Zwirn for forging the way for Democrats in long-Republican Nassau. In 1989, when he was elected as the first Democratic supervisor in the Town of North Hempstead in more than 70 years, it marked the beginning of the end of total Republican domination of the county.
To Republicans, there is a lovely promise in Mr. Zwirn's return. Some believe that, in the race to replace Mrs. Johnson, Mr. Zwirn will hand control to his old foes by spoiling the chances of the Democrats' candidate, Craig Johnson, the late legislator's 29-year-old son.
So Democrats are furious with Mr. Zwirn for running -- and apoplectic at the thought of him winning.
"It would create upheaval, really chaos at a time when the county needs stability and methodical, intelligent thinking," said Judith A. Jacobs of Woodbury, the legislature's presiding Democrat. "It is inexcusable for him to be putting his name in a race that could change the face of Nassau County government for many years to come."
Phoebe Goodman, the executive director of the Nassau Citizens Budget Committee in Manhasset, said she was concerned about a county legislature of "nine and nine and one."
"The one then becomes the ruler, whoever it is," she said.
The Republican candidate, a former North Hempstead town clerk, Linda Green of Port Washington, described Mr. Zwirn as "the last angry man" but said they shared some views. Both have criticized terms of the county's agreement in a Federal lawsuit that will require property reassessments by 2004.
In a manner his Democratic detractors describe as vintage Zwirn, Mr. Zwirn has hammered Mr. Johnson mercilessly over residency, saying the Republican has been a resident of Manhattan rather than Port Washington and is thus ineligible.
"I feel badly that his mother died, she was a friend of mine," he said. "But this is not England and we don't hand the throne down to the next in line. He can't just say 'Vote for me because I had a tragedy in my family,' but that is what he's saying."
Mr. Johnson, on leave from a Manhattan law firm, seems stunned by the vehemence. "Ben Zwirn has been going pretty negative on me and I don't know why," he said.

HEADLINE: An Unpaid Watchdog Looks Back at Tenure

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
AFTER three years as president of the League of Women Voters of Westchester, Jo Brill knows there are times when politicians just don't want to hear from her about all the things she -- and the league -- think they should be doing.
Her term ended on yesterday, and Ms. Brill is both nostalgic about her 50-hour-a-week unpaid job as a government watchdog and excited about things she may do in the future. 
 Of her presidency, Ms. Brill, 41, said: "It took over my life. You're surrounded by wonderful people who you work side by side with, but the work is unbelievable."
Ms. Brill, who lives in Peekskill with her husband, Dr. David L. Jensen, and their three sons, said that she found attending countless government and civic meetings exciting.
"Sometimes I'm amazed at the people you get to talk to just for showing up -- for free," she said. "I feel like I've been welcomed into rooms of so many interesting people."
In Westchester, there are 14 local leagues as well as the county league, which have a total of about 2,300 members. Their mission, she said, is twofold: to promote voter education in a nonpartisan way and to lobby for issues that they, by consensus, feel are important.
During Ms. Brill's tenure, the main issues were campaign finance reform, affordable housing, property revaluation, establishment of the county's Human Rights Commission, redistricting of legislative boundaries and budget reform. Some victories, some defeats, she said.
Born in Troy, N.Y., Ms. Brill grew up in Arkansas and received a master's degree in economics in 1984 from Cornell University in Ithaca. She settled in Peekskill in 1987 and was a stay-at-home mom until the county proposed building a sludge disposal facility in Peekskill. She joined with others to oppose it. (Ultimately, the county decided it did not have to build the plant because of changes in federal law.)
Ms. Brill then became active in causes that promoted health care and housing for the poor. She joined her local league (the Briarcliff-Ossining-Croton-Cortlandt League) in 1990 and became president of the county league in 1997.
"Sometimes I wonder whether pouring all this effort into good government in Westchester County is a good use of my life for three years," she said. "After all, it's not world hunger. But Westchester has a great government, an open government. And it's possible to be heard and to spread the word and make changes -- although it can be slow."
She is not sure what she will do next. She will remain on the board of the Westchester County Health Care Corporation and will probably find that she won't be able to stop showing up for the Monday night meetings of the Board of Legislators. Succeeding her as president of the county league is Roberta Wiernik of Chappaqua. DONNA GREENE
 
A Guide to Officials
 
 The League of Women Voters of Westchester's annual Directory of Officials is now available. The 48-page booklet contains the names, addresses and phone numbers of elected officials who represent Westchester at the federal, state, county and local levels, as well as similar information on many high-level appointed government officials.
To obtain the directory, call the league at 949-0507 or send a check for $3 a copy with a self-addressed, stamped envelope. The postage required for one copy is 55 cents. The league's address is League of Women Voters of Westchester, Rochambeau School, 228 Fisher Avenue, White Plains, N.Y. 10606.

HEADLINE: Special Unit Quells Gangs in Yonkers

BYLINE: By JAMES V. O'CONNOR 

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
LAST summer Officers Ray Montero and Jim Lloyd saw a man being beaten in front of a bodega on New South Main Street. They asked the victim if he wanted to press charges, but Officer Montero knew the answer would be no. He had been patrolling this street for 10 years and understood that the beating was an initiation for a new member of Chicano Nation, a Mexican street gang.
Yonkers is home to 30 street gangs, which were responsible for 368 crimes over the last two years, ranging from harassment to murder, said Jeanine Pirro, the Westchester County district attorney. The growth of such gangs in Westchester, she said, is a spillover from stricter law enforcement in New York City. 
 "Our proximity to New York City makes Westchester prone to gangs looking to increase membership," Ms. Pirro said. "Criminals don't recognize jurisdictional boundaries."
The first line of defense in the Yonkers Police Department is the Gangs, Graffiti and Bias unit, which is made up of four officers trained to recognize gang graffiti, known as tags, and develop intelligence on gang members.
Sgt. Tim Hodges, who was recently assigned to head the unit, is building a database of all gang members, hangouts and graffiti in the city. The unit works closely with the district attorney's office and a gang intelligence unit in the county jail.
Gang graffiti is one of the best indications of gang territory and which gangs are at war with one another. Officer Kenneth Davis is the graffiti expert, and he has formal training in art and has researched more than 5,000 different gang tags and their origins.
"Gang graffiti is bold and simple; it's not stylish or artistic," he said. "They use it to mark their territory, and they want their enemies to know that this is their turf."
The gang unit scours the neighborhoods for new tags, photographs them and reports them to a crew of city workers that tries to remove all graffiti, whether it is gang related or not, within 24 hours.
"These guys put a lot of time and effort putting up their tags," Sergeant Hodges said. "When they see us removing it immediately, it takes some of the wind out of their sails."
The tags reveal gang alliances as well as gang feuds. For example, Officer Davis said, the Unlimited Styles and the Hoover Boys are bitter enemies, and he pointed out tags where the US was crossed out in places and HB replaced it.
In contrast, he said, the Ravine Posse and Body Hurting Walliburton Crew have recently formed an alliance, which is indicated by their tags being placed next to each other.
There has been an explosive growth in Mexican gangs in Yonkers in recent years with the influx of illegal aliens drawn by the strong economy, said Officer Montero.
The largest Mexican gang is Chicano Nation, followed by Aztec Pride, Vatos Locos and 13 Locos.
"We are dealing with more vicious Mexican gang members now who have done jail time in Mexico and are behind a lot of homicides," Officer Montero said.
Some Mexican gangs have formed because members were victims of other established gangs in the area, especially the Bloods. Officer Montero said that the Bloods, an African-American gang, used to wait for Mexican workers who were paid on Friday and rob them of their wages.
"They banded together in a gang for protection initially," Officer Montero said. "But that's all out the window now. Now they're the ones victimizing people by selling drugs, forcing girls into prostitution and extorting store owners."
The biggest problem for the police in tracking and prosecuting gang members is that they are mostly a transient population. They all go by street names and almost never carry identification, Sergeant Hodges said.
On a sweep of gang haunts in March, only two of 18 members who were stopped and questioned had any identification. One had an expired Florida driver's license, and the other had a Mexican voter registration card. One knife was found as well as a small quantity of marijuana.
All the gangs have female members, usually juveniles who hold weapons and drugs, Officer Montero said. Juveniles are handled in family court and are less likely to draw jail time for possession charges, he said. "The female members are treated like communal property, and their only purpose is sex and holding weapons and drugs," Officer Montero said.
Westchester has aggressively prosecuted gang-related violence, despite the obstacles. The District Attorney's Office has had two big cases in the last six years by using a state law that carries a higher penalty for assaults committed by a group. Juan Alberto Cotto, a gang member, was sentenced to 17 years to life for the murder of Peter Lopez in 1999. Mr. Cotto was a member of the Lawrence Street Posse. He was killed, the authorities said, while crossing another gang's turf when he went to visit his mother.
The gang unit, the Yonkers Police Department and the Youth Violence and Gang Intervention Program in the District Attorney's office have been trying to prevent gang activity by discouraging children from joining gangs. The police regularly visit the middle schools and high schools, talking to students about the perils of gangs. The city has kept school gymnasiums open later and organized athletic leagues in gang-plagued neighborhoods to help children find positive outlets.
"The gangs prey on kids from dysfunctional families that don't have any money in their pockets and wear old clothes," Officer Montero said. "They give them some pocket money or buy them some new shoes. Once they take the money they're in. They make them enforcers or drug runners."
All the members in the gang unit believe that the best prevention is not to join a gang in the first place, because getting out is difficult. Gang members who do get away usually do it by moving out of the city or by being injured.
"Unless you move away or you're in a wheelchair, you're not going to be able to walk away from the gang life," Officer Montero said.

HEADLINE: Memo From Hartford;
Around Here, Don't Say Stupid

BYLINE: By COLIN McENROE; Colin McEnroe is a radio talk-show host in Hartford.

 BODY:
THE whole idea that Hartford finished dead last among large American cities in mail-back census returns rankles Bill Rocks.
"Stop talking about how stupid Hartford is," Mr. Rocks growled at me last week. "Hartford is actually doing a lot better than 10 years ago." 
 Mr. Rocks is the state census director and, therefore, a little touchy on this subject, but he has a point. In 1990, the city's mail-back rate was 38 percent. In 2000, it was 42 percent on April 20, when an article came out pronouncing Hartford dead last. By Monday, Mr. Rocks and his crew had somehow found another percentage point to bring the city to 43, and so-called "late mail returns" had yet to be factored in.
"People talk about 'comparable' American cities, but there are no comparable American cities," said Mr. Rocks. His point is that Hartford is tiny, only 17.8 square miles.
Most American cities encompass an area at least as big as Hartford, West Hartford and East Hartford, folding in middle- and upper-middle-class neighborhoods that can offset the low rates from the inner city.
On the positive side, when Mr. Rocks sends his enumerators door-to-door this month, they'll have less ground to cover than their counterparts in Newark and other undercounted American cities. One way or another, Hartford will probably claw its way out of last place in census compliance.
But even that statement says a lot about a city struggling not to prosper but to avoid desolation. The census article resonated for a few days because it seemed to sum up Hartford's basket-case status.
All cities have problems, but it would be hard to find another city failing on so many fronts at once.
The police force is the subject of a federal grand jury investigation. Six officers have been indicted for criminal offenses, some involving drugs and prostitutes. When a police dog bit an officer a couple of weeks ago, the local joke was: who could blame the dog for getting mixed up about which ones were the crooks?
A consultant's study suggested that even the law-abiding segment of the department was disorganized and out of touch with the citizenry. Ailing Chief Joseph Croughwell agreed to retire in return for a $569,600 settlement and a pension, but the city leaders worry that the department is too dysfunctional to attract high-quality successor candidates.
Fire Chief Robert Dobson was recently driven out after an embarrassing episode in which he was caught working for his wife's art-framing business while on the city clock, followed by allegations that he was disliked and distrusted by his firefighters. In one of those peculiar Hartford twists, Mr. Dobson was given the fabulous parting gift of a taxpayer-funded trip to a Florida firefighters' conference, after he was out of office.
School Superintendent Anthony S. Amato arrived last year with a single-minded focus: get the Hartford system out of last place in the Connecticut Mastery Tests. "Never be last again" became his slogan and, although it lacked some of the dash of "to infinity and beyond," it was something.
And Mr. Amato delivered, raising all the scores in one year and getting the city out of the cellar. He then shocked everybody by becoming, briefly, a candidate for the top educational post in San Francisco.
He later withdrew, apologized and explained that he was only trying to keep his name in circulation. Mr. Amato even claimed it was good exposure for Hartford, although how "lone bright spot looks for an exit" constitutes good exposure is something he found hard to elucidate.
(Lately, there has been talk in the schools of, no kidding, "mastery burnout," as the pressure of being not-dead-last was just more than the schools could bear.)
Meawnhile, Gov. John Rowland is often cited as Hartford's biggest booster, despite his apparent determination to move key state agencies out of the capital city and into his hometown, Waterbury, which he once described as "the center of the universe."
At a lecture sponsored by Fleet Bank in Florida this winter, Mr. Rowland, apparently unaware that a reporter was in the audience, described the Hartford school system as "a disaster."
"Anybody who's ever been to Hartford -- it's dead," said the city's biggest booster. "We haven't had a crane in the air for 30 or 40 years."
Mr. Rowland's recipe for health is, of course, Adriaen's Landing, a proposed mixed-use riverfront development with a convention center, apartments, retail shops and restaurants. The development is controlled by the Capital City Economic Development Authority, an ad hoc panel that has had its own problems, including the resignation of its original chairman after a scandal involving payments and government-subsidized loans to a longtime mistress.
The cost of a ringside seat for Hartford's chaos and squalor is high. The mill rate -- the amount of tax for each $1,000 of assessed value -- has climbed to 50, with a 15 percent surcharge for commercial real estate, which means that a business will pay 57.5 mills, more than 4 percent of market value. It's sort of axiomatic that you pay more taxes in a poorly run city than in a well-run one.
The Center for Economic Analysis at the University of Connecticut found that in the last 10 years Hartford's vacant properties increased by 12 percent, while the city lost 10 percent of its apartments and 5 percent of its businesses.
This was during a boom.
Now, if this article seems like the work of a sneering "build-a-wall around it" suburbanite, please understand that I'm writing it in an office, paid for by me, in downtown Hartford. When WTIC radio, where I work, moved out of Hartford last year, after 74 years downtown, I decided to maintain my own writing office, to keep in touch with the city.
I pay rent; I patronize downtown eateries; and chances are good I'm getting, right this minute, one of the pretty red-and-white parking tickets that are handed out in the city the way they hand out leis in Hawaii.
Why? I could work out of my house and my radio office, save money and avoid all the melodramas of Hartford.
It's like being a Red Sox fan or stuck in a dysfunctional family. You don't leave because you've sunk too much of yourself in and because it might finally get better and because, with all the smart and public-spirited people around, darn it, it really should be getting better.
And maybe it will. The Sox have a new center fielder, the daffodils are up, Uncle Bert quit drinking last month, and our mail-back census rate . . . well, in a sense it did get better. Wait till next decade, buster.

HEADLINE: A City Whose Time Has Come Again;
After Years of Deprivation, Jersey City, an Old Industrial Powerhouse, Is Remaking Itself

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
SQUINTING against the glare of sun on water, Bernard Hartnett stood on his eighth-floor balcony at Port Liberte and gestured toward the pinnacles of lower Manhattan, the up-close profile of Lady Liberty and the expansive harbor enveloping this luxury development that rises on the ruins of an old shipyard.
"You should see the view in the evening, when the setting sun reflects off the skyline and my white kitchen turns gold," said Mr. Hartnett. "It's spectacular." 
 Laughing gulls shot through the air as workers hammered away at the latest batch of neo-Georgian condominiums. In the distance, a seemingly endless caravan of dump trucks unloaded dirt over the site of a former oil-tank farm, the first step in turning the tainted earth into an 18-hole golf course.
Never mind the surrounding brownfields and the relentless grinding noise from an adjacent scrap metal plant. Town houses here -- the ones with backyard boat slips -- are selling for $900,000 and most of the 134 units under construction have already been spoken for. Another 1,100 are on the drawing board.
"Business,"' said Nancy Nassaney, a sales agent, "is fabulous."
As development continues to remake Jersey City's seven miles of once-desolate waterfront, officials here predict this former industrial powerhouse will soon overtake Newark as the state's largest city, a distinction that carries a measure of political, practical and symbolic heft.
"This used to be a place that people had just given up on," said Mayor Bret Schundler, gazing at a giant aerial photograph of the city as he rattled off recent milestones, plans and pie-in-the sky projects. "Suddenly everyone wants to be here."
While most people welcome growth after so many years of deprivation, there are some who believe the development juggernaut is rending the social fabric, displacing old-timers and drawing the kinds of people who work, shop, and play in Manhattan while using Jersey City as a place to sleep. "These yuppies think $2,000 for an apartment is a good deal," said Domenic Santana, 38, a local restaurateur owner who grew up here. "But to natives, it's a disgrace."
For many -- the poor, the unskilled and the recently arrived immigrants -- Jersey City's soaring skyline is little more than a dreamy, distant mirage. Melissa Holloway, a City Council member who represents some of the most desperate neighborhoods, said many residents have yet to taste the new prosperity.
"Local people can't even apply for these jobs by going to the waterfront," Ms. Holloway said. "You have to use headhunters in Manhattan. Imagine that. For now, it's just a tale of two cities."
It is, however, a remarkable tale.
Once lumped together with the state's other ailing urban centers known as the Big Six, Jersey City is the only one to experience a true renaissance. For the others -- Camden, Trenton, Paterson, Newark and Elizabeth -- talk of rebirth and renewal remains little more than feel-good sloganeering. Among the Big Six, for example, Jersey City accounted for 90 percent of all new jobs last year. In terms of new construction, population growth and gains in per capita income, it stands a head above the others. Indeed, if the population projections are accurate, Jersey City could surpass Newark in the next few years as the state's largest city.
But in truth, said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers, the benefits would be largely psychological. "It would mark a new stage of evolution for a city that has always been in the shadow of New York, one that was better known for its railyards than its major corporate players," Mr Hughes said. "Being the biggest would just be the icing on the cake."
Still, Jersey City has its share of urban woes: nearly 20 percent of its 232,000 residents live in poverty, and illegal drug sales and crime flourish in many neighborhoods. In addition, the public schools are not much better than they were in 1989, when the state took over because they were hopelessly mismanaged. After more than a decade of oversight, education officials say test scores are still too low to allow a return to local control.
But overall, Jersey City has come a long way.
In many ways, the story of Port Liberte provides a fitting metaphor for Jersey City's rocky voyage from post-industrial blight to high-tech boomtown.
Billed by its original developers as "Venice on the Hudson," the $750 million waterfront project was the first of many to break ground on the vast wastelands left behind by the railroad companies, detergent manufacturers and shipping companies that began departing in the 1940's. Lured by mesmerizing views and generous tax abatements, Port Liberte's developers planned 1,690 homes along 2.5 miles of meandering canals. But by 1990, the recession had driven them into bankruptcy, leaving such early buyers as Mr. Hartnett with a shell of the St. Tropez-style yacht club they had been promised.
"In the early 1990's, you couldn't give these places away," said Mr. Hartnett, 70, the president of the homeowner's association. More than any of the half-built carcasses that littered New Jersey's Gold Coast in those painful years, Port Liberte came to symbolize the overblown ambitions of a real-estate boom gone bad.
But heady days are here again. A new developer is completing Port Liberte's master plan -- slightly scaled down -- and construction is roaring up and down the Jersey City waterfront. Since emerging in 1993 from a recession that left a third of its office buildings dark, developers here have put up four million-square-feet of commercial space, two hotels and TK,000 apartments. The abandoned train yards and decaying piers have finally given way to a glimmering ribbon of marinas, riverfront promenades and glass-faced towers. And unless New York's economy runs out of steam, developers say there is no end in sight.
"We can't build them quick enough," said Sam LeFrak, the 82-year-old patriarch of the Lefrak organization, whose 600-acre Newport complex already boasts 5,000 residents and 11,600 workers and an ever-expanding megamall. "We have such grand plans. You ain't seen nothing yet."
Such grandiose promises do not thrill everyone. For the early wave of pioneers who turned shabby row houses into landmark gems, more buildings mean more people, more traffic and less open space. Those who live in such downtown neighborhoods as Paulus Hook and Van Vorst Park complain that daily life is increasingly marred by the pounding of pile drivers, the race for scarce parking spaces and early morning gridlock as suburbanites make their way to the waterfront.
For those who live along Jersey City's northern-most ridge, a neighborhood known as the Heights, soaring condominiums threaten to chip away at views that are perhaps the most astounding of anywhere in the metropolitan area. "A lot of people came here because of these incredible vistas," said Doris C. Brown, whose family has lived in the Heights for three generations. "We're not about to sacrifice that to some ugly high rise."
The proposed development, a pair of 43-story towers just below the Heights, would only obscure a thin slice of a view that takes in Hoboken, Jersey City's lowlands and the jagged spine of downtown Manhattan. But opponents fear the project, known as Millennium Towers, would be the first of many. "It would be the beginning of the end," Ms. Brown said.
Jersey City officials dispute that notion, however, saying current zoning restricts tall buildings at the base of the Palisades, an area that is still pocked by empty factories and vacant lots. The Millennium's developers, they say, will not go forward unless they receive a variance for a high-density project. "People in the Heights are afraid of a forest of towers but we're saying we can guarantee that won't happen,' said Mr. Schundler.
There is little trust between local residents and Jersey City officials, both of whom are still smarting from a redevelopment battle that took place several months ago. The Palisade Avenue Coalition, which led the opposition, claimed they were fighting to stop the demolition of their cliff-top community, which once cleared, would be handed over to developers. City officials said the group was misconstruing the facts.
To make their case, Ms. Brown and several friends recently led a visitor on a tour of this ethnically diverse neighborhood, with its sagging Victorians, densely packed tenements and boarded-up storefronts. Rents are still affordable, but that could change as an increasing number of New Yorkers discover the neighborhood.
"Granted, the vinyl siding is not romantic, but we see the problem as a skin condition and the city thinks it's bone cancer," she said. "The bones are fine. These buildings just need a good facial."
City planners said they never intended to bring in the bulldozers, but that a "blight" designation would have qualified the area for valuable federal and state redevelopment funds. The neighborhood's council member, Tom DeGise, said the opposition killed any hope for renewal by twisting the facts.
Long overshadowed by its giant neighbor across the Hudson, Jersey City is something of a black hole to most people, a nondescript blur of two-family homes and grimy warehouses they pass on the way to Newark Airport or the well-groomed suburbs beyond.
"We've had so many friends who refused to visit us because they thought we were in central Jersey," said Leon Yost, a photographer and early homesteader who traded his Manhattan studio for a century-old row house near Van Vorst Park. The cost in 1974: $13,000.
Since then, Mr. Yost said, five friends who braved the 15-minute PATH train ride from Manhattan have purchased their own homes here. These days, an Italianate-style home near downtown fetches $300,000 or more. "You know how it works," Mr. Yost said, a dismissive edge in his voice. "First the artists come and sniff out the cheap prices. Then once they've fixed the place up, the lawyers and dentists show up with all their money."
Still, with 15 square miles of space, there are plenty of ungentrified neighborhoods in Jersey City. These days, refugees come not only from New York City, but from nearby Hoboken, where housing prices have begun to mimic those in Manhattan and the tonier sections of Brooklyn.
As Jersey City's cachet grows, Daniel H. Frohwirth, the real estate director at the Jersey City Economic Development Corporation, says he is noticing a slight shift in the city's self-image. Less and less, he says, people are denying they are from Jersey City.
Like New Jersey's other big cities, Jersey City experienced its greatest glory in the decades before World War II, when heavy manufacturing was king. Originally occupied by the Lenni Lannape Indians, the marshes and rolling hills that later became Jersey City were settled by Dutch farmers in the 1630's, a few years after Peter Minuit made his notorious purchase of Manhattan island.
Much like New York, Jersey City has always been a landing pad for new immigrants. "America's Golden Door," its current promotional campaign, is visible all over town, and residents love to point out that Ellis Island is closer to Jersey City than it is to New York. Two years ago, after a long court battle between the two states, the Supreme Court gave New Jersey jurisdiction over much of the island.
In its heyday before World War II, German, Irish and Italian immigrants found work at Chloro, Colgate or Dixon, the pencil maker. But the single biggest employer was the railroads, whose national networks dead-ended on the Hudson. Until 1911, when the Pennsylvania Railroad Company built the first tunnel under the river, rail passengers transferred here for ferries to Manhattan or to trolleys that fanned out through Hudson County and beyond.
The last streetcar was junked in 1949; today only one rail line, the former Erie Lackawana, survives, with its soaring, copper-faced terminus in Hoboken. When the four other railroad companies went under, they left Jersey City the land that included their vast train yards and sheds, worthless then, but now the gold that is being gobbled up by so many developers.
By the 1970's, Jersey City was in a free fall. From 1950to 1980 it lost 75,000 people residents. And from 1975 to 1982 it lost 5,000 jobs, or 9 percent of its workforce. Although it had always had a reputation as a tough port town, any romantic notions about the old Jersey City were subsumed by a surge of violent crime. Mr. Santana, who grew up downtown, said those were crazy days.
"It was worse here than Fort Apache in the Bronx," said Mr. Santana, adding that as a teenager he was stabbed and shot during brawls. Wily thugs, he said, would stage fights at the Holland Tunnel entrance and divert 18-wheelers onto side streets, where others would cut their cargo locks and unload the loot. "Even old ladies would come out to pick over the stolen goods," he said with a laugh.
These days crime is way down. Mayor Schundler said it has fallen 40 percent since he took office in 1993, mainly through the brand of quality of life policing that has been used in New York.
Still, things have a long way to go in places like Lafayette, Bergen and Greenville, the predominantly black neighborhoods that occupy "The Hill," a gently rising slope that accounts for a third of Jersey City's topography. Most days it is easy to spot the drug dealers, although they usually scamper when Irene Carson comes down the block, slowly hobbling on her cane. Despite two open-heart surgeries and worsening diabetes, the 64-year-old Mrs. Carson fearlessly tells the dealers to leave Lafayette Gardens, the low-rise public housing project that has been her home for more than three decades.
"When I came here, it was so clean and nice, everyone tended their gardens," she said. "The young people, they just don't have respect."
As president of the Lafayette Gardens resident's council, Mrs. Carson has made some progress in her crusade to rein in the chaos. She leads anti-drug marches, steers youngsters into the local Little League and helps raise scholarship money for those who make it to college. The Irene Carson Scholarship Fund -- her neighbors named it -- usually gives from $200 to $500 to each college-bound resident, all of it raised through chicken dinners and children's fashion shows.
Though some of her neighbors disagree, Mrs. Carson thinks life is getting better at Lafayette Gardens. Any day now, she says boastfully, construction should begin on Lafayette Village, a mixed-income development that will bring 77 homes to a vacant lot across the street. Mrs. Carson said her next dream is to see a nearby parcel -- one she described as "that eyesore that attracts drunks and fights" -- replaced by assisted-living housing for Lafayette Gardens' aging residents.
Although she said she could have moved away long ago, joining her children in the suburbs, Mrs. Carson refuses to leave until she sees the return of the old neighborhood that nurtured her in the 1940's and 50's. "I'll stay here to make sure things are brought up," she said.
Further up The Hill, on Martin Luther King Drive, life is still an unending struggle. Merchants began disappearing from the drive, once Hudson County's pre-eminent shopping boulevard, in the 1950's, shortly after the middle-class took off for the suburbs. Block after block, a grim parade of darkened storefronts is all that is left of that other era.
But after decades of despair, there are unmistakable signs of renewal. A station for the Bergen-Hudson Light Rail has just opened on the drive, a new post office is nearly finished and a suburban-style shopping center called "The MLK Hub" is celebrating the arrival of its first tenants, among them such national chains as Ashley Stewart, One Price Clothing, Ponderosa steakhouse, and most importantly, a hulking supermarket. It is, most everyone agrees, a momentous thing.
Omar Barbour stood in the shopping center's parking lot one day last week shaking his head with a mix of pride and disbelief. "It might not look like much, but people here haven't had something like this in a long time," said Mr. Barbour, 46, who shepherded the project through 13 years of broken promises, false starts and fierce opposition.
Just then, Hattie Staggers, 70, came ambling up and gave Mr. Barbour a hug. For 28 years, Miss Staggers lived in a 17-room house on this very spot, she said, pointing toward an empty swath of asphalt. As part of the $18 million redevelopment project, she and about 100 people, 15 businesses and 4 churches had to go. "We took her house, her garden and her church," Mr. Barbour said. "It was a sacrifice she made for a greater good."
Although she was initially skeptical, Miss Staggers now agrees that the end justified the means. By the time the demolition crews came, Ege Avenue had long been a ghost of its former self. More than half the block was pocked by burned-out houses or garbage-filled lots. Before the crews took everything down, Mr. Barbour's group, the MLK Drive Neighborhood Development Corporation, found Miss Staggers an apartment and built her congregation a new church. "I have to say, they came through in the end," she said. "Because this is the most beautiful market I've ever seen."
It was a perfectly choreographed moment, except it didn't feel staged. With Miss Staggers out of earshot, Mr. Barbour admitted that relations between himself and local residents were not always so cordial. "I'm still condemned in this life and in the afterlife," he said, referring to the bruising fights over the project. "Sometimes I wondered if it would ever happen."
Against all odds, it did. Of course it remains to be seen whether The Hub will spark the neighborhood's revival. One of its earliest tenants, a black-owned automotive parts store, closed after only a few months.
But now that almost dozen new shops are open, Mr. Barbour believes the crowds will come. "As far as I'm concerned," he said, strolling through the supermarket's sprawling produce section, "it's already a success."
Before blue-chip titans like Merrill Lynch, American Express and Paine Weber discovered the New Jersey waterfront, there was Journal Square, the city's commercial heart, home to its tallest buildings and the place where generations came to see vaudeville acts, movie premieres and appearances by Bob Hope, Cab Calloway and Duke Ellington.
These days, Journal Square is best known for its huge PATH station and a busy bus terminal that serves 30,000 commuters a day. The few surviving brand-name retailers left in the 1980's, around the same time the last of the square's four movie palaces went dark. More than a mile from the waterfront, Journal Square, it seemed, was just too far from Manhattan's glittering skyline to catch some of its pixie dust.
By the time Brian Coleman was given the task of rejuvenating the square in 1995 it had become a place to be avoided. "It was full of garbage, vagrants and graffiti," said Mr. Coleman, executive director of the Journal Square Restoration Corporation. "The most prominent feature was an asphalt parking area for idling taxis."
On a recent sun-filled afternoon, Mr. Coleman stood on that same spot, except that it was now paved with granite slabs and full of pedestrians. The $7.5 million refurbishment of Journal Square, completed this month, has recaptured a bit of the area's lost luster. There is a lavish fountain, a Victorian-style kiosk for food and a grove of new trees. Private security guards keep a lid on boisterous behavior while uniformed cleaning crews chase down every last scrap of paper.
The current wave of construction, it seems, is finally moving off the water's edge. The old Earle Hotel, once a haven for squatters, is offering penthouse apartments for $3,000 a month. A 16-story office building, 26 Journal Square, recently received a $2 million makeover. And a real-estate consortium has plans to build apartments on the site of old State Theater.
If all goes according to plan, Mr. Coleman said, a decaying row of buildings will be replaced by a new home for Hudson County Community College, whose students currently take classes in buildings scattered throughout the neighborhood. "I think we're finally back on the map," he said.
Bricks and mortar are one thing. Bringing back Journal Square's soul is another. To that end, a small army of volunteers is resuscitating the old Loews Jersey Theater, which barely escaped oblivion in 1993 when its owners decided the land was worth more than the building. It was a close call, but the 10,000 signatures and relentless lobbying by local preservationists convinced the city to purchase the theater, which opened in 1929.
Since then, the Friends of the Loews, a nonprofit group, have made the theater's rebirth a citywide crusade. Every weekend, dozens of volunteers tend to the sumptuous interior, which was severely wounded when the Loews Corporation carved it into a triplex. But beyond missing chunks of ornament and a few vanished fixtures, the theater is in remarkably good shape.
A Czechoslovakian-made chandelier still graces the Hollywood baroque vestibule, winged cherubs abound and $38 worth of spray-on lubrication was all it took to get the orchestra pit elevator working again. The theater, inside and out, is a sight to behold.
Colin Egan, the project's only paid employee, estimates that devotees have put in the equivalent of $1 million in free labor; another $1.5 million has been raised through grants and fund-raising events.
These days, the volunteer workers are installing newly reupholstered seats, which have been liberated from 70 years of bubble gum. By summer, the marquee's lights will begin winking again and the legendary clock, with its 6-foot-high figures of St. George and the Dragon, will be doing their hourly dance. Back then, the show began on the sidewalk, Mr. Egan said.
When it opens, the Loews Jersey -- with 3,021 seats -- will be the state's largest theater, and Mr. Egan expects it to support an eclectic range of programming, from Indian dance and rock concerts to independent film and children's theater.
Two miles from Journal Square, beyond The Hill, past the acres of weed-choked brownfields, Port Liberte rises like a sentinel in an unsettled frontier.
With the uncertain years of bankrupcy behind him, Mr. Hartnett, the president of the homeowner's association, sees a grand future for Port Liberte. The clubhouse, which sat unfinished for more than a decade, is finally nearing completion. These days the most vexing problem, he said, is the giant scrap plant next door, which is poorly concealed by a row of hedges. "We're trying our best to come up with a solution", he said.
Growing up in Jersey City's old Irish neighborhood, the Horseshoe, Mr. Hartnett said he always knew his hometown was destined to be more than a railroad junction. A fourth-generation Jersey City native, he is the last in his family to remain. The Horseshoe was plowed over long ago to make way for the Holland Tunnel access ramps.
A tireless Jersey City booster, Mr. Hartnett believes the best is yet to come. "We have the Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island, the science center, Liberty State Park," he said, "and we're a few minutes from Newark Airport." He paused, and then added, "People laugh at me, but I think there will come a time when travel agents book vacations to Jersey City. You'll see."

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES;
In Vineland, It's Baseball Bilingually

BYLINE: By SHARON WATERS 

DATELINE: VINELAND

 BODY:
Vineland has long taken its high school baseball seriously, so seriously that the games are broadcast on local radio. But after decades of home runs and strikeouts, there are cuadrangulars and ponchados.
Welcome to WMIZ, 1270 on the AM band, which first introduced bilingual baseball broadcasts three years ago in covering the Vineland High School Roosters. This year the coverage was expanded to include the Sacred Heart High School Lions. 
 Sitting behind home plate, one broadcaster provides play-by-play in English while a second offers a Spanish translation.
"It's so unique, so unusual and so smart," said Phil Roberts, executive director of the New Jersey Association of Broadcasters. "I'd be surprised if it's not adopted by Major League Baseball."
The bilingual broadcasts are a hit not only with with the players and their fans, but with advertisers and Spanish teachers, who are considering using the radio shows in their classrooms.
Vineland, at 69.5 square miles the state's largest municipality in terms of area and midway between Philadelphia and Atlantic City, is a lush farming area that has long attracted Hispanic migrant workers, many of whom have stayed and established roots.
Today, more than one-third of Vineland High School students are Hispanic, a 13 percent increase since 1995, and almost 20 percent of all students have a parent who speaks Spanish at home, spokesmen for the school say. Moreover, they say, Hispanic pupils now outnumber Caucasian ones in the Vineland public schools by 41 percent to 39 percent. At Sacred Heart High School, 10 percent of the student body is Hispanic.
The numbers on the field are similar. On Vineland's varsity team, half of the 18 players are Hispanic, said the coach, Rich Klimek. On the Sacred Heart team, 5 of the 20 players and 2 of the 4 assistant coaches are bilingual, said Don Robbins, the Lions' coach.
"We have gotten to the point where we play salsa music when they run out on the field," Mr. Klimek said, noting the players speak Spanish during a game, sometimes confusing opponents.
The notion of offering bilingual broadcasts evolved while trying to appease WMIZ's program director, who objected to the Spanish station announcing games in English. As a result, WMIZ tried the bilingual format as an experiment.
"It became a hit so we kept it," said the station manager, Carl Hemple. "Sometimes you do things by accident, and they work out."
Mr. Roberts said that no other radio station in the state provides bilingual sports broadcasts. Indeed, he called the idea brilliant because the Spanish translation replaces the color man, who would ordinarily fill in dead time between plays with comments about the crowd, the weather and player statistics.
Interestingly, he said that the Spanish radio stations in the area have begun broadcasting commercials in English as they come to realize that many Hispanic people today use English as their first language.
Although second- and third-generation Hispanics may speak Spanish at home, they use English in school and at work. English commercials also reach listeners who tune in for the Spanish music but do not know a word of the language.
In addition, Mr. Roberts said, advertisers get more words for their buck because it is faster to say something in English than Spanish -- a one-minute English commercial translates to a 75-second commercial in Spanish.
The economics of the bilingual format is not lost on Mr. Hemple, the station manager, who noted that the station sells out ads on the broadcast of the games.
Local businesses target an audience of Spanish and English-speaking residents in the Vineland area. And WMIZ reaches about 4,000 listeners in the Vineland area in any given 15-minute period, Mr. Hemple said.
For Vic LaTorre, who owns LaTorre Hardware here, advertising on the bilingual broadcasts is a way of supporting youth baseball and reaching the local community at the same time.
"We're mainly trying to build image," said Mr. LaTorre, who has placed 60-second spots in Spanish and English. "It's difficult for a store of my type to sell any one product unless it's snowing and they want a snow shovel. We're just trying to target ourselves to the community."
WMIZ's concept was great in theory, but it could work well only with the right synergy between the two broadcasters -- particularly because under the current arrangement the man providing English play-by-play, Joe Habelow, the station's sports director, knows no Spanish. Mr. Habelow listens to a language he doesn't comprehend until he hears his name, the cue provided by his Spanish-speaking partner, Sony Lugo.
"When he says 'Joe,' I know I come on," Mr. Habelow said.
The harmony seems to stem from their friendly rivalry as Yankees and Red Sox fans. Mr. Habelow -- a Boston transplant who peppers his on-air remarks with references to Bill Buckner and Roger Clemens while dropping his R's faster than a Kennedy -- wore a Red Sox hat and shirt to a recent Lions game.
Mr. Lugo, a native of Puerto Rico, wears a Yankees hat and the smug grin of a fan of the repeat world champions.
Over all, the broadcasts feature more English, with Spanish summaries at the end of each half-inning. But exciting plays, pitching changes and controversial calls warrant an immediate Spanish translation.
Understandably, the broadcasts have stirred excitement among players and fans in the Hispanic community.
"They feel very proud," said Cruz Gomez, an assistant coach for Sacred Heart. "The Hispanics are feeling that now they're being welcomed in the town."
Baseball is big in Vineland, where last year the Roosters clinched the Cape-Atlantic League title and Sacred Heart's team won the state championship for the parochial B division.
Steven Gonzalez, for one, is pleased with the arrangement. Steven, a senior who pitches for Vineland High School, said his extended family -- some of whom speak Spanish and others English -- could listen to the games together.
And everyone who steps into his father's taxi can listen to the game on the radio.
"He's always in his car, so he's always listening," Steven said.
If a passenger asks, Steven's father, Robert Gonzalez, will discuss at length his son's playing ability. Indeed, some have already heard about the fourth-year varsity player.
The games are also popular among the other cab drivers who tune in when Steven pitches.
"We talk about it almost every day over there," said Mr. Gonzalez. "It makes me feel good that I can do my job and still listen to my son play ball."

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
Big Box Stores, Redefined

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: PARAMUS

 BODY:
Fittingly, perhaps, Casket Discounters set up shop in a bedding store. The telephone number is (877) 7AT REST.
Still, Andrew B. Paer, the president of the company, says it was not a sense of the macabre that prompted him to locate a business that sells caskets next to a showroom for mattresses and box springs. 
 There is the exposure -- Westwood Sleep Centers is situated at 736 Route 17 North in a major shopping area. There is visibility -- his sign in the window of a simply furnished but dignified office adjacent to the bedding showroom can be seen from the highway. And the space was available, since he is also an owner of the sleep center.
Of course, there is what Mr. Paer calls "a natural fit." Comparing a coffin with a bed, he says, with a touch of wryness: "What really is it? It's a final resting place."
His business, which opened in February, is one of a growing number of retail casket depots that have been showing up in shopping centers, strip malls and downtowns around the country since 1994, when the Federal Trade Commission ruled that funeral directors could not refuse or charge an extra fee for caskets bought from someone other than the funeral director.
Estimates vary as to how many stores there are because several went out of business not long after opening, said Maynard Cheris, founder and former chairman of the National Casket Retailers Association, who owns a casket store in Gurnee, Ill. Mr. Cheris estimated that there were about 200 such stores nationwide.
In New Jersey, there are more than a half a dozen, said Charles Graves, the owner of Evan's Casket Store in Linden, who is a spokesman for these businesses in the state. The stores, besides those in Linden and Paramus, are situated in Clifton, Green Brook, Union, Voorhees and Woodbridge, Mr. Graves said.
"This is a business that's going to take time to grow on the public," said Mr. Graves, who is beginning his second year. "It's not like a candy store. People really don't realize the savings they can have."
So what has been the effect of the stores on the $10 billion-a-year funeral industry?
"They've shaken up the troops," said Lisa Carlson, executive director of the Funeral Consumers Alliance, a consumer watchdog group in Hinesburg, Vt.
Ms. Carlson added, "Once a funeral home is losing 10 percent of its casket business they tend to lower their casket price and jack up their service prices."
But Kelly Smith, a spokesman for the National Funeral Directors Association, said the retail casket businesses have had little effect.
"It comes to about six a state, which is not a significant number," said Mr. Smith. "They've been more successful in generating media attention than selling caskets."
As for Ms. Carlson's assertion that funeral homes have been reducing casket prices and raise the cost of other services, Mr. Smith said he would like to see the data to back that up. In addition, he said, casket stores are not regulated like funeral homes.
"Consumers eventually learn they can receive a much higher level of service and consumer protection at a funeral home," he said.
The industry has been under attack for years. Jessica Mitford"s 1963 book, "The American Way of Death," led to an investigation by the Federal Trade Commission and the passage of stricter funeral rules in 1984 that required funeral directors to present an itemized list of charges, including casket cost.
In hearings earlier this month, the Senate Special Committee on Aging heard testimony about aggressive sales tactics, like the story of an 80-year old Florida woman who said she was talked into buying $125,000 in funeral items and services, including a $40,000 coffin.
Inflation in the industry has been running about 5 to 7 percent annually as against a general rate of about 2 percent, said Ms. Carlson of Funeral Consumers Alliance. The average cost of a funeral is $5,000 to $5,700, according to the National Funeral Directors Association. The cost including burial comes to $7,500.
But critics contend that funeral homes have historically inflated the price of coffins by 300 percent. Ms. Carlson said a cloth-covered particle board casket selling at $150 wholesale sells for as much as $995 in a funeral home but for only about $300 at a retail casket store.
For instance, Mr. Paer claims he can undersell undertakers on caskets from 50 to 75 percent because his overhead is low and because he is an independent agent. The L-shaped showroom adjacent to his office features 24 full-sized coffins -- the cheapest is a simple pine box that he sells for $399 and says would cost at least $1,000 in a funeral home; the most expensive is an Italian hand-carved solid mahogany casket for $12,000 that he claims would sell in a mortuary for $30,000 to $40,000.
"There is a need for this type of business," said Mr. Paer, who has a background in accounting and marketing and once worked in sales and marketing for a health and beauty care manufacturer.
Wilson H. Beebe, executive director of the New Jersey State Funeral Directors Association which represents 600 members, said he objected to the tone of Mr. Paer's advertisements.
"It's really pandering to prejudices which have created fears and a kind of mythology based on anecdotal information about the funeral industry that's been circulating for 30 years," Mr. Beebe said. He said Mr. Paer would be hard-pressed to demonstrate a 50 to 75 percent savings consistently. "People would be well-advised to check the price against local funeral homes because it may not be the case," he said.
One local funeral director, Tim Newman of the Riewerts Memorial Home in Bergenfield, said that within the last five years he has lowered his mark-up on caskets to the point that he makes only about $60 on lower-end and mid-level coffins.
Competition from casket stores is beneficial, Mr. Newman says, because it is making many funeral directors de-emphasize the coffin and accentuate service.
"It made us reassess our real purpose," Mr. Newman said. "Most of us that have some idea what's going on have affirmed that our value lies in being funeral directors and not casket sales people. They've actually done us a favor. Putting a very high mark-up on our caskets is not the way we should be going with people today."
As for Mr. Paer, sitting behind his sign facing Route 17, he said of his business after two months: "It's been an interesting process. I've been getting a lot of inquiries regarding the industry. I've been doing business delivering caskets and getting involved with monuments. But it's been basically a slow build."

Beth Roy, Michael Stanton

 BODY:
Elizabeth Anne Roy and Michael Henry Stanton, financial journalists, were married yesterday by the Rev. Louis Jerome at St. Patrick's Church in Yorktown Heights, N.Y.
The bride, 31, is a senior writer for TheStreet.com, covering the bond market. The bridegroom, 26, is the editor in chief of The Bond Buyer, a newspaper for the municipal bond business. 
 Mrs. Stanton, 31, is known as Beth. She graduated from Yale University and received a master's degree in journalism from Columbia University. She is a daughter of George Roy of Katonah, N.Y., and the late Joyce Roy. Her mother was a computer programmer for the City of White Plains. The bride's father teaches social studies at Rye High School in Rye, N.Y. Her stepmother, Dolores Vidal-Roy, is a clinical social worker in mental health for Westchester County, in Mount Kisco, N.Y.
Mr. Stanton received a bachelor's degree in economics from Columbia, where he was the managing editor of The Spectator, the campus newspaper. He is a son of Catherine and Henry Stanton of Yorktown Heights, N.Y. His mother is a consulting nuclear engineer and also an adjunct assistant professor in radiological health at Manhattan College. His father is deputy commissioner of transportation for Westchester County, in White Plains.
