HEADLINE: Deregulation Has Given Power to the Power People

BYLINE: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
WHEN New Yorkers last heard of William J. Catacosinos two years ago, he was being hounded from his job running the former Long Island Lighting Company after pocketing a $42 million paycheck that drew denunciations all the way to the governor's office.
Back then, the utility industry's prospects were cloudy as deregulation fever swept the states. And considering the wounds he took from Lilco -- whose rates, the highest in the continental United States, made him a favorite target of local politicians -- the circumstances hardly seemed inviting for Dr. Catacosinos to dive back into the business. 
 But he did. Weeks after resigning from his old job, he was in discussions that would lead to the first leveraged buyout of an electric utility. With CIBC World Markets and other investors, Dr. Catacosinos this month completed the $1.1 billion acquisition of TNP Enterprises Inc. of Fort Worth.
An act of masochism? Not a bit. The relatively low values that the market is assigning to utility stocks -- along with the favorable terms that the industry was able to negotiate as old-fashioned rate regulation faded -- have captured the attention not only of Dr. Catacosinos, but also of some of the nation's most prominent investors.
Last month, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts invested $550 million for a 20 percent stake in DPL Inc., the utility in Dayton, Ohio. And no less an investing icon than Warren E. Buffett of Berkshire Hathaway recently spent $2 billion to acquire 76 percent of MidAmerican Energy Holdings of Des Moines. Mr. Buffett told shareholders Berkshire's future utility investments "could be large."
Such deal-making -- along with a surge in merger activity and asset-swapping by utilities -- shows how quickly fears have evaporated that deregulation could cause widespread financial trauma in the industry.
Just three years ago, the Energy Department predicted that deregulation could lead to numerous bankruptcies, with some utilities losing 30 percent or more of their revenue.
Stripped of their monopolies, industry executives grumbled, they would never recoup the money spent over the decades building generation plants -- including nuclear reactors -- to meet demand. Competition from newer, lower-cost power producers, they complained, would force old-line utilities to eat more than $100 billion of "stranded costs" -- money spent building generation plants that would be unable to pay for themselves under deregulation.
Instead, the industry appears to be holding its own. Rising prices for electricity in many parts of the nation have helped make existing plants more valuable than most anyone expected. Nonetheless, the utilities continue to enjoy ratepayer-financed bailouts for nuclear plants and other assets, based on a gloomy post-deregulation outlook.
Five years ago, Moody's Investors Service, the bond rating house, estimated the industry's stranded costs at $135 billion; it now puts the number at just $10 billion.
"It turns out there is a lot of value in power plants, more than anybody anticipated several years ago," said Ken Rose, senior institute economist at the National Regulatory Research Institute, in Columbus, Ohio. "I'm convinced that with a little creative accounting, you can show stranded costs for just about anybody."
The Energy Department, meanwhile, has turned its attention to much different concerns. Policy makers worry that the big power generation companies -- still facing little competition, despite regulation -- will be able to use their near-monopoly power in some parts of the nation to keep prices artificially high, even as the nation's transmission grid suffers from neglect.
Too little has been invested in the grid in recent years, according to Bill Richardson, the energy secretary. "Couple that with some of the market power advantages some of the utilities have, and not only do you have the potential for outages and strain on the grid, but also for artificially high prices," Mr. Richardson said. He advocates greater federal control over transmission lines.
THE industry's turnabout is vividly illustrated by Dr. Catacosinos's deal for TNP, which serves 233,000 small-town customers through its Texas-New Mexico Power Company unit.
Not long ago, TNP seemed an unlikely candidate to attract smart money. In 1995, its shares languished at $15 amid worries about the debt-laden utility's future under deregulation. In particular, analysts wondered how TNP's generating plant, built for $640 million and fueled by lignite, a soft coal, would fare against cheaper energy from other sources.
So what attracted Dr. Catacosinos and his investors? Partly the prospect of owning a utility that was focused primarily on transmission and distribution services. But they also had the promise of a 1999 Texas law that allowed TNP to collect $23.4 million last year in excess earnings -- beyond a state-mandated cap on profits -- to speed the recovery of its stranded costs, mostly from the lignite plant. TNP can collect similar sums in 2000 and 2001, after which it can impose a surcharge on customers to recoup the remainder of the plant's stranded cost.
The new law was clearly important to the Catacosinos group, which did not agree to the deal until the final week of the 1999 Texas legislative session, when it became clear that the bill would pass. Ultimately, the group paid $44 a share, a 26 percent premium over the stock price before the deal was proposed.
Dr. Catacosinos did not respond to an interview request, and his spokesman declined comment on the law.
ACROSS the nation, similar legislation has aided utilities. But even without such arrangements, utilities are finding buyers willing to pay surprisingly fat premiums for generation plants. Many deals have been at two to five times book value -- in this case, the amount invested but not yet recovered under the old rate-setting structure.
According to an April report by the Legg Mason brokerage firm, about 68,000 megawatts of fossil-fuel and hydropowered generation capacity -- roughly one-twelfth of the nation's total -- were sold by utilities from 1997 to 1999, for a total of $24.4 billion. Those plants had been carried on their owners' books at $10.3 billion.
Here in Texas, the TXU Corporation, based in Dallas and the state's largest utility, said recently that it expected to receive as much as 10 times book value for a half-dozen gas-fired power plants. In Pennsylvania, the Duquesne Light Company, the largest unit of DQE Inc., had expected to take until 2005 to recover $1.5 billion of stranded costs through a special customer charge. But a pending deal to sell its plants at a fat price to Orion Power Holdings should allow that process to be largely completed next year.
Most of these sales are of older, fossil-fuel plants -- not the nuclear units that, because of huge debt service, would have trouble paying for themselves if left to compete on an equal basis with cheaper plants.
But nuclear plants have begun to make a modest comeback, too. Some utilities -- notably Peco Energy, the Philadelphia-based utility that is merging with Unicom, and Entergy, based in New Orleans -- have become major acquirers of nuclear plants, figuring that they can operate them more efficiently.
Just last month, Entergy bought two nuclear plants owned by the New York Power Authority for about 70 percent of book value. At a deal-signing ceremony, Clarence D. Rappleyea, chief executive of the authority, said such a deal would have been unlikely until very recently.
"There was no market a year and a half ago," Mr. Rappleyea said.
Analysts caution that some favorable trends for the industry could reverse, prompting a decline in electricity prices. A slowdown in the economy, for example, could reduce demand for power. Or natural gas prices could fall, making it cheaper for upstart generation companies to compete. And electricity supply is growing as new generation plants are built. Although it is difficult to say how many plants will be completed, analysts think 50,000 megawatts or more could come on line in the next few years, increasing the nation's power generating capacity by about 6 percent.
Yet apart from economic circumstances, the industry still wields tremendous political power at the state level. About half of the states have already passed competition plans, but utility lobbyists focused on persuading legislators to allow utilities to recover their stranded costs. By and large, they won, despite howls from critics who likened the arrangements to the savings-and-loan bailouts of decades past.
In some states, utilities have done one better, getting cash up front for their stranded costs by selling bonds to be paid off through special surcharges on customers. The Edison Electric Institute, the industry trade group, says $26 billion in stranded costs has been securitized this way. That has allowed Peco, for instance, to retire debt and buy back stock, bolstering first-quarter earnings per share by about 15 percent.
OVER all, American utilities are on track to generate $92 billion in free cash flow from 1999 to 2001, even after dividends and stock buybacks, said Daniele Seitz, an analyst at Warburg Dillon Read in New York. "Obviously, if you have massive assets that you intend to recover over 30 years, then all of a sudden the recovery period is supposed to be 5 to 10 years, you can imagine how much more cash you're going to have," she said.
In the 1980's, state officials fought bruising battles with utilities over rate increases. In the stranded-cost debate, legislators often sided with utilities but found political cover by mandating rate cuts of 5 to 15 percent in deregulation bills.
Some consumer advocates contend that, because of the economics of the business, rates would have fallen that much even under the old rate-setting structure. But when customers' bills are not rising, it is difficult to stir the public, as anti-utility organizers in California learned in 1998 when their initiative to block payment of stranded costs to utilities lost by nearly 3 to 1.
"What the utilities have been getting is absolutely astounding to me," said Kenneth Lay, chairman of the Enron Corporation, the energy and trading company in Houston that has sought to challenge regional monopolies on their home turf. The company has battled utilities in statehouses and in Congress.
By Mr. Lay's estimate, ratepayers nationwide are paying up to 50 percent too much to cover stranded costs, a situation that he likens to paying off a mortgage early but still having to pay interest to the bank each month. But he marvels at the industry's power at the state level.
"That is one of their core competencies," he said. "That may be their only core competency."
Utilities take sharp issue with that assessment. State lawmakers, they say, have merely made good on promises from decades ago, when generation plants were built with the understanding that utilities could recoup all prudently incurred costs.
Industry officials are less certain that stranded-cost concerns are gone for good. "I wouldn't agree that stranded costs have been driven to zero yet," said Mathew Morey, chief economist of the Edison Electric Institute. He said some utilities were still bound by old contracts to buy power at relatively high prices, an arrangement that constitutes a different type of stranded cost.
But, he said, "there's no question that the market valuations of a lot of the coal-fired plants have really been a surprise, well above the expectations of a few years ago." If projected increases in generation capacity do not occur, he added, there could be more upward pressure on electricity prices.
Despite the avid interest of big investors like Dr. Catacosinos and Mr. Buffett, utility stocks still may not be dependable investments for widows and orphans.
The main historical factor in the stocks' safety and reliability -- the monopoly profit guaranteed through state regulation -- has faded. To survive in the new world of deregulation, utilities have been adopting vastly different strategies, so investors may need to be much more selective than in the past.
Some utilities have decided to buy existing coal or nuclear generation plants, or to build gas-fired plants, in an effort to become large, efficient generators. Others are getting out of the generation business altogether, figuring that they are too small to compete effectively; instead, they plan to buy power in the deregulated marketplace, then distribute it to homes and businesses.
Still others have gone on shopping binges overseas, gobbling up foreign utilities. And some have even prompted pops in their stock prices by highlighting telecommunications or Internet-related subsidiaries.
IF utility shareholders are certain about anything, it is that the stock market has not been kind to them lately. Last year, the Standard & Poor's Electric Utilities index lagged behind the S.& P. 500-stock index by 43 percentage points. This year has been brighter, as the pummeling of technology stocks has helped utilities pull ahead of broader indexes.
But relative to the S.& P. 500, utilities still have the lowest P/E ratios and highest dividend yields in memory. Prices, in other words, do not appear to reflect the industry's resuscitation, some analysts say.
"The worries about bankruptcies and balance sheets getting blown up from two to three to four years ago have not proven out," said Steven Fleishman, a utility analyst at Merrill Lynch. "If I would have known this is how things would have played out three or fours years ago, I would have never believed the stocks would be where they are today."
But if some old risks have dissipated, some new ones have appeared, Mr. Fleishman said. Many utilities may be unable to build strategies to lure back investors who have become infatuated with the fast growth potential of technology issues.
Moreover, as utilities have acquired huge piles of cash from selling assets and recovering stranded costs, they face all the risks that accompany the allocation of large amounts of capital. The industry's record so far is mixed. Some overseas acquisitions have proved untimely, and some domestic mergers have shown little promise for bolstering shareholder returns.
From the ratepayer's perspective, complaints abound that recovery of stranded costs has impeded competition in some areas. In certain cases, the hefty surcharges customers are paying -- regardless of who they now buy power from -- do not allow much room for competitors to undercut incumbent utilities.
SOME industry observers wonder whether the recovery amounts are so large that ratepayers may end up paying far more than is necessary -- even though many states have provisions to adjust stranded-cost recovery up or down if necessary.
At a recent meeting of consumer advocates from various states, Dr. Rose of the National Regulatory Research Institute said he noticed that a number of officials were sounding very defensive about their decisions on stranded costs.
Should the recoveries prove too generous, said Dr. Rose, whose group is the research arm for the National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners, "the legislators, the commissioners, most of the people involved in the process are going to have a real hard time admitting they made a mistake."
In cases where utilities received their money up front by securitizing their stranded costs, Dr. Rose said, "the state's options are more limited if circumstances change."
"You can't take the money back once it's been doled out," he added.
Customers "may be paying for stranded costs that won't materialize in the future," he said, depending on the portion of stranded costs that were securitized.
Figuring stranded costs is as much art as science. In Mississippi, which has come late to the deregulation movement, regulators recently held hearings on the issue.
One big investor-owned generator, Entergy Mississippi, said it could have $90 million in stranded costs; the other, Mississippi Power, a unit of the Southern Company of Atlanta, did not release its estimate.
But Frank Spencer, an assistant attorney general in the state, argued that the utilities would each have $700 million to $800 million in what he called "stranded benefits" -- in other words, generation plants and other assets worth far more in a competitive market than what they are carried for on the companies' books. He contended that ratepayers might be entitled to share in such benefits.
Mr. Spencer's estimates, disputed by utilities, were based on studies of selling prices of comparable generation plants. "Utilities talk about how all these charges have to be passed on to customers," he said. But "this shows that there might be some costs consumers ought to receive the benefit of, some way."

 CORRECTION:
Picture captions last Sunday with an article about the improved financial outlook of the utility industry after deregulation misstated the location of a Pennsylvania power plant that the Duquesne Light Company has agreed to sell to Orion Power Holdings. Though it is called the Cheswick plant, it is in Springdale, Pa.

Chart: "An Improved Outlook"
A few years ago, utilities had collectively amassed over $100 billion in debts from building power plants, particularly nuclear plants. This debt loomed as a major hurdle to deregulation as utilities sought to recover what were termed stranded costs. Now, much of those costs have been, or are being, erased. Here is how three utilities did it.
 
1995 STRANDED-COST ESTIMATE
 
DQE INC., Pittsburgh
$1.356 billion
 
WHAT HAPPENED
Traded its share in five power plants to another utility for three power plants. It then sold those plants plus four others for $1.71 billion.
 
OUTCOME
Costs will be mostly recovered by next year.
 
TNP ENTERPRISES, Fort Worth
$941 million
 
WHAT HAPPENED
A law allowed the company to keep earnings above a mandated cap on profits through next year. After that, the utility will be allowed to impose a surcharge.
 
OUTCOME
Cost estimated to be collected over 12 years.
 
SEMPRA ENERGY, San Diego
$1.168 billion
 
WHAT HAPPENED
Sold two generation plants and 17 combustion-turbine generators for $466 million. The rest of the costs were recovered through customer charges.
 
OUTCOME
Costs were mostly recovered by last year.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: When Rent Becomes the Show Stopper;
Arts groups, with specialized space demands, are being squeezed by real estate costs

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
THE Trisha Brown Dance Company usually tours Europe for six weeks each fall before returning to New York, but this year it will spend three months there, then head to Salt Lake City for two weeks. While the troupe is pleased about the lengthened tour, its schedule owes as much to real estate concerns as to artistic considerations.
"The reason we'll be away so long is that our lease expires at the end of September," said LaRue Allen, the group's executive director, "and this way we'll have more time to look for another place." 
 Ms. Allen has already been searching for more than a year, she said, but "either it's impossible to find the space we need or the rent is out of sight."
In its present location, on the fourth floor at 211 West 61st Street, the dance company pays $16 a square foot for 8,000 square feet, an annual rent of $128,000, It pays nothing for an additional 2,000 square feet in the basement. "But those days are over," Ms. Allen said, adding that rents for many of the other spaces she has looked at have ranged up to $45 a square foot.
Clara Miller, the president of the Nonprofit Finance Fund, which makes loans to cultural and community organizations, said: "One of the ironies is that when times are good, real estate prices rise, and lots of groups can't afford them. A lot of groups come in to see us in a panic."
And times have been good indeed in New York during the last few years, with the booming economy fueling demand -- and raising rents -- for office and retail space. At the same time, there has been a proliferation of performance groups, all of which need not only stages but also office and rehearsal space. For rehearsals, not any old space will do: dancers need to be able to practice without having to dodge columns, actors need enough space to enter from the wings without immediately finding themselves center stage. And when the rehearsal spaces double as performance spaces, as is not infrequent with smaller performance groups, both need ceilings high enough to accommodate stage sets and lighting.
"In 1990, New York City had 150 theater members; today, there are nearly 350," said Virginia P. Louloudes, executive director of the Alliance of Resident Theaters/ New York (widely known as A.R.T./New York), whose members include the Lincoln Center Theater, the Roundabout Theater Company and the New York Theater Workshop.
One result, Ms. Louloudes said, is that "while the nonprofit companies are continuing to grow, the funding community can't keep up."
Lee Allen, the owner of Arc Advisors Inc., a commercial real estate company that works exclusively with nonprofit groups, said: "It hasn't been anywhere near this bleak since the mid-80's. Space is tight everywhere, but in Manhattan it's virtual gridlock unless you're willing to pay almost twice what a place is worth."
Even then, the race belongs to the swift, as Robert LuPone, a founder of the Manhattan Class Company theater group in Chelsea, found out when he starting looking for a space bigger than the current 99-seat theater. "I went to our board to tell them about a 30,000-square-foot building that was up for sale for $8 million," he said, adding that although he thought the price excessive, there was nothing else available. "But before we could decide anything," he said, "somebody else bought it."
John Denham of Denham Wolf Real Estate Services said that when he told a nonprofit company about a space that was overpriced but otherwise suitable, "that same day the landlord got so many offers he raised the rent 10 percent."
Paul Wolf, the other partner in the firm, said: "Three years ago you might be able to find free space with another nonprofit. Two years ago it was, 'Where can I find cheap space?' This year it's 'Where can I find space?' "
For a growing number of performers, the answer, increasingly, is nowhere. Which is why some real estate people, Mr. Allen of Arc Advisors included, are telling groups thinking of moving because they need need extra space, rather than because their lease is about to expire, to stay put in hopes that rents will sooner or later stop skyrocketing.
Paradoxically, although many artists live most of their professional lives with uncertainty, uncertainty about real estate seems to create even more anguish. "I never thought when I chose dance as my profession that I'd be inextricably linked to real estate," Ms. Allen of the Trisha Brown troupe said with a resigned laugh.
The space that the Trisha Brown Dance Company must vacate in September (to make room for the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, which exercised its option for the space) is that rare combination of three rehearsal studios, dressing rooms, offices and storage space.
The shortage is as acute for well-known dance groups like Alvin Ailey and Paul Taylor as it is for well-known theater groups like Primary Stages.
The Paul Taylor Dance Company, whose lease for a rehearsal studio above a Banana Republic in SoHo doesn't expire for two years, is already actively looking, just in case.
"The work of this dance company has been centered in Manhattan for 45 years," said Ross Kramberg, the Taylor troupe's executive director. "But when it comes time to renew, we know we'll face a doubling of our rent. And knowing that four other major dance companies are looking around and expecting rents to at least double, we have to look at all available alternatives, even if it means having to vacate the neighborhood where Paul Taylor has been a fixture for more than 25 years."
THE lease for Poets House, 2,100 usable square feet on the second floor of an office building at 72 Spring Street in SoHo, expires at the end of this year, but it, too, is looking for more space. In addition to housing 35,000 volumes of poetry, "we need space to nurture poets," said Lee Briccetti, its executive director, "poets who come in to write, read the books, attend readings and workshops on writing and publishing poetry." The current space, she said, would ideally be devoted solely to the library and public programs, while administrative offices and classrooms would relocate nearby, perhaps within the same building.
While the most acute real estate challenge is to find office and rehearsal space, performance sites are also in short supply, arts administrators say, although it has usually been possible to avert a crisis by staggering performance schedules and through other creative juggling.
The space picture for nonprofit groups is not entirely bleak. In Times Square, where a 10-story building at 229 West 42nd Street is well along toward completion, there will be three floors of offices for nonprofit groups as well as 14 rehearsal studios and what will be called the Duke on 42nd Street, a 199-seat experimental theater, available to theater, dance, music and other performance groups.
"We hope to open in June, and when we do, rents for nonprofits will be subsidized," said Cora Cahan, the president of New 42nd Street, the agency created in 1990 by the state and city to oversee seven of the nine theaters on 42nd Street in Times Square.
Preliminary plans have also been announced for the Women's Interart Center to create rehearsal studios and a cultural center complex in the renovated 10-story building it currently occupies at 549 West 52nd Street, as well as to add an eight-story addition.
Perhaps one of the most creative approaches to financing was the Roundabout Theater Company's recent deal with American Airlines. The airline will pay $8.5 million over 10 years to have the refurbished 740-seat theater at 227 West 42nd Street, formerly the Selwyn, renamed the American Airlines Theater.
Dancers are probably the most peripatetic artists. "Dance has always been a homeless art form," said David R. White, the executive director of the Dance Theater Workshop, at 219 West 19th Street. But his group is one of the lucky ones. Construction will start this fall on a new building for the workshop, which sold its air rights to developers for more than $3.2 million.
That gave it enough money to build a new home at its present location. The new building will be 25,000 square feet, compared with the current 7,500 square feet, the seating capacity in the theater will double to 200, and there will be two studios instead of one.
The real estate problem confronting performance groups is not confined to Midtown or Lower Manhattan. In Harlem, about 30 nonprofit groups associated with the Harlem Foundation for Arts and Culture have had to beg for space in church basements, school lobbies, conference rooms or simply outdoors.
"Everybody here has the same problem," said Joseph L. Persons, the foundation's founder and executive director. "Either there are no spaces to rent or rents are too high." That is why the Harlem Summer Arts Festival in July will again be held in whatever makeshift spaces the dancers, musicians, actors and writers can beg, borrow or scare up.
The scarcity of space often means that groups move from one temporary home to another. The Frank Silvera Writers Workshop, founded by Morgan Freeman and Garland Lee Thompson almost 25 years ago, has had five addresses in the last three years, including temporary quarters in the Harlem office of the borough president.
"You can't schedule weekly readings or workshops if you don't have the space," Mr. Thompson said, "and square footage on 125th Street has gone through the roof. It's the worst time we've seen."
THE Jewish Theater of New York is also having problems. After performing three years on Theater Row on West 42nd Street, it was forced to vacate last month to make way for wrecking crews knocking down four of the eight small theaters. They will be replaced by four 99-seat stages, a 199-seat theater and a 499-seat theater jointly owned by the Shubert Organization and an apartment building.
Although the plan is for the nonprofit theaters to return, "talk is cheap, so whether we'll ever get back in there, we just don't know," said Tuvia Tenenbom, the Jewish Theater's artistic director. Meanwhile, as Mr. Tenenbom works on an stage adaptation of the diary that Adolf Eichmann wrote in an Israeli jail, he has taken temporary office space in the Financial District on Greenwich Street, just above the Pussycat Lounge. "For a group that does cultural things," Mr. Tenenbom said, "it's very embarrassing."
To cope with the shortage of space, many Manhattan groups say they are looking for space in Brooklyn and the Bronx. Nineteen small performance groups, including 12 from Manhattan, have signed leases for space in a 19,200-square-foot building in Fort Greene, not far from the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Purchased for $1.25 million by A.R.T./New York, the five-story building has three rehearsal studios, an auditorium and office equipment, all for a rock-bottom yearly rent of $12 a square foot, including utilities, less than half the lowest rent of $30 a square foot in Manhattan.
The veteran Mark Morris Dance Group plans to move from offices in SoHo to a dance center in Brooklyn after it rebuilds the three-floor abandoned hotel that it bought across from the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Scheduled to open in October, the dance center will be rented to other performing arts groups.
But not even desperation is always enough to lure groups from one borough to another. "I could go to Hunts Point in the Bronx," said Mr. LuPone of the Manhattan Class Company, "but we wouldn't have much of an audience."
For smaller companies especially, moving from one borough to another, even one neighborhood to another, is not just a matter of moving a few blocks, or crossing a river. Unlike the big-name theaters with big-name actors that attract tourists, smaller companies tend to attract audiences top-heavy with people from nearby neighborhoods.
But many of those same people are wary about venturing into unfamiliar places, and doubly hesitant about going to neighborhoods where transportation is spotty.
E VEN Ms. Louloudes of A.R.T./New York, who conceived the project in Fort Greene, acknowledged the problem that performers, interns and volunteers face in keeping nonprofit groups afloat. 'If you don't have roots in Brooklyn," she said, "you don't wake up one day and say, 'Hey, I want to live in Brooklyn.' "
But if the "build it and they will come" spirit has not caught on with audiences when it means traveling far afield, it has a long history in Manhattan. Performance groups doubled as pioneers, venturing into Greenwich Village, Chelsea, SoHo and many other once-marginal areas because it was all they could afford.
"When we took over the WPA Theater in 1976, it was on the Bowery, and we moved it to a loft on lower Fifth Avenue in 1977, which people may find hard to believe was a no man's land back then," said Kyle Renick, the artistic director. "When people heard that, they warned us we'd never get an audience. But within a few years it was gentrified into one of the hottest areas in Manhattan."
When the building was sold, Mr. Renick moved to Chelsea, to West 23rd Street between 10th and 11th Avenues. "I got warnings again," Mr. Renick said, "things like 'Nobody will go there' and 'That's not Manhattan -- it's so far west it's in New Jersey.' But now it's like Gallery City."
Now the WPA Theater is facing another move because its building has been sold, and Mr. Renick is again beating the bushes for space. "In the 70's," he said, "I would have said to anybody interested in the performing arts, 'Learn p.r.' Since the 80's I would have told them, 'Learn real estate.' "
Some people were told as much and followed that advice. "When I first started in the theater in New York," said Casey Childs, the artistic director of Primary Stages, which has been presenting new plays by American playwrights since 1983, "someone told me: 'You have to learn real estate. You have to have a home if you don't want to find yourself in a perpetual floating crap game.' "
Ever since, Mr. Childs made sure that real estate people were on his board. So it is probably no coincidence that Primary Stages, with a building on West 45th Street with two small theaters and rehearsal space, appears close to buying another building on West 42nd Street, where it will have two 150-seat theaters.
The Joyce Theater is also in the anomalous position of owning real estate, yet still being short of space. The Joyce owns not only the 472-seat Art Deco theater on Eighth Avenue and 19th Street, a building it bought in 1977, but also what is now the 75-seat Joyce SoHo at 155 Mercer Street, which it bought in 1996. "Now we're looking for another building," said Linda Shelton, its executive director, "because even with three studios in Joyce SoHo, we can't fill the demand for rehearsal space."
The All Stars Project, a nonprofit theatrical production company that performs in the 71-seat Castillo Theater at 500 Greenwich Street and puts on 125 events a year in poor neighborhoods, rents a 9,000-square-foot loft in SoHo. It has raised $3 million of its $10 million goal for buying and renovating a building.
"We've been looking because we finally have the means to buy now," said Gabrielle Kurlander, the president of the All Stars. "But it's been very hard going because we'd like at least 25,000 square feet and between 199 and 250 seats. There isn't much available in our price range or with those specifications."
FOR every performance group in New York that finds itself without space or without enough space, there are any number that have never had rehearsal space nor even an office. These peripatetic artists include the Susan Marshall Dance Company and Yoshiko Chuma's aptly named School of Hard Knocks, both of which have been in New York for the better part of 20 years.
"We've had to scramble," Ms. Marshall said, "rehearsing one week here, one week there. But we never tried to get permanent space, because the overhead would have been too costly. We're strictly on an hourly basis."
The same is true for Ms. Chuma, who said that during her years in Manhattan, rental space has risen from $10 an hour to $15 to $25, and even then, it's often a scramble to book it when you want it.
To pay the bills, "we travel a lot," said Ms. Chuma, whose troupe has performed for paying audiences as far afield as Estonia. What's more, she was recently appointed artistic director of the Daghdha Dance Company in Limerick, Ireland, which, to her delight, has rehearsal space and will soon have a theater.
For all the hardship, both women say they wouldn't trade their profession for anything, and they would even have to think hard about trading their nomadic existence for one more stable.
"The Ping-Ponging between spaces isn't a lot of fun, but it does have its upside," Ms. Marshall said. "You don't have to go to work in the same place every day, so there aren't a lot of ghosts hanging around.
"Besides, we actually have two spaces all our own -- Manhattan Mini-Storage and a long-term storage place in Queens."

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about obstacles faced by cultural groups in renting space misstated the ownership of the Joyce Theater in Manhattan. Although leased to the Joyce Theater Foundation, it is owned by the Ballet Tech Foundation.
